item.title: Operational Excellence
item.dc:creator: Martin Davies
item.content:encoded: Since 2008, Irish Life has embarked on an Operational Excellence programme. The purpose of the programme was to train staff to improve the way that we work for the benefit of our Customer. Team members have received Lean Six Sigma training which originally evolved from the Manufacturing industry. Lean Six Sigma, due to its success, has spread across all Industries and is adopted by most major companies across the world. At present we have in excess of 200 members of staff trained to one of 3 levels. These levels are ranked in belts just like martial arts; Black Belts, Green Belts & Yellow Belts. The Belts relate to the level of training received and therefore projects are allocated to each level based on their complexity. Each trained staff member has delivered a project that improves service to our customers. Some examples have been improving the telephony service to our contact centre so that you, our customer, get to speak to someone who has expertise in resolving your particular enquiry. Other examples have been speeding up payments when cashing in or claiming on a plan. Where possible we now use Electronic Funds Transfer which removes the need for our customers to take time out to lodge cheques to their own bank accounts. Through these projects we have also improved our application forms. Questions have been revisited, reviewed and where possible removed to make the application process less time consuming and more straight forward. Our aim is to have every team member trained in Lean Six Sigma and to deliver improvement projects. We have huge amounts of information to help us with this. Every call or online request is logged and from this we can identify where further improvements can be made. As our training explains, no process is perfect and we will continually improve what we do for the benefit our customers.
item.excerpt:encoded: Irish Life have been practicing Lean Six Sigma principles since 2008, the following article is a summary of our efforts and achievements in that time

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi John,
What Martin is referring to here is our use of Electronic Fund transfer to "pay out" on our policies. So for instance if you had a savings account with us, and wished to withdraw, we would simply transfer the funds to your account, instead of sending you a cheque. The information you received regarding our use of direct debit is correct, this is our primary method of accepting your monthly premiums into a plan. However, we do accept one off payments by laser on some policies at no extra cost.

I find the part interesting where you state "Where possible we now use Electronic Funds Transfer which removes the need for our customers to take time out to lodge cheques to their own bank accounts." Only yesterday I was told that except for DD Irish Life still has no other payment methods to offer. Would be great if someone could clarify both statements.

item.title: Sovereign Concerns Are Now Spreading From The Eurozone To The US.
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded:
Sovereign Concerns are now spreading from the Eurozone to the US.

Monday 13th December Ruth Cooney is markets economist with Irish Life Investment Managers

SUMMARY: The US Government announced a fresh economic stimulus plan that if passed the deficit to GDP in the US could be maintained between 9-10% next year. The UK responds with a similar plan

The yield on the ten year US government bond increased last week from 2.95% to 3.33% and up from its low of 2.4% at the start of October. These moves come after the US government announced a fresh economic stimulus plan, a sharp contrast to the approach of fiscal austerity taken by both countries in the Eurozone and in the UK. It is thought that if this plan is passed then the deficit to GDP in the US could be maintained between 9-10% next year, according to the Financial Times. In December 2009, credit rating agency Moody’s published a report that the UK and the US must prove they could reduce their deficits to avoid the threat to their triple A credit rating. Although it is doubtful whether a threat to the US’ triple A status is conceivable, the rating agencies are highlighting that there are increased risks for the traditional “risk-free assets”. The UK has responded to this report during 2010 and has proactively put a clearly defined plan in place on how it will bring its deficit to GDP, which was 11.5% in 2009, back to a more manageable level in the future. However last week the Obama administration and the Congressional Republicans agreed to continued to spend. They have agreed to extend the tax cuts and unemployment benefits that were set to expire at the end of 2010, as well as the payroll holiday tax and tax breaks for investments. This package is significantly larger than had been expected and has resulted in the sharp sell off in triple A government bonds of UK, US and Germany over the past week, or as the chart below shows a significant rise in ten year government bond yields. Triple A Government Bond Yields Spiked last week (ten year government bond yield in Germany, UK & US) Rare but not unique in a historical context Moody’s responded to the extension of the tax cuts by noting that the stable outlook for the US triple A credit rating would not be impacted immediately by the latest fiscal stimulus. But the agency noted that the tax cuts were extended beyond the proposed two year time frame and hence “clearly makes the longer term outlook more negative”. In contrast to the concerns about fiscal sustainability for many of the advanced countries in the world, policy makers in the US could look towards Japan. Policy makers in Japan have maintained a loose fiscal policy over the past twenty years and government bond yields in Japan are the lowest in the world, despite its debt to GDP ratio of over 200%. The increased supply in Japan has been met by solid demand for Japanese bonds from domestic investors. The high savings ratio in Japan has ensured that the increased supply of Japanese bonds has been met by strong domestic demand, which has kept yields higher. However this higher savings ratio has been offset but much weaker domestic demand and the economy has become highly reliant on exports for economic growth. To date, demand for US government bonds has remained, even last week the 30 year bond auction in the US was 2.79 times covered, despite the sell off seen in treasuries. It is well known that China has been a large buyer of US treasuries, so much so that a sharp decline in the value of US treasuries would have a significant impact on China. However there are some signs that demand is declining, especially from foreign investors according to the latest inflow data. Further signs of waning demand for government bonds were evident by investors pulling their money from Pimco’s Total Return Fund, the world’s largest mutual fund through November. It was reported by Morningstar that the fund experienced net withdrawals for the first time in two years as investors redeemed $1.9bln from the fund. Elsewhere the Federal Reserve is currently a strong buyer of US government bonds, albeit in the secondary market, through its $600bln quantitative easing programme. A decrease of demand from foreign investors is a major concern for US policy makers. The Federal Reserve’s quantitative easing is only a temporary fix. Increased demand from domestic savers would help, although this could be at the expense of an economic recovery as increased savings would have a negative impact on consumption. The moves in bond markets over the past week are signalling to US policy makers that investors, particularly foreign investors are not as willing to fund the continued overspending by the US government. Hence a change in the policy stance may be necessary before the situation becomes unmanageable.

Important - Disclaimer

This page is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. item.title: A look at Market Returns for 2010
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded: 2010 will not only be remembered for the year that the Tipperary hurlers brought a halt to Kilkenny’s five in a row dream, but also as the year that the Eurozone sovereign crisis unravelled. However neither event was big enough to derail the equity market rally that started in March 2009, although the latter was responsible in creating much volatility for equity, bond and currency markets. 2010 was a year of sharp contrasts for investors, with great rewards for players who managed to be on the right side. Examples include fears of a double dip recession in the developed world versus the strong growth in the emerging economies, concerns about the over indebted governments and consumers compared to the cash rich corporations, record low bond yields in triple A countries versus high yields in the peripheral Eurozone countries such as Greece and Ireland. Finally the fiscal austerity measures being adopted across Europe compared to the unprecedented government and central bank stimulus put in place in the US. A re-rating of the risk free asset class The sovereign debt crisis which first emerged in January 2010 when it became evident that the fiscal situation in Greece was unsustainable. This crisis led to a reconsideration of safe assets as the risk of default is now being priced into what traditionally have been the one of the safest asset classes’ government bonds. Going into 2011 it is likely that the re-rating of safety is likely to continue as the rating agencies have signalled Greece, Portugal and possibly Spain are faced with further downgrades, while there are also rumblings that the “ultimate safe haven”- US Government Bonds could be put on review for a potential downgrade. Hence as the risk of default was priced into bond markets the appetite for the bonds of riskier countries declined. The danger is that as the number of “risky” countries increases that bailouts are less feasible. On the other hand, the credit risk attached to companies is easing, particularly as the balance sheets are very healthy but also as companies are much more mobile and have the ability to get exposure to countries with robust growth. As a result the spread between government bonds and corporate bonds has declined through 2010 and corporate bonds outperformed conventional government bonds. Benign and uneven economic recovery Expectations for the recovery in the US also deteriorated during the year, particularly as leading indicators peaked and have eased since the start of the year. Elsewhere, the recovery to date in the US has been jobless as the unemployment rate remained close to its peak at 9.8%. The negative economic data, during the year weighed on markets. However, in November and December policy makers in the US have stepped up as the Federal Reserve announced it will buy as much as $600bln government bonds and the US government announced an extension of the tax cuts and additional stimulus to business. This additional stimulus has boosted the outlook of the US economy for 2011 going into the year end; however concerns are also mounting about the sustainability of US government’s deficit. The returns for equity markets have been supported by earnings growth Earnings expectations for 2010 in both Europe and the US are set to come in well ahead of expectations. In January 2010 analyst were expecting that earnings for the S&P 500 would grow by 26% however at the end of December expectations had increased to 42% growth, while in Europe expectations have increased from 25% growth to 35%. The improvement has been driven by increased cost cutting, particularly in the US as well as double digit earnings growth from companies that have exposure to emerging markets. These measures have offset the sluggish low single digit revenue growth that has been experienced from developed countries. Emerging Markets outperformed Developed Markets Both emerging market debt and equities saw strong money flow as the outlook for the emerging economies continued to improve and investors sought to get exposure to companies, government bonds and the currencies of these regions. The emerging economies have continued to expand beyond the emerging Asian region as Latin America and Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA) region are also seen as attractive. The continued expansion of the middle classes in these regions is expected to drive growth in these countries over the next few years. The latest concerns for these regions are that they will over heat, particularly as food inflation, which has a much higher impact on consumer price basket in emerging regions than it would be in the developed economies, has been rising. What about 2011? Going into 2011 it is hard to believe that the sovereign concerns that started in 2010 are going away, if anything it is likely that these concerns will intensify early in the new year as countries attempt to front load the new debt issuance during the first quarter. This also with the treat of further downgrades by the rating agencies will lead to continued volatility for both bond and equity markets. Despite this, continued strong earnings, supportive valuations and robust corporate balance sheets are likely to support equity markets during 2011. Important – Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions.  It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. item.title: Another good year for global equity markets
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
Last year proved to be a reasonably good year for equities and the prospects for 2011 look positive. On a global basis equities, as measured by the FTSE World index, rose by 10.7% in local currency terms. And thanks to the general weakness of the euro last year, the return in euro terms was an even more impressive 20.6%. Most regions across the globe exhibited strong returns but Euroarea equities only produced a return of 3.2% as measured by the FTSE Euroarea index. The Irish market also had a disappointing year as it fell by 0.8% in 2010. It was really in the last quarter of 2010 that global equity markets recovered their mojo as a combination of strong earnings numbers, improving economies and the continuation of lax monetary and fiscal policies drove markets higher. The prospects for the global economy appeared to improve as 2010 progressed, as emerging markets continued to perform strongly and the U.S. economy benefited from the aggressive policy actions of both the Federal Reserve and the fiscal authorities. Elsewhere, the recoveries in Germany and Japan were also stronger than expected. Company earnings grew strongly last year as it is estimated that the earnings of the companies in the S&P 500 in the U.S. grew by over 40%. Constructive on global equities for a number of reasons
  1. In general, we are constructive on global equities in 2011 based on a number of reasons:We expect that the global economy will continue to grow this year, exhibiting solid growth in the region of 4.5%. The IMF forecasts that global growth will average around 4.5% over the next four to five years, with emerging economies being the key driver of growth.
  3. Monetary and fiscal policy is expected to remain very supportive for the most of 2011.
  4. Valuations, while not distinctly cheap, are below long-term averages and should prove supportive in the coming 12-months. The fact that earnings growth outstripped the growth in prices in 2010 saw the price/earnings ratio of many markets contract in 2010 and are now below their long-term averages. Furthermore, the dividend yields offered by many equity markets across the globe are now as attractive as the yield on ten-year government bonds markets in the major developed markets. The following table provides a good summary of key valuation metrics of global equity markets and in general, the markets look reasonably priced whether from a price to earnings (P/E) perspective or from a yield perspective.
Global valuation metrics
P/E FCF Yield Div. Yield P/B Operating Margin ROE Implied ERP
S&P 500 13.3 6.2 1.8 2.3 8.6 13.6 4.7
Stoxx Europe 600 11.0 6.1 3.1 1.8 10.5 8.9 5.8
Topix 13.9 4.0 1.9 1.0 5.7 7.2 5.7
MSCI Asia Pac. ex. Japan 12.9 9.6 2.2 2.4 11.6 11.4 6.4
Note: P/E is 2011 Earnings, all other data is 2009 or last 12 months Source: Goldman Sachs
  1. The risk of deflation appears to be receding and thus should see some element of pricing power returning to companies, particularly those with strong franchises. Commodity prices have started to rumble again last year, especially non-cyclical ones such as gold and agriculture commodities. However, there does appear to be something of a shift towards more economically sensitive commodities such as copper and oil. Consequently, with rising commodity prices, the danger of deflation does appear to be receding.
We are particularly disposed to large cap quality equities. They have underperformed other, more riskier sectors of the markets such as small cap equities, technology companies and emerging market equities for example. Since early 2009, global equity markets have recovered impressively, but much of the out performance was concentrated in the aforementioned higher risk sectors. But risks are evident There are numerous risks in the global economy and the most pressing at the moment include the sovereign debt crisis in Europe and concerns about rising inflationary pressures. The fact that Europe has still failed to tackle the debt crisis in a fully planned and co-ordinated fashion means the markets will look to target individual countries and their respective bond markets. This backdrop will continue to unsettle equity markets on occasion this year. In terms of inflation, equity markets like a little but not too much. The general consensus is that inflation should be reasonably contained in 2011, but any unexpected surprises will raise the spectre of higher official rates at some stage during the year. Despite this, continued strong earnings, supportive valuations and robust corporate balance sheets are likely to support equity markets during 2011. item.title: Your money family finance guide
item.dc:creator: ebusiness
item.content:encoded: January at the best of times is never an easy month. But in our current economic situation, we think families need all the help they can get with their personal finances. Thats why we've teamed up with the Irish Independent's personal finance editor Charlie Weston to produce Your Money: a family finance guide that was free with last Thursdays (the 13th) Independent. If you happened to miss it, you can read it online here, or download it as a PDF from here to browse through later.

item.title: Irish commercial property – any light, any tunnel?
item.dc:creator: Martin OReilly
item.content:encoded:
After major repricing in 2008 and 2009, the commercial investment property market generated a low negative total return of c.-3% for 2010. The decline in capital values estimated at -11% was offset substantially by the income return at c.8%. Weak rental values were the major contributor to the fall in capital value with yields broadly remaining stable.

Performance of Irish Commercial Property

While the level of repricing eased in 2010, the market continues to suffer from a lack of liquidity.  This is masking a number of issues.
  • 2010 has seen the emergence of long term and opportunistic overseas investors, focussed on secure prime assets. This has generated a handful of deals, including a number on Grafton Street.
  • There is a level of domestic investor demand for smaller investments up to €5m, with a range of deals transacting, despite the general lack of availability of debt finance.
  • Market illiquidity is due in major part to a lack of sellers, with the slow rate of progress in NAMA loan transfers and business plan approval being a major contributor.
  • The IMF/ECB bailout has seen investor interest cool for the time being resulting in a number of substantial pipeline deals being put on hold, including the Liffey Valley Shopping Centre and the Royal Liver portfolio.
Occupier markets continue to remain challenging, with declining rental values the major contributor to recent capital value falls. In the retail sector landlords are accepting short term occupiers at discounted rents, however evidence is emerging of longer term letting deals (including Forever 21, Sketchers and Fat Face). The vacancy rate in the Dublin office market remains stubbornly high at 23%. However take up has improved, albeit off a very low base, with 100,000 sq. m. let in aggregate (50% in the City Centre). New and expanding FDI companies (such as Google) are the main driver of activity, taking advantage of flexible lease terms and low rental levels. Over the next number of years property returns are likely to be based on rental income return, which is currently running at 8%+ p.a. We anticipate some further declines in rental values in the first half of this year but anticipate that stability in rents should emerge in 2011. We expect some increase in investment transactions, with non NAMA banks generating sales. It is difficult to predict NAMA driven activity over the next 12 months - but their sales focus may well be on the UK rather than Ireland. UK Property Market – prime continuing to outperform In terms of capital value growth 2010 was a year of continuous month on month growth. U.K. institutional investors were drawn into the market due to significant investor inflows, while overseas investors were primarily driven by the significant yield gap between bond yields and property yields and by a weak sterling. Since the trough of the market in July ’09 capital values have rallied by c.16% (6.5% in 2010), driving total returns of 13% for the year. While the pace of capital value growth averaged at about 0.9% per month in H1’10, the pace declined in H2 to 0.2% on average. The ease in market re-pricing in H2 was due to weakening investor sentiment linked to a difficult economic backdrop and occupational market uncertainties. Investment was further curtailed due to a continued reduction in bank lending to the sector. In addition, with increasing speculation that banks will release distressed property for sale in 2011, investors adopted a ‘wait and see’ approach in the latter half of 2010. 2010 was also a year of divergence in the investor and occupational markets. Central London and key provincial cities were the preferred locations for investors and while occupational markets recovered in Central London, markets in the regions, burdened by excess supply and weakening demand, saw rents fall. Due to investors continuing to discount void risk, prime and secondary property markets continued to diverge. With limited supply of prime investments coming to the market and increasing demand prime yields continued to compress while secondary markets with limited demand and an over-supply saw values continue to fall. In summary 2010 market trends would suggest that in the short term the market now appears to be entering a more difficult phase where yield compression gives way to some outward yield (fall in values) movement. Going forward into 2011 we believe property returns will be driven by income and it will be this income component that will keep total returns positive. Looking beyond 2011, and assuming no external economic shocks and the occupier market recovery broadens out across the whole market, we expect to see improved returns in 2012 and 2013. The graphic below charts anticipated ‘all-property’ total return in the coming years as forecast by Capital Economics, Morgan Stanley (Derivatives) and the IPF Consensus.

Total return forecasts for U.K. commercial property

Euro Property Market – continuing to rebound in prime assets A return to economic growth in H1 2010 and historic low bond yields led to a rebound in property prices in 2010, with risk adverse investors concentrating purely on prime assets in Western Europe. This demand for prime assets in core cities has created a polarised European property investment market with a significant divergence materialising between core, prime assets and peripheral secondary stock. High prices for secure prime assets are a strong indicator of a lack of market confidence and that investors are in defensive mode looking for virtually risk free investments. In this climate, secondary assets in struggling economies such as Portugal, Italy, Greece and Spain and parts of Central and Eastern Europe may face further value falls if their respective economies come under further pressure. It is for this reason that we expect that the focus on property investment going forward will be concentrated on France, Germany, the Nordics, UK, Austria, Benelux and Poland. While the pack will be hunting for super-safe investments there is an argument for investors to move up the risk curve and take on some leasing risk in good Western Centres and benefit from possible future tightening risk premiums. Ultimately, the decision to move away from super-safe property investments will come down to the investor’s belief that core European economies will remain robust. In terms of outlook, it is likely that pricing of safe-haven core European government bonds will underpin continued strong investor interest in 2011. The major European commercial property markets have already passed through the bulk of a positive yield correction, although so far it has been limited to the narrow prime segment. In 2011, capital growth will be driven (in all sectors) by rental growth, albeit modestly, given near term mixed economic growth forecasts. The continuing weight of money ready to enter the market is expected to fuel further yield compression (value increases) and combined with income should deliver returns of 6% to 8%.  However, with the significant yield gap between prime and secondary remaining historically wide, and on the basis that the economic recovery continues, the most attractive opportunities may be found higher up the risk curve in management intensive assets, short leases and niche markets. The graphic below charts anticipated ‘all-property’ weighted ungeared total returns in key ‘core’ markets in the coming years as forecast by Henderson Global Investors.

Total return forecasts for European commercial property markets

item.title: Another GAA year begins
item.dc:creator: David Coldrick
item.content:encoded:
Last weekend, the new refereeing season started.  2010 All Ireland Football Final Referee and Irish Life Assurance employee David Coldrick takes us through his 1st hectic weekend of the 2011 campaign.
Friday evening, DCU – pre National Football League fitness test. Bleeper test pass mark level 16.1, up from 15.6 a year earlier. This is only the level for the league. The pre championship level is likely to be around 17!   Because the test was so early in the year, I had to train over the Christmas & New Year period and watch what I was eating and drinking. Getting onto the national league panel is serious business. If you don’t make the league panel, you won’t be eligible for the championship panel later in the year.  I got to level 17.6 with Maurice Deegan. Felt this was enough for this time of year. One or two new guys got to 18.6 & 19.1 – super running. After the fitness test, the former English Premiership referee Dermot Gallagher spoke to the national referees group. He was very interesting, with lots of stories to tell. There were some serious points to take on board but what was striking was how similar our preparations were for games at the highest level in our respective codes. Premiership referees are professional but there is no doubt that the top gaelic football & hurling referees are as professional in everything but name. Saturday morning, Croke Park – annual rules test. Pass mark 94%. I came out with 100%. No issues on knowledge of the rules. Interpretation is the key for all referees. Remainder of the day was taken up by seminars on referees’ assessments at national level, nutrition & training and a very lively session on video clips of incidents from last year’s football championship. At national level, we now have this Turning Point technology, which is very similar to what was used by the audience on the Who Wants To Be A Millionaire television programme. Each referee gets a small device and for each clip, has to answer a/b/c/d on what the right action was to take on each incident shown. The potential actions range from free only to red card offence. Devices are matched to referees by serial number so it’s possible to know how each referee voted on each incident. This way a referee has to justify his decision if it runs contrary to the correct course of action as determined by the National Referees committee. I think this is a huge development in refereeing and will help to improve consistency among national referees going forward.    Saturday evening, Croke Park – National Referees banquet. I received my medal for refereeing last year’s All Ireland football final from the GAA president, Christy Cooney. It was a great night but again I had to be good as I was appointed to referee in the Leinster O’Byrne Cup the next day!
[caption id="attachment_216" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="David and his team before the 2010 All Ireland Final"][/caption]
 Sunday afternoon, Drogheda
Refereed the O’Byrne cup game between Louth & Wicklow in Drogheda. After a long working week & the efforts of the weekend, I found my first game of 2011 tough from a physical & mental fitness point of view. I didn’t feel at my sharpest and blew up too quickly a few times when I really should have seen the advantage. No major issues, thankfully. This post will be continued tomorrow
item.excerpt:encoded: Last weekend, the new refereeing season started. 2010 All Ireland Football Final Referee and Irish Life Assurance employee David Coldrick takes us through his 1st hectic weekend of the 2011 campaign.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Interesting that the pass mark on the rules exam is 94%. That means about 1 decision in 16 could be wrong.
How come these wrong decisions are always against Dublin?

item.title: Making the panel
item.dc:creator: David Coldrick
item.content:encoded:
National League panel
The result of the weekend was the creation of the gaelic football & hurling panels for the upcoming national football & hurling leagues.
The football panel will consist of around 50 referees. Each referee will get 3 games during the league. All games will be assessed by an independent assessor. We start with a maximum score of 100 and the only way is down! We can lose marks on areas of technical fouls, aggressive fouls, umpiring & teamwork, scores, control and fitness. It’s a wide ranging assessment and most referees wait with apprehension for their match assessment to arrive by email on the Tuesday/Wednesday post the game. Mid to late 80s is a good match assessment!
After the league the national football panel will be reduced from 50 referees to a championship panel of 15-18. Your league assessment scores are what determine if you’re in or out. There’ll be another pre championship fitness test to pass in order to tick the final box for inclusion in the championship panel.
The slate is wiped clean at the start of each year and you have to prove yourself all over again. I might have refereed the All Ireland final last year but that counts for nothing in 2011. After passing both the league fitness & rules tests, my only aim for the next few months is to referee to the best of my ability to get back on the championship panel for 2011 when it’s decided in late April this year.
I was supposed to have my first national league engagement on Feb 5<sup>th</sup> but the year-end valuation process and the long hours it involves meant that I had to withdraw. I didn’t want to pull out but I didn’t think that I’d be mentally sharp enough for a high profile inter-county game in 2 weeks time given my current work commitments. It can be difficult to balance my work & refereeing commitments at this time in the year.
However hopefully it won’t be too long before I get my first appointment of the 2011 national league and that it’s just the start of another long and busy refereeing season.
item.excerpt:encoded: Here is the second part of top inter-county Referee and Irish Life employee David Coldricks blog. David will be blogging throughout the league and championship season so be sure to keep an eye on the site for a unique view of the 2011 National League and Championship season

item.title: Climbing for the Red Door School
item.dc:creator: Nick Baird
item.content:encoded:
Veni, Vidi, Vici.

I set off for Tanzania to take on Mount Kilimanjaro, the highest mountain in Africa on 19th February.  Kilimanjaro, at 5895m (19,341ft) is the highest mountain in Africa (and Europe).  It’s also the tallest freestanding mountain in the world – meaning that it is not part of a range created by the shifting of the earth’s plates, instead this is just one mother of a volcano, built from millions of years of eruptions.  It’s not a technical ascent – no ropes or scrambling to speak of – the real challenge for would-be climbers is the altitude, which debilitates and sickens you from around half way up.  You can’t really train for this, and I certainly had no idea as to how this would affect me.
It’s not a technical ascent – no ropes or scrambling to speak of – the real challenge for would-be climbers is the altitude, which debilitates and sickens you from around half way up.
My day and a half long transit took me via Heathrow, Addis Ababa in Ethiopia, Mombasa in Kenya and finally to Kilimanjaro airport in North East Tanzania.  Tanzania is a poor country by any standards.  There is a basic transport and communication infrastructure developing, but most people where I saw lived a subsistence agricultural based existence.  In spite of this they are a colourful and striking people.  I spent the Saturday overnight in the idyllic Karama Lodge in Arusha where I first met the other 13 souls on my trek party and our guides Samuel (chief guide and super hero), Abel (very able) and Godbless (yes really!). The next day we were up early to get over the 3 hour bus journey around the Kilimanjaro National park to the gate, where would begin our ascent up the Marangu Route.  A hold up at park entry and the organising our luggage amongst our army of porters meant we were delayed in starting, but finally we began climbing at around 12.30pm.
On the first 4 days we were advised to consume over 5 litres of fluid daily
The first day was a relatively easy ascent from the Marangu Gate at 1950m to Mandara Huts at 2700m.  Distance over the ground was approximately 12kms all through tropical jungle, complete with a treetop audience of Colobus monkeys.  While this was listed to take a reasonably leisurely 5 hours, the intense humidity made it hard going.  Fortunately, I was prepared for this and drank water like a fish from my Camelback system (a 3 litre water pouch carried in my daysack with a tube allowing constant liquid top ups without the need for stopping).   On the first 4 days we were advised to consume over 5 litres of fluid daily.  As well as preventing dehydration, this would help oxygenate our blood like a Tour de France cyclist. While we plodded up this path we were passed out by our crew of porters who strode past us carrying our baggage, food and their own equipment.  They are limited by law to a load of maximum 20kg each, which they mostly bundle up and carry on their heads! On arrival at Mandara we took an extra 1 hour excursion to Maundi Crater for a sunset view over Kenya and of Mawenzi, the second highest peak of Kilimanjaro.  While impressive to look at with its jagged teeth-like profile, at only 5149m Mawenzi was not our prey – it was the presently hidden Kibo, at 5895m, that we sought.   Day 1? Hankuna matata as they say in Swahili – No Problem.
item.excerpt:encoded: During the month of February, Nick set off to climb Mount Kilimanjaro in aid of the Red Door School, a special school for children with Autism. Read part one of Nicks adventure here..

item.title: Irish Government Bonds
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded: What does Minister Noonan mean when he talks about “burning the bond holders”? Currently burning the bondholders refers to the senior bonds of Nationwide and Anglo Irish bank. It has been the policy of the Fine Gael and Labour to “burn the bond holders” right through the election campaign and most recently on Minister Noonan’s trip to the US. Since taking office there has already been a burden sharing programme with the junior bond holders of AIB, Bank of Ireland and IL&P. Since March 2011 the department of finance estimates that subordinated bond holders have contributed almost €10bln to the recapitalisation of the banking system. The government has explicitly stated that it is not going to pursue burden sharing with the senior bond holders in the pillar banks (AIB, Bank of Ireland or IL&P) and all of those bondholders will be repaid whether they are guaranteed or not. However Minster Noonan has stated that the state needs assistance in dealing with the senior bond holders of Anglo and Nationwide. How much money would this save the government? Currently Anglo Irish Bank has €2.8bln worth of senior unsecured debt outstanding, €769mln of which is due to be paid back in the second half of 2011 and a further 1.9bln will be paid back in 2012. Irish Nationwide has €631mln of senior secured debt of which is due to be repaid in 2012. Therefore if there is going to be any burden sharing for these bond holders the government need to act promptly. It is unlikely that the entire €3.4bln could be written off but certainly a 50% reduction would be a possibility if burden sharing with senior bondholders is allowed. What hurdles is the government facing to such a strategy? Noonan believes that because the merged Anglo and Irish Nationwide is just a “warehouse for impaired assets”, i.e. it no longer accepts deposits or lends money, it no longer works like a bank. This is now an issue for the IMF, the EU and the ECB. The difficulty arises with the ECB, who is very much against burden sharing with the private sector. The ECB is concerned about the contagion effects that any burden sharing may have on the European banking sector. As a result the policy stance from Europe has been clear that for now no burden sharing is allowed for senior bond holders. What is the implication for government bond markets from this policy? The government is committed to repaying all of its obligations, either bonds that have been issued by the banks through the government or bonds that the government has issued itself to finance its own liabilities or money that it has borrowed from the EU/IMF. The only debt that it is considering imposing losses on is the senior unsecured debt of Anglo and Nationwide. However the recent Greek crisis has created much turbulence in government bond markets particularly for Greek, Portuguese and Irish bonds because policy makers in the EU are now in favour of sharing the burden of Greece’s liabilities with the private sector, even though the ECB remained against any burden sharing. However the deal which has been negotiated in recent days includes some private sector involvement, although the details of which have yet to be hammered out. It is likely that any involvement by the private sector will have to be voluntary in order to avoid a credit event for the Greek sovereign and as a result needs to contain strong incentives to generate meaningful contribution to debt rollover. It currently looks like the private sector will be asked to voluntary swap bonds that are due to be repaid between now and 2014 with bonds that will mature much later. This reflects a turnaround in the policy stance from the EU, who previously had ruled out burden sharing until after 2013. Markets are now pricing in that Irish government bonds that mature after 2014 will only receive 70c for every €1 invested. What has to happen for Ireland to repay its commitments? Currently the Irish government is on track to meet the targets set out by the EU/IMF and as a result is continuing to receive funding on from the programme every quarter. This was not the case for Greece and as a result Greece had a funding gap of €12bln in July. To continue to meet the EU/IMF austerity requirements Ireland must continue to enforce austerity. The government is committed to cutting an additional €3.6bln from its deficit in 2012, following the approximately €20bln that has been taken out of the economy since 2008. Further cuts will be made in 2013, 2014 and 2015. Economic growth is also essential to Ireland returning to a stable debt trajectory. Currently the Department of Finance estimates that the Irish economy can grow by 0.8% in 2011, 2.5% in 2012 and 3% thereafter until 2015. For this to happen global economy needs to continue to grow and the domestic economy needs to stabilise. It is certain the politics will play a major part. The political will needs to continue in Ireland to make the necessary cuts and reforms to bring the debt levels back to a stable trajectory. However it is also necessary that EU politicians remain willing to support the peripheral countries, continuing to provide funding for the region. Without this funding Ireland would have to fill the €18bln annual gap in its funding immediately as it is already locked out of the markets to raise this money. Currently markets are pricing that growth, austerity and politics will fall down along the way and bond holders will not get all their money back. Ireland is different to Greece and Portugal in that it is a flexible economy with a strong export base which helps growth. However the high level of private sector debt is still a major burden for the economy. Important – Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. item.title: Commodity Price Inflation – The next major challenge to Central Banks
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded: Commodity Price Inflation – The next major challenge to Central Banks Markets focus on extremes, particularly when you look at the most recent inflation/deflation debate. Last summer the dominant concern was that the US and many of the western economies would experience a prolonged deflationary period. Currently focus has turned to the recent surge in commodity prices and now an “inflationary spiral” is back on the cards. Headline inflation has been increasing globally; initially it was evident in the emerging region, most notably in China, where inflation currently stands 4.6% YoY. More recently concerns are shifting to developed economies. For example inflation in the UK surprised markets and jumped to 3.7% in December. Eurozone headline CPI increased by 2.2% in December ahead of the ECB’s preferred level of 2% as food and energy prices continued to rise. Even in Ireland which has seen deflation since 2009, saw CPI jump to 1.3% YoY in December by the largest since 2008, primarily driven by higher energy prices. However this increase in headline inflation has come when domestic demand has remained lacklustre in many economies. Currently the inflationary driven pressures are coming from the recent rise commodity prices. In 2010 Irish Life Commodity Fund returned 24% and although some of this return is as a result of the weakness in the Euro, the dollar return for commodities was 9.1%. The agriculture sector was one of the out-performers, particularly as adverse weather conditions in many key food producing countries led to a supply shock for this sector. Since the start of 2011, food and energy prices have continued along this upward trajectory, spurring fears that the inflationary pressures will persist throughout 2011. The problem with this higher commodity price inflation is that it has also led to speculation that central banks such as the Bank of England, ECB and Federal Reserve will have to reverse some of the extra loose monetary policies that have been undertaking to help these economies, before adequate growth is seen in these economies. It has been noted that central banks should not respond to a commodity related spike in inflation because such spikes are beyond their control. Emerging economies have already started to adopted tighter monetary policy as China has increased rates and started decreased the liquidity available in the banking sector. However the Federal Reserve to date is not concerned with this commodity led inflation and is continuing to print money and purchase government bonds in the market (through its $600bln quantitative easing programme). But speculation has started to mount over recent weeks that the ECB and Bank of England may be forced to tighten policy, soon than had been expected in line with their commitment to their inflation targeting. This is evident in the spike in the 2 year government bond yield in the UK and Germany.     Despite this, the recovery in the UK remains fragile, particularly as the economy contracted by 0.5% in the fourth quarter. Given the fiscal austerity measures that are currently being adopted by the UK government an increase in interest rates would cripple the domestic economy further. There are also concerns that like in 2008 when the ECB responded to commodity price inflation and raised interest rates that the ECB could act again, even though financial instability remains. It is imperative that central banks examine whether there are secondary effects to this commodity price inflation, particularly a shift in inflation expectations or wage price inflation. As can be seen from the chart below inflation expectations in Eurozone remain in line with the ECB’s target, allowing the ECB to remain on hold. For now a change from the current policy stance endangers the recovery as central banks would be responding to price increases that are already hampering the already fragile economic recovery.   Important - Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. item.title: Key changes for pensions in budget 2011 – why the time to act is now!
item.dc:creator: Tony
item.content:encoded:
With the financial situation facing the Government, the recent budget was always going to be a tough one – and early indications were that pensions were going to get hit badly. The reality is that, while some of the advantages have been cut slightly, the attractiveness and need for pensions is as strong as ever. The most important thing to remember about pensions is that if you want any kind of financial security when you retire, you simply have to put some money away now. In the current financial situation, relying on the State pension is unlikely to be an option. The state funds public pensions through taxes such as income tax. So the more people working, the more the Government has to spend on state benefits such as pensions. Just take a look at the following diagrams.

This is going to put massive pressure on the public pension system, and we’re already seeing the results of that. The Government has announced that it is to increase the state pension age to 68 by 2028 and the reality is that, even if they can avoid cutting the state pension soon, it is quite likely that the amount will reduce in real terms over the coming years.     This means that planning a pension is really important and it explains why, even after the budget cuts, the Government continues to give such good incentives for people to contribute to their pension.  Our pension calculator is a simple tool which shows how much you should save in your pension. So what was the impact of Budget 2011 on pensions? Here are some of the changes announced. 1. Removal of PRSI and Health Levy relief on pension contributions Pension contributions generally receive income tax relief up to a percentage of your earnings –Self Employed people can claim relief when they submit tax returns. For those in employment, the tax relief is either given at source or by applying to your local Inspector of taxes to adjust your tax credits. Even with the removal of PRSI and health levy relief a tax payer on 41% tax will still get €41 back in tax relief for every €100 they invest. Similarly, a tax payer on 20% tax will get €20 back in tax relief for every €100 they invest. Their pension fund will grow fully tax free, meaning that their funds would grow at a higher rate than savings funds. Finally, they can access a portion of their funds tax free (usually a quarter) and the rest will be taxed as an income, meaning that some will be tax free, some at 20% and only the remainder at 41%. PRSI will be deducted and the Universal Social Charge (replacing Health and Income Levies) will now also apply to pensions in payment. 2.         Limiting the ability of high earners to fund very large pensions
  • Tax free lump sum is capped at €200,000
In terms of the maximum tax free lump sum of €200,000, most pension holders can take a quarter of their fund tax free, so this will generally only impact you if your fund is over €800,000. Even if you are lucky enough to have a fund of that size or more, you can still take the balance taxed at 20%. For example, as the diagram below shows, if you had a fund of €1 million, you could take €250,000 cash - €200,000 would be tax free and €50,000 would be taxed at 20% - meaning you just pay €10,000 tax or 4% of the cash amount.

  • Allowable income for tax relief purposes is capped at €115,000
For example, if you’re 50 you can get relief on pension contributions of 30% of salary - this is now capped at €34,500 (30% of €115,000 per year). Also, it doesn’t affect the amount your employer can contribute for you through a company pension.
  • The total pension fund you can build is capped at €2.3 million.
In reality, it will not impact on most pension savers as most don’t earn over €115,000 and won’t build up a fund of over €2.3 million. However, even if you do earn over that amount, it only caps the personal contribution to your pension that you can get tax relief on. Why not take a look at how pension tax relief can help you 3. Minimum withdrawals on ARFs increased to 5% The idea of an Approved Retirement Fund or “ARF” is that it’s a fund you have after you retire that you can use to draw down an income from. Some people were’nt using it for that purpose, but were keeping it intact to pass on to their dependents. Because of this, the Government decided to tax these funds as if you had drawn down 3% a year, this has been increased to 5% in the budget with immediate effect (December 2010). So it makes more sense, tax wise, to actually draw down 5% a year as income. If you take a regular withdrawal from this product, it’s possible that expected growth may be lower than expected and taking a regular withdrawal could reduce the capital you’ve invested. These were the main changes in the recent budget. Working to maintain tax-relief incentives on pensions In the Governments 4 year plan, there was an additional proposal that between 2012 and 2014 tax relief on pensions could be reduced to the lower rate of tax (currently 20%). We’re hopeful of finding a solution that works for the Government and continues to provide a strong incentive for people to save for their retirement. So in summary:
  • You really need to sort out your own pension. Even if it’s just a small one, when added to the state benefit, it will make a difference
  • Pensions remain a tax efficient way to build up money for retirement
  • It is possible that tax relief could reduce in the future, so it’s worthwhile considering how you can maximize how much you contribute to your pension now. 
This article is meant to just give a broad overview of some of the main changes to pensions in the recent budget. If you need to review your pension plan, it’s important that you talk to your financial advisor  or contact us at customerservice@irishlife.ie. Warning: The income you get from this investment may go down as well as up. The value of your investment go down as well as up. Pensions are a long term investment plan that can only be taken at retirement. Irish Life Assurance is regulated by the Central Bank of Ireland. Useful Links: www.pensionsboard.ie www.revenue.ie www.taxrefund.ie

item.dc:creator: T.J.
item.content:encoded:
In 2012 Irish Life paid out a total of €83.5 million in Life Insurance benefits held by 1,168 customers. A further €41.5m was paid out to 606 customers in respect of Specified Illness Cover plans.
Included in those figures, is a payment of over €5 million, the highest claim paid by the company in 7 years.
Irish Life Head of Claims, Martin Duffy, said that the €5 million Life Insurance payment is the highest made by Irish Life in the past 7 years and compares to the highest claim paid in 2011 of €700,000. “There were a number of very high (€1m +) claims paid out in 2012 which reflects, in part, the higher value insurance which people acquired in the boom years.”
Duffy said, however, the average claim for Life Insurance was just over €71,500. “We did have a number of very large payments last year, but the fact that the average payment was just €71,500 suggests that the level of Life Insurance taken out by many Irish people is still insufficient to look after their dependants in the event of an early death, especially as the average age of adult claims is 62”.

item.title: Inflation on the prowl in 2011
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
Below please find a summary of our views - please click on link for full article. Inflation on the prowl in 2011
  • Equities should perform reasonably well in 2011, but will face  a number of headwinds – in general, we believe quality large  cap companies look attractively valued, especially on a  comparative basis.
  • We would be cautious about long-term government bond markets in the core Euro area and in the U.S. and the U.K. this year. On the other hand, Irish 10-year government bond yields at around 9% look a tempting proposition but do carry a higher risk of default.
  •  Deposit rates will likely remain broadly unchanged in 2011 but the actual rates on offer will vary from institution to institution.
  • Commodities should continue to perform strongly over the next 12 months, underpinned by continued strong emerging market demand and easy policy conditions in the West.
  • Irish commercial property values are expected to continue to drift lower due to weakening rental values (yields should remain broadly stable). However, the market appears to be close to its cyclical bottom and looks attractively valued. U.K. and core Euro area markets will continue to see strong investor interest for prime secure properties but non prime property values will remain under pressure.
  •  In general, investors and savers need to guard against the risk of rising inflation and a greater allocation to real financial assets is warranted.
  •  There are a number of obvious risks facing the markets in 2011 and these include Higher inflation, sovereign risk contagion and political flare-ups in Asia, especially the North-South Korea stand-off.

Link to full report here
item.excerpt:encoded: This week Pat O'Sullivan, (Head of Investment Strategy) and Ruth Cooney, (Market Economist) have prepared an in depth document, Irish Life's View on Investments - Inflation on the prowl in 2011.

item.title: The cost of leaving money on deposit
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
“Neither a borrower nor a lender be; for loan oft loses both itself and friend, and borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry”. "Hamlet", Act 1 scene 3 William Shakespeare must be turning in his grave given the debt laden ways of the modern western world. Unfortunately, for us (that is the Irish) we certainly didn’t pay any heed to this advice as we over-borrowed during the boom years. However, we’re attempting to mend our ways, as Irish households have increased their savings quite significantly in recent years and are in the process of repairing their “balance sheets”. With the increased level of uncertainty in the domestic economy, cash funds and deposits – once the choice of the conservative investor – have become a more attractive investment option for a broad spectrum of Irish investors. Deposit rates can vary quite significantly from one institution to another in the Irish market and looking at the rate on 6 month deposit accounts for example, it ranged from as low as 0.5% to as high as 2.85% at the end of last year. However, it is not the actual rate of interest that has driven the demand for deposits by Irish investors and savers, but rather a desire for safety. Consequently, Irish households continued to favour having access to their money over higher potential returns and preferred deposits and cash funds over real financial assets, such as equities and shares over the last 12 months. Irish households have built up huge cash savings Irish households have shown very conservative saving and spending habits over the last couple of years. Household’s savings increased from €3.6 billion in 2008 to over €11 billion in 2009 – the only sector to show an increase in savings over this period. The household net saving ratio, which expresses net savings as a percentage of net disposable income, increased from 3.9% in 2008 to 12.3% in 2009, with this trend likely to have continued in 2010. The saving rate is expected to stay high for this year and the foreseeable future. It is estimated that Irish households have somewhere in the region of €100 billion sitting in cash and deposit accounts. The key motivation, as we have mentioned, is a precautionary one but one has to suspect that once domestic fears subside that there will be pent-up demand to spend and invest. Evidence of the potential for the Irish consumer to spend can be seen from growth in car sales this year, spurred admittedly by the government’s car scrappage scheme. In November, motor sales increased by just under 15% in year-on-year terms. This pent-up demand could in time increase domestic inflationary pressures along with the rise in commodity prices in the global economy. The real cost of deposits While having money on deposit and in cash reduces the risk, it does come with a significant opportunity cost when assets, such as equities, commodities, property and corporate bonds perform positively. Last year was a case in point where most risk assets produced strong returns, with about half of the returns for both equities and commodities were due to the weakening of the euro currency. In euro terms in 2010 global equities returned 20.6%, while commodities returned 16.9% according to the S&P GSCI Commodities Index. Commercial property in the U.K. and in the euro area performed strongly last year helped by increased institutional investor interest. Last year, however, was not a particularly good one for Irish assets, with equities, property and government bonds all showing negative returns. In terms of fund performance, funds with a broad spread of assets, such as Irish Life’s Consensus fund which increased by 12%, have performed well. Consensus is a managed fund that is diversified across assets and geographic regions. Positive on equities and commodities in 2011 In general, we are positive on global equities and commodities in 2011 based on a number of reasons:
  1. We expect that the global economy will continue to grow this year, exhibiting solid growth in the region of 4.5%. The IMF forecasts that global growth will average around 4.5% over the next four to five years, with emerging economies being the key driver of growth.
  2. Monetary and fiscal policy, which is the control of money supply and the use of government expenditure and revenue, is expected to remain very supportive for the most of 2011.
  3.  Valuations of company shares, while not distinctly cheap, are below long-term averages. The fact that earnings growth outstripped the growth in prices in 2010 saw the valuation of many markets improve in 2010 and are now below their long-term averages. Plus, the dividend yields offered by many equity markets across the globe are now as attractive as the yield on ten-year government bond markets in the major developed countries.
  4. The risk of deflation appears to be reducing and this should see some element of pricing power returning to companies, particularly those with strong franchises. Commodity prices started to fluctuate again last year, especially non-cyclical ones such as gold and agriculture commodities. However, there does appear to be something of a shift towards more economically sensitive commodities such as copper and oil. Consequently, with rising commodity prices, the danger of deflation does appear to be reducing. 
But risks are evident There are many risks in the global economy and the most pressing at the moment include the sovereign debt crisis in Europe and concerns about rising inflationary pressures. The fact that Europe has still failed to tackle the debt crisis in a fully planned and co-ordinated fashion means the markets will look to target individual countries and their respective bond markets. This will continue to unsettle equity markets on occasion this year. In terms of inflation, equity markets like a little but not too much. The general consensus is that inflation should be reasonably contained in 2011, but any unexpected surprises will raise the spectre of higher official rates at some stage during the year. Summary Despite this, continued strong earnings, supportive valuations and robust corporate balance sheets are likely to support equity markets during 2011. We believe that the returns from cash this year will not be able to match the performance from risky assets, similar to what occurred in 2010. However, regardless of what actually happens in terms of respective returns this year, the other significant risk is that inflation will take hold in the Irish economy again and that it will erode the purchasing power of Irish households’ savings over the longer-term. This is the hidden cost of placing all of your money on deposit.
item.excerpt:encoded: This week, Pat looks at how the Irish over borrowed during the boom years and the examines how we are attempting to mend our ways.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Whatever the pre-cash investment vehicles were for the average Irish investor, and then the 'dash to cash' panic response, and whatever follows on from that from here on, to me, raises concerns about average Irish investor expertise and decisions/responses seeming more haphazard & panic-based than strategy-based. How do our patterns of investor behaviour through all this compare with other, perhaps more experienced, investor nations such as the US, Canada or the UK? Accepting, of course, that there are many very experienced and capable Irish investors, but trying to take a perspective on the average.

The dash for cash and government bonds has been a pronounced feature in the U.S. and the U.K., with huge flows in to government bond mutual funds in the U.S. So, the desire for security and the heightened sense of risk aversion was/is not unique to Irish investors and savers. However, I do think the scale of the economic crisis in Ireland has exacerbated these trends and may mean the retail investors at home will be slower to take on real financial assets than those in other countries. Not only will Irish investors suffer an opportunity cost (that is the differential between what they earn on cash/deposit versus the returns on other asset classes) but also suffer from a loss of purchasing power because of rising inflation.

item.title: League v Championship
item.dc:creator: David Coldrick
item.content:encoded:
So the national league has started and for the first time in a number of years, there are no experimental rules for a referee to deal with! This time of year is not an easy time to referee gaelic games. Bad weather & the resulting heavy state of county pitches gives rise to much slower games of football with more clusters of players scraping for possession than you will see later in the year. You sometimes hear managers and players refer to two sets of rules in gaelic games, one set for the league and another set for the championship. As a referee, I only have one set of rules to work with throughout the year. The problem for the referee is that teams don’t change their style between championship and league, with possession and constant hand-passing remaining the name of the game. More mistakes are likely to happen in the league than later in the championship, as players find their feet again after the winter break. There are many more challenges for possession and more tackling among numerous players for the referee to adjudicate on. The game becomes more open in the championship as the speed increases at least four fold versus the league. As the league progresses, players get fitter and the pace of each subsequent round of games quickens. The referee’s fitness level needs to build from game to game in the league as well. People often say to me that football referees have to be fitter these days because of the speed of the game but that the hurling referees must have to be fitter again. There’s no doubt that hurling is the faster game but while fitness is obviously important for a hurling referee, positioning and making sure you’re not too close to the play at any given time is arguably more important. There are so many  break-downs of play in football and the opportunity for cluster defending, etc. that fitness and closeness to the play is much more important for top inter-county football referees. That probably shows itself in fitness tests, like the one just gone. With the exception of Barry Kelly (hurling) who is extremely fit, the majority of referees achieving the highest scores in the bleeper test are football referees. Nothing like a bit of friendly competition between the football & hurling referees! As the league begins, it’s probably a good time to point out one or two of the common misperceptions out there:
  • A linesman cannot bring a technical foul, like a pick off the ground or an illegal hand-pass, to the attention of the referee regardless of how close to him it may have happened.
  • The fact that the free count might have been 40-20 in a game doesn’t mean that a referee was biased, it just means that one team fouled more than the other!
  • A referee doesn’t distinguish in any way between the strong & the so-called weak teams.
  • A referee taking charge of a game where one team is from his own province does not referee that game any differently to one where both teams are from outside his province. I can say, without a shadow of a doubt, that all referees at inter-county level are extremely professional people who take their role in gaelic games very seriously.
On a personal note, I’m glad the last few weeks of year-end work are behind me so that I can increase my focus on fitness and involvement in the national football league as it unfolds. Like every player, every referee just wants to be involved in the big games.
item.excerpt:encoded: In his latest article, David explains the difficulties of refereeing in the National League compared to the championship, and gets a friendly dig in at hurling referees over fitness levels!

item.title: Why do retail investors buy when they should sell, sell when they should buy
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
“Bull markets are born on pessimism, grow on skepticism, mature on optimism, and die on euphoria. The time of maximum pessimism is the best time to buy, and the time of maximum optimism is the best time to sell.” -Sir John Templeton[1] Why do investors buy when they should sell, sell when they should buy? Unfortunately for most retail investors their interest in any particular asset class generally only manifests itself once optimism abounds and the underlying bull market is showing signs of aging. Retail interest reaches a peak when the horizon is apparently clear and euphoria starts to take hold. Conversely, the point of maximum selling by retail investors also tends to occur at the height of maximum pessimism. These traits are all understandable and have been explained in the annals of behavioural finance but they are deadly in terms of returns. In very simple terms, emotion impacts on the decision to invest. More often than not, the best time to invest is when everyone else is selling, and the economic outlook is clouded with uncertainty and nervousness. However, it is also the most difficult time to make that decision. The following chart illustrates the pattern of retail clients tending to buy high and sell low – a strategy that is not conducive to very positive results. The yellow line is the total return on global equities (the year-over-year change in the MSCI All Country World Total Return Stock Index in U.S. dollars) and the blue line is net new cash flows into equity mutual funds in the U.S., which is largely retail money.  What is readily apparent is that both lines move pretty much in tandem. It is a near perfect chart of the buy high/sell low characteristic of retail investors and the high correlation between market returns and investor interest. Retail investors follow performance and end up buying high and selling low The last couple of years offer a clear insight into this type of behaviour by retail investors. In early 2009, global equity markets were at their lows but the selling by retail clients was at its most intense. By that stage global equity markets had fallen by approximately 50% to 60% and retail investors were still dumping equities by the truck load, somewhere in the region of $40 billion a month. And it was only after the market had rallied by 70%, did retail investor flows turn positive. A more extreme pattern evolving at home A more extreme pattern has happened in Ireland over the last two years, as Irish households want only safety and security and care little about performance. Irish households have been stockpiling cash and deposits and paying down debts over the last two years, with the actual savings rate hitting an astonishing 12.3% in 2009 or approximately €11 billion. This trend was probably repeated last year, but official numbers won’t be released for a number of months yet. Irish households are in the process of de-leveraging According to the Irish Central Bank[2], ‘Households’ net lending (that is saving and paying off debt) increased further in Q3 2010, reaching almost €4 billion, its highest level to date. The (following) chart shows that the increase in net lending has been driven in part by households’ investment in financial assets (largely cash and deposits), but also largely by a reduction in household liabilities. Since late 2009, households have been undergoing a period of deleveraging as they have sought to reduce high debt levels. The high household net lending figures indicate that household saving continues to be high in Q3 2010.’ From ‘flaithiul’ to frugal Irish households are no longer spendthrifts Understandable, but opportunities missed Given the scale of the economic calamity that has befallen the Irish economy over the last couple of years it is understandable why investors and savers have flocked to cash. But this has occurred at the expense of 90% plus returns in global equities since the lows of 2009. Furthermore, while the easy gains have been made we believe that equity markets can produce quite strong returns over the next 12 to 18 months and easily beat what is on offer on deposit. Using Sir John Templeton’s famous quote as a guide, we believe that we are in the sceptical stage of the cycle and that markets have still to benefit from widespread optimism. One simple and very effective way of over coming the highs and lows of markets and the attendant emotions is to invest via a savings plan (a.k.a. dollar cost averaging). The advantages of regularly investing via a savings plan: • Investing regularly allows investors and savers to buy more units when financial markets are low and buy fewer units when markets are more expensive. • Investors and savers don’t have to worry about deciding when is the right time to make an investment as they are buying the units in their chosen funds at the ‘average’ price. When falling markets are good for savers! The simplified example below highlights the benefit of taking out a savings plan. That is, as the value of the fund falls in year 2 the saver gets the advantage of buying units when the prices are low. However in year 3, when the unit price rises the saver buys fewer units. It sounds crazy, but for somebody starting a savings plan they should actually cheer a bear market in the early years of a plan. This is an example only and is not an accurate indication of the actual or future performance of any particular fund. Investors and savers in Ireland have very big allocations to cash and deposits and a more meaningful allocation to real financial assets, such as equities are warranted especially those with a long term investment horizon. And a good stepping stone for the nervous investor/saver is a simple savings plan. [1] Sir John Templeton was one of the foremost investors and stock pickers of the 20th century and ranks up there with Warren Buffett.
[2] Central Bank of Ireland, Quarterly Financial Accounts for Ireland, Q1 2002 – Q3 2010   Important - Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions.  It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. ILIM and ILA manage investment funds which may have holdings in stocks commented on in the document.  These products may be affected by changes in currency exchange rates.  Past performance may not be a reliable guide to future performance.  Investments may fall as well as rise.  ILIM and ILA are regulated by the Central Bank of Ireland.
item.excerpt:encoded: Why is it that retail investors always seem to sell when the market reaches its lowest and buy at the top? Irish householders have been saving at record levels but are missing an opportunity in equities.
