item.title: A prompt for action - claims paid and True Grit
item.dc:creator: Martin Duffy
item.content:encoded:
A prompt for action - claims paid and True Grit I saw a review of the new ‘True Grit’ film on The View recently. I remember seeing the original in the cinema in 1970 as a child! It was fantastic and still one of my favourite films. Little did I know I would be showing the original to my four daughters all these years later!! There is something important about having the courage or ‘true grit’, as a couple with children, to discuss what would happen financially if one parent died. Not a pleasant conversation. In the same way looking at real claims data can also serve this purpose in highlighting the need for action. When you do a good thing like taking out some life assurance cover to protect your family, if you were to die, you really never think about a claim ever happening. Each year in January we in Irish Life do a review of all protection claims paid in the previous year to both improve the claims process and help customers to better understand the importance of having cover in place. As part of this review this time, we also looked at claims paid by Irish Life in the last 5 years. Incredibly we have paid out over €1,000,000,000 in protection claims to over 30,000 Irish families over this time. During 2010 we paid claims under life assurance and specified illness plans to residences in every county and corner in Ireland. We are a locally based company paying claims locally for over 70 years. Our 2010 data reveals some surprising information: In respect of death claims….. Average claim amount on death claim was only €65,000. Clearly inadequate to provide a realistic level of replacement income to a surviving family. 11% of the 1256 death claims paid during 2010 were as a result of an accident or unintended death (road traffic accidents, work related accidents, fires, drowning etc). 30 death claims in respect of road traffic accidents. Average age of deceased for under all the accidental deaths was only 47. 70% of these accidental deaths were on male lives. 52% of all death claims for lives under aged 40 were as a result of an accident. Some people think they don’t need life assurance cover as they as healthy! Well if you are 40 and healthy, that’s great but based on our claims experience, for 1 in 2 deaths under age 40, the cause of your death will be an accident. How unexpected a death can occur
  • during 2010 we paid a death claim on a man in his 30s who died in Road Traffic Accident  only 8 months after cover was taken out – over €300,000 paid.
  • also in 2010, we paid a death claim on a man in his 40s who died in a work place accident only 3 months after cover was taken out – over €100,000 paid.
Largest claim paid in 2010 was €1.2 million to a man in 60s who died as a result of bowel cancer. In respect of Specified Illness claims….. Of the 569 claims, malignant cancer is biggest cause of specified illness cover claim at 58% and heart related at 22%. For women malignant breast cancer is biggest with 85 claims. For men its heart related with 54 claims, and then followed by malignant cancer of prostate with 50 claims. How unexpected a specified illness cover event can occur:
  • during 2010 we paid one specified illness cover claim to a woman in her 40s for malignant breast cancer - €50,000 plan in place for only 1 year.
  • During 2010 we paid a claim for a civil servant for a heart attack - €50,000, plan in place for 11 months.
Largest SIC claim paid in 2010 was for €500,000 to a man in his 40s for a heart attack. Largest female claims for lung cancer – women in 50s €300,000 paid. Lots more claim information on our website. Real claims. Real people. PS We are proud of the fact that we have paid 95% of all death and specified illness claims during 2010. What do you think of this? Martin Duffy Head of Underwriting, Life New Business and Protection Claims Click here for a more detailed view of our claim statistics
item.excerpt:encoded: As Irish Life Assurance today announced that it has paid out over €1bn in claims over the last five years, Head of Underwriting, Life New Business and Protection Claims, Martin Duffy highlights some of the headline statistics from the last five years.

item.title: It’s not all roses for emerging markets – Some risks to be aware of
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded:
It’s not all roses for emerging markets – Some risks to be aware of China is now the world’s second largest economy after it over took Japan and expectations are now mounting that China could take over from the US as the world’s largest economy in ten years time. In fact, growth in emerging economies is expected to significantly outstrip that of developed economies over the coming years as evident by Chart 1 Moreover there has been a change in the flow of funds, particularly in the latter weeks of January. Morgan Stanley has reported that emerging market funds have experienced strong outflows, following the large inflows that were evident through 2009 and 2010. Chart 1: Emerging market economies are expected drive global growth   There are very strong fundamentals for investors having an exposure to emerging market assets, as emerging economies do not carry the financial woes that developed economies do, the demographics of these population are much stronger than developed, the population of China and India are becoming richer and hence will become large consumers. Emerging markets asset classes have weathered the financial crisis much better than developed markets and have outperformed over the past two years. Despite this investors should be aware of some near term risks for these asset classes.   As evident by Chart 2 emerging market equities have been underperforming developed market equities since October 2010, after consistently outperforming since September 2009.  Moreover, there has been a change in the flow of funds, particularly in the latter weeks of January.  Morgan Stanley has reported that emerging market funds have experienced strong outflows, following the large inflows that were evident through 2009 and 2010.  The change in sentiment towards emerging markets has come as concerns about the sustainability of the recovery, in the region is now in question. The change in allocation to developed markets has come as a result of three reasons in our view: 
  1. Tighter monetary policy as a result of rising inflation in emerging economies.
  2. Concerns about the overheating of the Chinese economy, in particular the property sector.
  3. General improvement in the outlook for developed economies
Shift from a pro-growth to tightening policy stance  Emerging market headline CPI and PPI indices are running at over 5%, according to Morgan Stanley. The drivers of this high inflation are low real interest rates and higher food prices. Food prices on average represent 30% of the CPI basket for emerging markets (in contrast to around 10% in developed market CPI indices) and expectations are that food prices will continue to rise into 2011.  This has resulted in a tighter monetary policy stance from central banks. For example China has raised rates three times in four months and raised the required reserve ratio (i.e. the amount of reserves that it requires it’s banking sector to hold on deposit). India, Taiwan, Korea, Brazil have also raised rates. The tightening monetary policy stance could lead to continued underperformance of emerging equity markets versus developed markets as the central banks of developed economies are expected to remain on hold through 2011.  Overheating of the Chinese economy  China is a very central story to investing in emerging markets, not only because it represents 17% of the MSCI emerging market index, but it is also a key driver of growth in the Asian region. Elsewhere China also is also a major driver of commodity prices which boosts the economies of Latin America and EMEA.  Growth in China is expected to slow from 10.3% in 2010, to close to 9% in 2011 and 2012 as the effects of the government stimulus that was introduced in 2009 eases. One major concern for commentators is that there is a housing bubble in some of the cities in China. According to the Financial Times, the value of housing stock is set to exceed 350% of GDP in 2011, while construction currently accounts for around 25%  of GDP, which is similar to the level that Ireland reached prior to the collapse. Property prices in China have risen continuously over the past decade and since 2009 the amount of outstanding credit has jumped.  There is anecdotal evidence that millions of apartments are empty in Chinese cities, despite the urbanisation of the Chinese population. This is certainly a risk to the Chinese outlook to be aware of, however timing the burst of a bubble is never easy, but tighter credit conditions or an increase in the cost of credit could be a catalyst.  Recent improvement in the outlook for developed markets  Expectations are that global economic growth will be robust for 2011 and 2012, albeit slightly shy of the growth seen in 2010. It is also expected that the growth will be diverse between regions. The economic outlook for developed markets appears to be improving, albeit on the back of government stimulus measures and strong global trade. On the other hand there has been some increase in negative sentiment towards emerging markets, as central banks start to tighten policy. These changing dynamics have also been reflected in the respective business confidence surveys for  both regions. Consequently, it would not be surprising if developed equity markets put in a period of out-performance versus emerging markets in the months ahead.  Important - Disclaimer  This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person.  ILIM and ILA manage investment funds which may have holdings in stocks commented on in the document. These products may be affected by changes in currency exchange rates. Past performance may not be a reliable guide to future performance. Investments may fall as well as rise. ILIM and ILA are regulated by the Central Bank of Ireland.
item.excerpt:encoded: Ruth takes a look at emerging markets like China but predicts that there is some near term risks for investors to think about

item.title: Big match preparation
item.dc:creator: David Coldrick
item.content:encoded:
Appointments for rounds 2 & 3 of the National Football League were made on Monday evening. I’ve been appointed to take charge of the Dublin-Cork game in Croke Park this Saturday.
Preparations for the league have been going well since the year-end valuation work started to quieten down. Training three days last week & a game in Meath at the weekend has got my fitness levels back up to a good standard for this time of year. One more gym session on Friday morning – a bleep test being run in the staff gym – will be the last physical exercise before the game.
I’ve also been using the new inter-county referees’ website to prepare for the weekend. It’s probably the biggest development in refereeing education in the last 10 years. The website has numerous video clips of technical and aggressive fouls from the 2011 provincial winter tournaments and the 1<sup>st</sup> round of the National League available for all inter county referees to review and learn from. There are also discussion videos that referees are asked to comment on in order to encourage healthy debate on particular elements of the game.
I’ll meet my umpires early on Saturday and we’ll spend a good length of time discussing effective teamwork, positioning & communication in the game. They know they are as much under the spotlight as I am in inter-county games and future refereeing appointments are as much in their hands as they are in mine. There can be a perception out there that umpires are just a group of the referee’s friends, with no formal training in the rules of the game. This perception is untrue. My umpires are trained and I have full confidence in them. If I didn’t, they wouldn’t be with me. I can’t afford to have a weak link on my team, given the importance of all inter-county games nowadays. I’ve had to make big decisions in the recent past regarding my team of umpires, decisions which weren’t popular at home (!) but ones which had to be made given where I want to be as a referee.
The weekend will also be a first for the recent changes to the referees’ assessment system. While we will still get independently assessed, this season we get the opportunity to assess our own performances. This is taking a leaf out of the AFL system of referees’ performance appraisal. I would probably be my own harshest critic. I normally don’t need anyone to tell me what did or didn’t go well in a game. I have very high expectations of myself and the level of performance that I need to satisfy to stay at this level. I might have refereed two All Ireland finals but you can’t take anything for granted as it only takes a second for one incident to change the course of your inter-county refereeing career.
I’m looking forward to Saturday. The build-up has started. I’ll be thinking about lots of refereeing related issues between now & then as I zone into this game and out of everything else – it happens every time. Hopefully everything will go well and everyone can enjoy a good, sporting game of football.
item.excerpt:encoded: This week, David brings us through his preparations for the latest round of National Football League matches.

item.title: What the papers said about our claims statistics
item.dc:creator: ebusiness
item.content:encoded:
Earlier in the week, we launched our 2010 claims statistics, a breakdown of the life cover, serious illness and income protection claims that we paid out over the last year.

This launch also marked an important milestone for Irish Life, marking over €1 billion in claims paid over the past 5 years. The announcement received good coverage overall in the national press, a breakdown of which we've included here; Conor Pope, consumer affairs correspondent with the Irish Times gave a good breakdown of the figures, noting that there has been a substantial rise in claims on illness and life policies. Article here. Charlie Weston, personal finance editor for the Independent, wrote that Irish life had paid out over €1 billion on claims last year! Whilst flattering, the correct time frame for the €1 billion paid was over the last five years, but we'll forgive him. Here's a link to his piece. Evelyn Ring, writing in the Irish Examiner, also covered the announcement. In her article she focussed on the fact that one in four people will suffer from a serious illness at some stage in their life. Finally, Deborah Condon, writing in irishhealth.com focused on the cancer figures in the announcement, noting that almost half of the life assurance claims for 2010 related to the disease. You can read more about our 2010 claims announcement, in this blog post by Martin Duffy, head of underwriting, life new business and protection claims for Irish Life.

item.title: Eurozone equities are cheap but be aware of the event risk in March
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded:
As a result of the underperformance of Eurozone equities through 2010, mainly due to the problems in the debt burden of peripheral countries such as Spain, Portugal, Greece and
Ireland, valuation for the Eurozone region now look attractive versus the rest of the world. As
evident from Chart 1, equities in the peripheral region underperformed, while a stronger
performance was evident for countries in the core region on the back of the robust recovery for
these regions.



As a result of this underperformance valuation levels for the Eurozone countries are now
cheaper on price earnings as well as on a dividend yield basis than other developed markets.
In our view there are two issues for Eurozone equities going forward
  1. The likelihood of a credible solution to the Eurozone Sovereign crisis for the peripheral countries.
  2. The sustainability of the recovery for the core region.

The Eurozone Sovereign Crisis
Since the start of 2011, the asset classes that had been affected by the sovereign crisis such as the
government bonds and equities in the peripheral regions as well as the Euro have outperformed on the expectation that Eurozone policy makers will present a broad range of reforms to contain this crisis at their next meeting on March 24th. The continued out-performance of these asset classes is very much dependent of these reforms being introduced. It is also important that these reforms are seen as a credible and adequate resolution to the crisis. There has been a significant shift in the policy stance of EU policy makers since the start of the year. To date markets have been focusing on the following policy responses:


1. Size of the Fund:
The EFSF fund was reduced to €257.3bln during the summer, as this was the maximum amount that the fund could lend if it were to maintain the necessary AAA status from the credit agencies. It is now expected that European policy makers will increase the EFSF fund back to its original size of €440bln or a total of €750bln when the IMF funds are also included. This means that the current AAA countries in Europe will have to commit extra capital and hence take on an increased burden and potential higher interest rate. Ireland is currently the only country that has drawn down funds and €67bln are coming from the lending facility in place. There are projections that Portugal would require €80bln, Spain would require €350bln and it is also expected that Greece may need an additional €50bln in 2012 that has not already been covered by the €110bln package that it received last May.


2. Decline in the borrowing costs
Currently the average borrowing cost for Ireland is 5.8%, which is regarded as very punitive, especially if Ireland is expected to be able to return to a stable debt trajectory. Currently the EFSF is able to borrow from the market at a rate of 2.9% on five year duration. It is expected that policy makers will adjust the rate that they are charging Ireland and other drawers from the fund lower, although the size of the adjustment is unknown.


3. EFSF will intervene in distress bond markets and buy bonds
By granting the EFSF the ability to purchase government bonds in either the primary or secondary markets at current market prices, may allow governments to take a haircut on their bonds, without triggering a “CDS” or default. This solution would decrease the debt burden for countries.


All of these rumoured remedies require support from AAA countries to the peripheral countries. To date the Eurozone domestic policies has been a hurdle to any remedy, however since the start of the year authorities in France and Germany particularly have showed signs that they are committed to pre-emptively tackling the crisis.


Investment consequence for DJ Euro Stoxx 600 Index
The performance of Eurozone equities will be very much determined on whether or not these resolutions are enforced. Currently 24% of the DJ Euro Stoxx 600 is invested in the peripheral countries of Spain (11.1%), Italy (10.1%), Ireland (1.1%), Portugal (0.9%) and Greece (1.1%).  23% of the DJ Euro Stoxx 600 Index are financial stocks, which is the sector that is most exposed to this crisis. In January the financial sector outperformed as the contagion risks from the crisis decline and more importantly the funding costs for banks also decline. The banking sectors of non peripheral banks are implicated as a result of the exposure to peripheral countries’ bonds and banks. The major risk to this scenario is that the remedies will disappoint market expectations.


The robust performance of the Core Eurozone Region
Despite the uncertainties in the peripheral Eurozone, the German economy grew strongly in 2010 and is expected to continue to perform strongly in 2011. Currently business confidence as measured by the IFO, is at an all time high, while the PMI business confidence for the manufacturing and services sectors are all above the highs reached in the first quarter 2010. To date much of the strength in the Eurozone has been driven from the export sector as recoveries in the domestic economies have lagged. Therefore any risk to the outlook for global trade poses a threat to the strong recovery that has been evident in the Eurozone today.

For example continued strength of the Euro would certainly pose a risk to the recovery. In January the Euro increased from its low of 1.29 (10th of Jan.) to a high of 1.38 (2nd Feb). Credit Suisse has estimated that for each 10% rise in the Euro Dollar exchange GDP declines by 0.8 percentage points.

However one of the biggest risks to the recovery in the Euro area would also be an ECB rate hike. The OECD interlink model predicts that for each 1% in Interest rates would take 0.8 percentage points from growth. However more significantly, the already struggling peripheral countries such as Spain and Ireland would be particularly affected, where household debt is very high and is predominantly based on floating rate. The ECB focuses solely on inflation, and particularly looks at second round inflationary impacts. Currently headline inflation is 2.4% ahead of the ECB’s target, whereas core inflation is 1.1%.
A significant slowdown in the Emerging economies would also pose a threat to the export recovery in the Eurozone.

The ILIM Indexed European Indexed Equity Fund is a straight forward way of getting exposure to European equities. The fund tracks the FTSE Europe ex UK index, with German and French equities accounting for approximately 40% of the index.


Important - Disclaimer
This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions.  It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. ILIM and ILA manage investment funds which may have holdings in stocks commented on in the document.  These products may be affected by changes in currency exchange rates.  Past performance may not be a reliable guide to future performance.  Investments may fall as well as rise.  ILIM and ILA are regulated by the Central Bank of Ireland.

item.title: A new dawn for a new day or just one big yawn…
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
With regime change acting like a contagion across North Africa and the Middle East, Ireland had its own well flagged revolt over the weekend. However, it’s unlikely that Che Guevara type posters and t-shirts with images of Enda Kenny and Eamon Gilmore emblazoned on them will become historical keepsakes. Much will be expected of the new government not least the prospects of re-negotiating key elements of the EU-IMF bailout package. At this stage it is difficult to foresee what will come of these negotiations but it is becoming increasingly apparent that the current arrangement will pose too great a strain on the public finances and Ireland’s prospects for reasonably strong growth in the years ahead. On the other hand, a less onerous package could facilitate the renewal of strong growth in Ireland. And strong economic growth, coupled with falling unemployment and rising wages will be needed to tackle the bourgeoning problem of arrears in residential mortgages and negative equity. Mortgage arrears a growing problem The Central Bank of Ireland published the latest data on mortgage arrears and repossessions for the period ended December 2010. The figures show that at the end of December 2010 there were 786,164 private residential mortgage accounts held in Ireland to a value of almost €116.7 billion. Of these, 44,508 mortgage accounts, or 5.7% of the total residential mortgage accounts, were in arrears for more than 90 days. This compares with 28,603 accounts that were in arrears for more than 90 days at the end of December 2009 or 3.6% of the total mortgage accounts at that time. Percent of loan accounts in arrears for more than 90 days Furthermore, the data shows that overall mortgage debt outstanding for private residential mortgages decreased by almost €1.7 billion since the fourth quarter of 2009. Irish households are in the process of deleveraging and are increasing their savings and repaying their debts. As we have mentioned in previous commentaries, Irish households have been stockpiling cash and deposits and paying down debts over the last two years, with the actual savings rate hitting an astonishing 12.3% in 2009 or approximately €11 billion. This trend was probably repeated last year, but official numbers won’t be released for a number of months yet. Export growth the only show in town at the moment While the domestic economy continues to struggle given the austere fiscal measures that have been imposed by past budgets and by the conservative saving and spending habits of Irish consumers, the export sectors continues to grow. This has been underpinned by the improved competitive position of the Irish economy. Also, the fact that Ireland still remains an attractive location for foreign direct investment will play a key part in helping the economy back on a strong path to growth. In this regard it is interesting to note that according to NCB, ‘The 2010 IMD World Competitiveness Yearbook, for the key measures influencing foreign direct investments, ranked Ireland;
  • 1st for corporate taxes
  • 4th for the availability of skilled labour
  • 4th for being open to new ideas
  • 6th for labour productivity
  • 7th for the availability of financial skills
  • 7th for the flexibility and adaptability of people
As part of the overall negotiations with the EU-IMF, it is imperative that Enda Kenny and the new government ensure that the 12.5% rate of corporation tax is not in any way compromised. The export side of the economy will lead the recovery, while the domestic will lag and is not expected to drive economic growth in the coming years. The biggest challenge facing the new government is to turn some of the electoral promises in to jobs and growth in the domestic economy. item.title: Insurance Gender Equalization
item.dc:creator: Declan
item.content:encoded:
The European Courts of Justice (ECJ) & “The Crying Game” The ECJ ruling this week means that just like the main character in the movie “The Crying Game” insurers can not tell the difference between a man and a woman!! It is worth asking, what is discrimination in an insurance context? Is it where everybody gets the same cover for the same price, regardless of the statistically proven differences in their risk, or is it where people get the same cover for a different price because of the statistically proven differences in their risk??. In the context of gender at least, the ECJ ruled this week that it is discrimination to charge gender specific premiums regardless of the statistical evidence to back up a difference. In other words, they are happy that those who are higher risk pay lower premiums and hence will be subsidised by lower risk individuals who will pay higher premiums relative to their risk. Is this a good or a bad thing? Depending on whether you are an apparent winner or loser as a result of this ruling, I guess this will influence your opinion on whether the ruling is the elimination of discrimination or whether it is now introducing a new discrimination against those who currently pay lower premiums. However, looking around Europe and even within the Irish insurance industry itself we can see that our current view of this discrimination already varies quite considerably. You just have to look at the two Irish examples below to see this:
  • The Irish health insurance market operates on a community rating basis, which basically sees everybody pay the same premium regardless of risk. This is something that society values and closely guards, despite the fact that there is clear evidence of health differences in risk by both gender and age in particular.
  • The Irish motor insurance & life insurance industry uses gender as an important rating factor which evaluates a customer risk and hence is used in calculating the cost of cover. This has been in place for a long time and is broadly accepted by society as correctly reflecting the approach that the premium a customer is charged should reflect their relative risk.
The European way: The difference in the use of gender between countries and within countries reflects the evolution of the insurance markets within those countries, the maturity of these markets, the social attitudes & traditions that exist in a country’s society and finally sometimes the deliberate decisions taken by successive governments to use insurance for societal engineering.
The problem with the ECJ ruling isn’t so much the ruling itself, but the fact that its implementation across the EU is a one size fits all approach & its failure to recognise that each country within the EU is equal but different. Of course this approach by the EU is nothing new, and reflects a concerted effort to standardise as much as possible across the EU. I am thinking mileage to kilometres, pounds and ounces to grams and kilograms, the battle to ensure that Cadbury’s chocolate could remain as chocolate and even the standards & requirements for cucumbers & bananas!! In fairness to the EU, the philosophy of the EU Gender Directive is that men & women should be treated equally, which is an approach that the vast majority of people in the EU agree with. However, in this instance the ECJ ruling will have an impact on the efficiency of insurance market. Removing of the use of gender in the calculation of some insurance products’ premiums leads to the introduction of uncertainty for insurance companies where it didn’t previously exist. As a tried and trusted model including gender made it easier to predict what price was appropriate to cover the overall risk. What will be the overall result for customers? As a result of this ruling, the overall cost for insurance at a societal level may rise slightly as all insurers take a more cautious approach to premium setting. How much extra cost, will depend on how confident insurance companies are over the medium to long term with their assumptions about their gender mix. It is hard to be exactly sure how this will work out. However, the insurance industry is very competitive, so I expect that over the intervening period, between now and when the ruling takes effect in December 2012, that insurers will be working hard to develop solutions that have the least impact on customers. Watch this space.
item.excerpt:encoded: In the context of gender at least, the ECJ ruled this week that it is discrimination to charge gender specific premiums regardless of the statistical evidence to back up a difference. In other words, they are happy that those who are higher risk pay lower premiums and hence will be subsidised by lower risk individuals.

item.title: The economic impact of the oil price spike is manageable for now
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded: Since the start of the year, oil prices are up 18% in London and while this is a positive for investors with exposure to commodities there is now a fresh wave of concern about the effects of this oil price spike on the global economy and hence hampering the outlook of other asset classes such as emerging market equities, developed market equities, corporate bonds, base metals etc. Since the collapse of Lehman Brothers in September 2008, there has been a positive correlation between oil prices and equity markets. However in recent weeks this relationship has weakened as evident by the chart below. Since the recovery in risky assets since 2009, equity markets have moved up with commodity prices as commodity price rises were seen as a consequence of growth as opposed to a threat to growth. However since events in the Middle East North African region have started to intensify, oil prices have moved higher on concerns that supply of oil will decrease sharply. As a result the relationship positive between equity prices and oil price has broken down. The scale of the problem The increase in Brent crude prices (crude oil that trades in London) from $100 per barrel to $118 per barrel is as a result of the political situation in the Middle East and North Africa. Goldman Sachs has predicted that to date there has been a partial shutdown of 1.7 million barrels of oil production capacity per day of which 1.5 million barrels per day would have been for exports. This shortage has been increased as the fields that are producing are not exporting crude as the terminals at the coast are not offloading oil into tankers. It is also estimated that OPEC currently holds spare capacity of 2.5-3.0 million barrels per day. Therefore there is enough spare capacity in the system to keep production going, however if the situation in Libya were to intensify or the political unrest were to spread to other countries such as Algeria or Saudi Arabia then this may be at risk. The economic consequence of higher oil price Historically sharp increases in oil prices have been associated with subsequent recessions or periods of economic weakness. Currently Brent is up 48% over the past twelve months, although historically declines in economic activity have tended to occur when oil has risen by 85-90%. It is worth noting that the oil burden (i.e. the value of oil consumed as a percentage of growth domestic product) is approaching 4%, a level that has been historically associated when oil demand turns negative. Elsewhere the two historical occasions when increases in oil did not lead to US recession was in 1987 and 2009 and in both occasions it was in the earlier stages of the economic cycle and monetary policy was loose. Economic weakness tends to follow and oil price rises when central bank policy is much tighter than it is today. Nevertheless there are a number of considerations to calculate the exact the economic impact of higher oil price on the global economy. Generally it has been estimated that a 10% increase in oil prices may reduce global economic growth by 0.2% per annum over two consecutive years. Personal consumption will be lowered as consumer spending power will decline, business investment decisions will also be delayed as costs are now higher. Certain regions will have a higher exposure to rising oil prices, notable the emerging market region which is by far the world’s largest user of oil. The move today will only have a small impact on the current outlook for the global economy which is expected to grow by around 4.5% in 2011 and 2012. As a result it appears that the global economy can handle the recent spike in oil prices for the moment, although investors need to be aware of the risks of associated with supply drive oil price spikes. Therefore if the geopolitical events were to move to other oil producing nations or if the Libyan troubles continued for a prolonged period then oil prices could curb the global recovery. item.title: Japanese Earthquake – Impact on financial markets
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
It goes without saying that the devastation of the Japanese earthquake and accompanying tsunami is very much a human tragedy. Our thoughts and prayers are with the people of Japan and we can only hope that the ongoing relief operations are successful. The following note outlines our thoughts on the economic and financial implications of the earthquake. The earthquake region The Tohoku Pacific Coast of Japan has taken the brunt of the earthquake and the tsunami. The area in general is quite vast and while it is broadly rural in nature it does have a number of important industries located in that area. However, the industrial heartland in Japan is formed by a band that extends south from Tokyo along the Kanto plane through the Kansai region to the southwest, and to the island of Kyushu and as such much of the Japanese industry was spared the worst of the effects of the earthquake. Nevertheless, there is extensive damage to roads and bridges and huge damage to small ports along the northeast coast of Japan. Furthermore, there is also major damage to electricity production facilities, with the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex being particularly badly damaged.   The initial financial market reaction has been negative equities and positive for government bonds: - Japanese equities fell sharply on Monday and Tuesday
  • Topix               -16%
  • Nikkei 225        -16%
  • Japanese equity markets have rallied 5% on Wednesday.
- Global equity markets have also been adversely affected since Friday’s close
  • DJ Euro-3.4%
  • S&P 500-1.9%
  • FTSE 100-3.5%.
- Government bond markets have seen a flight to safety
  • Japanese 10-year bond yields: 1.21% versus 1.24% on Friday
  • German 10-year bond yields: 3.13% versus 3.21% on Friday
  • US 10-year bond yields: 3.29% versus 3.40% on Friday.
  • UK 10-year gilt yields: 3.52% versus 3.63% on Friday.
- Currencies have been only marginally impacted. The affected region of the Japanese economy accounts for about 6% of domestic GDP. The Japanese economy is one of the bigger global economies and accounts for approximately 9% of global trade. While the Japanese economy can be expected to contract in the immediate aftermath of the earthquake it should not have a significant impact on the global economy. There should be a reasonable rebound in Japanese growth as the year progresses and rebuilding gathers momentum.   Impact on funds Japan accounts for around 8% of the FTSE World index and all of our Flagship funds have less than a 4% allocation to Japanese equities. Our flagship funds are:
  • CORE
  • Consensus
  • Protected Consensus Markets fund
The earthquake in Japan and the ongoing political unrest in North Africa and the Middle East will make investors very nervous in the short-term. This has been clearly illustrated in the last couple of days by the flight to safety to government bonds and the sell-off in global equity markets. Our flagship funds are very well diversified and will mitigate the worst of the declines in the global equity markets. CORE has an allocation of 50% to global equity markets while the Consensus fund has an allocation of 74%.

"There should be a reasonable rebound in Japanese growth as the year progresses and rebuilding gathers momentum."

Outlook In general it is still very difficult to forecast exactly what will occur, but assuming that the nuclear problems affecting the Fukushima plant can be contained there is every chance that investor sentiment will recover and global equity markets can recover reasonably quickly. On the other hand, the flight to safety to long-term government bond markets will probably not prove to be sustained and we could see yields actually rising again in the medium term. Global equity market valuations were not particularly stretched prior to the current sell-off, while long-term bond yields were at very low levels prior to the flight to safety. Consequently, it can be reasonably expected that these crisis driven money flows will reverse course in time.

Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person.

item.excerpt:encoded: The Japanese earthquake and subsequent tsunami is undoubtedly a human tragedy. In the aftermath, here are our thoughts on the economic and financial implications for Japan and the Global economy.

item.title: Japanese Equities - a cheap equity market or a value trap
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
Given the traumatic events of the past few weeks, it is hard to imagine Japanese equities as being a particularly attractive investment. The fact that there are approximately 50 nuclear power stations located in Japan which, as we have seen to devastating effect, is a very seismologically active part of the world only adds to the risk of investing in Japan. However, based on current valuations, the market does look attractively valued.

A number of interesting articles in the financial press highlight Japanese equities

There were a number of interesting articles in the Financial Times over the weekend focusing on Japan. Two are particularly noteworthy in their assessment of the Japanese equity markets.

 

"Japanese companies are half as expensive as US companies"

The first one by John Authers in his weekend column highlights the risks but also the opportunity of investing in Japanese stocks today.

http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/0722d6f2-51b1-11e0-888e-00144feab49a.html#ixzz1HEmv9Goo

Quoting directly from the article:

“Japan’s litany of problems is well known. Its economy has stagnated for two decades, there is no room for stimulation from easier money, the government has the developed world’s most serious deficit and its population is ageing, suggesting that things are destined to get worse. If you want to live in a country enjoying fast economic growth, you might do better than move to Japan. But none of this precludes the chance that the market is pricing Japan’s stocks too cheaply.

If we assess value relative to other countries, Japan has been cheap for ages and looks infeasibly so. Judged as a multiple of book value (assets minus liabilities on their balance sheets) Japanese companies are half as expensive as US companies.

Judged by cyclical price/earnings multiples (comparing share prices to the average earnings over the past 10 years), Dylan Grice of Société Générale shows Japanese stocks, at a multiple of 16 for the Topix index, are as cheap as they have been since the late 1960s. (Adjusting for inflation, they were slightly cheaper in 1978.)”

"Are Japanese companies really worth that much less than everyone else’s companies?"

The other article was written by Merryn Somerset Webb in the Money section of the FT:

http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/e2ff6a7e-5192-11e0-888e-00144feab49a,dwp_uuid=6997947c-a442-11dd-8104-000077b07658.html#axzz1HEmMQAR4

The article again highlights some of the reasons why the Japanese market is attractively valued. A number of quotes stand out in particular.

“The market is fundamentally cheap in a way that hasn’t been the case since 1989. The price to 10-year reported price/earnings ratio (just a longer term version of the p/e ratio) is at “levels unseen since the early 1970s”.

At the same time, Wood points to the fact that the price-to-book ratio on Tokyo’s Topix index is now just below one – "you could buy the lot for less than you’d get flogging their assets in a fire sale."

"A price-to-book ratio at this level is 40 per cent below the global average. Are Japanese companies really worth that much less than everyone else’s companies? I can’t think that they are."

Nor can Mizuho Bank’s Tomochika Kitaoka. This would only be a correct level, he says, if “the very existence of Japan was at risk”. It is not.

Over the last 20 years many a good analyst has stated that now is good time to buy Japanese equities only to see prices fall further.  The following chart illustrates the highs and lows of Japanese equities over the last 40 years, with the last 20 being a near continuous grind lower.

Japanese equities – 20 years of disappointment

Nikkei 225 in local currency

Source: Bloomberg

But also 20 years of improving valuations

MSCI Japan P/E ratio

Source: Bloomberg

Valuation looks compelling but…

Despite the devastating impact of the earthquake and tsunami on Japan and the significant economic and structural problems facing the economy, the current valuation of the local equity market does look compelling. However, it still remains a market with high level of attendant risks, not least of which is the battle to contain the fallout from Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. The fact that Japanese official rates are at rock bottom and with the debt to GDP ratio in and around 200% means that the authorities have little conventional room for manoeuvre in terms of economic stimulus. Having said all that, for equity markets to be cheap, there has to be a reason and Japan has many.

A simple way of investing in Japanese equities is via the Irish Life Indexed Japan Equity fund which tracks the FTSE Japan Index, which is a high risk fund on our risk scale. Like all higher risk investments, such as country and sector equity funds for example, they should only form a small part of a well diversified portfolio as many things can go wrong and volatility can be very high.

Nevertheless, I will leave the last word to Warren Buffett when he stated in a recent interview: “If I owned Japanese stocks, I would certainly not be selling them because of the events of the past 10 days or so. Something out of the blue like this, an extraordinary event, really creates a buying opportunity.”

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Japanese Equities - a cheap equity market or a value trap
An article discussing recent articles in the financial press regarding Japanese Equities in light of the traumatic events of the last two weeks.

Japanese Equities - a cheap equity market or a value trap
japan, equities, values, warren buffet,
An article discussing recent articles in the financial press regarding Japanese Equities in light of the traumatic events of the last two weeks.

item.title: Mid Season Assessment
item.dc:creator: David Coldrick
item.content:encoded:
We've just passed the mid point in this year’s league and so far so good from a refereeing point of view. I’ve taken charge of three games so far. The Dublin-Cork game was a very open game played at moderate intensity whereas the Cork-Monaghan & Down-Monaghan encounters were tighter in nature & played at high intensity.  All three games were played in a very good spirit with some excellent passages of play and some great scores.

"There are always decisions in every game that play on your mind afterwards"

It’s been interesting getting used to the new self-assessment system.  I’d usually spend an hour or so on the evening of the game or the next morning being as honest about my own performance as I can.  There are always decisions in every game that play on your mind afterwards:
  • should I have booked for that trip or was I right to consider it unintentional?
  • was that a high tackle or was it clumsy because of the height difference between the two players?
  • was there a pick-up in the build-up to that score or was the ball just off the ground?
Comparing my self assessments with my independent assessments from the first two games in this year’s league, I have definitely been harder on myself than the two assessors.  A lot has been said in the early part of the league about referees ‘reffing games for the assessor in the stand’.  As a referee, from the moment you throw up that first football to start the game, the assessor is the last person on your mind.  You’re just trying to referee the game to the best of your ability, full stop! As has been the case in recent years, we have seen a small number of incidents being referred back to the referee for further adjudication.  While referees would probably prefer not to get that email including the line ‘David, a chara, are you happy that you adjudicated appropriately on incident X in the attached video?’, it’s part of the current disciplinary process and referees accept that.  No referee is pressurized into a particular response.  He is only asked to consider the clip in the context of the current playing rules of the game.  In the same way as referees are not thinking about assessors during a game, referees are not considering potential future appointments when deciding on the answer to the question above.  Referees at inter-county level have too much integrity to fall into these ‘traps’.

"Some of the comments directed towards the referee were over the top"

I decided to go to the Dublin-Mayo game at the weekend as a neutral observer.  When I do get the odd chance to go to a game as a neutral, I find myself looking at the referee and his performance as much if not more than the game itself.  It was an amazing game in that Dublin looked like they were going to run away with it in the first 20 minutes but then Mayo fought back and made it a tight, tense last 15-20 minutes.  Sitting in the crowd there wasn't a word about the referee in the first 20 minutes but once the game got tighter, every decision he made was closely scrutinized by spectators.  People can get very worked up when it comes to sport and supporting their own team but some times this does spill over.  Some of the comments directed towards the referee were over the top, particularly when people don’t know the rules the referee is actually penalizing players for.  I think it’s always interesting to compare players & spectators reactions to refereeing decisions.  The vast majority of the time players reactions will show that they know they fouled & accept the decision but because spectators only see one side, the referee is usually the one deemed to be in the wrong.  I know this is part and parcel of the game, but only if it doesn't spill over!  The referee is an amateur who gives as much commitment and dedication to the GAA as players do. Round 6 in two weeks time.  Refereeing Tyrone-Kildare in Omagh.  I’m expecting another high intensity clash.  Both teams are fighting for promotion to division 1.
item.excerpt:encoded: As we come to the mid point of the National League season, David explains that it is not just the teams involved that go through a tough self assessment

item.title: EU Policy is managing to create a two tiered periphery
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded:
The spread of the yield between German government bond yields and the yields of Ireland, Greece and Portugal moved out to record levels last week and markets became more concerned about the sustainability of the debt burdens in these countries. It also now appears likely that it is only a matter of time before Portugal receives funding from the EFSF (European Financial Stability Fund) and the IMF. In contrast to previous crisis i.e. when Ireland and Greece accepted assistance from Europe and the IMF, Spanish and Italian bonds have continued to make gains, while the Euro has also remained strong. This raises the question has to whether European policy makers have been successful in containing the contagion of the debt crisis.
Source: factset
What was agreed? The EU council meeting on March 11th surprised the market by agreeing on their resolutions to the sovereign crisis ahead of the meeting on March 24/25th. The following adjustments have been agreed:
  • Increased the EFSF back to €490bn that had previously been agreed in June 2010 from the €250bn that it had been decreased to in August 2010, ensuring that there are now enough funds available to cover the financial needs of Spain, if it were to require assistance.
  • Extended the duration of the Greece’s borrowing from the EFSF from 3 years to 7.5 years (in line with the Irish agreement).
  • Decreased the interest rate that Greece had to pay on the debt by 1%.
Last week the EU Council agreed the following
  • Agreed a permanent mechanism which will exist after 2013 called the ESM (European Stability Mechanism). This will be €700bn of funds that will be available to countries that require assistance. The fund will seek a triple A credit rating. It is also worth noting that the creation of the ESM is not cut in stone as it does require ratification from each member state. Also countries who are receiving assistance under the ESM programme can restructure their debts, which is not currently available under the EFSF structure.
What remains to be agreed?
  • Although the EU Council members agreed to increase the EFSF fund, the details of how the expansion will take place was not agreed. Further agreement on this should be reached at the next Council meeting in June and this will be after the Finish elections which may have been a stumbling block for the delay.
  • There was no deal made on the interest rate charged to Ireland, although there were some comments from Taoiseach Enda Kenny and the German Chancellor Merkel that a compromise on the corporate tax rate may be found. This will be negotiated in April after the stress tests have been conducted on the Irish banks.
Containing Portugal’s funding crisis? Despite the political turmoil in Portugal last week, Portugal may have no option but to accept support from the EFSF and the IMF, especially considering the acute liquidity pressures that it will come under over the next three months. Prime Minister Socrates resigned after the parliament rejected proposes additional austerity measures. Although it now appears likely that an election will occur in May, Portugal has a €4bn bond maturing in April and therefore it is unlikely that it will have the luxury of a government in place before it is forced to accept assistance to meet this maturity. As EU council members have agreed to extend the amount available from the EFSF to €490bn, markets are assured that there is enough funds available to countries that require it. Therefore the contagion from Portugal entering the fund has been much lower than what was experienced with Ireland and Greece crises. There is no doubt that the significant change of political will in Europe to deal with the sovereign crisis has resulted in confidence that the Euro will survive as a currency and has also stemmed the contagion into the larger economies such as Spain, Belgium and Italy. However questions remain as to whether the efforts taken to date adequately deal with the bigger issues that are facing the periphery. For example what will happen to Greece’s debt burden after 2013 as the debt trajectory continues to look unsustainable, or how the Irish banking system will repay the €150bn Euros that it owes to either the ECB or the Irish Central Bank. Also Spain cannot afford to make an mistake and although its debt trajectory appears sustainable and it’s fiscal consolidation is on track, the saving banks or Cajas do require a more meaningful recapitalisation, which to date has been pushed aside by both Europe and the Spanish Central Bank. Furthermore, the political will of the core countries to continue to support the periphery also remains a major risk, particularly after Chancellor Merkel’s election loss in Bavaria over the week end. Also there is an election in Finland in April, where anti-euro party is currently gaining support. While policy makers have been successful for now in calming markets. To date the response has been about providing liquidity support to countries at a high rate. Policy makers have also attempted to deal with the competitiveness of the peripherals countries. However no response has been considered to deal with the solvency of countries, which is core to solving the problem.

item.title: The need to hedge – inflation on the prowl
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded: Cash is currently the asset class of choice for Irish investors. Irish households have in excess of €100 billion sitting in cash and the personal savings ratio is running at around 13% or €12.2 billion per annum. Of this, some of it may be used to pay off debts and some may be used to increase savings. The decision to remain in cash throughout 2009 and 2010 hasn't been an altogether bad one as real returns of 8% and 4% were achievable. However, there was a significant opportunity cost, with global equity markets rallying by approximately 90% (based on the FTSE World Index) from their lows over that period. This decision to hold such huge levels of cash is understandable given the uncertainty in the domestic economy and the shock of the credit crisis that saw financial markets collapse in 2008. However, it is unlikely that savers and investors will switch 100% from cash into higher risk products. Nevertheless, with inflation risks mounting and other asset classes continuing to outperform, a shift to real financial assets may be warranted Consumer prices fell by an average of 4.5 % in 2009 and with deposit rates running at around 3% to 4%, this meant that the real return for sitting on cash in 2009 was around 8%. Consequently, getting a risk free real return of approximately 8% was very attractive for the risk adverse Irish saver. Unfortunately, this type of real return is an exception and is unlikely to be repeated again. Money is not what it used to be Irish inflation is currently running at over 2% and the expectation is that it will increase further as the year progresses. To highlight the impact of inflation it is worth considering the purchasing power of €1 over different time periods. According to the CSO, the purchasing power fell by 25% in the 10-years to 2010 and by 64% in the 20-years to 2010 and by a massive 240% in the intervening 30 years. In fact, according to the CSO, €1 in 1940 is now equivalent to over €44 in today’s money. The reduced purchasing power of a euro today is all down to inflation, and the only meaningful way to protect against rising inflation is by investing in real financial assets. For example, the average national price for a pint of stout was €1.90 in 1990 and today it costs €3.96 (an increase of 108%), while a litre of diesel cost €0.68 compared with €1.32 at the end of 2010 (an increase of 94%). It is worth noting that inflation in the last decade was downwardly impacted by two years of significant deflation in 2009 and 2010. A litre of diesel up 94% since 1990… …rashers up 66% and… … most shockingly of all, a pint of stout is up 108% in 20 years Inflation pressures mount……… According to the CSO, Irish consumer prices in February, as measured by the CPI, increased by 0.9% in the month. This compares to an increase of 0.4% recorded in February of last year. Prices on average, as measured by the CPI, were 2.2% higher in February compared with February 2010. As seen above, the impact of rising inflation year after year significantly erodes the purchasing power of money. Consequently while staying in cash might be a good decision in the short-term, longer-term it becomes an increasingly risky proposition. item.title: Slow news week
item.dc:creator: David Coldrick
item.content:encoded:
Last Tuesday was obviously a slow GAA news day, the Irish Independent had 2 articles about referees on the same day! The first article, while not doubting the integrity of a number of referees appointed to referee the crucial Division 2 NFL games last weekend, suggested that the referees in question should not have been appointed because they were affiliated to counties involved in the division.  I was one of the four referees in question,  taking charge of the Tyrone-Kildare clash but as a Meath-man and with Meath due to play Tyrone in the final round, it was inferred that I could be put under pressure to make decisions that could help Meath win that final game and avoid relegation!  The consequence for Tyrone would be to lose out on a potential place in the NFL division 2 final.  If there is no doubting the integrity of the officials concerned, you wonder why the article was actually necessary?
"it was inferred that I could be put under pressure to make decisions that could help Meath win that final game and avoid relegation!"
The second article, which was actually a follow on from a similar article two weeks earlier, concerned a particular referee who hadn’t been appointed to referee for four rounds of the league.  The article suggested this was due to the referee in question, not upgrading a particular incident from a yellow to a red card offence upon receipt of the CCCC video clip of the incident.  It’s unusual to see some of the media concerned with the lack of appointments a referee is getting at national level that we get two articles over the course of two to three weeks on the same topic.   I have no idea why the referee in question wasn’t appointed for rounds 3-6 inclusive of the NFL, neither article mentioned that the key criteria for appointments by the National Appointments Committee are assessments.  I wouldn’t want the media fighting my corner in this regard, as the articles are more a direct challenge to the CCCC/NAC and the question of trial by video, rather than having any real concern for the referee in question. As mentioned above, I refereed the Tyrone-Kildare game last weekend.  Tyrone dominated the contest from mid way through the first half and never really looked back.  Kildare are definitely a better side than what they showed last weekend – it was just one of those days when very little went right for them.  The game was moved quite late from Omagh to Dungannon because of the sad death of Ronan Kerr, the 25 year-old PSNI officer, in Omagh the previous evening.  There was a minutes silence prior to throw-in that was impeccably observed by all those present.
"Kildare are definitely a better side than what they showed last weekend - it was just one of those days when very little went right for them"
I’ve now completed my four NFL games and I’ve received my assessments, so there’s no way to change anything now!  My average NFL assessment mark will get a 50% weighting in the ‘actuarial-like’ formula driving inclusion or exclusion from the 15-man championship panel of football referees due to be announced on April 22nd.  The other 50% weighting is based on the pre league fitness & written exam results.  The hope is that my overall score is high enough when compared to my colleagues to make the panel.   There are always winners & losers in this process, but all referees accept this is the way forward.  There’s no such thing as ‘favourites’ as the formula is fool-proof.  This was quite clear last year when the referee who had taken charge of the previous season’s Munster football final was excluded from the championship panel as his NFL score didn’t put him into the top 18 (to be reduced to 15 this year I believe).  It was a shock but also a clear signal from the powers that be that no-one is assured of their place on the championship panel! My involvement in the NFL is not over yet.  I’ve been appointed to act as stand-by referee in the Wicklow-Clare Division 4 clash in Aughrim this weekend.  The match is to be refereed by one of the up and coming new referees who I’ve no doubt will do a great job.  Hopefully I’ll be able to give him a little insight from my refereeing experience to date.

item.title: Inflation is no longer on the prowl – it’s back!
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
Irish consumer prices for March rose 3% in year-on-year terms A risk that we have been highlighting since late last year in our blog and other publications is the risk of inflation taking hold in Ireland. This risk is now materialising with headline rates of inflation accelerating and likely to increase further in the months ahead. The decision by Irish households to hold large swathes of cash on deposit will prove increasingly costly if inflation continues to track higher. The latest inflation numbers Consumer Prices in March, as measured by the CPI, increased by 0.9% in the month, which is the second consecutive monthly increase of 0.9%. This compares to an increase of 0.1% recorded in March of last year. Prices on average, as measured by the CPI, were 3.0% higher in March compared with March 2010. The annual rate of inflation in Ireland for the last 10 years can be seen in Chart 1. The most striking feature is that inflation has risen from a low of -6.6% to currently stand at 3% in little over a year. The most notable changes in the year were increases in:
  • Housing, Water, Electricity, Gas & Other Fuels      +12.5%
  • Miscellaneous Goods & Services                           +7.6%
  • Communications                                                   +4.1%
  • Health                                                                  +4.1%
Obviously, the impact of rising energy prices is having a very big impact on the level of consumer prices and it can be expected (hoped?) that this rate of price increase will not be sustained. However, inflationary pressures are becoming more widespread and are evident in many other components of the index as can be seen from the following Chart 2. Chart 1:    From a low of -6.6% to 3% and rising – inflation is back! Chart 2: It’s not just energy prices and mortgage costs Inflation erodes the purchasing power of cash As we have often stated, cash is a low risk option in the short-term but it becomes an increasingly risky option as time goes by. The ravages of inflation can destroy the purchasing power of money and the only meaningful way to protect against rising inflation is by having exposure to real financial assets, such as equities, property and commodities amongst others. With inflationary pressures also mounting on a global basis, the outlook is for rising consumer prices for the year ahead. In our view, the most appropriate asset allocation for a medium to long-term investor who wants to beat inflation is a multi-asset fund rather than a concentrated allocation to one management style or asset class, especially if that asset class is cash or deposits. CORE a great stepping stone CORE, as a multi-asset fund, is very well diversified and is also capable of benefiting from any rally in global stock markets. The combination of asset classes gives CORE the flexibility to benefit from global growth and also reduces the high levels of volatility associated with equity markets. One of the key reasons that CORE can achieve the combination of similar growth and lower volatility than the average managed fund is because of the allocation to alternatives. However, given CORE’s allocation to real financial assets, it should also prove to be a very effective hedge against rising inflation. We believe CORE could be a great stepping stone into real financial assets. It has lower volatility than the average managed fund while also delivering similar potential returns over a full investment cycle. Important – Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions.  It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. item.excerpt:encoded: Its something we've been highlighting for some time now, but according to the consumer price index in March, the risk of inflation gripping Ireland now appears to be materializing.

item.title: Sustainability of US debt back in question
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded: The S&P rating agency surprised markets yesterday (April 18th 2011) and announced that it is reviewing the AAA credit rating of the US government debt for a possible downgrade. A negative outlook means that there is now a 33% chance that the S&P will downgrade the US sovereign within the next two years. Considering that in 2011 the government deficit as a percentage of GDP is forecast to be over 10% of GDP with gross debt expected to rise to 72% of GDP in 2011 and potentially reach 85% of GDP by 2016, the debt dynamics are very PIIGSish in nature. The S&P said that: “Because the US has relative to its “AAA” peers, what we consider to be very large budget deficits and rising government indebtedness and the path to addressing these are not clear to us, we have revised our outlook on the long-term rating from stable”. The rating agency is also concerned about: “the material risk that US policy makers might not reach an agreement on how to address the medium and long term budgetary challenges by 2013, if an agreement is not reached and meaningful implementation is not begun by then, this would in our (S&P rating agency) view render the US profile meaningfully weaker than that of the peer AAA Sovereigns. The catalyst for the negative outlook was the increased risk that there would be no resolution to the “medium term and long term fiscal challenges” facing the US until after the 2012 elections. Once the two political parties put their reduction plans on the table it became clear how difficult the road would be to political convergence. More than two years has passed since the financial crisis and there has been no agreement on how to bring the fiscal position back to a sustainable path. The market’s immediate response to the announcement was abrupt as major currencies rallied against the dollar, equity markets traded close to 2% lower, and US government bond yields increased, although some of this move was later reversed. In contrast other triple A government bonds such as Germany and UK made gains, while other safe havens, such as gold also rallied. This move from the S&P comes after the IMF highlighted in its April 2011 World Economic Outlook (published last week) that the risks around advanced economies having such weak sovereign balance sheets could result in much more volatile interest rates. However, the IMF also noted that there was little chance of sudden changes to government bond yields in the short term that the risk would threaten global financial stability. Elsewhere this week, President Obama is set to deliver his message of a proposed plans to reduce the deficit with a combination of spending cuts and tax increases for the rich. This is Obama’s attempt to block the Republican’s plan that would reduce the deficit by reducing Medicare and spending on education and other social programmes. However it is now becoming more evident that in order to avoid a downgrade of government debt, the administration needs to convince markets that there is a plan to bring the spiralling debt and deficit back to a more sustainable path. This, though, may prove highly problematic given the bi-partisan nature of US politics at the moment. Ideally, Congress would agree to a credible deficit reduction plan, before the markets start to punish the US government through higher bond yields. This happened in the UK in 2009 as the negative outlook in May 2009 prompted the  UK to implement a package of austere fiscal measures. This reassured the rating agencies and by October 2010 the negative outlook on the UK ratings was removed. However the political will in the US is less clear cut particularly given the Republican’s majority in congress. The House Republicans passed a budget last week that would reduce the federal deficit by $4.4tln in 10 years with programme cuts alone, however no Democrats voted for the plan. Hopes for a plan were being pushed out until after the Presidential election in 2012, however S&P’s announcement or more importantly markets may not give politicians the luxury of waiting until after the elections.
