item.title: National League Review
item.dc:creator: David Coldrick
item.content:encoded:
National League review
Cork showed their strength in depth in the final twenty minutes and picked at Dublin’s lead calmly and confidently, getting ahead when it really counted
So another national league is over and Cork have picked up another trophy. It’s amazing how a team that just couldn’t get across that final hurdle for two to three years until last year’s league success, just can’t stop winning games when it really counts.  The division 1 final was a very open affair.  Cork showed their strength in depth in the final twenty minutes and picked at Dublin’s lead calmly and confidently, getting ahead when it really counted.  Dublin had their chances to at least force extra-time but it just wasn’t to be on the day.  Both teams will learn a lot from their respective league campaigns as they head into the summer championship and both will have the same goal for the summer season.  Only time will tell whether either will achieve it. If the division 1 final was a very open game, the division 2 final couldn’t have been more different.  Both teams played with 13 men behind the ball in a very defensive game plan, which resulted in clustered play throughout.  It’s probably the most difficult type of game to referee.  Hopefully it’s not the norm for the championship! Championship panel The championship panel was announced last Thursday evening.  My league scores were good enough to make it.  The football panel again consists of 18 referees.  There were 3 retirements (>50 years old) from last season so places for three new referees were automatically up for grabs.  Only 1 of last year’s panel didn’t make it back this year.  It’s not easy to get that call saying you haven’t made it, especially when it means not refereeing at the highest level for a full championship season.  However the process again shows that no-one is guaranteed their place on the panel, and as a referee it’s the equivalent of making the final county football or hurling championship panel.  It’s hugely satisfying.
It’s not easy to get that call saying you haven’t made it, especially when it means not refereeing at the highest level for a full championship season
Two more hurdles to jump before getting ratified to officiate in this year’s championship.  The championship fitness test on May 6th and, for my umpires, this year’s formal training & exam takes place on April 30th.  I need to pass my fitness test and my umpires need to pass their rules exam for my team to remain intact for this year’s championship.  I’ve seen a draft version of the new umpires training course and it’s very professional and well put together.  I have no doubt that inter-county umpires will benefit greatly from the overhaul of the training course.  Hopefully the two final hurdles will be cleared and roll on the championship season!
item.excerpt:encoded: David gives his verdict on this years National League finals and gives us an insight as to what is required to make the Referee's championship panel.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: national-league-revie

item.title: Kate Middleton’s Pension
item.dc:creator: Stephen
item.content:encoded: The focus of conversation amongst your average Royal Wedding enthusiast will inevitably be Kate Middleton, her dress, the guest list and so on. In our line of business - life cover, pensions, investments - the conversation down the pub might be limited to a Yes/No response to “Do you have a pension at your job?” The great thing about research is that it can give fantastic perspective on what is actually important to people. When people think about their futures it’s simply not a conversation starter. That said we’ve come to learn that people do quite a lot of research themselves because it is very important to them personally. People might talk about Kate Middleton looking great but what is important personally is how she got to look that good. People then think - they rarely say out loud - “how can I look this good?”. There are 1,220,000 searches done on google each month for “Kate Middleton”. How many are interested in her diet? Well at the moment it is breaking out on google which means searches about her diet are rocketing. It has been growing rapidly for a few weeks and I’m sure it will be massive over the next few days as hysteria reaches boiling point. Her diet is called the dukan diet, or so I’m told and this graph illustrates search trends on google: Google knows the stuff that people really search for and therefore stuff they are truly interested in. Interestingly, for the search term “Kate Middleton” it is us Irish who are searching the most: Let's just compare how often people search for “pension” and how often they search for “wedding dress” in Ireland. 'Pension’ is about 10-20% more popular in the Google world. In the real world people just don’t talk about pensions that much while it’s often hard to stop ‘certain groups of people’ talking about wedding dresses when they get started. When we look at straightforward research like this it gives us confidence to invest energy and time to build useful research apps for people. They’re clearly looking for it. Our pension calculator, our life cover calculator and income protection calculators might give people a quote but they also give an understanding of, for example, what is the correct amount of life cover you should have. They are above all built for research. We launched our pension calculator almost a year ago and each month it is used a by a few thousand people. The proof of the pudding is truly in the eating. Speaking of pudding, “Royal Wedding Food” is a hot search on Google right now:

item.title: Ireland, a fast growing population and the pent up demand for financial products
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
In general, older, better educated, and higher income households will have a greater propensity to hold financial products such as pensions, investments, savings and protection products. However, given the economic crisis of the last number of years, the demand for such financial products by Irish households has faltered. Nevertheless, the underlying demographics still point to the potential of strong growth for financial products in the years ahead and that a considerable amount of pent up demand is occurring at the moment. Demographics – Growing Irish population now just entering key buying cohorts An expanding population is an important factor that drivers the underlying demand for financial products in any country. The Irish population is expected to grow strongly over the coming decades in contrast to other European countries as illustrated in Figure 1. Based on the forecasts by the United Nations World Population Prospects: The 2010 Revision, Ireland will have one of the fastest growing populations in Europe[1] and is expected to grow by 11% by 2020, 20% by 2030 and 28% by 2040. Figure 1 U.N. population growth forecasts for Europe 2010-2040 Source: United Nations, Department of Economics and Social Affairs, Population Division (2011). World Population Prospects: The 2010 Revision. (Medium-fertility variant). Another key factor influencing the purchase of financial products is the age of the underlying population. International evidence indicates, and mirrored by our own customer experience, that age cohorts from around 30 to 60 have the greatest propensity to invest and save. From this perspective, the Irish market offers significant opportunity as Ireland is still a demographically young country with a significant bulge in the 25 to 45 year age cohorts as can be seen in Figure 2. Figure 2 Source: Irish Central Statistics Office, September 2010. The 25-45 age cohort accounts for 32.1% of the total population In Ireland and compares very favourably with other European economies. The average for Europe is 27.5%, and in Germany for example, accounts for only 23% of the population[2]. Pension coverage increases by age As the population ages, the level of pension coverage increases and this can be clearly seen in Table 1. While the data relate to only voluntary private pension coverage, there is a clear rising trend of such coverage by age across a number of countries with inherently different pension arrangements. Irrespective of country and inherent pension structure, a definite trend is evident.
Table 1 Coverage of voluntary private pension plans
Percentage of total employment
By age
Source: Antolín, P. and E.R. Whitehouse (2009), “Filling the Pension Gap: Coverage and Value of Voluntary Retirement Savings”, Social, Employment and Migration Working Paper No. 69, OECD; OECD analysis of national datasets (Finland and Norway) In Ireland for example, voluntary private pension coverage is 27.5 per cent in the 20-24 age cohort and this coverage increases through the age cohorts and peaks at between 64 to 65 per cent in the 35 to 54 age cohorts. Similar patterns are evident in the other countries examined in the paper. The fact that Ireland still has a bigger than average proportion of its population in the younger age cohorts and the fact that the population is growing means that the demand for pensions, investments and savings, while depressed at the moment, should recover strongly in the years ahead.
  [1] Europe is defined as the combination of Northern, Southern, Western and Eastern Europe as described in the United Nations Population Database and covers 48 countries.
[2] The averages calculated for Europe and Germany are based on data from the UN World Population Prospects: The 2010 Revision.

item.title: Planet Jedward is the future!!!
item.dc:creator: T.J.
item.content:encoded:
Pension Levies, the Queen and Obama visits, these are all massive talking points in Ireland at the moment.  We have jobs funds, NAMA, debt restructuring and the country is coming to a standstill in preparation for the Royal visit next week, so you would assume that these would be the topics that are trending on twitter at the moment?  Well you would be wrong, it’s the Eurovision and in particular, Jedward.   Jedward and their legion of fans have created phenomenal hype around this years event, the front page of the national newspapers are dominated by the twins this morning, walk through any town or city and count how many “Jedhead” hairstyles or “Quiffs” you spot, the country is gripped in a Jedward fever!!
 Jedward are doing their bit to lift the gloom in the country at the moment
So why the sudden resurgence of interest in the Eurovision?  As far as I am concerned, the answer is simple, we’re all looking for a good news story, particularly in these dark days, and like them or loath them, you have to admit, Jedward are doing their bit to lift the gloom in the country at the moment.  Those of us old enough to remember back to the mid to late 80’s will remember the bad times but what will be foremost in our minds are the good news stories, Johnny Logan winning in ‘87 with Hold me Now, Barry McGuigan winning the world title in ’85, Big Jack and the Boys in Green in ’88. Fast forward to today, replace Barry McGuigan with Katie Taylor, our big hope for the Olympics in London next year, for the Irish soccer team, see the Leinster rugby team, and hopefully Jedward can take Johnny Logan’s mantle.
replace Barry McGuigan with Katie Taylor
I think the really positive message in this is that there are good times ahead.  So maybe Jedward can make their millions after a win on Saturday and BOD’s probably not overly worried about financial planning but while the rest of us might not make the millions we can certainly plan for our own good times.  It’s never too early to start thinking about your pension, and here at Irish Life we have the tools to help you start planning yours today.  Why not try our pension calculator or speak to one of our Financial Advisors and get the good times rolling for your future today.  We will leave the last word to the boys themselves, straight from their twitter feed this morning…”WE ARE SO EXCITED ARE YOU EXCITED BECAUSE WE ARE EXCITED” OMG, COME ON JEDWARD!!
item.excerpt:encoded: With Jedmania sweeping over the country, TJ outlines just why success for the twins could be so important for our future...

item.title: Robbing Peter to pay Paul
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
Colm McCarthy has written a very interesting article in relation to the government’s proposed 0.6% levy on pension funds. The article itself can be found here. In it, he highlights a number of problems with respect to the introduction of the 0.6% levy and the main ones are: -          The inequitable nature of the levy -          The lack of regard about the longer-term implications Not all’s fair in love and war
    Firstly, he highlights the inequitable nature of the levy between public sector pensions and private sector pensions. ‘Around 520,000 people own the €80 billion in these funds, an average of about €154,000 per person. The levy will cost them about €920 per annum on average. About 330,000 employees have entitlements under public service pension arrangements. These schemes are unfunded and thus have no taxable assets, but the total liability has been estimated by the Comptroller and Auditor-General at €108 billion. It follows that the average sum standing to each member in these unfunded schemes is about €327,000, more than double  the amount standing, on average, to those in funded schemes and liable for Mr. Noonan’s levy. The jobs initiative is being funded, in effect, not by those who are fortunate enough to have occupational pensions, but by those who have small occupational pensions. Those with the bigger pensions, public servants in the main, will not be contributing. Interestingly, since the new levy is a levy on assets, it will affect disproportionately the older members of the private sector workforce who have more substantial funds already saved. Younger workers can relax: they have too little in the way of retirements savings at risk.’ Robbing Peter to pay Paul - intergenerational transfers at work, but not very well In another part of the article, Colm McCarthy also makes the pertinent observation that, ‘in March of last year, the government released a document on pensions policy which expressed alarm at the condition of private sector funded pension schemes, including the inadequate level of contributions and limited coverage. The new government has sent a clear signal that it is content to see these problems get worse.’ Examining this point further we can see that there have been a number of changes to the Irish pension system over the last couple of years driven by the fiscal problems facing the economy. While it is entirely understandable why the government is looking for any sources of revenue it can get today, undermining the long-term incentives to fund for pensions is only storing up even bigger fiscal problems in the future. Demographic pressures building – Peter and Paul are both not happy The Irish economy is getting older and this, combined with the fact that life expectancy is increasing, means that the number of people in the 65+ age cohort is going to increase significantly. In terms of numbers, there will be over 1.4 million people aged 65 and over in 2050 compared with less than 500,000 in 2000. It is obvious that the government in the future will not be able to fund the pension requirements of prospective retirees in the years ahead and individuals will have to rely on their own pension savings.  However, if the incentive for individuals to fund for their own pensions is undermined, people will save less and this will result in significantly lower living standards for future retirees. Figure1.          Life expectancy after pensionable age in Ireland, 1958-2050

    Women beat men again!

    Source: OECD

    Figure 1 illustrates clearly that life expectancy for both men and women after the retirement age is increasing in Ireland. For example, in 1971, the life expectancy post retirement age for men was 7.7 years and 9.9 years for women. This increased to 15.1 years and 18.6 years for men and women respectively by 2002 and by 2050 life expectancy is expected to have increased to 20 years for men and 24.2 years for women. One of the consequences of living longer is that the dependency ratio (that is the proportion of the population 65 and over as a percent of the population aged 20-65) will increase from 19% in 2000 to 50% by 2050. This will be a dramatic change to the structure of the Irish population that we need to be prepared for well in advance. Unfortunately, recent pension policy has turned a blind eye to this, albeit, longer-term problem.   Important - Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions.  It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. item.title: Protection fit for a Queen
item.dc:creator: T.J.
item.content:encoded:
So the historic occasion of the Queen’s visit has almost come to an end.  A tour of the Rock of Cashel, Coolmore Stud and a trip to Cork are last on the itinerary today. Anyone in the capital during the week will have in some way been inconvenienced by the visit, whether it was delays getting to or from work, having your bag searched as you walked down the street or even simply by not being able to find a bin on O’Connell St to put your rubbish in!! Over a years work has gone into planning the security for the visit, easily the biggest security operation the country has ever seen, with over 8,000 of our Gardai deployed, and an overall estimated cost of €30 million.
the biggest security operation the country has ever seen, with over 8,000 of our Gardai deployed, and an overall estimated cost of €30 million.
But in my view it was worth it. We have much to be proud of in this county and a lot of it was showcased this week, the GAA, the racing industry, our artists and all with true leadership from our president, Mary McAlesse who has been fantastic all week.  I even had a taxi driver rave about the Queen’s visit yesterday and they, as we all know, are hard to impress! So the Queen was undoubtedly protected during her time here, but it does raise the question; how much is protection worth to you?  Almost 50% of Irish adults, that’s 1,500,000 of us, have no life cover, nothing in place to look after our loved ones in the event of our death.  A statistic made even more frightening when you consider that in 2010, the average age of deceased for all accidental death claims paid out by Irish Life was only 47!
the average age of deceased for all accidental death claims paid out by Irish Life was only 47!
While we don’t do barriers and thankfully have no need for armed escorts, Irish Life is totally committed to providing excellent protection for our customers.  And it’s not just words, we have paid out more than €1 billion in death, specified illness and income protections claims to more than 30,000 Irish families in the last 5 years. So why not try our Lifecover calculator, or have one of our qualified Financial Advisor’s call you back and see how we can help you protect your family this week. We know your home is your castle and therefore you’ve a royal family of your own to take care of!!

we're in protection season for sure!

Now for the US President, we’re in the midst of protection season for sure!
item.excerpt:encoded: So the historic occasion of the Queen’s visit has almost come to an end. A tour of the Rock of Cashel, Coolmore Stud and a trip to Cork are last on the itinerary today.

item.title: Barack O'Bama
item.dc:creator: Stephen
item.content:encoded: Security in Dublin City is tight and all this protection has been put in place for the most important person in the world. It’s not irrational to think the visit of Barack Obama to Ireland is influenced mainly by the chance to win some influence over those 12% of Americans who consider themselves of Irish ancestry.  It is true too that he may have just a little more than a passing interest in that small percentage of his own genes that carry Irish roots. Obama, however, is a proud African American and his interest in this small island lies outside threadbare genetics. “Eleven days and a half gone and I have crossed three thousand miles of the perilous deep. Instead of a democratic government, I am under a monarchical government. Instead of the bright, blue sky of America, I am covered with the soft, grey fog of the Emerald Isle. I breathe, and lo! the chattel [slave] becomes a man. I gaze around in vain for one who will question my equal humanity, claim me as his slave, or offer me an insult.” - Frederick Douglass. “My Bondage and My Freedom” In the 1800’s Frederick Douglass was a formidable campaigner for African-American freedom and the first black citizen to hold high rank in the U.S. government.  As an infant he was separated from his slave mother – he never knew his white father – and lived with his grandmother on a Maryland plantation. In his late 20’s as a freed slave he went to Europe to further his work for slavery’s abolition. He spent his first 6 months in Ireland. Ireland had a rejuvenating effect on a jaded Douglass - giving him strength to pursue his dream which he was struggling to achieve in America. During his time in Ireland nobody had such a strong influence or was as inspiring for Douglass as his new friend Daniel O’Connell. O’Connell’s skill as an orator captivated Douglass. Having watched O’Connell speak publicly for the first time he wrote: “His eloquence came down upon the vast assembly like a summer thunder-shower upon a dusty road” “It was an example worth emulating.” Emulate was in fact just what Douglass did and in the years to follow it was O’Connell’s oration style that strongly influenced Douglass. He became a leading figure in America and a powerful orator. It’s not hard to see why today’s US president draws heavily from Douglass and in turn O’Connell, in his own speeches and in his oration style. When Obama speaks on College green in Dublin City Centre, he will be closer to O’Connell Street than Moneygall and probably closer to the part of Ireland that actually had the biggest influence over his success. The Irish Life head offices are just a few hundred yards from O’Connell Street. It is here where all of the processing and decisions are made by our Claims Team for protection products such as life insurance. You might think Daniel O’Connell has no influence on anything to do with life insurance but there are parallels. Famously, or rather infamously, in 1815 O’Connell mortally wounded a noted duellist called John D'Esterre. D'Esterre had taken offence to a speech by O’Connell and challenged him to a duel. O’Connell’s conscience was scarred by D'Esterre’s death and for over 30 years until his own death he paid a share of his income to D'Esterre’s widow. She initially declined his offer but consented for the sake of her daughter. In 2010, Irish Life paid an income to 1256 families, with an average payment of over €65,000. In fact over the last 5 years we have paid over €1 Billion in protection claims to over 30,000 families. That’s a lot of protection but the most important people in the world are those closest to you. It is our job to make sure them feel secure.
item.excerpt:encoded: Security in Dublin City is tight and all this protection has been put in place for the most important person in the world

item.title: Now that the celebrities are protected...
item.dc:creator: Karl
item.content:encoded:
What a week - if a well known beer company made ideal weeks…
Saturday : Last Saturday was emotional, the proverbial game of two halves. First half we may have fought a bit but nothing was going as planned. Passes going astray, tackles being missed. Second half was just sublime and I wouldn’t mind but we’d lost 4-0 away to Crumlin only 2 weeks ago and here we were turning a 1-0 half time deficit in the return leg into a 4-1 win! Go Malahide United U9's!
After all that excitement it was nice to come home and sit down with the kids and relax watching Leinster (slowly!)warm-up for the Magners.
Monday : Today we’re presenting to all of our Customer Service staff to play back the findings from our Brand Review project in our new Customer Centre. We started working on this over 9 months ago with a wide range of people - our own staff, customers, advisers and our brokers. It’s been a great voyage of re-discovery for everyone. One of the real joys has been spending some time looking through our history - finding out how we were founded in 1939. World War 2 had just started and the country was in financial chaos and yet here we are over 70 years later talking about how much we have to be proud about in Irish Life.
I’ve worked here for over 26 of those years and I can honestly say I’ve never seen everyone more excited about what we’re doing now. Our business is back to the basics - helping people to feel secure and confident about their future so that they can get on with living their lives now - that’s a pretty good place to be.
Wed: Our new Irish Life advertising campaign goes live today. We haven’t made a TV ad for over 4 years, so naturally there’s a lot of interest in it from everyone in the company, which is great. One of the reasons we’re making this ad is that there’s an astounding 1.5 million - yes 1 in 2 Irish adults - that have no life cover of any kind. As the parent of a young family, I really believe the best thing I can do in my working life is to encourage parents to protect their kids’ future by making sure they have life cover.
We made the ad in Ireland over the last few weeks. It would have been much cheaper to make the ad overseas. However we're an Irish company and our customers are Irish - we believe the right thing is to keep the money in our economy and support an Irish production company. And they've done a really great job - it proves once again that we've got really world class companies on our own doorstep.
<object width="550" height="319"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/9F-vNhu1Mpo?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" /><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always" /><embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="550" height="319" src="http://www.youtube.com/v/9F-vNhu1Mpo?fs=1&hl=en_US&rel=0" allowfullscreen="true" allowscriptaccess="always"></embed></object>
Before we made the ad, we spoke to a lot of parents, and the one thing they keep saying to us is that as parents we’re to- busy living and taking care of our kids! So if you guys want to get our attention, you have to work to get my attention and really force me to think about it. The prize is that if we do our job and get you to do something about protecting your family, that's actually something that's very very positive for Irish families.
The reality is that over the last 5 years alone we’ve paid out over €1 billion to thousands and thousands of families right across this country. I sleep better at night knowing what a difference that makes to people's lives.
Friday: Every day for the last 2 months my eldest daughter wakes us to tell us how many days are left to her communion. We try to be as enthusiastic as possible but at 5 in the morning , and having had her brother make his communion last year as well, it can be hard to get too excited. However this morning felt a bit different - there’s only 1 sleep left and I’m taking today off to finally give a help at home to get the house ready. And there was the added excitement this morning when communion girl got to hear her name called out on TV3’s Ireland AM. As I type this the girls are singing along to Dora, the grass looks fantastic if I say so myself (although the senior event manager for the communion has hardly noticed!), and there's laughter and screaming coming from the trampoline.
Here’s to some sun and a Leinster/Barca double tomorrow and a Malahide Utd U9 win in our play off on Sunday. That would probably be the ultimate end to a great few days!
item.excerpt:encoded: A look back on a very exciting week for the Irish Life brand, and a few others..

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I've just seen this ad. (and btw you'll never publish this).
I find it highly offensive that you'll use such a tragic event to hock your wares. Shame on you.

Thanks for posting feedback to my blog. I'm sorry that the current ad has upset you and want to explain the background to our campaign.
As a life assurance company we're in the business of providing life and specified illness cover for parents - paying lump sums to support families if a breadwinner dies, often unexpectedly, or suffers from one of a range of specified serious illnesses.
We developed this campaign because almost 1 in 2 adults say they have no cover at all and the majority of those with cover have too little to provide real long term financial protection for their family (our average life cover pay out last year was just over €60,000).
And, because we're dealing literally with matters of life and death, to help in the making of this campaign we got the views of hundreds of parents. Parents overwhelmingly told us that we needed to communicate the real benefits that they feel life cover provides - peace of mind in the present that if anything ever happens to you in the future, that your family will be taken care of financially.
So our campaign overall has set out to address the following issues:
1. Raise awareness of the need for cover and to highlight the fact that Irish families are under-covered. 2. Promote the fact that cover is very affordable for most families - you can buy new cover from as little as €15 a month. 3. Provide helpful information including a simple guide to life cover and tools on our website such as our simple life cover calculator to make people aware of how they can protect their family and shortly we'll have lifestyle tips from Dr Mark Hamilton showing how people can live healthier lives.
I'm sorry once again that the campaign has upset you. As a parent and the son of a parent who died very young, I feel I have a personal insight into this issue as well as a professional one. I fully believe that what we're trying to do - make more parents aware of the need to have life cover - is the right thing to do and that, based on our extensive customer research, we have tried to do it in a very appropriate way.
Thanks again for giving your feedback on my blog.

As a life assurance company we're in the business of providing life and specified illness cover for parents - paying lump sums to support families if a breadwinner dies, often unexpectedly, or suffers from one of a range of specified serious illnesses.
We developed this campaign because almost 1 in 2 adults say they have no cover at all and the majority of those with cover have too little to provide real long term financial protection for their family (our average life cover pay out last year was just over €60,000).
And, because we're dealing literally with matters of life and death, to help in the making of this campaign we got the views of hundreds of parents. Parents overwhelmingly told us that we needed to communicate the real benefits that they feel life cover provides - peace of mind in the present that if anything ever happens to you in the future, that your family will be taken care of financially.
So our campaign overall has set out to address the following issues:
1. Raise awareness of the need for cover and to highlight the fact that Irish families are under-covered. 2. Promote the fact that cover is very affordable for most families - you can buy new cover from as little as €15 a month. 3. Provide helpful information including a simple guide to life cover and tools on our website such as our simple life cover calculator to make people aware of how they can protect their family and shortly we'll have lifestyle tips from Dr Mark Hamilton showing how people can live healthier lives.
I'm sorry once again that the campaign has upset you. As a parent and the son of a parent who died very young, I feel I have a personal insight into this issue as well as a professional one. I fully believe that what we're trying to do - make more parents aware of the need to have life cover - is the right thing to do and that, based on our extensive customer research, we have tried to do it in a very appropriate way.
Thanks again for giving your feedback on my blog.";s:14:"comment_parent";s:3:"167";s:7:"user_ID";s:1:"6";s:7:"user_ip";s:15:"194.125.111.194";s:10:"user_agent";s:100:"Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1) AppleWebKit/534.24 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/11.0.696.77 Safari/534.24";s:8:"referrer";s:63:"http://blog.irishlife.ie/wp-admin/post.php?post=680&action=edit";s:4:"blog";s:24:"http://blog.irishlife.ie";s:9:"blog_lang";s:5:"en_US";s:12:"blog_charset";s:5:"UTF-8";s:9:"permalink";s:72:"http://blog.irishlife.ie/general/now-that-the-celebrities-are-protected/";s:9:"user_role";s:13:"administrator";s:21:"akismet_comment_nonce";s:6:"passed";s:22:"POST_newcomment_author";s:0:"";s:28:"POST_newcomment_author_email";s:0:"";s:26:"POST_newcomment_author_url";s:0:"";s:12:"POST_user_ID";s:1:"6";s:11:"POST_action";s:15:"replyto-comment";s:15:"POST_comment_ID";s:3:"167";s:20:"POST_comment_post_ID";s:3:"680";s:11:"POST_status";s:0:"";s:13:"POST_position";s:1:"1";s:13:"POST_checkbox";s:1:"0";s:9:"POST_mode";s:6:"single";s:32:"POST__ajax_nonce-replyto-comment";s:10:"d3408e8581";s:32:"POST__wp_unfiltered_html_comment";s:10:"2e9432f177";s:12:"POST_content";s:2159:"Thanks for posting feedback to my blog. wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Thanks for the reply, well phrased in the form of an ad, I like it.
The message itself is sound, but the delivery is poor and I found it upsetting. I put it to you that next time you embark on such thorough research, maybe don't ask the parents, but ask the children.

Hi Karl,
I found this ad upsetting as well, and I don't understand why you chose to sentimentalise such a painful experience in order to sell insurance. I thought it was mawkish, and as someone who is also the child of a parent who died young, I found it distressing and sort of provocative.
You took a deeply painful, profoundly isolating experience and prettied it up for public consumption in a way that will probably make the small number of young people who are actually affected by this kind of loss feel even less understood. I don't believe that exploiting the experience of parental loss was the only way you could have gotten your message across.
It's great you'll be putting up tips for living more healthy lives on your site. Why not post up resources for kids who are dealing with the loss of a parent as well? Are there any groups in Ireland offering programmes for children who have suffered such a loss? A donation would be a nice gesture, since I suspect your ad is affecting a lot of people you'll never hear from.

Powerful ad. I find it humourous that people are complaining since the very idea of an advert is to "hawk your wares". Expressing outrage that an ad for life assurance portrays what happens if you die and leave your child without a parent, yet cared for, is a bit naive. Companies do this all the time, and it does its job to raise awareness and revenue.

item.title: [UPDATED] A crucial week for the Eurozone sovereign debt crisis
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded:
The debt crisis in Europe has been heating up over the past few weeks, particularly as it has become evident that Greece is not on track to meet the conditions set by the IMF and EU and as a result can no longer receive its funding. The next tranche of funding in due around the end of June and is worth €12bln. Greece needs these funds to continue to pay for its public services but also to repay bond redemption by 20th of July. As a result peripheral bond investors are now pricing in a significant probability of default into the Greek bond market, particularly in the bonds that are maturing in the next year as can be seen in the Chart below. This chart represents the yield on each government bond maturity. Although the deadline for paying the fifth tranche over to the Greek government is approaching fast, a consensus about a resolution to this problem seems far away. It has become much more difficult over the past week given the political uncertainty that has increased dramatically in Greece, while the political environment across Europe is also proving a challenge to a resolution. Europe & the IMF want Greece to adopt an additional €6bln austerity and continue on with their privatisation programme in exchange for an additional package. The German government also believes that this package should be accompanied by some sort of restructuring of Greece’s debt, most likely offering investors who hold bonds maturing over in the near term the option to exchange these for bonds that will mature in a number of years out. However there are significant difficulties with these options:
  • There is no political consensus in Greece at the moment. There is a vote of confidence in the government today (June 21st) and if the government wins this vote it is expected that the additional austerity package is expected to be voted for. However if the government looses then a general election will have to be held and any austerity package will be delayed.
  • The ECB does not believe that the Eurozone should allow Greece to restructure its debt now. The banking stress tests are being conducted currently and the results of which are being released during the summer months. Currently the French and German banks have significant exposure to Greek government bonds and no losses have been expected for these positions. Therefore a restructuring could undermine the stability of the Eurozone banking system. Also the ECB is a holder of Greek debt as it had been purchasing peripheral bonds through 2010 in order to help stabilise markets.
  • The rating agencies have noted that any restructuring of Greece’s debt would be considered a default and hence would be reflected in their rating.
  • There are still potential contagion effects for the other Eurozone periphery countries, which could result in a much higher cost for the European Union. Although markets have started to differentiate between peripheral countries since the start of this year, a Greek restructuring could undermine the stability of the larger peripheral countries such as Spain, Italy and Belgium.
These concerns are reflected in bond markets as can be seen from the chart below. There are three issues for Greece in this crisis –
  • Solvency problem whereby debt to GDP is likely to be over 150%
  • A liquidity problem whereby its deficit to GDP is expected to be 10% of GDP
  • Eurozone problem – the contagion effects to the rest of Europe and the
    • European banking system are unknown.
As a result, a solution to this problem is complex. Greece can’t go it alone if it is to keep paying for its public service. It is a political decision by both Europe and the IMF as to what the conditions will be for further funding and currently these look like there is additional austerity and accelerating the privatisation programme. Restructuring of Greece’s debt is also a political decision but the decision is probably restructuring now or later. Therefore the solution to the crisis is political and what ever happens will result in additional volatility for investment markets and will be difficult to predict. UPDATE: The Greek government has secured a vote of confidence last night which will avoid a snap election and increases the likelihood that the government will be able to pass the additional austerity on June 28th. The market reaction has been muted to this news as it was expected and had been priced into markets yesterday (June 21st). Greece's 10 year government bond yield has remained unchanged. Risk aversion has remained evident in markets as the yield on the German 10 year government bond has decreased to 2.96% from 2.98%, while the price of gold, the ultimate safe haven, has continued to move higher. Equity markets in Europe are broadly unchanged this morning following the gains made yesterday. While the vote of confidence in the government, eases concerns about the political risks in Greece it is just a hurdle for Greece to receive a second bailout package. The next condition that has been set by EU Finance ministers is that the new fiscal and structural reform measures are agreed. However the long term problem of Greece's unsustainable government debt levels continues. END of UPDATE Important - Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. ILIM and ILA manage investment funds which may have holdings in stocks commented on in the document. These products may be affected by changes in currency exchange rates. Past performance may not be a reliable guide to future performance. Investments may fall as well as rise. ILIM and ILA are regulated by the Central Bank of Ireland.

item.title: Protecting Your Health - Advice from Dr. Mark Hamilton
item.dc:creator: Dr Mark Hamilton
item.content:encoded:
As part of our campaign to highlight the importance of protecting your family, we’re delighted to have Dr. Mark Hamilton share some practical help and advice on taking care of your health. As well as being the presenter of RTE’s very popular tv show “Health of the Nation”, Mark is an A&E Doctor and is also the father of two young children – the ideal qualifications to provide some straightforward guidance for parents on protecting your family.
In the first video, Dr. Mark touches on the various aspects involved in your overall health and has some very positive messages on what we can all do to live a longer and healthier life. He also discusses how important your mental health is to preventing other potential health issues. Given that most of us are looking for more ‘peace of mind’ these days, we think you’ll find this particularly interesting.
Dr Mark also has some very important points to make about the importance of staying active, including an interesting statistic on its benefits versus taking Anti-depressant medication.
<object width="610" height="375"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/aQQ2U0J9JOQ?version=3&hl=en_US&rel=0" /><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always" /><embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="610" height="375" src="http://www.youtube.com/v/aQQ2U0J9JOQ?version=3&hl=en_US&rel=0" allowfullscreen="true" allowscriptaccess="always"></embed></object>
We hope you find this video interesting and in our next clip Dr. Mark will give you some tips on your diet and how to manage it to help keep you healthy.

item.title: Who wants to be a Referee?
item.dc:creator: David Coldrick
item.content:encoded:
After the weekend’s gaelic games, you’d have to wonder who would want to be a referee. There’s huge broadcast & print media attention on referees at inter county level at the moment and this has been building steadily over the last few years.  There’s no doubt that this puts pressure on referees each weekend during the championship season.  Referees understand that this comes with the territory but what also needs to be understood is that the referee has a split second to make each and every decision in a given match.  He doesn’t have recourse to 5 different camera angles or have the ability to watch 5 replays of the incident.  Referees call it as they see it and this is no different now to any point in the past, it’s just that there are far more cameras and ‘experts’ pouring over each and every decision a referee makes now.
There’s huge broadcast & print media attention on referees at inter county level at the moment and this has been building steadily over the last few years
It’s easy to criticise referees.  Gaelic football has a set of playing rules and whether people have problems with those rules or not, the referee’s job is to implement them honestly and impartially.  I’ve said before that one of the main problems in the GAA is lack of knowledge of the rules amongst the various parties to the game.  All referees are big enough to take criticism of individual decisions on the basis of erroneous implementation of the playing rules but where criticism is sometimes based on someone’s ‘own’ set of rules which may bear little resemblance to the actual playing rules adopted by the GAA, it can be hard.  What is also difficult to accept is when media criticism becomes a personal attack on a referee. This is cheap and not part of the game.  Each referee has a family and neither the referee nor his family should be subjected to negative personal comments in the media.  This should also be the case for players and their families.
What is also difficult to accept is when media criticism becomes a personal attack on a referee. This is cheap and not part of the game.
GAA referees adopt a professional approach to training and preparation for games. We continually strive to meet high standards and improve performance as the speed and intensity of games increase and the media scrutiny also intensifies. Referees are proud to be volunteers in the GAA. I refereed the recent Ulster championship match between Armagh and Derry.  It was a very open game of football with both teams using accurate kick passing a lot more than has become the norm in the football championship in recent years.  Unfortunately I picked up a calf injury in the game and although I tried my best to shake it off last week (3 extremely cold bath treatments & a number of physio sessions), my fitness test last Friday didn’t go as well as I needed it to and I had to make the difficult decision to pull out of the Leinster semi final clash between Kildare and Dublin. Although no referee wants to miss championship games through injury, it was the correct decision to pull out as Croke Park offers no hiding places. This weekend I’m looking forward to refereeing the Munster Final in Killarney – fingers crossed it’ll go well!
item.excerpt:encoded: David takes a look at the past weekends action in the championship and asks the question, who would want to be a referee?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
David,
There are very few sports that I know of where referees give interviews to the media after games. GAA referees usually speak through the head of the National Referees (currently Michael Curley). Mick would contact us to discuss particular/general refereeing matters with us and he would then deal with the media on our behalf. I think this works well. As referees what we need to avoid is a 'backwards & forwards' difference of opinion with the media that is of no benefit to anyone involved in the game.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: If that is the case then I feel referees need to stand up to the GAA,we all do, the fans, players and officials because as it stands the power is held by a few dinosaurs who see modernity as a sin. I appreciate your view points on what rule changes there should be and your use of this platform. You need to encourage your colleagues to do the same. What would the GAA do if there was a collective movement against them from the most important groups, the fans, the players and the referees?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Jerry, the advantage in gaelic football is a difficult one to consistently get right as a referee. It's a split second judgement call which at times can backfire on the referee. I've often thought about whether a call back mechanism would help. I wouldn't be in favour of an advantage lasting as long as it does in rugby and our game moves a lot quicker than rugby so it may be difficult to come up with something that can be consistently applied at all levels of the GAA.

John,
I am previously on record as saying that personally I wouldn't be against the use of video (or other) technology being discussed & considered for gaelic games. But I think it's a bit unfair to tie not using technology into a question of respect for referees as we have little or no say in such matters. It is up to senior GAA management & Congress to decide on such issues on behalf of the Association.
Regards,
David Coldrick

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Surely the lack of resources such as cameras is to be addressed and altered, not used as an excuse. I try my very best to respect referees but when it costs such a big game when there is such an easy solution it's very hard to respect them. The argument against video technology is that it can't be universal, it shouldn't have to be, an Inter-County Championship match is the pinnacle of the game and that is where Cameras should be active. Cricket, Tennis, and Rugby all get by with using technology without it been present at lower levels so why can't the GAA follow suit?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I can only echo your comments about so called experts or pundits. The media and in particular TV are getting carried away with themselves and my OPINION is that is may have to do with a ratings war between the 2 broadcasters to see who can drum up the most controversy. In the past forthnight so called experts/ pundits commentators have criticised referess for making the correct decisions. (PS: I'd have shown Red to Donaghy - I made that remark in work this week and the reply I got was that it was soft but the same argument has to be made it's not the referee's fault if it's soft or not, A free is a free, A foul is a foul & A stamp or a kick to opponent is red). On another issue, Would you welcome the opportunity to give interviews to media after a game?. I think by being restricted in this capacity referees become alienated and this may go some way to explaining why media & supporters are giving ref's such a hard time. Like to know your views on that one.

I was at the Kerry match on Sunday and thought you did a great job. As a Kerry fan in the terrace right in front of the Donaghy "incident" I thought he was very lucky to just get a yellow. I did laugh when a guy beside us shouted out, when you were speaking to him "give him Galvin's name". Overall you let the game flow and you were very consistent. There were a few times where you played advantage and nothing came of it. Would you like to be able to call play back for the free as in rugby?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'd Agree Jerry, Advantage rule needs to give greater advantage to the player fouled. Referee tries to play advantage and within a second or 2 player fouled looses possession we can hardly call that an advantage to him, I think if the 4 step or time to take 4 step rule was applied when playing advantage it would give refs a proper opportunity at either penalising the offender or letting the player in possession go.

item.title: A strong performance for the Irish economy - but the devil is in the detail
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded:
Although Irish bonds continued to make losses last week, as the yield on the ten year Irish government bond increased from 11.3% to 11.7%, the CSO confirmed that the Irish economy is on track to meet the expectations of the government. GDP in the first quarter grew by 1.3% since the fourth quarter of 2010. The report issued by the CSO confirmed that the recovery is very much export led, as has been predicted by almost every commentator. The domestic economy continued to remain a drag on the economy, contracting by 1.9% during the quarter. Looking for spillovers from exports to the domestic economy The growth in exports has been remarkable and increased 7.1% in the first quarter from the fourth quarter of 2010 and is up 7% over the past year. This implies that the growth in the economy is purely led by the export sector as had been expected given the drags on the domestic economy. Also the multinational sector has also been leading this growth, in particular the pharmaceutical and medical sector. However there has also been a recovery in the traditional sector, with agriculture, forestry & fishing up 4% over the past year, although some of this gain did reverse slightly in the first quarter. The recovery in this sector which tends to be more labour intensive was also evident in the labour market data as employment in the agriculture sector increased during the first quarter. There are initial indications that there may be a spin off from this export recovery to the rest of the economy as investment component of GDP increased in the first quarter by 1.1% despite the continued sharp decline experienced in the construction sector, implying that companies are starting to reinvest in machinery and equipment. Also the labour statistics showed employment gains in six sectors including transport & storage, professional, scientific & technical and administration and support services. Waning business confidence remains a risk The outlook for business has slowed since the first quarter as business confidence for both the manufacturing and services sectors has eased but continue to point to growth in these sectors, in line with the slowdown that has been seen in global business confidence surveys. Currently it appears that this slowdown is being partially attributed to the production disruptions as a result of the Japanese natural disaster in March and hence is expected to recover in the second half of 2011. Needless to say, any further slowdown in the global recovery could slow the Irish export led recovery. Domestic demand remains in a recession: The report continued to show that the domestic economy is struggling as consumer spending and government spending both contracted by close to 2%, confirming that the environment remained exceptionally weak for the consumer in the first quarter. Retail sales have continued to contract in April and the effect of the car scrappage scheme which is due to finish at the end of June continues to fade. Elsewhere consumer confidence has rebounded somewhat albeit from a low level in May as expectations have moved slightly higher. A number of head winds continue to persist for the consumer over the next few months that will delay any material recovery in consumption:
  • Inflation has started to pick up in Ireland and in May was 2.7% higher than a year ago, boosted by higher energy and mortgage costs, even though wages remained pressured
  • Consumers are expecting increases taxes, mostly likely indirect taxes such as water charges and a property tax. The lack of detail on these charges is dampening confidence and hence spending.
  • Consumers are continuing to repay the high level of debts that were built up in previous years.
  • The labour market has also remained fragile as the quarterly national household survey confirmed last week that employment continued to fall in the first quarter albeit by a slower rate than previously.
Positive news for the government bond market, EU & IMF is that the economy is growing. The government has predicted that the economy will grow by 0.8% during 2011. This is the economic growth that is required for the government to meet the targets to continue to receive funding from the EU & IMF. It is essential that Ireland meets this target for 2011 and then set clear and achievable targets for 2012. The current growth target of 2.5% for 2012 currently looks challenging, considering that interest rates will be rising and an additional €3.6bln will be taken out of the economy from the government. But for now the government is on target with its plans. Important - Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. ILIM and ILA manage investment funds which may have holdings in stocks commented on in the document. These products may be affected by changes in currency exchange rates. Past performance may not be a reliable guide to future performance. Investments may fall as well as rise. ILIM and ILA are regulated by the Central Bank of Ireland.
item.excerpt:encoded: Although Irish bonds continued to make losses last week, the CSO confirmed that the Irish economy is on track to meet the expectations of the government. GDP in the first quarter grew by 1.3% since the fourth quarter of 2010.

item.title: The Outlook for Equity Markets Going into Q3
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded: Disappointing economic data, concerns over the excessive debt levels, the natural disaster in Japan and higher food and energy prices have all hampered the outlook for equity markets recently and resulted in weaker markets. The realisation of risks in this lacklustre economic recovery is going to result in a more volatile period for equity investors; however gains are still likely while the economic recovery is in tact for now. The economic data, particularly in the US has weakened and as a result has pushed forecasts for economic growth for 2011 back to the forecast that were seen in the fourth quarter 2010.Growth forecasts in Europe have held up remarkably well as the export led recovery in the core Eurozone countries has gained momentum. There are also concerns that some of the emerging market economies may be overheating. Despite these concerns the global recovery is on track. The IMF expects global growth of 4.4% in 2011, although weaker growth in the advanced economies is being offset by buoyant growth in the emerging economies. The global recovery is in an early stage, it has started only two years ago, which is short by historical standards. On average since 1980 recoveries have lasted six years. Also the economic environment does not have many excesses that would usually be associated with the late stages of the economic cycle. The labour market is loose, companies continued to have spare capacity, consumers are saving as the saving ratios are at a fifteen year high in the UK and the US. Monetary policy is also very accommodative. As a result we expect that the global economic recovery will continue. Despite this there are a number of significant risks that will weigh on the magnitude of the economic recovery. Most notably there is a huge debt overhang in advanced economies and deleveraging will continue over the coming years. Governments, including the US, will have no option but to cut down on spending and raise taxes which will be a drag on growth. Elsewhere consumer saving rates will remain high. Therefore it will be up to the consumer in emerging economies and business spending to drive growth. This means that the recovery will be slower than normal but also more volatile than previous recoveries. Consequentially earnings growth will be more subdued than seen in recent cycles. Recently earnings revisions for the US and Europe have turned negative implying that the robust levels of earnings growth that had been expected by analysts now appears less realistic. We expect that earnings expectations for 2011 will be revised down further during for the remainder of the year. However we are still optimistic that earnings can grow by about 10% during 2011. Valuations are also undemanding by historical standards and attractively valued versus other asset classes, most notably government bonds. As a result, the valuation story is likely to support equities at or close to these levels. Although investors must have an appetite for risk as volatility will remain much higher than investors usually experience at this stage in the cycle. All in all, ILIM expects that equity markets can achieve single digit returns in 2011, in line with the earnings growth. Important – Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. item.title: Get the balance right - Diet advice from Dr Mark Hamilton
item.dc:creator: Dr Mark Hamilton
item.content:encoded: There is no such thing as a bad food, just a bad diet.. As part of our campaign to highlight the importance of protecting your family, we’re delighted to have Dr. Mark Hamilton share some practical help and advice on taking care of your health.  As well as being the presenter of RTE’s very popular tv show “Health of the Nation”, Mark is an A&E Doctor and is also the father of two young children – the ideal qualifications to provide some straightforward guidance for parents on protecting your family.   In this clip, Dr. Mark discusses the importance of your diet to your overall health. He also discusses some of our less appealing habits such as smoking and how to get help to give them up and provides a reminder as to what our weekly alcohol intake limits are. The key word in this video is balance and we think that’s great as it’s important in all aspects of live in bringing us ‘peace of mind’ which we’re all looking for. We hope you found this video interesting and remember to come back next week when Dr. Mark will give you some final advice on rest and sleep and how important it can be to help keep you healthy.
item.excerpt:encoded: There is no such thing as a bad food, just a bad diet...

item.title: The ups and downs of the euro
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
Despite the on going sovereign debt crisis in the Euroarea, it might be surprising to know that the currency itself has managed to hold up very well versus the dollar and sterling. However, this has probably more to do with the problems that the U.S. and U.K. economies face rather than any inherent strength in the Euroarea economy. In contrast, the Swiss franc and gold (denominated in euros) have seen significant gains over the past few years, especially as the sovereign debt crisis has escalated. The U.S. dollar and sterling offer no safe port in the current credit storm The following charts highlight the resilient performance of the euro versus the dollar and sterling. As can be seen:
  • The euro has performed quite strongly versus the U.S. dollar since July of last year, rising in value from US$1.22 to currently stand at US$1.40, a rise of approximately 15%.
  • Versus sterling, the euro has risen by approximately 7% in value from GB£0.81 in July of last year to currently stand at GBP0.87.
  • Furthermore, the euro is well above the lows of early 2006 versus both the U.S. dollar and sterling and is an indication that the U.S. and U.K. are not considered safe havens in the current environment.
The ultimate safe havens – the Swiss franc and gold In contrast to the U.S. dollar and sterling, the Swiss franc and gold have offered considerable protection against the sovereign debt crisis in the Euroarea. Both the Swiss franc and gold have performed very strongly in recent years as can be seen in the following charts.
    • The euro has fallen in value quite significantly versus the Swiss franc from just under CHF1.70 at the end of 2007 to CHF1.12 at the moment, a fall of approximately 35%. While many commentators believe that the Swiss franc is overvalued versus the euro, there does not appear to be any immediate sign that the fall in the euro versus the Swiss franc is about to end.
    • The price of gold has proven to be an excellent investment over the last five years driven by number of factors, including fears of inflation, demand from emerging markets and as a hedge against the current credit crisis. In euro terms, the price of gold has nearly tripled since 2006, rising from just over €400 an once to just under €1,200 an ounce.
item.excerpt:encoded: Despite the on going sovereign debt crisis in the Euroarea, it might be surprising to know that the currency itself has managed to hold up very well versus the dollar and sterling.

item.title: A Good Nights Rest
item.dc:creator: Dr Mark Hamilton
item.content:encoded: As part of our campaign to highlight the importance of protecting your family, we’re delighted to have Dr. Mark Hamilton share some practical help and advice on taking care of your health. As well as being the presenter of RTE’s very popular tv show “Health of the Nation”, Mark is an A&E Doctor and is also the father of two young children – the ideal qualifications to provide some straightforward guidance for parents on protecting your family. In our final video, Dr. Mark gives us some peace of mind with a message on the importance of a good night’s rest. How many hours should you be getting every night? He signs off with a reminder to make sure to get things checked out if we ever have any concerns about our health and not to leave it too late. We hope you found Dr Mark’s video’s interesting and keep checking in on our blog for information on keeping your finances healthy also. We have more from Dr Mark Hamilton here: Health Advice and Get The Balance Right

item.title: The consequences of a booming Ireland
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
Ireland’s population continued to grow strongly from 2006 to 2011, mainly due to a high number of births. According to the 2011 Census, the total population was 4,581,269, an increase of 341,421 (8.1 per cent over the past five years) on the 2006 Census.   High birth rates and falling death rates One part of the Irish economy that continues to boom is the birth rate, with 73,000 births per year between 2006 and 2011, up 20% per year in the period 2002-2006 and 54,000 per year from 1996-2002. And while births have taken off, the death rate has steadily fallen over the years from 42,000 per year in the 1920s to 28,000 per year on average currently. The difference between the birth rate and the death rate is called the natural increase in the population. Ireland has one of the fastest rates of natural increase in the population compared with our European peers. The rates of natural change per 1,000 population in the European Union was 1.0 in 2007 and 1.2 in 2008. The same rates for Ireland were 9.8 and 10.4 respectively. Obviously, we are good at something! Inward migration surprisingly positive Another factor that has boosted the numbers of people in Ireland is the level of net migration which has, to some degree, being surprisingly positive over the years 2006-2011.  The number of people entering the country averaged 24,000 per year, or a total of 118,650 between 2006 and 2011. However, it should be noted that unlike the 2002-2006 period, where there was a clear pattern of net inward migration across each of the four years, the pattern over the 2006 to 2011 period is noticeably different. Ireland continued to experience strong net inward migration for the first half of the latest census period followed by a switch to net outward migration over the second half. But the population will age The Irish population, while still growing, is also forecast to get older. This will mean that the amount of people at or close to retirement will increase significantly compared with the number of people in work. As a result, the State’s ability to provide for greater numbers of people retiring in 30 and 40 years time will be significantly reduced. Given this demographic outlook the responsibility to fund for retirement is on the individual through personal and company pensions. Otherwise, a large portion of the population in the years to come will suffer a significant decrease in their living standards.       The consequences of a growing population There are a variety of consequences of a growing population, both good and bad which are outlined as follows:
  • Growth in the population is a positive factor in the long-term as this will underpin domestic demand.
  • This growth adds to the capacity of the overall economy and in more normal economic conditions creates the potential for strong growth.
  • Given the current state of the economy and the high level of unemployment, a growing population can also put significant pressure on the financial resources of the State.
While we cannot ignore the extra pressure that population growth may put on the State to provide adequate funding for current and future generations, we can clearly see that it will add to the capacity of the economy and domestic demand. What’s paramount is that as the population ages it will be increasingly up to individuals to fund for their own retirement.
item.excerpt:encoded: Ireland’s population continued to grow strongly from 2006 to 2011, mainly due to a high number of births.

item.title: Cookies for a free lunch
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded:
As web users most of us are aware that most websites track your movements around their site. This is almost always done through cookies.  In light of the EU Cookie directive  - which to my knowledge nobody has implemented yet - I was asked to report on the use of cookies across our different websites and web facing applications. While I was doing this it got me thinking … just how extensive is third party ad tracking on the websites that most of us visit every day? So I visited a number of popular sites in Ireland – including the main news, tv, mobile phone and banking sites. I also visited google, facebook, yahoo, youtube, boards, imdb, and ebay. Using a tool called Collusion, which is an addon for the Firefox web browser I was able to build up a startling picture which shows the extent to which my web browsing was being tracked. Courtesy of Collusion (http://collusion.toolnes.org) and Privacychoice.org The red dots indicate websites which set tracking cookies - as confirmed by privacychoice.org. The grey dots are not advertisers but they could be collecting data about your movements. Most of these would be standard traffic measuring tracking - what are the popular pages, how long are people on the site and so forth. Based on my browsing the organisations doing the most tracking - denoted by the big red dots are: 1. doubleclick - owned by Google, was tracking me across all of these sites: independent.ie, irishtimes.com, rte.ie, zedo.com, alexa.com, facebook.com imdb.com, stumbleupon.com, breakingnews.ie, thesun.co.uk, cnet.com, tripadvisor.com, youtube.com, yieldmanager.com, bluelithium.com, linkedin.com, bbc.co.uk, donedeal.ie, ryanair.com, rubiconproject.com, specificclick.net, adnxs.com, atdmt.com Note that some of these domains are just serving ads - I'm not aware that I'm visiting those sites. 2. scorecardresearch.com (part of www.fullcirclestudies.com) tracked my behaviour across the following websites: independent.ie, irishtimes.com, rte.ie,  linkedin.com, alexa.com, doubleclick.net, zedo.com, facebook.com, imdb.com, stumbleupon.com, breakingnews.ie, thesun.co.uk, cnet.com, tripadvisor.com, youtube.com, yieldmanager.com, bluelithium.com, bbc.co.uk, donedeal.ie, ryanair.com, rubiconproject.com, specificclick.net, adnxs.com, atdmt.com boards.ie, b-static.net Again, I was not aware i was visiting some of these domains.

Why are they doing this?

The advertisers claim they do this so that they can target you with more relevant ads and more relevant content based on what you have been browsing. The websites make money each time you click an ad. Therefore, if the ad is more relevant to me and what I’m interested in, I’m more likely to click on it.

A free lunch … but with a cost?

Most of these sites provide their content free of charge. Independent.ie, irishtimes.com, rte, breakingnews.ie and most of the big UK newspapers and broadcasters are all free for anyone to use. You may think that this is great – we get all these free websites and loads of up to date content. But there's a saying which exposes the reality of whats happening:

“If you’re not paying for it, you’re not the customer; you’re the product being sold”

Everyone loves and wants free stuff but they rarely question what it means. For websites it means you're being sold by websites to advertisers. All your browsing habits - your favourite sites, content you view, ads you click, things you search for, what day of the week and time of day you visit various sites – is all being collected.

Can I stop this from happening?

Does the extent of web tracking surprise you? Want to do something about it? The EU already has - they've issued a directive. There’s some information about it on dataprotection.ie and ico.gov.uk. The upshot is that websites will have to tell you what they are tracking and get your permission on your arrival at the website. All modern browsers have settings that can allow or block different types of cookies and other tracking mechanisms. In order to do this you need to get in and  navigate around the security and privacy settings on your web browser. There's plenty of resources on the web to show you how to do this. If you use Firefox there's an add-on called Adblock Plus which blocks ads from being displayed and advertisers from tracking your movements. Google Chrome has an ‘Incognito’ mode which creates a private browing experience by blocking all cookies.

Is regulation on the Internet good or bad?

In closing, these directives and rules that are being introduced are a double-edged sword. On one hand, the lack of regulation on the internet has enabled it grow and expand and change at fast pace. On the otherhand, having more regulation does benefit the consumer in terms of transparency, honesty and treating them fairly.
