item.title: Well, here’s another nice mess you’ve gotten me into!*
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded: Ollie’s catch phrase seems quite an apt description of recent events ranging from the Republican and Democratic spat over the debt ceiling in the U.S., to the lack of leadership in Europe over the sovereign debt crisis in the Euroarea to President Obama’s reaction to the S&P downgrade of the U.S. government debt from the coveted AAA status to the less auspicious AA+. The culmination of all these events has seen significant declines in global stock markets and investors running for safe haven assets (and that includes U.S. Treasuries and the US dollar!). Go figure. The U.S. downgrade – what does it mean? In reality, the risk of the U.S. actually defaulting on its debt is minimal, as the downgrade has as much to do about politics as it does about the economic strength of the U.S. economy. The S&P stated that “the downgrade reflects our opinion that the fiscal consolidation plan that Congress and the Administration recently agreed to falls short of what, in our view, would be necessary to stabilize the government’s medium-term debt dynamics”. This is a long way off of the S&P actually stating that they think that there is a material chance that the U.S. could default and is more in the realm of theoretical naval gazing. As Neils Jensen of Absolute Return Partners states, “A U.S. downgrade is, in itself, almost meaningless. A nation that issues debt denominated solely in its own currency and which is in full control of its monetary policy, cannot default unwillingly. Nations default because they run out of foreign currency to service their debt, but the U.S. doesn’t need foreign currency to service its debt.” However, the downgrade will add further to the level of uncertainty and fear in global markets and will raise concerns about the credit rating of many other countries. In this volatile situation, risk assets such as equities and corporate bonds will exhibit marked volatility and on balance will probably end up lower over the months ahead. Somewhat perversely, the U.S. dollar and U.S. Treasuries will probably benefit as safe haven assets as will other safe haven currencies such as the Swiss franc. Global equity markets – hit hard Global equity markets have been hit hard with falls ranging from 3% to 5% on Monday, on top of sizeable declines over the preceding week. In year to date terms, European and Asian equity markets have seen pronounced falls, in the region of 10% to 20%, while the U.S. equity markets have seen more modest declines. The size of the declines in Europe has improved the valuation of the European equity markets with the price-to-earnings ratio for the MSCI Europe index now around 10x trailing earnings. This valuation is reasonably tempting as it is below its long-term average but is still higher than the lows reached in the depths of the 2008 crisis. There is value in the market but there is every chance that the markets will get cheaper before they recover. MSCI Europe Price to Earnings ratio The dollar is our currency but your problem The downgrade of the U.S. government debt could have a significant impact on Europe as the U.K. and France have fiscal problems on a par with the U.S. If these countries see their ratings downgraded it would worsen the sovereign debt crisis in the Euroarea. However, this might force the hands of the European politicians to tackle the problems of the Euroarea in a more meaningful fashion. Nevertheless, the reaction of markets would be quite negative until they see the policy response from the Euroarea governments and the ECB. It does appear that recent events will ensure to keep monetary policy very expansionary in the U.S. and the Euroarea. That is, short term interest rates should remain lower for longer and the ECB may well even consider reversing course and cut rates again if the Euroarea economy stalls over the months ahead. Low interest rates would be particularly helpful to Irish households on tracker and variable rate mortgages, but a slowing global economy would not be much help to our export sector. Summary The events of the last week might just force the hands of politicians on both sides of the Atlantic to take meaningful and concrete action to solve the sovereign debt crisis. However, markets will take a large degree of convincing and ongoing volatility over the months ahead seems likely. Equity market valuations are improving but will probably improve further over the short to medium term but given the large amounts of cash Irish investors have built up over the last number of years, the next three to six months could provide some significant buying opportunities. Important - Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. ILIM and ILA manage investment funds which may have holdings in stocks commented on in the document. These products may be affected by changes in currency exchange rates. Past performance may not be a reliable guide to future performance. Investments may fall as well as rise. ILIM and ILA are regulated by the Central Bank of Ireland. *This famous phrase is often misquoted as "Well, here's another fine mess you've gotten me into." The misquoted version of the phrase was never used by Hardy on film; the misunderstanding stems from the title of their film Another Fine Mess (1930).

item.title: Confidence at a premium
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded:
Global markets continue to convulse due to fears over the sovereign debt crisis in Europe and the prospect of a double dip recession. A quick survey of global headlines in recent days clearly highlights the level of fear and uncertainty that is prevalent. A few of the more eye catching include:
  • The chief executive officer of Deutsche Bank AG, Josef Ackermann, said market conditions remind him of late 2008
  • Christine Lagarde, the newly appointed IMF chief (and the recent French finance minister) stated that European banks need "urgent recapitalization" to stop the spread of the Eurozone’s sovereign and financial crisis
  • On going speculation that a number of European banks are under significant funding pressure
  • Greek government bonds continue to be shunned with 10-year yields close to 20% and 1 year yields at a whopping 88%
  • The German stock market (the Dax) is down 24.9% so far this year, and dropped by nearly 6% on Monday the 5th of September
  • Chancellor Merkel lost another by election in Germany
  • The Swiss are starting to hate the safe haven tag with the Swiss National Bank (SNB) announcing that they will do everything in their powers to prevent the Swiss franc from appreciating further. In fairly blunt terms, the SNB stated that it is "aiming for a substantial and sustained weakening of the Swiss franc. With immediate effect, it will no longer tolerate a EUR/CHF exchange rate below one Swiss franc twenty. The SNB will enforce this minimum rate with the utmost determination. It is prepared to purchase foreign exchange in unlimited quantities."
  • U.S. 10 year bond yields are at 60-year lows and hit 1.91% at one stage during the week while German government 10-year bond yields hit their lowest ever at 1.81%.
    • The idea of living in interesting times might be appealing to some but for investors and savers the current environment holds little attraction. Also, business and manufacturing confidence across the globe has been eroded in the last number of months as can be seen in the following charts. U.S. manufacturing confidence – peaked early in 2011 U.K. manufacturing confidence – has clearly peaked as well German manufacturing confidence – the export engine is also faltering All of these confidence indicators are finely balanced between contraction and expansion and while they still signal growth, (albeit very sluggish growth), the obvious risk is that many of the developed economies will slip back into recession. Europe is at the greatest risk of recession, which is no great surprise given the fiscal austerity measures being implemented across the periphery and the unfortunate decision by the ECB to tighten monetary policy earlier in the year. What is to be done? Martin Wolf, as ever, has a very insightful article in the FT and can be found here The article in essence argues that governments that can access cheap funding in the global bond markets should borrow to invest in the infrastructure and productive capacity of their underlying economies, while at the same time setting out coherent policies to reign in government spending in the long-term. Countries like Ireland don’t really have this choice as they are locked out of the international bond markets but certainly a recalibration of spending towards capital spending would make sense. Short-term outlook clouded over In the short-term, it does look like the global economy will continue to weaken and global equity markets are unlikely to stage any meaningful recovery in the next couple of months. However, many parts of the global equity markets look quite compelling, such as large cap blue chip value companies and many of the emerging equity markets. For the brave, there are opportunities, but these opportunities may well get cheaper and more plentiful before they recover. item.title: All aboard now.
item.dc:creator: Colin
item.content:encoded:
band•wag•on Noun/ˈ bandˌ wagn/ 1. A wagon used for carrying a band in a parade or procession. 2. A particular activity or cause that has suddenly become fashionable or popular.
With Rugby World Cup 2011 set to kick off in the early hours of Friday morning, the time has come again for all of Ireland’s faithful to jump on board and get behind the boys in green. Forget the disgruntled looks and mumbles from the die-hards, laugh off their tales of trips to the Sportsground in January for an inter-pro, where they put de-icer in the tea on the Clan Terrace; for the next two months (or at least until the 2nd of October) you’re a dyed-in-the-wool rugby supporter. Needless to say, in order to pull off that uniquely Irish trait of being an instant expert on the latest sporting adventure to involve anything Irish, you need to be armed with some facts and a firm, long held conviction on the topic de-jour. Alas, your task in this instance is complicated by the fact that Rugby World Cup is the only major sporting event where (barring a disaster) Ireland are guaranteed to qualify every time; In this instance the art of blagging requires a little more subtlety than that gleaned from the more traditional Google-Wikipedia-Youtube troika of expert makers. With this is mind, if you really want to impress you mates, and you’ve finished your dissertation on how Kidney should bring balance to the Irish back-row, or why Ma’a Nonu brings more the All Blacks than Sonny Bill, we’ve dug up the kind of trivia on Ireland’s group C opponents that Ryle Nugent would be proud of; Ireland V USA - Sunday September 11th, 7.00am Bryan Habana may have once raced a Cheetah, but when faced with a one-on-one against American winger Takudzwa Ngwenya, the world cup winning springbok found himself tackling fresh air in the 2007 tournament. Heineken Cup fans might also remember the Biarritz man blitzing Wales and Ospreys flyer Shane Williams to score a 70 metre try in the 2010 Quarter Final. One to watch. Ireland V Australia - Saturday September 17th, 9.30am Quade Cooper is set to be one of stars of this World Cup. But the mercurial fly-half may be hoping his triple Olympic champion girlfriend, Stephanie Rice, keeps off Twitter during the tournament. The swimmer got into some *cough* "hot water" for posting a homophobic slur on the service in the aftermath of Australia’s victory over South Africa in last years Tri-nations, a game in which her man came in for some rough treatment. Are you listening Sean O'Brien? Ireland V Russia - Sunday September 25th, 6.00am Russia will be making their world cup debut in New Zealand, thanks in no small part to the talents of winger Vasily Artemyev. Sure to be the only man in their squad with a south Dublin accent, the Northampton Saints recruit was educated at Blackrock College, where he played alongside Luke Fitzgerald, even representing Ireland at U19 level while in the Leinster academy. He returned to his native Russia in 2008 and made his debut for the national side in February '09. Ireland V Italy - Sunday October 2nd, 8.30am Sure to be among Irelands chief tormentors in Dunedin on the final day of the group stages is Martin Castrogiovanni. The veteran tight-head is a team mate of Geordan Murphy at Leicester Tigers, and you may be surprised to hear that the pair are partners in a restaurant in the town. Among the specialities on the menu at "Timo" are; "Ben Youngs' Spaghetti Lobster", "Pollo alla Toby Flood", and Geordan's own "Cotoletta di Pollo Milanese" - an old Newbridge mothers recipe no doubt...

item.title: 10 reasons why pensions still make sense
item.dc:creator: Susan
item.content:encoded:
1. What will the state pension be in the future? The State Pension (Contributory) personal rate for a single person is currently €230.30 per week, or €436.60 per week with an adult dependant allowance.
  • Demographic changes in Ireland, as in countries across the EU, will put pressure on government finances as the cost of state pensions and health care for the elderly increase. Currently in Ireland there are 6 adults of working age for every one adult over 65, but this ratio is predicted to change to 2 to 1 by 2050. (Source: National Pensions Framework 2010).
  • Steps taken in the past to plan for this demographic change can no longer be relied upon. The National Pensions Reserve Fund was established to help meet costs of social welfare and public service pensions from 2025, but is now being used to make investments in credit institutions and Irish Government securities as directed by the Minister for Finance.  Simply put, you cannot be sure the State will provide you in your old age with the same level of pension income, medical card support or other benefits as are provided currently.
 2. State Pension age increasing Legislation is now in place that will increase the age at which the state pension becomes payable in the future.These changes are happening soon and people need to look now at the impact they will have on their plans for retirement.Somebody turning 50 this year will not receive the state pension until they are 68. 3. Life Expectancy Life expectancy for those born in Ireland is now 76 years for males and 81 for females (Source: CSO 2009). While increasing life expectancy is a good thing, it is also something your clients need to consider when planning for retirement. If your client’s retirement fund is to last longer your clients will either need to set aside more, or take a lower income each year in retirement.  Your clients retirement savings may need to last for up to 30 years after your clients finish working. 4. Income Tax Relief Income tax relief is still available on contributions made personally to a pension. This may change, but right now relief is available on up to 41% of the contribution for a top rate tax payer, or 20% for a standard rate tax payer. For a higher rate tax payer, this is equivalent to the government topping up your net pension contribution by up to 69%! In addition to income tax relief on any personal contributions, employer contributions to a Company Pension are also tax deductible and no benefit in kind is appropriated to the employee. No BIK means, no income tax, no PRSA & no USC - potentially around 52%. Pension income in retirement is subject to income tax at your clients highest rate on withdrawal, Universal Social Charge, PRSI (if applicable) and any other charges or levies ("tax") applicable at that time. Tax Free Retirement Lump Sum Tax free retirement lump sums are still available when taking retirement benefits. Within the pre-existing limits of 25% of the fund or 1.5 times final salary, a lump sum can be taken up to €575,000 before it is subject to marginal rate income tax treatment, as other income would be. The first €200,000 can be taken tax free, with the remaining €375,000 taxed at 20%. Someone who can take the full lump sum allowance of €575,000 would pay tax of €75,000 and receive €500,000 in their hand. In comparison with someone who retired before 1 January 2011, this has the effect of reducing the lump sum he receives by 13.1%. 6. Lifecover The same income tax relief that applies on pension contributions is also available for Pension Term Assurance, which means cheaper life cover. For example, a 40 year old self employed male non-smoker taking out €200,000 of life cover to age 65 with indexation and conversion option could choose between a life term cover plan and personal pension life cover. The tax treatment of a lump sum paid out on death is the same for life term cover and pension life cover. In each case the lump sum is subject to inheritance tax, and there is no tax if the lump sum is going to a spouse or registered civil partner. 7. ARF options for all The ARF option has been extended to all members of Defined Contribution company pensions. This means that the ARF option is now available on
  • Members and directors in DC Company Pensions
  • AVCs for those in DB Company Pensions
  • 5% directors in DB Company Pensions
  • Personal Pensions
  • PRSAs
Individuals need to consider their options carefully on retirement, and will need advice more than ever in this area. However, the ARF option gives what many individuals want in terms of
  • control over income drawdown
  • control over investment options
8. Inheritance Planning Pre-retirement The tax treatment of pension funds on death can result in a tax efficient way of inheritance planning.  A summary of the tax treatment of lump sums paid on death is set out in the table below For children the inheritance tax threshold is €332,084 per child, including any other gifts and inheritance received from parents since 1991. If a spouses, dependants or children's pension is provided this will be taxed as income. Company Pensions are subject to a limit on the lump sum death benefit if the member dies while still in the relevant employment.  The lump sum limit is 4 times salary (including any retained benefits), plus a return of their own personal contributions. This limit on lump sums paid on death does not apply to Company Pensions or PRBs if the member has left the relevant employment, assuming you completed at least two years pensionable service for those leaving employment after 1 June 2002.  Also there is no such limit for PRSAs and Personal Pensions. Post-retirement ARFs, AMRFs and vested-PRSAs are all treated the same on death.  A summary of the tax treatment is set out in the table below. Amounts passing to a child over 21 are subject to income tax at the 20% standard rate.  This is lower than the current 25% rate for inheritance tax, although the inheritance tax threshold is not available. 9. Gross Roll-up Exit Tax on savings and investment plans is 30%.  DIRT is 27%.  Capital Gains Tax is 25%, with an annual exemption of €1,270. (rates as at 2011) Pension funds are exempt from Irish income and capital gains taxes (however pension income in retirement is subject to income tax at your clients highest rate on withdrawal, Universal Social Charge, PRSI (if applicable) and any other charges or levies ("tax") applicable at that time).  The impact of the Government Pension Levy will depend on each individual's circumstances.  This will apply at 0.6% of the fund for four years. 10.  Investment Pension allow for a wide range of investment options to suit the risk appetite of every client.  This includes investments in equities, bonds, property, commodities, but also deposits, trackers and other secure options.  Different currencies such as Euro, Sterling or Dollar are also available. Please refer to product booklets for further information.  Pensions are long term savings plans that can only be taken at retirement.  Tax relief is not guaranteed.  Rates are current as at August 2011.  To claim tax relief, your client can apply to their Inspector of Taxes to adjust their tax credits.  Contributions deducted from salary will receive immediate tax relief. Want to know more? Why not try our Pension Calculator today

item.title: The Italian government bond market – too big to fail, too big to save!
item.dc:creator: Pat
item.content:encoded: The Eurozone sovereign debt crisis has spread from the smaller and more manageable countries, Ireland, Portugal and Greece to the larger countries of Spain and Italy. As can be seen in the chart below the Italian and Spanish government bond yields spiked in July just after the EU leaders announced the second rescue package for Greece. Markets are now focusing the high level of government debt in the Italian economy and whether it is sustainable. However, we would argue that there has been no fundamental change in the Italian situation to justify the yield increase. What caused the yield to increase? The following catalysts led to a decreased tolerance for holding peripheral government bonds: The second Greek bailout package totalled approximately €165bln, of which €110bln is coming from the EU/IMF and the remaining €55bln is from the debt exchange programme with private sector debt holders. This private sector involvement added to the heightened volatility in the European bond markets. The rating agencies were also active around this time as Portugal and Ireland were downgraded to junk status which resulted in Portugal been removed from the investment grade government bond indices. Ireland however has continued to have an average credit rating above investment grade and therefore remains in the main indices. The economic data for Spain and Italy deteriorated. Business confidence as measured by the PMI slipped below 50 in July indicating that these economies are moving in to a recession.Finally the Italian government proposed a new austerity programme for Italy with the aim of bringing the deficit to GDP back to zero by 2014. However, this plan lacked credibility as many of the measures were back loaded and were to be implemented after the next election in 2013. The fundamentals have not changed: Italy has two fundamental problems of low growth and a high stock of government debt. Since the 1990s Italy’s debt to GDP has been over 100% and the average growth rate in the Italian economy as been a modest 1%. However, as the chart below shows Italy has been able to reduce its deficit and debt levels even in very low growth environments in the past. In 2011 the European Commission is predicting that Italy will run a primary balance, i.e. its tax revenues will be greater than its expenditure when you exclude interest payments. As a result the austerity measures that have to be taken in Italy are much more manageable than have to be made in some of the other peripheral countries to start to reduce the level of outstanding debt. The interest expense as a percentage of GDP and as a percentage of total tax revenues has been much higher historically. Nevertheless as the Italian government bond yields rise, the interest expense as a percentage of GDP could move to an unsustainable level. Elsewhere Italy did not experience the construction related booms that were evident for other economies such as Spain or Ireland. As a result Italy has a relatively low level of private sector debt compared to other countries in Europe. Italy is too big to fail! Italy is one of the largest bond markets in Europe and it represents approximately 24% of European government bond indices. A default in Italy would be a major systematic event and would lead to large losses for the banking and pension industries in Europe. Therefore the least costly response to this crisis would be to support economies that are in need of liquidity and ring fence Italy. Otherwise, a default in Italy would also have contagion effects to the safer AAA countries in Europe. But markets are reflecting the increased risks for Italy: The current concerns for Italy are liquidity ones. To date Italy has completed approximately only 65% of its gross funding requirement for 2011 and therefore will be going to the market every month for the rest of the year. However, the net issuance (issuance minus redemptions) for Italy has been front loaded and the remaining funding requirement is really to repay debt that is maturing and coupon payments. In September Italy has raised €3.9bln in a five year auction, however it had to pay up for this money as the yield was approximately 0.5% higher than money that had been raised previously. ECB intervention has helped underpin the Italian market The ECB has been somewhat successful in curbing the spiralling Italian government bond yields by purchasing bonds in the secondary markets. Since the start of August it has purchased approximately €60bln worth of government bonds in distressed markets. However the concerns are that it will be more challenging for the ECB to remain effective particularly given the size of the Italian bond market. Also the ECB is sterilizing the effects of this bond purchasing by taking in deposits from the banking system and therefore is limited in the amount of bonds that it much purchase. Thirdly, it will be difficult for the ECB to keep up with the issuance emanating from Italy for the remainder of the year. Liquidity, not solvency, at the heart of the Italian problem As a result, the recent volatility in Italian bond markets has increased the liquidity risks for the Italian government. However, unlike Greece we do not think that there is any significant solvency risk for Italy at this stage. Nevertheless, these liquidity risks will be an ongoing source of volatility for European bond markets in the near term and would be exacerbated by political infighting in Italy and concerns about a possible ratings downgrade to Italy. However, the fundamentals are unchanged in our view over the past few months and investors would be giving up a significant yield spread by readjusting their portfolios into AAA assets right now, particularly given the risk aversion which is built into the AAA yields. Important - Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. Any comments on specific stocks are intended as an objective, independent view in relation to that stock generally, and not in relation to its suitability to any specific person. ILIM and ILA manage investment funds which may have holdings in stocks commented on in the document. These products may be affected by changes in currency exchange rates. Past performance may not be a reliable guide to future performance. Investments may fall as well as rise. ILIM and ILA are regulated by the Central Bank of Ireland.

item.title: Pension Tension
item.dc:creator: Gerry Hassett
item.content:encoded:
There’s only three certainties in life - death, taxes, and the Pensions time bomb! We all know about death and taxes so let’s focus on the pensions time-bomb. There are some things about this we know to be absolutely certain;
  1. Ireland may be a young country today, but its getting older. There’s 6 of us working for every 1 in retirement today, but by 2050 that ratio will shrink to 2 to 1
  2. We’re also living longer. If you’re lucky enough to be alive at age 65, my actuarial colleagues tell me you’re likely to live for a further 16 to 20 years
  3. The state pension is a valuable benefit, but for most people it’s not enough to live on. Someone earning €60,000 a year can expect a drop in income in retirement of up to 80% if they rely solely on the state pension. And with the pressure on public finances, it’s inevitable that the State pension will erode in real terms, as indeed the age at which it is received has already been extended.
Clearly, these three factors combine to create a major funding challenge for Ireland Inc. into the future. However, proper long-term planning in our public policy can make this challenge manageable. That’s if we start planning today, and encouraging people to plan for themselves to reduce the burden on the state has to be part of the solution. Planning for the time-bomb Quite properly, the Government today is obsessed with the €15bn fiscal adjustment that’s required between now and 2014. However, there’s a real risk that in solving today’s problem we create an even bigger one for the future. Many of us believe that the seeds of Ireland’s demise were actually sown long before the crash in the prime years of the Celtic Tiger, around 2000 and 2001, when we began to spend money we simply didn’t have. I genuinely believe we are making the same mistakes today in the area of pensions. Every single policy measure of recent years has been negative, and it’s created a crisis of confidence in pensions. Recent Irish Life customer research indicates that almost one quarter of our customers are considering either reducing or suspending payments in the next 12 months, which also bears out our experience of the past 12 motnhs. What an appalling vista it would be, if the youth of Ireland who inherited negative equity from the generation before them, were themselves condemned to poverty in retirement. In the excesses of the Celtic Tiger we had people borrowing money they couldn’t afford to invest in dreams that could never be realised. Pension customers are different and should be supported. Even in the teeth of recession they are prepared to put something aside today so they can enjoy their retirement and not become a burden on the state. Supporting middle Ireland For the workers of middle Ireland – 85% of our customers earn less than €70,000 – retirement planning is a noble cause. I believe it is in society’s interest to support these people today in their honest endeavour and their hopes and dreams for the future. Unfortunately, these middle income workers don’t feel valued today. In a recent Irish Life survey, 70% of middle income workers said they did not believe that the Government was actively trying to encourage people to save for their retirement. The current Programme for Government sets an objective of rebuilding a broken society. In its introduction it quotes Albert Einstein
‘Learn from yesterday, live for today, and hope for tomorrow’
That’s why I’m calling on Government today to give clarity to the workers of middle Ireland that it will continue to support them in planning for their retirement and allow them to hope for their futures. Paying our share Of course, the reality is that every section of society has to make a contribution in a time of national crisis. I fully accept that. The plain fact is that the pensions community is being asked to fund about €1bn of the total €15bn fiscal adjustment. That’s a significant adjustment in anyone’s language. We’ve signed up for this and we’re working with Government to see how we can deliver. However, in addition to this €1bn annual saving, we then had the recent Pensions Levy from which a further €1.8bn contribution is expected over next four years. The Pensions levy has had such a devastating impact, not just because of the €1.8bn reduction of all our pension funds, but because it has undermined any remaining confidence in retirement planning. Pensions generally – public and private – are long term contracts of trust and it’s incredibly difficult to repair such a breach of trust. It’s the latest in a long line of negative signals that being sensible today is not valued by the state. Now, I’ve heard many commentators suggest that the Levy was actually originally suggested by the industry, and I’m glad to set the record straight here. The idea of a levy has been around for over 20 years. For example, the Pensions Board is currently funded via a similar levy. It is true that some in the industry, suggested a lower % levy as an alternative to a change in tax relief. However, the Government has introduced the Levy – not as an alternative as was suggested but as an additional measure with no commitment to retain tax relief at the marginal rate. Effectively, it’s a ‘double whammy’ and completely at odds with what was originally intended. But that’s history and we need to deal with today. The simple fact is this. The chronic lack of confidence in future incentives for retirement planning is contributing to a record level of workers stopping paying into their pensions. In turn, this is generating surplus flows to the exchequer over and above those projected in the €15bn National Recovery Plan. A recent analysis carried out by Milliman Actuarial Consultants has indicated that even if the Government did nothing else in the area of Pensions, it would achieve over 90% of the savings required in 2011 and 2012 in relation to the €940m goal. And that’s before we even consider the levy. It’s a very significant conclusion so I’ll repeat it – even if the Government introduces no new pension initiatives in the budget it will achieve over 90% of the savings required for 2011 and 2012. Now, whilst this is good news for the exchequer in the short-term, it’s bad news for us all in the longer term. The Government is relying on workers stopping their pensions and thus increasing tax revenues. That’s going to store up even bigger problems for the Exchequer in the future. Reducing pension tax relief is a bad idea The recent National Pension Framework recommends reducing pension tax relief to a hybrid rate of 33%. I believe that would be a retrograde step. I think it would be very difficult for most financial planners to recommend to their customers to lock money away for 20 or 30 years at say 33% relief, when they could be taxed at 41% (or more) in retirement. There are simply more attractive short-term savings options available and professional advisers would be bound to recommend them. This would not be in the long-term interests of the State and would inevitably impose an increasing burden on the first pillar which is the state pension. Yes, tax relief at the marginal rate is an attractive incentive, but you need an attractive incentive if you are expected to put your money way for 20 or 30 years. We need to be honest here, when discussing tax relief too many commentators think about Michael Fingleton’s €27m pension pot, rather than the 85% of pension customers who earn €70,000 p.a. or less. These days the marginal tax rate kicks in at €32,800 so reducing tax relief will undoubtedly hit the middle income worker. So, I would urge the Government to give a commitment to retaining relief at the marginal rate for middle-income workers. I also agree that we need to do more for lower paid workers and women who have less opportunity to build a pension pot given the more stop / start nature of their working career. We need to be innovative here, and I think some of the ideas contained in the National Pensions Framework can provide the solution. Equity in pensions We need to ensure that the scarce reliefs are widely available, and not the domain of the few. The State cannot continue to support wealth management type incentives in the current climate and the various measures of recent budgets have quite rightly closed off these loop-holes. However, it’s vital that middle-income workers continue to be given every incentive to plan for their retirement. We need equity between defined contribution members and defined benefit members. Now, I meet pension trustees every week and I am very sympathetic to the concerns of defined benefit schemes. The recent decision by the trustees of the Tara Mines scheme to cut benefits in retirement by 10% is a devastating blow to the workers involved and is perhaps only a pre-cursor of things to come, particularly once Trustees come to grips with the down-stream impact of the recent Levy. However, the simple fact is that most defined contribution schemes are equally under-funded. The under-performance of various markets over the past decade and continued low interest rates have left most defined contribution holders significantly under-funded. Most of the public debate centres on defined benefit, but I believe that the needs of defined contribution workers also needs to be addressed. The other area of equity is between the private sector and the public sector. Now as we know, public sector pensions are funded on a ‘pay as you go’ basis. This represents its very own ‘pensions time-bomb’. A recent review by the Department of Finance indicated that pensions in payment to public servants has grown by around 70% since 2006 from €1.4bn to €2.4bn. Pensions in payment now represent 16% of the entire public sector wage bill, and there are now 2.5 active public servants for every one in retirement. Within a couple of decades, there’s likely to be more public servants in retirement than working, and serious reform is required here if another fiscal black-hole is to be avoided. The average retirement income to public servants is €22,500 (not including the social welfare pension). This equates to a fund of approximately €700,000 which is about five times more than the average fund of €150,000 for the private sector worker in a defined contribution scheme. Now, the Programme for Government proposes a maximum limit of €60,000 p.a. on any public sector pension. And if we are going to have equity between the public and private sectors, then I’m assuming the Government is also proposing a €60,000 limit for the private sector. However, where pension practitioners do have a problem here is around the basis in which this income is converted into a notional lump sum for defined contribution workers. The current factor of 20 times is nowhere near the market rate. Most of us in this room would love to provide an income in retirement using such a factor, but it’s simply not possible. A recent independent study conducted for PIBA concluded that for a public servant retiring at age 60, the relevant factor is between 30 to 40 times. That indicates that the current maximum fund threshold of €2.3m may be not far off the mark as to what’s required. We’re passionate about pensions in Irish Life. For generations, we’ve helped over 1 million middle-income workers plan for a peaceful retirement. It greatly saddens me that confidence in the future of retirement planning is so low right now. I think it’s in the interests of every one in society that we build collective hope in our shared future. That’s why its vital the Government commits to support middle Ireland to plan for their retirement. You see, the fundamentals of retirement planning have changed. It’s no longer about what age we can retire at, it’s more than ever about what income we can afford to retire at.
Irish Life Chief Executive Gerry Hassett discusses the pension crisis on Morning Ireland

item.title: €200 Million in FREE Life Insurance? Yes Really.
item.dc:creator: Gerry Hassett
item.content:encoded:
Yes, really,  we are giving away €200,000,000 in FREE life insurance to Irish Parents for one year. This is our BIGGEST EVER OFFER, it’s a major move to highlight the importance for parents to protect their family’s income should they die. Why do we need to highlight this? Well it continues to be a major problem for Irish families when you consider the facts:
  • There are 500,000 Irish families with Children under 13.
  • 60% of parents say that they could not cope financially if one parent died.*
  • Yet only one in every three families have life cover other than basic mortgage protection.
  • This leaves around 350,000 Irish Families with insufficient cover.
That’s why we are offering €10,000 worth of life insurance to up to 20,000 parents of young families on a first come-first served basis.  The promotion is available through brokers and financial advisers around the country and of course right here on our website. It’s open to adults under 55 years of age who have a child of 13 or younger and the application process is simple. We are passionate about making sure every parent is aware of the importance of life insurance.  In the last 5 years alone Irish Life has paid out OVER HALF A BILLION EURO in death claims.  Many of those claims were paid to customers with young families.  We want Irish families to really think hard about their life insurance and if we can do this, the €200 Million promotion will be well worth it. Listen to Matt Cooper talk to Charlie Weston (personal finance editor of the Irish Independent) on todayfm
Sign up for the free life insurance now. You'll hear plenty about the €200 Million giveaway over the next 3 weeks as we’ll be on the airwaves and online working hard to drive attention to life insurance.   [caption id="attachment_1073" align="alignleft" width="600" caption="Declan ONeill - Senior Marketing Manager and Gerry Hassett - CEO, launch Irish Life's Free Life Insurance Promotion"][/caption] * Research carried out among 1,000 (850 online and 150 face to face) interviews by Amarach on behalf of Irish Life in March 2011.

item.title: A solution to the crisis will be easier than a breakup
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded: The Eurozone sovereign debt crisis has now created a sharp decline in confidence in Euroarea assets and robust action is needed to restore confidence. Concerns are currently centred on the larger economies including Italy and Spain. These economies are seen as too big to save and as a result the outcome of the crisis has become almost binary. Either EU leaders commit every possible resource available to the crisis or the "Euro project" breaks up. We continue to believe that EU leaders will eventually adopt the necessary policies to save the region, a break up of which would certainly come at a much higher cost to all countries and also to the global economy. The Crux of the problem – too much debt The problems in the Eurozone are complex and hence the region has been in crisis mode now for eighteen months. The fundamental problem facing the global economy is the high level of debt both public and private in the advanced economies. However the crisis is exploding in the Eurozone and is highlighting the difficulties in having a monetary union without a fiscal union. Although on aggregate the economic indicators in the Eurozone as a whole look reasonable, we are now well aware that many separate economies have been mismanaged. For example in 2010 the Eurozone as a whole had a deficit to GDP of 6% but this masked the -31% (when you include the banking costs) that Ireland had. Furthermore, Debt to GDP for the region is far lower than for Japan or even the US but obviously Greece now has a debt to GDP of 170%. Within the economies there are also large imbalances as the Eurozone over all has a balanced current account, masking a substantial deficit in Greece, Portugal and Spain and a surplus in Germany. Prior to 2008, bond markets did not price the risk of these imbalances into debt markets as the spread of Greek government bonds over German government bonds would have been as low as 0.34%, while other countries spreads would have been even lower. As a result, bond markets allowed the Greek government to mismanage its public sector, financing the build up of excess debt levels. The problems in other countries are different. For example Spain and Ireland have banking and housing crises, while Portugal and Italy have major obstacles to economic growth. More and more uncertainty… The Eurozone sovereign crisis has being intensifying since July when the EU government leaders agreed to apply a haircut to private sector investors who held Greek government bonds. In doing so EU leaders attached a credit risk to government bonds that did not previously exist. This credit risk has now been priced into markets as the yields of Italian, Spanish and French debt have risen. Furthermore the latest EU plan that was agreed at the end of October has also increased pressures in the Eurozone debt markets. In particular, European banks are now required to price government bonds at market prices rather than par for the purpose of assessing their capital ratios. This measure has also resulted in large scale selling of bonds that are perceived as risky by markets. As a result banks and insurance companies are no longer willing to take on the credit risk that has been associated with government bonds in the Eurozone. This has left the limited bond purchasing programme of the ECB as the only buyer in town of Eurozone peripheral debt. Currently the Eurozone bond purchasing programme differs from that of the "quantitative easing" policies in the UK, the US and Japan because the ECB is required to “sterilize” any money spent on bond purchases. This means the ECB is required to raise money to purchase the bonds by either taking in deposits from the banking system or selling other assets from its books. This limits the amount of government debt that the ECB can purchase. In contrast, market participants know that the central banks in the UK or the US have an unlimited wallet and are lenders of last resort for UK and US debt. In addition there is a complete lack of political agreement to deal with the crisis and to date any policy response has been insufficient. Despite numerous efforts, EU leaders have been unable to differentiate the smaller peripherals or even just Greece from the other countries in the region. However leaders in France and Germany have continued to discuss an orderly exit of Greece from the Euro, which has put the sustainability of the currency into disrepute and intensified the contagion risks. The fallout so far The economic picture in Europe has deteriorated dramatically since the first half of 2011 when the core countries in Europe were experiencing solid growth. Since August, economic indicators have declined, particularly business confidence for the manufacturing and services sectors which now point to a contraction in these sectors as evidenced by the chart below. As a result many commentators are predicting that the Eurozone economy will move into recession in early 2012.The main question now lies with how deep and how long the recession will be. Most governments in the Eurozone are implementing austerity programs which alone will lead to a much lower growth outlook. However the banking sector is also paying down its debts and as a result bank lending into the economy will be very weak. Although structural reforms are certainly needed to address the excesses that have built up in the peripheral countries during the boom times, the pace of overall de-leveraging needs to be addressed in order to stimulate economic growth. Stresses are also evident in the financial sector and liquidity is becoming tighter. Banks in the Eurozone are finding it increasingly expensive to borrow money in the wholesale market as is evident from the chart below. This chart shows the difference between what the banks and the government have to pay for three month money underlining that stresses in the Eurozone banking sector have increased, although not to the levels that were seen in 2008 at the time of Lehman’s collapse. The ECB is currently supporting the banking system by providing unlimited liquidity through its three and thirteen month tenders in December. Furthermore five global central banks are also providing dollar funding to the Eurozone banks. However this has still not been enough to sufficiently rebuild confidence so that banks will lend to each other. Volatility for financial markets has increased sharply since August and despite the market rally in October, equity market volatility remains high. Volatility has also increased for bond markets, most notably last week when the German ten year government bond yield increased from 1.8% to 2.3% following the failed bond auction earlier in the week. These large swings in both equity and bond markets continue to force investors into safer haven assets. How bad can it get? The most obvious risk for markets at the moment is that Italy or Spain will be unable to fund themselves next year at current refinancing levels. Italy has a primary surplus i.e. it takes in more tax revenues than it pays out on expenses when you exclude the payment of interest on its debt. However next year Italy has government debt worth €300bln to repay and has also to pay coupons of approximately €50bln on existing debt. If Italy has to refinance this money at a yield of 7% its debt becomes less sustainable and its debt to GDP ratio could rise to 130% very quickly. Spain, on the other hand, has to raise €250bln to meet its financing needs. Given that banks and insurance companies are shying away from holding Italian and Spanish debt it is difficult to see who will take up this issuance unless the ECB changes its stance. What would solve the crisis? Austerity & Reform is essential in the peripheral countries The external deficits that have built up over the past ten years in the Eurozone can only be addressed through austerity and an internal devaluation because of monetary union. This adjustment will lead to a recession in these regions and also deflation. In order to avoid a recession in the entire region, the countries that have benefited from the improvement in competitiveness need to be the drivers of growth for the region as a whole. As can be seen from the chart below, Germany was successful in improving its competitiveness from 2002 to 2011. As a result the core economies that have not allowed excesses build up in their economies now need to adopt pro growth policies to help offset the weaknesses in the peripheral economies. These adjustments to the peripheral regions will take some time to implement and therefore will not stabilise markets in the near term. However, the rebalancing of the economies in the Eurozone is essential to the longer term stability of the region. The EFSF fund needs to be reformed In the shorter term the financing of government debt needs to be resolved. To date the IMF and the EU have established the EFSF fund, which currently has the capacity to raise as much as €440bln for countries in difficulty. Greece, Ireland and Portugal have already committed to this programme and are expected to use approximately €250bln of the funds available. However a programme cannot be offered to Spain and Italy in the same way because the EFSF does not have the capacity to meet a €600bln financing need for 2012. In the October EU meeting it was proposed that the EFSF fund would be increased to €1tln through a guarantee from the other countries in the region, notably the AAA countries aswell as by raising money from abroad. Since November, it is evident that increasing this fund is unlikely because there has been lacklustre demand for the EFSF particularly as the fund’s €3bln auction at the start of November did not go as well as had been expected. Also the spread of the EFSF bonds over Germany have widened to 1.6% versus 0.55% back in June 2011. It is therefore unlikely that there will be enough interest in the fund as it currently stands. The structure of the EFSF fund may be addressed when the EU council meets on the 9th of December. ECB quantitative easing will help Many commentators have agreed that a quantitative easing programme by the ECB, where it prints money and purchases government bonds in the secondary market is now essential as part of any resolution to the crisis. The ECB could do this by announcing that it will purchase a substantial sum of government bonds as has been the case with the Bank of England and Federal Reserve. Alternatively, the ECB could announce that it will keep the Spanish and Italian government bond yields at a targeted level, which would allow these countries to raise the necessary finance next year at an affordable rate. Either solution would be a positive for markets. To date Germany in particular has been very much against this idea as printing money creates inflation and currently the only mandate of the ECB is to control inflation. However it could be argued that if countries are adopting the necessary reform policies to remove imbalances in the region that some inflation is needed to offset the deflationary austerity policies. EU policy makers can be more confident in recent weeks that these policies will be adhered to after the technocrat governments have been implemented in Greece and Italy. Although deadlock remains on the possibility of ECB purchasing bonds for now it is acknowledged that private sector outflows must be replaced in order to keep governments running next year. Some solutions being explored is that the ECB lends money to the IMF with the IMF subsequently distributing the money to the Eurozone countries requiring assistance on condition that the recipient countries undertake prescribed austerity measures. A Eurobond may be a solution in the longer term The idea of a central financing mechanism for the Eurozone is also being explored but similarly to the structural reforms it will be a longer term solution to the crisis and would greatly address the crux of the problem by supporting the monetary union with a fiscal union. This solution would make it easier for the ECB to be lender of last resort for the system as it would not have the dilemma of which countries’ bonds should be purchased vis a vis others. However a Eurobond would require much greater fiscal unity than currently exists and major social, economic and policy hurdles would have to be overcome to achieve this. A break up of the Eurozone Although there is a lot of talk in the media about the possibility of a break up of the Euro, we continue to see this as an unlikely occurrence. No political leader wants the Euro to break up as the economic, social and political costs are too great. Firstly there is no legal framework for a country to leave the Eurozone as a country can not be expelled and therefore would have to elect to leave. The main advantage seen to leaving the monetary union would be that the new currency would devalue and competitiveness would increase. However this would be offset by a greater cost to a country. Firstly countries that currently have deficits and are receiving funding from the EU/IMF would have to have an immediate adjustment as it is highly unlikely that they would be able to fund those deficits on international markets. Other consequences would include a default of government and corporate debt, a collapsed banking system and capital controls that would hamper international trade. The economic fallout would consequently be great. Another EU summit… Next week is another crucial week for the Eurozone sovereign debt crisis as on Thursday (8th December) the ECB has its meeting, where it may increase support to the banking system and will most likely cut interest rates. It is unlikely that it will announce a quantitative easing program as this would more likely be agreed with the EU leaders at the summit on Friday (December 9th). As long as politicians can be continually assured that the peripheral governments are implementing the necessary austerity programmes a more complete solution will likely be agreed at this summit. It is yet unclear how this may look but the more recent suggestion of the ECB financing the IMF may be a step forward from the recent deadlock. It is now essential that the ECB is part of whatever solution is agreed and its role needs to increase regarding a resolution of the crisis. It is clear therefore that there is much more that policy makers can do before they throw in the towel and opt for an expensive break up. item.title: Irish Life’s €1 million cash-back promotion!
item.dc:creator: Colin
item.content:encoded:
Start a new Life Cover plan and get your first two months payments back, or a minimum of €50. Between now and 02 March 2012 inclusive, We are offering you the opportunity to get cash back on your first 2 months premiums when you take out a new life cover policy with us. We all need to protect what’s important to us. With a Life Cover plan you can relax knowing your family could be looked after in the future. So, Irish Life would like to give you a helping hand to get you started. Apply to Irish Life for any new Life Cover plan before 02 March 2012. Then start the plan on or before 27 April 2012, pay into your plan for two months and you will get your first two months payments back. This offer is available from 16 January 2012.

How the cash back offer works We will pay you two month’s payments back with a minimum cash back payment of €50 and a maximum of €1,000.

So if for example your monthly payments are €550, after your second monthly payment is made, we’ll give you €1,000 cash back. And, even if your monthly payments are €15, after your second payment is made, we’ll still give you back €50! Once you make your second plan payment, we’ll issue your cash back within 60 working days of this payment. To avail of this offer This offer is open to all new Life Insurance applications received between 16 January 2012 and 02 March 2012 inclusive. It’s limited to one plan per person and one cash back payment on each plan. When you have paid your first two months payments into your plan on time, you will get your two months cash back. This offer is only available if:
  • Your application is received between 16 January and 02 March 2012 inclusive.
  • Your plan is accepted and starts by 27 April 2012.
  • You have not cancelled an existing Life Insurance plan with Irish Life in order to apply for this offer.
Remember, you must keep up your payments to stay on cover. Acceptance and terms and conditions apply. For full terms and conditions visit www.irishlife.ie/cashback.

item.title: Another Emergency Summit
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded:
Europe moves closer to integration, albeit slowly The EU summit meeting on Friday (9th of December) took the first big step in moving towards a fiscal integration which is a major step in addressing one of the major flaws of the Euro and also removes the moral hazard of supporting a government without having control of any its policies. Nevertheless the resolution has fallen short in many other ways, particularly how Italy and Spain are to raise finance to repay debts in the case of Italy and to fund exchequer spending in the case of Spain in 2012. Hence we would expect that volatility will continue in Eurozone debt and equity markets well into 2012 and a challenging economic environment to persist. What was agreed on Friday (December 9th) Reform agenda continued to push through EU countries have agreed to set in their constitutions a maximum deficit target which they will adhere to. This rule is to be incorporated into the legal systems at constitutional level. The European Court of Justice will also be involved in transferring the rule at national level. The EU Commission may also be granted more rights to control national budget bills and may have the right to veto the budget bill if it does not comply with the Stability & Growth Pact. Hence some countries may have to hold a referendum to ratify this treaty change. Strengthening the stabilisation mechanism Prior to last Friday’s meeting the current bailout mechanism for countries that were finding it difficult to raise funds on the markets was the EFSF fund. This consisted of €440bln, of which Greece, Ireland and Portugal were already drawing funds from. At the October Summit meeting plans were announced to increase this fund to €1tln however investor appetite appeared to be limited for the fund and the €1tln target appeared unlikely. On Friday it was announced that the permanent stability mechanism would be brought forward to July 2012 from July 2013. The governments have committed to “reassessing the adequacy of the overall ceiling of the EFSF/ESM of €500bln”. However increasing the amount available the EFSF/ESM would be politically challenging, particularly as Germany has already faced difficulties in getting agreement on the current level of support that it is providing. Furthermore the EU will confirm with in ten days of the meeting whether it will commit an additional €200bln funding to the IMF. They expect that these funds will be matched by other international players. These two steps have increased the total amount of funds that would be available to member states to approximately €650bln. This is still short of what the market would consider necessary as both Spain and Italy have a requirement of about €600bln in 2012 alone. The ECB’s response to date The ECB as expected cut interest rates by 0.25% to 1% on Thursday at this monthly meeting. The central bank has acknowledged the very challenging economic environment that is facing the region and has decided to use unconventional methods aimed at reviving credit growth to foster an economic recovery. The ECB announced it will provide 3 year liquidity to the banking sector and also loosened the collateral rules allowing the banking sector gain this additional liquidity. However contrary to expectations that the ECB would be in some way part of the resolution at the Summit meeting on Friday, President Draghi closed the door, if anything to the possibility of extending the current SMP programme which allows the central bank to purchase government bonds in the secondary market. He also pushed out any speculation that the ECB may lend money to the IMF. Where are we now? The most positive and important step from the summit was that all the members of the EMU (European Monetary Union) remain committed to the currency union and have taken a step towards close fiscal integration. However the path that they have chosen is disappointing, particularly compared to what we had been expecting last week.
  • Eurozone government bonds, particularly for countries with higher debt and deficit dynamics, remains a much riskier asset class than investors of government bonds typically like to take, as private sector losses remain a possibility for such assets. It is difficult to see the traditional investor base returning to purchase government bonds when such a risk continues to persist.
  • As a result the ECB has been the only purchaser in town. However President Draghi’s speech on Thursday implied that the ECB is withdrawing support rather than previous expectations that the ECB would be a key part of a solution in the short term.
  • The large refinancing needs for Spain & Italy remain for 2012, particularly the first quarter of 2012. The mechanism for support of country that can only finance its debt on the bond markets at an unsustainable price remains too small to support these countries over the next year.
  • The treaty changes will be drafted up before March 2012 and after that individual countries will be faced with ratifying the changes. This will pose political risks, most notably for France, whose general election is due to take place in May 2012.
The market reaction to the summit has been subdued, although the Euro has been seen the largest losses falling to 1.32 from 1.33 against the dollar on Friday. Peripheral government bonds yields have also increased, albeit remain well below the highs that were seen in November, while the ten year German government bond yield decreased to 2.04% from 2.1% on Wednesday evening prior to the ECB announcement. Equity markets in Europe have traded lower. We would expect that volatility will continue in this environment for both equity markets and bond markets as uncertainty around the Euro debt crisis have yet to be resolved. In this environment core government bonds should continue to outperform. Important - Disclaimer This document is intended as a general review of investment market conditions. It does not constitute investment advice and has not been prepared based on the financial needs or objectives of any particular person, and does not take account of the specific needs or circumstances of any person. item.title: Review of 2011
item.dc:creator: Ruth
item.content:encoded:
2011 saw two distinct halves for investors and once being on the right side of the risk on or risk off trade at the appropriate time rewarded investors. Investors with appetite for riskier assets benefited during the first half of the year, but a more cautious approach rewarded investors in the second half. Furthermore the optimism around inflation, economic growth and higher risk asset prices all faded in the second half of the year. Concerns about the indebtedness of the advanced economies dominated and resulted in a flight to quality that saw gold reach record high levels, government bond yields of the safe havens such as Germany, UK and US reach a new low level and equity markets in emerging markets, Europe and Japan fall. Fears of rising inflation and tighter monetary policy stances from the first half of the year were replaced with suspicions of a double dip recession and even looser monetary policy. One other striking outcome of 2011 has been the divergence in performance of US and European equities, which has resulted in a significant valuation differential.

Eurozone Crisis – the continued search for the golden solution

The sovereign crisis in Europe spread into the larger economies, especially after EU leaders conceded to their commitment that private sector holders of Eurozone government bonds would not have to take a haircut, after they asked the private sector holders of Greek debt to take first a 20% haircut and then later in the year a 50% haircut. This attached a credit risk to Eurozone government debt and set the yields on Italian and Spanish government bonds to a level where Ireland, Portugal and Greece received a bailout from the IMF/EU. However as the current bailout system is inadequate to deal with the large financing needs of these countries, markets feared the worst and began pricing in a recession and even the possibility that the Euro may no longer exist in its current form. The ECB stepped up its efforts to help these government bond markets and restarted its SMP bond purchasing programme and managed to keep the 10 year yields of Italy and Spain below 7% and 6% respectively, albeit an unsustainable level for these countries to refinance themselves. In December the ECB announced that it would lend an unlimited amount of money to the banking system at 1% for 3 years in December and again in February 2012, allowing the banking sector to refinance its maturing debt over the next few months which has also resulted in yields of government bonds with a maturity of up to three years to fall. This along with the commitment by EU leaders for closer fiscal integration has reinforced views that policy makers will do whatever necessary to keep monetary union together. The solution to date has not been the “golden solution” that markets have been looking for and therefore has resulted in much higher market volatility. However policy makers are ensuring that individual countries with higher debt and deficit problem adopt the necessary austerity and reform programmes and are just about doing enough to avoid liquidity or funding crises.

The debt crisis has dominated bond markets

In 2011 bond market volatility has increased, particularly as the Eurozone sovereign crisis has led to a wide dispersion in the performance of government bond markets. The higher growth outlook and inflationary concerns in the first quarter of 2011, led to a spike in government bond yields, back to what would have been seen as a more normalized range. For example in April the ten year German government bond yield peaked at close to 3.5%. However soon after that risk aversion increased and AAA government bond yields fell as investors sought out much safer assets and the ten year German government bond reached a historical low level of 1.67% in September. Furthermore the divergence between bond markets in Europe also widened during this period as the spread between the Italian and Spanish government bond yield over the Germany government bond yield moved out to historically high levels. Even other AAA government bonds such as France saw increased yields as markets started put an additional credit risk on French bonds. Despite this, the Italian government bond market was the principal underperformer in 2011. Some of these losses in government bond markets were recouped in December, especially after the ECB announced the three year LTRO, or longer term liquidity into the banking system which has led to increased buying of government bonds towards the end of the year.

Equity markets have re-rated significantly in 2011

Global equity markets sold off significantly in the second half of 2011, notably in August when risk aversion peaked. Concerns about a global recession as well as the contagion effects of the Eurozone sovereign crisis has resulted in 10-15% sell off in European, Japanese and Emerging market equities. These market moves have come despite the resilience in earnings expectations for the full year 2011 as earnings grew by 3.6%, 2.5% and 7% respectively. As a result valuation levels have fallen back towards the levels that were seen at the bottom of the market in 2009 for these regions. US equities have also de-rated although to a smaller extent as earnings are expected to increase by 10% and markets increased by just 3%. Currently European and emerging markets equities are trading on 9 times 2011 and 2012 earnings, while US equities are on 13 times. Going into 2012, expectations are that earnings forecasts will be revised down further, although at these valuation levels, a lot is in the price.

Currency markets pushed safe haven currencies higher

In 2011 two central banks, the Bank of Japan and the Swiss National Bank intervened in currency markets to curb the increases of the yen and the Swiss Franc, which had been increasing as currency investors sought out “safer asset” classes. The Swiss National Bank has successfully managed to put a floor on its currency, which had been rising steadily since 2007 and was starting to negatively impact the Swiss economy due to an erosion of competitiveness. Similarly the Japanese yen rose to a record level and the Bank of Japan intervened in markets. Elsewhere in currency markets the Euro held up well for most of the year, especially considering the moves that were evident in government bond and equity markets in Europe. However sentiment towards the currency turned more negative in the latter months of the year as it suffered losses against sterling and the Dollar.

Ireland became the poster child in Europe

Although the yield on Irish government bonds increased in the first half of 2011, investor sentiment towards Ireland became much more positive in the second half of the year. Firstly the government managed to renegotiate the interest that the EU and IMF are charging on the money that Ireland borrows from them. This greatly improved the debt sustainability for Ireland. Furthermore news that Bank of Ireland had received an investment from a group of US investors also helped to improve the positivity towards Ireland as did news that the economy grew in the first half of the year on the back of stronger exports. As a result Ireland government bonds have outperformed and the yields on the ten year government bond fell from a high of 14% to finish the year 8.2%.

Looking towards 2012

Going into 2012, the Eurozone sovereign crisis remains high on the agenda. A key risk for the first quarter of 2012 is how or at what cost Spain, Italy and France will refinance the large amount of debt that is set to mature during the quarter. This issue alone will create volatility for equity and bond markets. However if we muddle through the crisis yields on government bonds in Europe should converge with German yields rising as some risk aversion eases and other Eurozone bond yields falling as the credit risk being attached to these bonds eases. Aside from this earnings are expected to be downgraded on the back of the slower economic growth outlook. However equity markets in Europe, emerging markets and Japan have de-rated significantly during 2011 as prices fell by 12-15% even though earnings have increased by 5-10% in these regions. As a result equity market valuation levels are now close to the March 2009 level implying that equities are now pricing in a lot of bad news. In the US the de-rating has not been as aggressive as in Europe although valuations are still well below long term averages levels. Therefore if investors have the risk tolerances to cope with the volatility that may arise as a result of the Eurozone sovereign crisis, equity market are looking more attractive now than they have done in recent history.
