item.title: In 2011 we paid out over €117 million in death and specified illness benefits
item.dc:creator: Martin Duffy
item.content:encoded: This morning we released our claims statistics for 2011, this is something we do around this time every year and it gives us an opportunity to emphasize how important Life Insurance can be in securing your family's future in the event or the unthinkable. It also allows our customers to see what were the main causes of claims in the preceding year. And cancer was once again the main cause of claims for both death and specified illness benefit in 2011. Overall, in 2011 we paid more than €81 million in death benefit to 1,311 dependents – an average payment of just over €62,000, and paid out almost €36 million in specified illness cover (SIC) in respect of more than 600 claims, an average payment of more than €59,000. Once again these figures show how important it is for Irish people to take steps to look after their dependents in the case of serious illness or worse still death. Death and specified illness cover are one of the best value insurance products available and it's important to emphasise that this sort of financial protection is just as important for those on lower incomes as it is for those on higher incomes. To give an example from last year, we settled a €100,000 claim with a 39-year-old shop assistant just eight weeks after she took out her serious illness cover. It’s probably fair to say that the €100,000 we paid out to that customer is more significant for her than some substantially bigger claims we settled for customers on higher incomes. A 35 year-old can obtain €100,000 worth of death and specified illness cover for the next 15 years for just €10 a week and at Irish Life, we will pay out whichever claims comes first – specified illness or death. €10 a week for the peace of mind €100,000 worth of cover provides is extraordinarily good value. It is also significant that almost 4 in every 10 accident-related death claims involved people under the age of 40, highlighting the need for people to take out life assurance at an early age. Accidents accounted for 11% of the death claims we settled last year and a large proportion of these accident-related claims involved young people. Of the more than 1,300 death claims Irish Life settled last year, 44% were the result of cancer and 18% the result of heart-related conditions. But 11% of death claims – a total of 141 - were the result of accidents and of these alcohol was a factor in one in seven. It has to be of real concern that alcohol continues to feature as a factor so prominently in our accident-related claims. Year after year, the same pattern is there and the various public awareness campaigns don't seem to be having much effect. Maybe we need to consider a different approach. Cancer remains the main cause of specified illness claims, accounting for almost-two thirds of the 603 claims settled, and of those claims, breast cancer accounted for some 28%, followed by prostate cancer (8.5%) and colon cancer (4.8%). Monday morning I spoke to Ian Guider on NewsTalk about the figures, you can listen back here: Newstalk Interview I also spoke to Matt Cooper on the Last Word this Monday Afternoon: Today FM You can also read about our claims stats in the news; The Irish Times The Irish Independent Again The Irish Examiner The Belfast Telegraph The Journal Breaking News

item.title: Love and Paris in the spring
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded: It sounded romantic and I’m sure in plenty of houses around Ireland it was sold as such; a weekend in Paris to celebrate Valentines, Irish ladies would be treated in their thousands this year to romance in the city of love.  The stage was set for a hot weekend.  However, as the temperature hit -9 degrees in Paris last Saturday night, the romance was on hold, it was going to be about the passion for the next 80 minutes; passion to be shown not by 1 man alone, but indeed by 15 men in Green!! Unfortunately, Mother Nature (and some bad planning to say the least) intervened and as loyal fans cursed a lack of under-soil heating, they retreated to the heart of Paris for an early night. Many will ask if anything positive will come of the weekend or was it a weekend wasted? We heard interviewees use words such as “disgrace” and “disappointment” but they had surely forgot the love!?!  You see, all was not lost; perhaps the romance and the early night will help us maintain our grand slam lead in one area where we have regular 6 nations success – our replacement fertility levels!! Yes indeed, except for a blip in performance levels in 2005 and 2006 we have consistently lead our 6 nations rivals in the reproduction stakes!  Romance is alive and well in Ireland!! It acts as an important reminder as we arrive into the last 2 weeks of our special two month cash-back offer on new Life Insurance plans.  When the fertility rate rises, it means more new families and larger families, which of course increases the need for parents to take out Life Insurance to ensure their families are provided for financially should the unfortunate happen. It may not be romantic but it’s as practical as under-soil heating in Paris in the Spring!

item.title: Best in class
item.dc:creator: Gerry Hassett
item.content:encoded:
Acceptance speeches may not be our forte, but we are extremely proud to have been chosen by Brokers for the Top Life Company award, again.
"They really provide a quality service to brokers in all areas and are eager to improve and help by thinking outside the box where necessary.  They are flexible and helpful."
For the second year running, the members of the Irish Brokers Association(IBA) voted the service Irish Life provides to them and their clients as the best in the business.  We also hold the same award from the Professional Insurance Brokers Association(PIBA).
Tony Lawless, General Manager of Brokerage in Irish Life, receiving the award from IBA President Mr Carl Rainey. Also pictured from left to right: Barry Skelton, Susan Gibson, Paul Smith, John Roberts, Gerry Hassett, Donal Wood, Dave Lennon and Andy O'Connor 

Of the 44 categories for the IBA awards, Irish Life ranked best in 35, and were the only company from the top 3 to improve its score year on year.  The PIBA have 32 categories that are judged, and Irish Life came top in 28 of those, and 2nd in the remaining four.

"Most superior company in the market in terms of new business, products offered, underwriting and administration.  Not matched on the market."

So what does it all mean?  Well, by holding both awards, Irish Life is now unanimously the No 1 choice for Brokers in Ireland.  In terms of support offered to brokers, range and quality of products, and quality of staff, Irish Life has been voted 2nd to none.

"Excellent all around.  Very much in partnerships with brokers."

To sum it all up, we are extremely proud to win these awards but rather than resting on our laurels, we are more determined than ever to further improve our scores in all categories, and continue to be the no 1 supporter of independant Brokers in Ireland.

If you'll pardon our bashful ways, um - thanks...again.  But there's more work to do.

item.title: Protecting what's important
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
The saying “your health is your wealth” rang true when we conducted an attitude survey among 1,000 adults recently.   The main concern for 37% of those surveyed was that they or their partner would become ill or die suddenly, compared to 16% who were more concerned with losing their job.  Losing their home (11%) and being unable to pay bills (10%) were the next most important concerns for the respondents.
The main concern for 37% of those surveyed was that they or their partner would become ill or die suddenly
Half of those surveyed said they are aware of a family where the main income earner died prematurely at less than 50 years of age.  [caption id="attachment_1262" align="aligncenter" width="542" caption="Irish Life launches campaign to raise awareness that cover starts from €15"][/caption]
 
The survey reveals that in general people totally overestimate the cost of taking out a family protection plan.  In fact, almost 70% of those surveyed thought life insurance costs over €35 a month, which is more than twice the normal starting cost of €15 a month for €100,000 cover for a typical 35 year old parent.
It would take the average household 80 years or more to save €100,000 for their family by putting €15 by on deposit to help their family financially in the event of death.
Gerry Hassett, Head of Irish Life Retail said, “The survey shows that although the main concern people have is around what might happen if they or their partner became ill or died, people need to take steps to protect their lives or the lives of their families.  While it makes sense to put some money by for a rainy day, it costs just €15 a month to get €100,000 worth of life cover for a typical 35 year old parent of young children.  It would take the average household 80 years or more to save €100,000 for their family by putting €15 by on deposit to help their family financially in the event of death.  Rather than just topping up their savings, people really should consider protecting their family with life insurance.”

Find out how much €100,000 Life Insurance would cost you

Note: €100,000 worth of life insurance costs €15 per month for a 35 year old male or female non smoker with Irish Life’s Life Term Cover plan.  The cost of life insurance depends on your age, health, amount of cover, gender and product type.  80 years to save €100,000 based on monthly savings of €15 on deposit at 4% per year net interest rate, after tax.

The research was carried out in March 2012 by iReach, with a sample size of 1,000 adults of 18+ using a nationally representative model.
item.excerpt:encoded: Irish adults are more concerned about their health that holding on to their jobs, a major survey of 1,000 adults by Irish Life on attitudes to protecting what's important to them in life reveals.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: protecting-whats-important

item.title: Taxi’s, Savings plans and Life Insurance!
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded:
It was a wild evening last Wednesday and it cost me €18 in taxi fares, but it was just one of those evenings where you just really wanted to get into the warmth and out of the rain, it felt like €18 well spent when the door shut behind me. It was easy to imagine the origin of the saying “saving for a rainy day”. It was not a night for going back out!

The rainy day is on a lot of minds at the moment, as we are all too aware, anyone who is lucky enough to have money, is saving like we’re in a never ending storm. Let’s hope we’re not but that’s a discussion for another day! Right now we all want the peace of mind that both ourselves; and our families can keep the proverbial fire alight should our rainy day come. It makes sense.

But it got me to thinking, had I walked home, or more realistically got the bus, I’d have saved about €15. Say I saved this amount every month for 10 years, how would that help the nest egg? Well, in 10 years time, saving €15 a month, that would leave me with €1,800 plus whatever interest I can get, so I felt I need lots of €15’s to really make a difference but it did make me feel better about getting the taxi!!

There are many other uses for my €15 and I’m sure yours, but of course working in the industry, it did highlight the value in Life Insurance right now. For some like me, a 32 year old man, I could set up a life cover plan for the next 10 years with my €15 a month and this would ensure that my family would receive €196,317 should the worst come to the worst and I die in that time. It’s not a pleasant thought granted, but it’s a big figure and maybe worth being part of your rainy day planning?

So if you’ve got something specific you’re saving for then great, I say go for it, but if like me, you’re storing up a small bit extra for peace of mind, then €196,317 is a lot of peace of mind for €15. It might be worth thinking about this weekend.

Check out how much Life Insurance you can get for €15 a month.

item.title: Some spring cleaning on the Irish Life Blog
item.dc:creator: Stephen
item.content:encoded: We’ve spent a little time cleaning up our blog, as regular readers may notice. We’ll be ironing out any bugs over the next week or two. We're always working to keep things fresh so we hope you like the clean up! Speaking of freshness and in the interest of it being a Friday (and for some blatant padding out of this post) why not sit back and enjoy some of the best of what the internet has to offer us on this very day: 200 reasons not to leave Dublin ‘Phoenix Park ‘, ‘A proper fry’, ‘Dublin Bikes’, ‘The girls are so pretty’ – just some of the top 200 reasons not to leave Dublin from an article on http://www.totallydublin.ie which is trending on twitter right now. You just got Geoff Shreevesed Geoff Shreeves ripping Ivanovic’s heart out on live television is a top video on youtube today: Ridiculously Photogenic Guy Ridiculously Photogenic Guy, currently one of the internet meme's doing the rounds (can you spot him?): OMGPOP - It's what all the kids say these days And finally, my favourite; the ‘Draw Something’ app for smart phones which is available for download at all good app stores. If you haven't played it yet then you're missing out, it's top notch.

item.title: The Last Word Stability Treaty Debate broadcasts live from Irish Life
item.dc:creator: T.J.
item.content:encoded:
We are now nine months into our successful sponsorship of Matt Coopers show, The Last Word on Today FM. As part of our sponsorship, The Last Word will be broadcasting live from Irish Life Head Office on Thursday 17th May from 4.30 – 7pm.

During this live broadcast, Matt will be chairing a debate on the upcoming Fiscal Treaty Referendum. We’ll have panellists and comment from government, opposition - and further afield - on both sides of this crucial decision about Ireland's future in Europe. To follow the debate - tune into Today FM this Thursday at 4:30 pm.

item.title: ‘Mobile’ is the buzzword of the Year
item.dc:creator: Stephen
item.content:encoded: I find it’s an important task, at the start of every year, to research and learn what the top 10 buzzwords I’m likely to hear during that year will be. It’s important because when the bossman comes a knockin’ we need to be ahead of the game so we can lower his expectations straight away. ‘Mobile’ has now replaced ‘Viral’ which replaced ‘Social’ as the most common buzzword said at me over the past 2 years. Now I am generally sceptical about buzzwords - my blank stare response is usually a good indication of this - mainly because it’s hard to use 1 or 2 or even 3 words to describe what can be an entire world of…anything. So at the start of the year I see ‘mobile this’ and ‘mobile that’ as being the popular buzzwords I’m about to hear, in truth they have been popular for a number of years but 2012 is really the year of mobile. When I see them being popular I know that it’s what I’ll be hearing from the bossman over the next few months. Strangely for a buzzword this makes me pretty happy. It means we’re really thinking about what a customer wants rather than jumping onto a bandwagon. Customers don’t necessarily want a viral video or the ability to ‘like’ us, but if it’s there they’ll embrace it. They do want the ability to connect with their policies in an easier way. Mobile just makes things easy. So we began the year thinking mobile and this week we’re realising mobile with the release of our new app for customers on the Apple iTunes and Google Play markets: http://www.irishlife.ie/mobile/my-irish-life-app.html You can now log in to our app and view your policy plan information. Depending on your type of product, you can see: Current values, Payment History, Investment history and Fund performances. Who will use an Irish Life app? It’s crazy to think but 10% of all traffic to irishlife.ie is from mobile phones. Every month that is growing. 1 in 10 people are reading this on a smartphone. The new Galaxy SIII phone from Samsung is out in 2 weeks and has a whopping 9 million pre-orders already and growing. 5 million a month will be sold. The mobile world is getting bigger and the phones are getting smarter. According to google* smartphone penetration in Ireland is at 43% and 61% of these people access the internet every day using their phone. 89% of smartphone users surf the web while doing something else like watching TV. Over a quarter (26%) of these people would rather give up that TV than give up their smartphone. It’s important to Irish Life that we don’t restrict users from checking their policies just because they’re not near a pc. Smartphones are computers now. That is why we’ve released this app and that’s why in 2012 we’re going mobile. *http://www.ourmobileplanet.com/en/
item.excerpt:encoded: According to google* smartphone penetration in Ireland is at 43% and 61% of these people access the internet every day using their phone. 89% of smartphone users surf the web while doing something else like watching TV. Over a quarter (26%) of these people would rather give up that TV than give up their smartphone.

item.title: Happy Father's Day!
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded:
"When I look at the smiles on all the children's faces I just know they're about to jab me with something."   --Homer Simpson
I can't wait for Father's day. Been looking forward to it for ages. It's the one day of the year when we - the daddies - the men of the house - can be the centre of attention for a few short hours. We get a card and the wife and kids do their best to be nice to us for just one day. Who knows, we might also get control of the TV remote if we're lucky. On Father's day last year I was having a grand old time making the most of the day when my 6 year old daughter decided she'd had enough. "I'm tired of this" she says, "You never do anything for us". "Wha, I never do anything, do I. Is that what you think?" I say increduously. "Yeah", she says, "starting to giggle". Ha Ha - big mistake! "Right then," I began. "Who reads your bedtime stories?" "Who brings you out cycling and makes sure you've got your helmet on properly?" "Who brings you to the playground in the park and stands underneath you, ready to catch you, when you climb the monkey bars?" "Who makes sure you have enough sun-blocker on so you don't get sunburned?" "Who makes sure we always have a band-aid and a hug when you cut your knee?" "Who pays for the food you eat and the house you live in rent free?" - Well, ok, I didn't say the last one. At this point she lost interest and ran back outside to play with her brother. I sat there thinking - it's a day to realise how much you do look out for them. You get more out of it than any amount of thanks could give - and then still milk the thanks anyway!! Enjoy the day lads!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Happy Fathers Day!

item.title: GAA Football Championship 2012 - The view from the man in the middle
item.dc:creator: David Coldrick
item.content:encoded:
Championship 2012 is getting to the business end of the season. The new GAA president Liam O' Neill appoints new committees for his 3 year term of office. He has appointed Pat McEnaney as the head of the referees committee.  Pat brings huge experience to the job having been one of the top inter-country football referees for many years. There’s no doubt he’s going to be good for refereeing and he’ll look to develop new refereeing talent during his tenure. The committee have already started down this road with championship panel places being given to Barry Cassidy (Derry) & Conor Lane (Cork) this year. This continues the policy of developing referees that was progressed under the last committee. I’ve been north and south over the last few weeks refereeing Cork-Kerry and Tyrone-Donegal in championship 2012. The games have passed off without major incident. Referees are individuals and each has their own personal communication style on the pitch. I’m a firm believer in maintaining control through regular communication with players. It tends to serve me well but it’s a personal approach. Having said that, the rules are applied and when big decisions have to be made, they’re made.

A referee needs to be able to read a game. Being able to read a game allows a referee to know when he can let play develop and when he needs to step in. This isn’t always easy and comes with experience. I’m not saying a referee will get that balance right all the time, even with experience. A referee has to be physically and mentally prepared for a game so that he can sense quickly if his control over the game is waning and he can retrieve the situation quickly & easily. We’re already in early July but unfortunately the summer hasn’t really arrived yet. Wet & windy conditions are hard for players to deal with and it’s the same for referees. A referee needs to try to allow for conditions but ultimately players need to take responsibility for their own behaviour no matter what the conditions.
 Being able to read a game allows a referee to know when he can let play develop and when he needs to step in.
Media attention on referees hasn’t reduced since last year, if anything social media has brought it to another level. It is unfortunate that referees are becoming the subject of social media ‘tweets’ but it’s the age that we live in and there’s not a lot we can do about it (the rugby approach appears to be to reply but I’m not sure that helps!). All I would say (and I have said this before) is that a referee goes out to do his best in every game and never to “do” a player or team. Mistakes can be made, just like players & managers. A common denominator for managers, players and referees is that we all hope that any mistake won’t affect the outcome of a game. Respect is a two way street. Referees need to respect players & team officials and vice-versa. The GAA’s ‘Give Respect, Get Respect’ initiative which is an attempt to build this two-way respect from schools level up is a good idea but it’ll only work if all parties are bought into it.
 The GAA’s ‘Give Respect, Get Respect’ initiative which is an attempt to build this two-way respect from schools level up is a good idea but it’ll only work if all parties are bought into it.
Championship referees meet once every 3 weeks during the championship season. These sessions focus on key decisions made by referees since the last time we met. The sessions are open & honest. There are no hiding places – numerous video clips are reviewed & debated. Each referee has an opportunity to voice his opinion, starting with the referee involved. It’s not a scapegoat exercise but it is an extremely important learning tool. Referees, not unlike players & managers, can always improve their performance and this is what we’re striving to do. The next set of appointments has just been made and I’ve been appointed to referee the round 2 qualifier game between Laois & Monaghan. Preparations have started & hopefully it’ll go well.
item.excerpt:encoded: So we are at the Provincial Final stage of the 2012 Football Championship, and top inter county referee, and Irish Life employee, David Coldrick gives us a referees view on the season so far

item.title: Desktop websites don’t work for mobile users
item.dc:creator: Stephen
item.content:encoded:
According to Google research* only 19% of Irish people are ‘Completely Satisfied’ with browsing websites on a smartphone. That’s pretty low considering that about 55% of Irish people look for information about local businesses or services on a smartphone at least once a week. People look for this information no matter where they are:   Setting up a useful mobile version of irishlife.ie is a goal we’ve had for a while but now the statistics were lining up in our favour to make it a reality. In June 2012, 15.75% of all traffic to irishlife.ie was from mobile devices. For the same period in 2011 it was only 5.46%. More Android devices are switched on every day than people are born (700k Vs 300k). So usage is going one direction but satisfaction is not following as fast. Websites aren’t responding quickly enough. It was important that we respected how people prefer to visit our website and responding to that is a way to show that respect. So we did. Over the last week or two we’ve rolled out our mobile website – m.irishlife.ie - with a single goal of serving the needs of mobile specific customers & users. We redirect our mobile visitors to this site automatically. Our mobile website offers a vastly superior user experience than viewing a desktop website on a small screen. It is, however, just the beginning for our mobile website. We’ll be building up statistics on how users interact with the various pages on the mobile site, we’ll listen to feedback and we’ll test as much as we can so updates and changes continually improve the site. It’s been a positive experience so far and we hope that it will continue. Here are some initial indicators of a better user experience on the mobile site than on the desktop site when using a smartphone.
Desktop version from a smartphone Mobile version from a smartphone
Pages per visit 1.65 4.93
Average visit duration 1 min 39 sec 3 mins 09 sec
Bounce Rate (% people who leave straight away) 73.20% 32.42%
      *http://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/mobileplanet....

item.title: Attitudes to Retirement Survey
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
We published our findings from a major survey on attitudes to retirement this week.  When asked for their key aspirations in retirement, 89% of the 1,000 adults polled said “good health” while 81% said “financial security for myself and my spouse”. The survey also found that 43% do not know how they will manage financially in retirement.  Nearly half (45%) of people say they have no private or company pension provisions.  Of these, 1 in 4 say that they will rely solely on the state pension to fund their retirement lifestyle.
The survey also found that 43% do not know how they will manage financially in retirement.
Commenting on the findings of the survey, Gerry Hassett, Chief Executive, Irish Life Retail said, “As well as providing practical financial support to people in their retirement, a pension also helps people to fulfil their hopes and dreams in later life.  The reality is that the state pension will not be enough for people to live on yet our research shows that only half of people have their own pension plan.”
While these are obviously difficult times, it’s important that people realise that a pension is also an investment in our family’s future and that it deserves real planning and consideration like other aspects of our lives.”
The survey coincides with our of a new advertising campaign aimed at raising awareness of the importance of planning for your retirement. Our tv ad features “Sean and Babs”, and Sean has a few “innovative” plans for how they can fund their retirement fund.  To ensure you don’t end up like Sean, check out www.irishlife.ie where you will find a range of tools to help you plan for your retirement on our website, including our pension calculator and our new simple guide to pensions.
item.excerpt:encoded: Health and wealth top the poll when it comes to what is most important to people in their retirement, a major survey on attitudes to retirement published by Irish Life this week.

item.title: Donegal Abú
item.dc:creator: T.J.
item.content:encoded: The dust may have settled in the rest of the country, but “Jimmy’s Winning Matches” can still be heard ringing out from the North West of the Country.  20 years is not a long time in the grand scheme of things, but when it’s the gap between your first and second ever All Ireland Football victories, ask any Donegal fan and they will tell you it’s an eternity. But the wait is over, and Donegal are the champions, overcoming a valiant Mayo side in the decider with a scoreline of 2-11 to 0-13.  The hunt for tickets in the build-up to the encounter was phenomenal, with one pair of premium level tickets being sold on eBay for €7,100! One Donegal woman who got to treat her son with tickets to the game was Mrs Ann Mcgroary from Laghey.  Ann entered a competition organised by Irish Life Customer Services and won two premium level tickets for the big game. [caption id="attachment_1698" align="aligncenter" width="224"] Our lucky winner Mrs Ann McGroary pictured with her two Premium Level tickets[/caption] Ann's son had attended all Donegal's matches in the lead up to the final but couldn't secure tickets for the big day.  He had been doing a few odd jobs around the house for his mammy, and wouldn't take any payment, so when Ann offered him the two tickets for the final, he couldn't believe it until he actually saw them for himself! So, the day was enjoyed by all in Donegal, and according to Ann, the party is still going strong in the North West, with a backlog of loan applications to fund the celebrations.  Congrats to Ann(and her son) again and lets hope it won't be another 20 years before we see them back!
item.excerpt:encoded: The dust may have settled in the rest of the country, but “Jimmy’s Winning Matches” can still be heard ringing out from the North West of the Country. 20 years is not a long time in the grand scheme of things, but when it’s the gap between your first and second ever All Ireland Football victories, ask any Donegal fan and they will tell you it’s an eternity.

item.title: Understanding the Gender Directive
item.dc:creator: Colin
item.content:encoded: For most people, it’s the slightly surprising mild inconvenience you’ve never even heard about. But make no mistake, its coming. By the end of December this year the EU gender directive will be in place and insurance as you know it might be changed forever. What the gender directive means is that insurance companies will not be able to discriminate between men and women in assessing risk for insurance purposes. So what will that mean? Well, if you’re a woman, you currently pay on average 25% less for Life Insurance with Irish Life than men. This is because women tend to live longer than men, and are generally rewarded for this in their insurance premiums. And if you’re a man? Sullen stares and grumbles from the ladies in your life about having to take up the financial slack for our general inability to keep ourselves out of harm’s way. Brass Tacks From December 21st, prices will be the same for men and women. Unfortunately this means that the cost of life insurance for women is likely to increase. To give an example; currently, a smoking man, aged 39 who has a €150,000 Life Insurance plan with Irish Life for 25 years, pays €49.37 per month. This is €11.19 (25%) more than a smoking woman of the same age. What if I don’t have life insurance? Act now before the change. Any policy taken out and fully issued on or before the 21st December 2012 will remain at those rates even after the 21st December. What if I have a policy already in place? No change. The directive only applies to new contracts concluded after 21st December 2012. What if I am currently in the process of taking out a policy? Current rates will only be applicable until the 21st December. Therefore, any policies not in force before the 21st December 2012 will not be issued using current rates, and therefore may potentially incur higher premiums. Get a quote from Irish Life now.

item.title: Top 10 things to do this mid-term!
item.dc:creator: Sarah Blake
item.content:encoded: It can be hard to keep the kids entertained for the whole of mid-term especially when they’re full of energy from all the Halloween sweets… sugar rush! There are some great family days out in Dublin and around Ireland that will keep the kids entertained and don’t necessarily cost the earth. Check out our top ten things to do this mid-term. All cost €50 or less for a family of four!   10. The Wax Museum Check out all the celebrities and historical figures at the Wax Museum. The creepy Chamber of Horrors is definitely worth a visit! A family ticket (2 adults, 2 children) costs €35. Click here for more details. 9.   AquaZone at the National Aquatic Centre A great place to avoid the rain and still enjoy splashing around! The AquaZone is filled with lots of slides and watery adventures for all ages.  It’s €45 over the mid-term for a family of two adults and two children, click here to find out more!  8.  Bowling Bowling is a great (and dry) family day out for all ages. If you visit the Leisureplex bowling alleys in Dublin or Cork, you can get an hours bowling for up to six people for €39.  7.   Turoe Pet Farm and Leisure Park Stop by the Turoe Pet Farm and Leisure Park if you are in the Galway area. Based in Loughrea, It’s a great family day out where you can play with all the animals and have a rumble through the inflatable city. The cost for a family (2 adults and 2 children) is just €35! 6.   Fota Wildlife Park If you’re in the Cork area the Fota Wildlife Park is definitely worth a visit. Families can get up close to a wide range of animals. A family ticket to the park costs just €44. Click here for details! 5.   The National Gallery (Free) The National Gallery also run a series of events for families and young people. They’ve lots happening this mid-term, check out the calendar here for more information. 4.   Dublin Zoo Dublin Zoo is always a popular one with the kids, especially if the sun does decide to shine! A family ticket to the zoo costs €44.50. For more information on what’s happening at the zoo click here. 3.   National History Museum (FREE!) Full of real stuffed animals and other archaeological interests, sure to keep the most inquisitive minds entertained. The museum also has some great Halloween events happening this week just click here to find out more! 2. Tayto Park The House of Horrors is open in Tayto Park in Meath until Sunday 4 November… a spooky treat for all! A family ticket costs just €40. For all the details click here. 1.    Cinema (FREE – possibly!!) Now we know it’s hard to get a family trip to the cinema for less than €50 especially when you include treats on top of the cost of the tickets. Which is why Irish Life are giving away a family trip to your local cinema including popcorn and treats. All you have to do is visit our Facebook page and answer the question to enter!   So tell us… where is your favourite spot for a family day out? Don’t forget to enter our competition to win a family ticket to the cinema and like us on Facebook for more competitions in the future!

item.title: Ladies, bag yourself a bargain before Christmas
item.dc:creator: Laura Taylor
item.content:encoded:
It’s oh ho ho so easy to get caught up in the Christmas craziness… Tinsel, glitter, mince pies, shopping, presents, nights out. But Christmas is also about a lot more… (Don’t worry I’m not going to take a religious stance on this!) It's also about time spent with friends, loved ones and remembering what matters most - family.  Christmas is a time to cherish and acknowledge all of those day-to-day kindnesses we sometimes neglect to appreciate and a time when we really miss those we love if they cannot be with us...
It may seem like an unlikely present - it’s not something we like to think about
It may seem like an unlikely present, and it’s not something we often like to think about, but providing life insurance for your family in the event that something awful happens to you, could be the greatest gift of all. At the moment women typically pay 25% less than men for life insurance, so there is room for bargain hunting – even when it comes to life insurance.  
From 21 December 2012 the Gender Directive states - women and men will pay the same prices for new life insurance plans.
However from 21 December 2012 onward, women and men will pay the same price for new life insurance plans. This upcoming change is a result of the Gender Directive (a European Court ruling) which states that having different prices for insurance plans based on gender is discriminatory and should not be allowed.  In future the cost of your life insurance will depend on your age, health and the level and type of cover alone, and not on your gender. The traditional difference women have enjoyed on life insurance plans compared to their male counterparts will disappear.
In the run up to Christmas women's life insurance is 25% cheaper than their male counterparts.
Over the next few weeks in the run up to Christmas women will still have the opportunity to purchase their life insurance at prices that are 25% cheaper compared to their male counterparts. So ladies, if you have a family and you are thinking of taking out life insurance - bag yourself a bargain at the lower price and buy your cover before the Gender Directive comes into force on 21 December 2012.  Click here to get a quote for Life Insurance now. It may be an unusual present, but it could be the one thing your family will appreciate the most. To help you with the rest of your Christmas shopping, Irish Life are delighted to play secret Santa this year – with four €250 Smyths Toys Superstores vouchers to give away over the next 4 weeks (1 per week). Like us on Facebook to be the first to hear about our competitions and giveaways. Find out more.   Note: Under the Gender Directive the move to gender neutral pricing applies to new plans started after 21 December 2012. Once you start a plan such as term life insurance or mortgage protection before that date, your price is fixed for the term of the plan. Image thanks to http://www.littlemisshomes.com/2011_12_01_archive.html
item.excerpt:encoded: It may seem like an unlikely present, and it’s not something we often like to think about, but providing life insurance for your family in the event that something awful happens to you, could be the greatest gift of all. At the moment women typically pay 25% less than men for life insurance, so there is room for bargain hunting – even when it comes to life insurance.

item.title: MythBusters: 97% of Life Insurance Death Claims Are Paid
item.dc:creator: Stephen
item.content:encoded:
iReach Consumer Omnibus Research helps us understand people's thoughts about Life Insurance in Ireland. - 40% of people think that life companies decline 50% of claims for Life Cover and Specified Illness Cover - 16% think they decline 75%+ of claims for Life Cover and Specified Illness Cover. - 20% of males believe that 75%+ claims for Life and Specified Illness Cover are declined as opposed to 14% of females. The truth is quite different at Irish Life. We pay claims. In 2011 Irish Life paid out 97% of all Life Insurance Death Claims and 90% of all Specified Illness Cover claims. 6,241 death claims paid have been paid by Irish Life since 2007. That adds up to €386.6m paid out to families. In 2011 alone we paid out €81.5m.

Enter Our Competition

We have a €250 Smyths Toy Superstores Voucher to win. Enter the competition now for a chance to win!

item.title: Changes to Pensions in Budget 2013
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
While there isn't much good news in Budget 2013 (property tax, more DIRT, and on and on) Irish Life does welcome the commitment by the Government to continue to provide incentives for middle income people to pay into their pensions to save for their retirement.
We think that capping tax relief benefits on pensions over €60K p.a. is a much fairer solution than reducing tax relief for everyone.
The early release scheme for Additional Voluntary Contributions (AVC) is also good news. This allows people to withdraw - subject to marginal tax rate - up to 30% of the value of their AVC fund. This will be available for 3 years following the passing of the Finance Act.
The commitment not to renew the Pension Levy after 2014 is also welcomed.
More commentary to follow ....

item.title: ARF Imputed Distribution Payments
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded:
Information on Imputed Distribution ... for customers with ARFs and Vested PRSAs.

  The Finance Act 2006 introduced a minimum annual withdrawal amount on Approved Retirement Funds (ARFs) and from 2012, Vested Personal Retirement Savings Accounts (PRSA). These are called Imputed Distributions and Irish Life pays these to our customers in December each year.   We've put together a booklet for our ARF customers explaining in the simplest terms everything you need to know about your Imputed Distribution payment.   Download the booklet at irishlife.ie. (PDF opens in a new window).   If you need to contact us click here.

item.title: Protect your family - Fire Safety at Christmas
item.dc:creator: Aileen
item.content:encoded:
Yep, 'tis the season to be jolly! Time to dust down those Christmas decorations and turn your house into a magical wonderland!
 
To ensure you have a safe holiday this festive season, see below some hints and tips for Fire Safety at Christmas, to ensure you and yours are protected this Christmas!
Christmas Trees
• Place real Christmas trees securely in a sturdy base filled with water – metal stands cause trees to dry out and become flammable • Check water level daily • Ensure artificial trees have been pre-treated to increase flame resistance • Keep tree away from candles, heaters, fireplaces or other heat sources • Dispose of tree properly – never burn a real tree in the fireplace • View a video that demonstrates how quickly the fire can develop when a DRY tree is exposed to an open flame.
Check out Laura's latest blog for great Crafty Christmas ideas! 

 

Christmas Lights

 

Indoors 

• Only buy Christmas lights marked with a safety standard • Make sure a competent person checks all connections and examines the wiring for fraying • If in doubt, throw them out. • Don’t overload sockets • Unplug all Christmas lights and electrical appliances before leaving your home or going to bed Outdoors • Ensure lights are suitable for outdoor use • Check all wiring and follow manufacturers instructions. • Fasten the bulbs securely and point the sockets down to avoid moisture building up. • Never use indoor extension leads outside. • Keep outdoor electrical connections above ground and out of puddles and snow. • Ensure trees hung with Christmas lights are not touching power lines

Candles

An Office of the Director of Consumer Affairs (ODCA) survey found that consumers are exposed to serious risk due to the lack of advice when using candles and candle-holders. Of the 482 items inspected 117 or 24.3% failed a visual risk assessment either due to lack of warnings, warnings not provided in English or because the items clearly presented a safety hazard. Remember when it comes to candles: • Keep them out of reach of children and pets • Trim the wick to 6mm (1/4 inch) each time before burning • Always use an appropriate candleholder placed on a stable, heat-resistant surface • Keep burning candles away from drafts, vents and air currents • Extinguish a candle if it smokes or flickers repeatedly or if the flame becomes too high • Keep the wax pool free of wick trimmings, matches and debris at all times • Do not burn a candle for longer than manufacturer recommends • Extinguish the flame if it comes too close to the holder or container • Place lighted candles at least 75mm apart form one another • Never place a candle on top of a TV set and keep well away from curtains • Always extinguish candles before leaving the house or going to bed • Never use candles on Christmas trees, even artificial ones • Remember hot wax burns!

Other Christmas Fire Safety Tips

• Never burn wrapping paper in your fireplace • Keep strings of Christmas cards away from candles and open fires • Fit a spark guard in front of open fires • Extinguish cigarettes properly and do not let ashtrays get overfilled • Check that your smoke alarms are in perfect working order • Never remove batteries from smoke alarm to use in children’s toys • Clean out the oven and stove prior to Christmas
Information thanks to  fire@dublincity.ie   
  

Enter Our Competition

We have a €250 Smyths Toy Superstores Voucher to win. Enter the competition now for a chance to win!

item.title: Protect your family home this Christmas!
item.dc:creator: Aileen
item.content:encoded:
Some tips to help ensure your home is secure over the festive season: Searched the internet and there are lots of information as to keep your home safe this Christmas, a selection of these are listed below: Festive lighting - be secure. A common mistake of many festive decorators is to feed extension cables through partially open windows, criminals know to look for this vulnerability. When it comes to outdoor lighting, opt for solar or battery operated lights or install outdoor electrical outlets. Dispose of gift packaging carefully. Refuse collections over the Christmas and New Year period are normally at different times. If you can't take packaging to a recycling point, make sure you only put your rubbish out just before the collection and do your best to break apart boxes so that they do not advertise your new contents of your home to thieves! Be careful not to advertise your home to burglars on social media! Social media savvy families have a tendency to publish their whereabouts during the holiday season, including any vacation plans. This lets burglars know when your house is going to be empty. Uploaded photos of pricey Christmas gifts can also be a problem as it basically allows burglars to go shopping just by viewing your Facebook profile. Check doors and windows for weak spots. Installing a few dead-bolts and new window hinges could increase the security of your home exponentially. Keep your curtains, drapes and window blinds closed at night, making sure valuable items are out of sight. When going out for the evening make use of inexpensive timers to give the illusion of occupancy. Away over Christmas - plan ahead!!. If you're going away at Christmas be sure to cancel any newspaper or milk subscriptions. Arrange for a neighbour to park on the driveway to help create the impression someone is home. Do not to leave descriptive telephone answering machine messages or and again make use of light timers. Secure garages & sheds. Make sure that garden tools or ladders that could be used to force entry into your home are not left lying around or accessible from an unlocked garden shed. Garages are often targets for burglars looking for tools, bikes and gardening equipment - make sure the garage is secure and your possessions are secured too in the case of bikes and tools. Naturally make sure anything portable / valuable is recorded on immobilise. Don't hide keys & use alarms if you have them. Burglars know to look for hidden door keys so don't hide spare keys under rocks, in flowerpots, or above door ledges. Instead give the spare key to family or trusted neighbour. Many houses these days have alarms, many though are rarely set, make sure yours is on and protecting your home. An Garda Síochána have lots of useful information covering all areas of personal safety/burglary prevention: http://www.garda.ie/Controller.aspx?Page=1921&Lang=1 Below is one of the information sheets found on the link above.. I challenge all to do the check list, just how many 'No's' will you get?   An Garda Síochána Crime Prevention Information Sheet Burglars like easy opportunities. If they have to make a lot of noise, spend a lot of time or risk being seen, the chances are they won’t bother. A good rule of thumb is the 3 minute delay test. If you can deny entry for 3 min- utes or more – chances are the burglars will go elsewhere. Complete this simple home security survey to deter- mine how well your home is secured against burglary. Ignore questions not relevant to your own home. Remember, every NO answer is a threat to your home security. Doors and Windows
  1. Are all your external doors properly fitted and equipped with appropriate secure locking sys- tems? (i.e. 5-lever mortice locks for wooden doors, multi-point locking for uPVC doors etc.)
  2. If you have glass panelled doors – are they reinforced in some way so that they cannot be shattered?
  3. Have you a wide-angled viewer in your front/main entrance doors or other means of viewing callers?
  4. Do you have a door chain / limiter fitted and do you use it?
  5. Since moving into your home (where there may have been a previous occupier) have you had the locks changed?
  6. Are your spare keys kept with a trusted neighbour and never left under an external mat, flower pot etc.
  7. Do you lock your external doors when away from home, no matter how short a time?
  8. Do you lock the doors out of your view when working in the garden / yard?
  9. Have you installed an additional lock(s) to your sliding glass / patio doors?
  10. Can you close and lock your garage / outhouse doors?
  11. Are the garage / outhouse doors protected with quality locks or deadbolts?
  12. Do you close and lock your garage /outhouse doors?
  13. Are all your windows secure?
  14. Can the window openings be restricted for ventilation?
  15. Do you check to see if all windows are secured when you leave your home?
Inside Security
  1. Do you ask for identification before allowing unknown servicemen / callers into your home?
  2.  Do you avoid leaving cash at home?
  3. Have you automatic timers on some lights when your house is vacant?
  4. Does your home always look like someone is at home?
  5. Have you recorded serial numbers of your valuables?
  6. Have you, for identification purposes, photographed your valuables especially items for which you have no serial numbers such as jewellery, china, crystal, paintings, antiques etc?
  7. Are your car / house keys kept in a location not visible from the outside?
  Outside Security
  1. Is your house number visible from the street?
  2. Is there sufficient illumination around your home to allow visible inspection of any dark areas around it?
  3. Is there sufficient external lighting outside every door to illuminate visitors?
  4. Do neighbours and passers-by have a clear view of your home?
  5. Have you trimmed all hedges and shrubs so they can’t hide a burglar at work on the windows and doors?
  6. Have you ever walked around your house looking for ways a burglar might be able to get in?
  7. Do you keep tools or ladders etc. in places inaccessible to potential burglars?
  8. Are machines, tools and other high value items stored in garages or sheds securely padlocked or chained to prevent removal?
  9. Is your shed / garage secure?
  Holiday Security
  1. Have you a reliable neighbour whom you can notify of your travel plans and give a key to, with a request for a periodic house check?
  2. Do you have a neighbour collect your mail or newspapers when you are away or do you avail of Mailminder from An Post?
  3. Do you cancel all deliveries?
  4. Do you have your neighbour park his / her extra car in your driveway when you are away from home?
  5.  Do you arrange to have your lawn mowed?
  6. Do you notify the Gardaí of prolonged absences from your home?
  Electronic Security
  1. Do you have an intruder alarm system fitted and do you use it?
  2. Does it conform to the European Norm standard EN 50131?
  3. Is it maintained and serviced annually?
  4. Are you aware of the current Garda Intruder Alarm Policy?
  5. Do you know how to operate and use your alarm system functions?
  6. Have you considered connecting it to a monitoring centre or your mobile phone?
  7. Have you appointed a keyholder(s) and will they respond appropriately to an alarm activation?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: So true, we need to secure our safety especially this Christmas Season. Thank you so much for the tips!

item.title: Protect your family - Road Safety this Christmas!
item.dc:creator: Aileen
item.content:encoded:
We often hear about the tragic deaths on our roads, but rarely hear about the survivors of road accidents, who are left with serious injuries and require lifelong support and attention. Did you know that 19,681 people have suffered serious injuries on our roads between 1996 and 2011? Be safe this Christmas...  SLOW DOWN, DO NOT DRINK AND DRIVE, AND ALWAYS WEAR YOUR SEATBELT! Below is the recent press release from the RSA and An Garda Síochána. Elaine Hanley's story is one that brings the statistics to life, it could happen to any of us, as Elaine mentions herself, we really need to take great care when out on the roads! Press Release 10 December 2012  

LAUNCH OF CHRISTMAS AND NEW YEAR ROAD SAFETY CAMPAIGN

  The Road Safety Authority (RSA) and An Garda Síochána today launched their Christmas and New Year Road Safety Campaign in collaboration with the National Spinal Injuries Unit in the Mater Hospital. The focus of this year’s campaign is serious injuries as a result of collisions as statistics showed that 19,681 people were seriously injured in a collision in the period 1996 to 2011. A further analysis of the statistics shows that the number of serious injuries has decreased in recent years, in line with the reduction in road fatalities, with the lowest number of serious injuries recorded in 2011 (440)*. This was echoed in the presentation given by Mr Keith Synnott, Consultant Orthopaedic Surgeon at the Mater Hospital who said that in the past, most spinal cord injuries admitted to the hospital were as a result of road collisions (up to 50% in many studies), but that this had significantly reduced in recent years. Speaking at the launch today, Minister for Transport, Tourism and Sport, Mr Leo Varadkar TD said: “Last year we had the lowest number of deaths and serious injuries on our roads since records began. Nevertheless, we must continue with efforts to reduce the toll even further. Today I visited the National Spinal Injuries Unit in the Mater Hospital, where the members of staff are doing extraordinary work to support patients recovering from spinal cord injuries. This visit puts into perspective the simple things we all take for granted. And it serves as a sharp reminder of why we should all strive for road safety, particularly over the festive period.” In his presentation, Mr Keith Synnott, Consultant Orthopaedic Surgeon, Mater Hospital also presented hospital data from the past two years which showed a considerable reduction in the number of spinal injuries presenting themselves to the Unit as a result of road collisions. "We are delighted to be able to collaborate with the RSA and An Garda Síochána by hosting this launch at the Mater Hospital and the National Spinal Injuries Unit. Spinal cord injuries have a devastating and truly life changing impact on people who suffer them and their families. Unfortunately in many cases the damage to the spinal cord and its consequences are irreversible,” said Mr Synnott. “The highly skilled multidisciplinary team that work with these patients in the Mater are dedicated to helping patients survive these injuries, to prevent further injury and disease in these complex and challenging cases and to help them begin the often long and difficult road to rehabilitation. The goal of treatment is often to help patients maximise the function that remains following their injury. In spinal cord injury the old adage that prevention is better than cure is never more apt and it is with this in mind that we hope that this launch will encourage people to take care on the roads over Christmas and heed the message of the RSA and An Garda Síochána.” At the launch, Mr Gay Byrne, Chairman, Road Safety Authority reminded people not to forget those who have been seriously injured in collisions: “When we hear or read about road collisions, more often than not, it’s because someone has died. But what we often forget are those who are seriously injured in these collisions. It’s estimated that for every death on EU roads, there are at least eight serious injuries such as spinal cord injuries, as we have heard today, severe brain damage and injuries that require lifelong support and attention.” “As we enter the final days of 2012 and the beginning of a new year, I want us to all to remember these people and to remember that all it takes is a split second for a serious injury or worse to happen. Our message, as always, is simple – don’t take risks on the road. Slow down, wear your seatbelt, never ever drink or drug drive and make sure you get home safely this Christmas.” Over the festive period, there will be a determined focus by An Garda Síochána on high risk behaviour such as excessive and inappropriate speed, drink and drug driving and the non-wearing of seatbelts. Speaking at the launch, Garda Commissioner Martin Callinan said: “An Garda Síochána, through the Traffic Corps, is committed to working with all of the agencies involved in road safety to ensure we minimise the tragic impact of road collisions, be it a death or a serious injury. As such, over the festive period, we will be dedicating our resources to stamping out irresponsible, risky behaviour on our roads. But I would like to remind everyone that this is not about catching people, it’s about protecting each and every person who uses the roads so that we can all have a safe and happy Christmas and New Year.” At the launch, Elaine Hanley spoke about how her life has changed since she was in a collision last year.  “Last year, I was a typical 23 year old girl. I was working as a nurse in a care of the elderly hospital, hoping to do further study in the field of geriatrics. I enjoyed going out with friends, going for walks with my dog and helping my family with the farm. Then in August 2011, my life changed. I was in a collision and when I woke up, I was in the Mater Hospital with a spinal injury that left me paralysed from the chest down. The turnaround from being a nurse to being a patient, literally overnight, was overwhelming.” Elaine added “My life has completely changed for my family and me since that day in August. Living with a serious injury is a daily struggle and life, will never be the same again. Nobody ever thinks they will be in a crash or that something so serious could happen to them but it can. So I would like people to realise that we are so fragile when on the roads and that we really need to take great care.” A total of 154 people have been killed in road collisions to date in 2012 compared to 174 deaths to the same date in 2011. This represents 20 fewer deaths this year compared to last. When broken down by road-user, this represents 78 drivers, 25 passengers, 23 pedestrians, 16 motorcyclists and 8 cyclists who have died on Irish roads to date this year.   For further information contact:
  • RSA Communications Office, Ballina: 096 25008
  • Brian Farrell, Communications Manager: 086 3881009
  • Garda Press Office: 01 666 2071 or email pressoffice@garda.ie
  *Number of People Seriously Injured, 1996 to 2011
Year Number of People Seriously Injured
1996 2,360
1997 2,182
1998 1,916
1999 1,867
2000 1,640
2001 1,417
2002 1,150
2003 1,009
2004 877
2005 1,021
2006 907
2007 860
2008 835
2009 639
2010 561
2011 440
TOTAL 19,681

item.title: A little help to get in shape
item.dc:creator: T.J.
item.content:encoded:
Well that was quick wasn't it? No sooner had we said Happy Christmas to our friends and families, and we are now into the new year. And with the new year normally comes the fear, the fear of trying to get back into shape after the Christmas festivities.
Why did I not just go for a walk rather than watching Willy Wonka for the 42nd time
Everyone over-indulges a bit over the Christmas period, and when January comes rolling around, you can be rolling after it. The first time you pull on the runners for a jog or a visit to the gym can bring about the sweats even just thinking about it. Flashbacks of empty miniature hero wrappers scattered across the living room floor, that second Christmas dinner eaten at 7 pm on Christmas night, the beer, the wine, the crisps, why oh why did I let myself do it. Why did I not just go for a walk rather than watching Willy Wonka for the 42nd time, why did I have the 2nd bowl of sherry trifle when I didn't even need the first one! [caption id="attachment_1998" align="aligncenter" width="400"] All the signs tell you its time to get excercising[/caption]  
We at Irish Life are giving you the chance to win a €200 Elverys Sports voucher so you can get yourself kitted out so you at least look good as you wheeze your way through the machines in your local gym.
[caption id="attachment_1946" align="alignleft" width="100"] Click to enter[/caption] We know how hard it can be, and sometimes all that is needed is a gentle push to get you started again. With that in mind, we at Irish Life are giving you the chance to win a €200 Elverys Sports voucher so you can get yourself kitted out so you at least look good as you wheeze your way through the machines in your local gym.

So, Happy New Year to one and all, and best of luck with those resolutions!!

item.title: Newspapers and the World Wide Web
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded:
Are newspapers attempting to destroy the web or vice-versa?

  There's some discussion on the web this week - but notably not in Irish Newspapers - regarding the National Newspapers of Ireland's (NNI) desire to charge people and organisations for linking to their content. Not copying, not reproducing, not syndicating, just linking to a page. The NNI is the representative body for most of the Irish Newspapers. This came to light after the NNI wrote to a charity, Women's Aid, asking them to pay for links to articles on Irish Times website. This is part of a review of existing Copyright legislation by the Copyright Review Committee under the Dept. of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation. While this has gotten significant coverage internationally throughout the week (New York Observer , Techcrunch to name but two) , it doesn't seem to be newsworthy for Irish Newspapers. Indeed, it finally got mainstream coverage in Ireland this morning (Friday, 4th Jan) on RTE Radio 1.  

This is not new

This has a precedent - in 2007 a Belgian court ruled that Google's news search infringed copyright law, forcing it to remove links and snippets of articles from French and German language newspaper websites. This dispute was eventually resolved with both sides claiming victory, although the likelihood is that traffic to the websites suffered when they were being excluded from search results pages. Read more here on Google Blog and Bloomberg.  

More links to your site is good, right?

Competing news sites and news aggregators aside, I would have thought that newspapers would be encouraging links to their sites. More links means more visits and more visits means more ad impressions. More impressions means more revenue. If NNI are attempting to charge for linking to content then why do news sites like Irish Independent, Irish Times and Irish Examiner have share buttons beside every article? And not just to share on Facebook on Twitter, but also blogging platforms such as Tumblr, Blogger and Wordpress.  

Do I want to pay for this?

Going down the road of charging for links will force everyone to ask themselves - "is this worth paying for?". Online subscription models have not worked for the most part for newspapers, only large papers like the NY Times or The Times have a large enough readership to possibly make this work. If it has been shown that people aren't prepared to pay subscriptions, then it's safe to assume that they won't pay for mere hyperlinks. I presume that NNI would be going after Google too as they not only have links to content, but in many cases Google stores actual content and produces this in search results. If Google won't play ball the NNI sites could end up isolated from the rest of the web and that will not end nicely.  

Getting some attention

Hugh Linehan, editor of Irish Times has been in conversation on his personal Twitter today regarding the issue. He has made the following encouraging comments -
@tupp_ed @brianhonan @conor_pope We do not propose any charge or license for linking to @irishtimes . Reproduction a different matter — Hugh Linehan (@hlinehan) January 4, 2013
@daraghobrien @conor_pope @brianhonan Story up soon. The Irish Times loves people linking and we're not looking for anything in return. #nni — Hugh Linehan (@hlinehan) January 4, 2013
@jayrosen_nyu The Irish Times 's position will be represented clearly in a news feature to be published shortly on irishtimes.com — Hugh Linehan (@hlinehan) January 4, 2013

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Statement from Irish Times, please don't charge me for it.

item.title: We paid out over €125 million in Life insurance claims last year
item.dc:creator: Martin Duffy
item.content:encoded: In January of each New Year, we like to take a look back at the year that was, and publish details of our customers’ Life Insurance claims experience from the previous year. The figures reveal that in 2012 Irish Life paid out a total of €83.5 million in Life Insurance benefits held by 1,168 customers. A further €41.5m was paid out to 606 customers in respect of Specified Illness Cover plans. Our largest payout last year, a €5 million Life Insurance payment is the highest made by Irish Life in the past 7 years and compares to the highest claim paid in 2011 of €700,000. Indeed, this was just one of a number of claims north of €1 million paid out last year. The average claim for Life Insurance however was just over €71,500, and the fact that the average payment was just €71,500 suggests that the level of Life Insurance taken out by many Irish people is still insufficient to look after their dependents in the event of an early death, especially as the average age of adult claims is 62. Death and Specified Illness Cover is one of the best value financial products available. This sort of financial protection is just as important for those on lower incomes as it is for those on higher incomes. Last year we paid a €69,800 death benefit in respect of a Special Needs Assistant and a Specified Illness Cover payment of over €220,000 in respect of a young Home Care Assistant who contracted Multiple Sclerosis. It’s probably fair to say that the payments to those customers are probably more significant to them and their dependents than some substantially bigger claims we settled for customers on much higher incomes. Cancer and heart-related conditions continue to account for a majority of death and Specified Illness Cover claims. Cancer accounted for 46% of death claims and 63% of Specified Illness Cover claims, while heart conditions accounted for 14% of death and 19% of Specified Illness Cover claims. Cancer was the cause of 56% of death claims involving females and 43% involving males, while heart conditions were the cause of almost one-in-five of claims involving males compared to just 7% involving females. Accidents accounted for 135 Life Insurance claims – 12% of the total – and these were concentrated heavily among younger people with 40% of all Life Insurance claims for customers under age 40 the result of an accident. A total of 21 Life Insurance claims were the result of a road traffic accident. Alcohol was a factor in 7% of all accident claims. There has been a welcome improvement in the incidence of alcohol as a factor in accidents from 14% in 2011 to 7% last year and I hope to see a further improvement in the current year. Keep an eye on the website, as in the coming days we'll be producing our 2012 claims map, which gives a county by county breakdown of our claims paid.

item.title: Last year Irish Life staff raised €140,000 for charity
item.dc:creator: Cormac
item.content:encoded: Another year has passed and it has seen an exceptional response from Irish Life staff with a massive €70,000 raised. This will be matched by the company and given to the two charities voted for by Irish Life staff, namely IMNDA & Haiti Orphanage Project ESPWA Each year staff select two Irish charities, one who do their work in Ireland and the other who do their work abroad. The charities are voted for by staff, and are typically a charity where there is an affiliation, directly or indirectly, with that charity. Since 1996 Irish Life staff have donated €1.25m to their selected charities through various (and imaginative) fund raising events organized by their Staff Charities committee. These have included fashion shows, fake weddings, walking a mile in her shoes, abseiling down their 9-storey building, skipping through lunch (conveniently called "Skip-Lunch"), and Copper Kilo, where 200kg's of coppers were collected, to name but a few! 2012 was no exception.  We utilized the Euro 2012 football finals to raise funds through Jersey days, and prediction competitions.  The ever lucrative book sales have seen some of the popular books turn into money making machines, as they keep coming back for re-sale once people finish reading them!  Also on the events calendar was a fun run along the quays at lunch time, and back to the office for a cake sale, just to replace all those burned calories! There are normally a couple of big events during the year. This year is no different.  After a 3 year gap, we teamed up with White Collar Boxing once again for another showdown in the squared circle, giving some staff the opportunity to step into the ring to (safely) take on one of their colleagues in a boxing match. The event took place in a full sized boxing ring assembled in the staff restaurant and was titled the "Rumble in the Restaurant II - unfinished business" 30 members of staff, both male and female, spent 10 weeks getting in shape and learning the basic skills to step into the ring and battle it out, all in the name of charity! The grueling training regime took place at the National Boxing Stadium. There was added excitement and motivation at one of the sessions, as the participants got to meet Katie Taylor and Paddy Barnes just back from their heroic achievement in the Excel Arena at London 2012 Olympic Games. Aoife Murphy, one of the boxers on the night couldn't resist the photo opportunity!  The event took place at the end of September, so by now the bruised bodies (and in some cases, bruised egos) should be recovered, and people are back speaking to each other again. The other big event saw the Staff Restaurant turn into a fabulous Winter Wonderland for the Staff Charities Christmas Party. While this was a great fundraiser, it also gave the Staff Charities Committee an opportunity to say thank you to everyone for their generous donations during the year. Lastly, the final and most important event was the cheque handover over to both charities, which is normally the proudest moment for the staff and the committee, as they get a chance to see or hear how the money they have raised is going to be used to improve the lives of many people. Looking forward to 2013, when we can do it all over again... We have some ideas already....

item.title: We’re giving away €500 million worth of Life Insurance
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
One of the things we’re always banging on about here in Irish Life is just how important it really is to have Life Insurance, and just how few Irish people actually have a life insurance plan in place. So we’ve decided to do something about it. Starting from today, we will give cover of €25,000 for a year to 20,000 adults. The offer is available online, and through brokers and financial advisers. In addition, we’ve published some research on customer attitudes to life insurance. The key findings from the survey of 1000 people were:
• That 60% of adults in Ireland do not have life insurance which often means that dependents could face significant financial problems in the event of their death.
• That 56% of people say they could struggle financially in the event that something would happen to them. This is an increase of 10% (from 46% to 56%) from March 2011.
• That 34% of adults assume the cost of cover is significantly more expensive than it typically is – they assume that €100,000 of cover will cost more than €50 a month. Whereas in fact for €100,000 cover with our Term Life Insurance plan the price could be less than a third of that amount - just €15 per month for an adult aged 40 or younger, over a 10 year term who is a non-smoker and is in good health.
Life Insurance should be at the core of every family’s financial planning. Last year Irish Life paid out €83m in death claims to 1,168 families. However what may surprise people is that over half of this amount, €45m, was paid in respect of people younger than 55 years old, which is the upper age limit on our Free Parent Insurance promotion. Many of these customers had young families who would have been left financially stranded if they didn’t have life insurance in place and that’s why we’re encouraging all parents to consider whether their family is protected. As well as giving 20,000 parents an extra layer of cover for a year, this promotion highlights the affordability and the benefits of life insurance in the event of a family being faced with a crisis.

item.dc:creator: Conor
item.content:encoded:
A complete breakdown of the number of claims, the average ages of people making claims, and average claim payout per county for 2012, is now available here on our website. The information is broken up into two categories, one for specified illness claims and the other for the number of death claims made.
