A more detailed look at these figures is discussed in one of our previous blogs.

item.title: Irish Life welcomes acquisition by Great-West Lifeco of Canada
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
Great-West Lifeco, the parent company of Canada Life in Ireland, has announced that following negotiations with the Irish Government, it has reached agreement to acquire Irish Life. [caption id="attachment_2141" align="aligncenter" width="380"] Kevin Murphy, Group Chief Executive, Irish Life; Michael Noonan, Minister for Finance; Allen Loney, President and CEO, Great-West Lifeco.[/caption] The transaction is a major vote of confidence in Ireland and will be one of the largest overseas investments ever in the Irish Financial Services sector.
"A transformational deal for our respective businesses in Ireland and for our customers" - Kevin Murphy, Group Chief Executive, Irish Life
It's also very good news for Irish Life customers.  Great-West Lifeco is one of the strongest life assurance companies in the world, with €417 billion of assets under administration.  They are rated AA (Very Strong) by independent ratings agencies Fitch and Standard & Poors.  This financial strength provides an additional layer of reassurance for the Irish Life customers. [caption id="attachment_2136" align="aligncenter" width="380"] Kevin Murphy, Group Chief Executive, Irish Life; Michael Noonan, Minister for Finance; Allen Loney, President and CEO, Great-West Lifeco at the Press Conference announcing the acquisition of Irish Life by Great-West Lifeco[/caption] Future developments The transaction is expected to close by the end of Quarter 2, 2013 and is subject to regulatory approvals. Great-West Lifeco has confirmed that following the transaction the life and pensions operations of Irish Life and Canada Life in Ireland will come together as one combined business, which will operate under the Irish Life brand name. With access to experience and expertise on a global scale, we plan to create a life and pensions company with world class products, customer service and technology to meet your changing needs. Please be assured that your plans with Irish Life will be completely unaffected by this change, and that customers of both organisations will have continuity of products and customer service under Irish Life. As we bring the two companies together, our number one priority is to make sure we take care of our customers and continue to provide outstanding customer service. Thank you for choosing Irish Life to look after your financial needs and we look forward to continuing to serve you in future as part of Great-West Lifeco, one of the world’s leading life assurance companies. More Information
  • Irish Life Press Release
  • Video Podcast from Gerry Hassett, CEO
  • Customer FAQ
item.excerpt:encoded: Great-West Lifeco, the parent company of Canada Life in Ireland, has announced that following negotiations with the Irish Government, it has reached agreement to acquire Irish Life.

item.title: Facebook Like & Share is the new spam.
item.dc:creator: Colin
item.content:encoded: Here’s a little exercise for you: open up your Facebook and log in. Go to your timeline and count the number of posts or photos that have been shared to your timeline by your friends. Now look at those again and identify the number of those that could be considered 'like and share' competitions. By this, I mean those which make 'liking' and 'sharing' the post a condition of entry. On an average day, my timeline is filled with friends, family, casual acquaintances alike, all liking and sharing Facebook pages for no other reason than to be in with a chance of winning something free. Why wouldn't they! At time of writing, a quick look at my own timeline and I can see 3 examples. I’d say that’s typical. [caption id="attachment_2150" align="aligncenter" width="480"] Picture taken from Condescending Brand page: Link[/caption] All of these competitions are in violation of Facebook’s terms of business. Facebook’s response to this type of activity, when made aware of it, is to remove your page. Worse than that, these competitions don’t really work and may be harming your business’ reputation. This type of promotion spams people’s timelines with unwanted and irrelevant content. And if you’re a small business owner or an online marketer, do you really want to be that guy? So why do it? The default raison d’etre for these types of competition is to build Facebook likes on your page. And what’s the harm I hear you say? - We get more likes on our page and somebody gets a nice prize... - Well actually, the harm is twofold; You can like and share a post without actually liking the page. And I mean this both metaphorically and literally. You’ve heard it a thousand times before; any organization embarking on social media marketing must develop some specific goals from the outset. What do you want to achieve, and why do you want to achieve that? Social media has fantastic power as an engagement platform, but the goal has to be meaningful engagement. Someone liking your post just to be in with a chance of winning a prize isn't necessarily interested in your offering. A 'like' should be treated as a means to an end, a signal of genuine interest in what you have to say. It should not be an end in itself. And to state the obvious; Facebookers 'liking and sharing' a competition post from their own newsfeed need never even visit your page, let alone 'like' it! The Lives of Others The second problem concerns those who don't enter your competition; the Facebook friends of those who've 'liked and shared' your post. What impression are they likely to form of the organization filling their newsfeeds with unwanted, irrelevant, spammy, annoying and unoriginal content? When you look at the bottom of a post on your Facebook page and see that ‘X people saw this post’, it’s worth considering what their reaction to it was; If these potential customers view your posts as getting in the way of the stuff they really want to see, are you really better off for having reached them? [caption id="attachment_2152" align="aligncenter" width="522"] Spam.[/caption] So are all competitions bad? Hell no! In Irish life we run competitions all the time on our Facebook page, and we think they are a great way to build engagement and reach people we might not ordinarily reach. The key is to design content that people want to share. Personally I love to see people 'commenting in' their friends in the comments below a post; this tells me they've thought about who might be interested, and specifically included them. Bottom Line Facebook relationships are a social graph, not an interest graph. Friends and family do not necessarily share interests, but most Facebookers are willing to tolerate a certain degree of unwanted content from friends in their newsfeed, because of the overall value that Facebook holds for them. This is not a bountiful well of tolerance, and the minute users start to feel their timeline is being hijacked by content whose express objective is to do just that, you've lost. To make matters worse, this is bad business for Facebook and they will eventually lash out against this type of activity in a more ruthless way than they have to date. When that day comes pages that are caught in the crossfire, either through ignorance of the rules or risk taking, will have nowhere to turn to.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: testing

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Well done, Irish Life, for highlighting this. You're right, asking people to like & share a page, as a condition of entry to a competition, is indeed in breach of Facebook rules & regulations, and not only that, it is annoying. You're completely right in everything you've said here. I would say up to 40% of the posts on my newsfeed daily consist of "like & share" competitions. I find them very irritating but at the same time, they are usually posted by my friends, so I don't like to be rude by replying to them saying that this sort of thing is against FB rules and is annoying me! So instead, I'm going to share your post and get my message across in a more subtle way, thanks! ;o)

item.title: How do you put a value on peace of mind?
item.dc:creator: Karl
item.content:encoded:
"They saw you coming!" My wife on hearing how much I’d agreed to pay for our new double-glazing. I recently got around to buying two things that had been on the “family to-do” list for ages. Our windows had been in the house when we moved in almost 15 years ago and I’d managed to kid myself I was saving money by putting that off – I probably spent twice as much in lost heating. And two weeks ago I finally bought a new car.  I say new in the “new to me” but old to the person who had put nearly 100,000 kilometres on the clock. Still it means that I get to be the weekend taxi service for my kids’ soccer, football, basketball, piano and tennis activities. Anyway what I found funny was my son’s reaction – “why would you buy a car that’s almost 7 years old and why didn’t you get that Audi TT that you always wanted!”.  He was right. I really did want the TT – the mind wondered again for a minute thinking about the soft-top with the roof down and the wind blowing through the hair.  This beautiful moment was interrupted by “What hair Dad?”.  Anyway I had bought an Audi ….A3 and it would do the job!
That’s a lot of people walking around carrying a huge financial risk for their families, possibly for as little as €15 a month?
  It got me thinking about that old discussion about what’s more important  – the price of the good or service itself or the value that you’ll ultimately derive from it.   And how do people put a value on things that they’re not really buying for themselves but for someone else, such as their family. For example our customer research shows us that people think Life insurance is twice as expensive as it actually is. That’s why over 3 in 5 people, such as young parents, think that they won’t be able to afford it. That’s a lot of people walking around carrying a huge financial risk for their families, possibly for as little as €15 a month? [caption id="attachment_2177" align="aligncenter" width="350"] Try our Life Insurance Calculator today[/caption] That’s why we’ve been trying to encourage parents over the last year to take a look for themselves and see what great value life insurance really is.  For example for just €15 a month a 35 year old could buy over €125,000 of life insurance for 20 years with our Term Insurance Plan.  Of course as with all life insurance the price you pay will depend on your health.  You can use our straight-forward life insurance tool to see how much cover you could get for €15 a month – it’ll only take you a couple of minutes. I think you’ll be pleasantly surprised – it’ll be one more item to mark off the family “to-do” list
item.excerpt:encoded: So whats more important, the price of something or the value that you'll ultimately derive from it?

item.title: Time to start thinking about the skin you're in
item.dc:creator: T.J.
item.content:encoded:
So we are into the month of May, into the Summer, although you wouldn't think it by looking out the window.  With the increase in temperatures comes also an increase in the risk of Melanoma or Skin Cancer. May is National Melanoma Awareness month, and unfortunately it is a condition that is on the rise in this country.  Even though there is no comparison with the weather, more people now die of Melanoma in the UK than in Australia. The infographic below shows some facts about claims paid out by Irish Life for Malignant Melanoma cases for the last five years.  Click on image to enlarge.

Like all forms of Cancer, prevention is much better than seeking a cure, and the Irish Cancer Society have some useful tips on their website to help to prevent contracting the disease.
  •  Avoid the sun between 11am and 3pm
  • Wear protective clothing
  • Always wear sunscreen, apply every 2 hours, more often if swimming or perspiring
  • Avoid tanning beds or sunbeds
item.excerpt:encoded: May is National Melanoma Awareness month, and even though we may think that the Irish weather doesn't create much risk of contracting it, the facts are that it is a disease on the rise in this country.

item.title: Do I need illness and life insurance?
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded:
Consider this story ...

Mr & Mrs Smith are an affluent couple in late 30’s/early 40's. They have 6 children – 3 biological, 3 adopted. He is an actor and she is involved in humanitarian causes. They both look incredibly healthy. They were approached several years ago about life & illness cover but their Financial Advisor was unable to explain the value of this to them.

Then disaster struck. Mrs Smith’s mother died of ovarian cancer at age 56. Mrs Smith then decided to take a predictive genetic test to see whether she carried the mutated genes. On confirmation that she did carry the gene responsible for breast cancer, Mrs Smith took the incredibly difficult decision to take preventative measures through bilateral mastectomy (surgery to remove both breasts).

According to the medical statistics, while only about 5% of breast cancers can be directly attributed to a family history of breast cancer, if you are in this particular risk category, then the chances are unfortunately high that you will develop breast cancer.

So Mrs Smith realised there was a risk to her and did something brave to reduce this risk. Her risk of developing breast cancer is now reduced from almost 90% to around 10%.

We can all reduce our own individual risk of developing cancer; e.g., stop smoking, lose weight, eat more fruit and veg, drink less alcohol etc.

But the crux is that whilst we can reduce our risk, we cannot eliminate it altogether. Mrs Smith still has a 10% chance of contracting breast cancer notwithstanding her surgery.

However, Irish Life can help Mr & Mrs Smith do something positive to protect her family if the unfortunate happens. In our view they both need cover – both life and illness cover - more than ever now.

The good news is that they would be most likely acceptable risks (although Mrs Smith will probably have an exclusion for breast cancer). Most people would think that Mr & Mrs Smith’s opportunity to get cover had passed – when actually they need it now more than ever.

  In the last 7 years Irish life has paid out 590 specified illness claims for malignant breast cancer to a value of €38.9m. The youngest claimant was just 29 years old. And by the way, males can get breast cancer too - we've actually paid 5 claims to males for breast cancer in the last year or so.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Wow your post really hits home why everyone needs illness AND life insurance. Doesn't make sense to me why people don't get it. Must be a bad financial adviser, they've never been known for bad advice have they? Ha!
Great story, loved the post. Keep it up!
Ash

item.title: It's a Dad's Life, or is it?
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded:
"Some people ask what’s the secret to a good marriage?   Twice a week; we take time to go to a nice restaurant, candlelight, a little wine, soft music. She goes Tuesdays. I go Fridays." - Anon  
This Sunday is Father’s Day. Now on Mother’s Day I’m expected to have a nice card and maybe some chocolates or perfume on hand (which I pretend my children have bought). I’ve no problem with that – Mums are special. However, Father’s Day seems to be a non-event in our house. I could be waiting long time for any sign of appreciation. To be honest I’d even settle for a pair of socks at this stage.  We did a survey of attitudes recently and it seems I’m not alone – only 1 in 3 Dads say their kids appreciate them, while less than half say their wives or partners appreciate them! In fact our research shows  found that Mums and Dads don’t see eye to eye on a lot of things!. For example -
  • • Dad says he spends an average of 55 hours a week on housework or childcare – Mum says it’s more like half that at 29 hours!
  • • Dad enjoys about 23 hours a week free time – about double what Mum gets.
  • • Dad thinks he spends 14 hours quality time a week with his partner, she thinks it’s just 10 hours (she doesn’t count watching sport!).
  Click the images below to see the full size infographs.   This might be a bit of fun but there’s an important financial point at the end of it. Dad’s may feel under-appreciated by their families, but this also means they underestimate the financial consequences to their families if they were not there.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: fathers day
Happy Fathers Day!

item.title: Win a family holiday in Disneyland Paris
item.dc:creator: T.J.
item.content:encoded:
With Secondary schools already on their Summer break, and Primary schools about to close down for the Summer break, parents across the country are scratching their heads and counting the cents to plan and pay for that family holiday that will appeal to all siblings in the family. There is no doubt about it, but Disneyland ticks all boxes on that front.  Everyone of us, young and old, have grown up with the Disney characters, so from the moment you enter the theme park, you are transported into a nostalgia filled journey of childhood memories.  If the memories are not enough for you, then the adrenaline rush from some of the most famous and exhilarating theme park rides like Space Mountain might make the holiday one to remember.
 you are transported into a nostalgia filled journey of childhood memories
[caption id="attachment_1946" align="alignleft" width="100"] Click to enter[/caption] Well you might be wondering why I am here extolling the virtues of Disneyland Paris in this blog.  No, we are not branching out in to the travel agent industry, but we are giving one lucky person the chance to win a family holiday in Disneyland Paris, and it couldn't be easier. You will find all you need to enter by clicking the link to the left.  Closing date is Friday 28th June, so time is running out.
item.excerpt:encoded: Looking for somewhere to bring the family on summer holidays but can't afford to, then our latest competition might provide the answer for you.

item.title: Market Review - Week 26
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“It takes considerable knowledge to realise the extent of your own ignorance”. Thomas Sowell  
  • Markets started the week on a quiet but negative note with worse than forecast industrial data in the US at the end of the previous week and a small softening the University of Michigan consumer confidence survey concerning traders
 
  • In the UK, the Rightmove House Price index increased again in June bringing total gains for the year to +2.7%. Interestingly, the recovery in house prices outside of London and the Southeast is gathering pace with prices up 9.2% in the North of the country
 
  • In Ireland there was good news on the export front with the April volumes up 4% and stemming the sharp slowdown experienced in the second half of 2012
 
  • The US is also showing signs of a housing recovery with the home builders’ confidence survey hitting 52 in June (from 44 in May), a level last seen in 2006. The poor reading in May looks to have been a temporary phenomenon
 
  • Inflation is on the move – US headline rates have gone from 1.1% to 1.4% and in the UK from 2.4% to 2.6%
 
  • The major market event this week was the indication from the Federal Reserve Chairman, Ben Bernanke, that their bond purchase programme (which has been supporting markets) will now be tapered off in 2013 and finish completely in 2014. Equity markets were surprised by this move and reacted negatively as a perceived support was removed. Bond markets also reacted negatively and yields moved higher. Bond investors interpreted the move as a signal that the underlying economy was perhaps stronger than previously thought
 
  • Equity investors were also hit by a weak Chinese manufacturing survey number inflaming fears over the health of the economy. It fell to 48.3 indicating a decline in manufacturing
 
  • Despite the turbulent week for markets, it ended on a higher note for Ireland. The EU Finance Ministers have agreed to allow the ESM to directly recapitalize banks directly. What does that mean? It means Europe may put up to €16bn into Irish banks in the long term
 
  • The story of the week for me…both amazes and horrifies me in equal measure. Nivea, the people who aim to protect you skin from the harmful rays of the sun, are running an ad campaign in Brazil showing a paper-thin solar panel with a USB plug that aims to recharge your phone without needing an electrical socket – even on a beach! This “talk’n’tan” strategy surely spells the end for the beach as one of the last sanctuaries of peace from the digital chatter in offices, buses, trains, planes and just about everywhere else. (Un)Fortunately, this device is unlikely to make it to Ireland. Something about needing sunshine to work….

item.title: Market Review - Week 27
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Between two evils, I always pick the one I never tried before”. Mae West  
  • Market continued to be weak on Monday post Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke paving the way for a reduction in the bond buying programme that has supported markets for some time now
 
  • US 10 year yields rose over 0.40% in a week to touch 2.6% and the dollar has strengthened to $1.31 against the Euro as investors move money into dollars as interest rates improve
 
  • Ireland’s upcoming budget was the subject of much debate as the government consider their options around €1bn saved via the Anglo promissory note. Pressure will mount to give something back to the taxpayer although it would come at the expense of eliminating our budget deficit. European eyes will be watching
 
  • Mortgage arrears here were also in focus as the number of owner occupiers in 90+ days arrears rose from 11.9% to 12.3%. That figure increases to 19.7% for the buy-to-let market
 
  • Global markets are still unsure where the next leg of growth is coming from. What is becoming clear, however, is that the US recovery is fragile and China is not firing on all cylinders. Europe appears to be the beacon of light for the short term where economic indicators are still edging higher
 
  • Commodity prices are still under pressure with copper, aluminium and nickel all hitting 52 week lows recently. Clearly, this is impacting on Emerging Markets performance
 
  • Late in the week data on the Irish economy for H2 2012 emerged showing that although it was essentially flat, the falloff in export led growth was offset with a rise in domestic spending
 
  • However, GDP for Q1 has shown a weak start to 2013 and domestic demand will be key to maintaining at least flat performance year on year
 
  • House prices in Ireland look to have cooled again although volatile, down 0.8% in April. The market is still guessing what impact the legislation around repossessions may have on prices and liquidity in the market. In the UK, house prices continue their rally
 
  • The story of the week for me…is as scary as it is bizarre. Huggies, the nappy people, have aired an advert in which dads can now be a more integral part of pregnancy. They have developed a special “belly” belt prospective fathers can wear which simulates real time kicks and movements via sensors in a belt worn by mum. Huggies defended the product for dads saying “they’re pregnant too” and this was a way of “compensating” them. Before someone invents the “birthing belt”, perhaps men should draw the line at celebrating the birth with one too many drinks and their own take on morning sickness…

item.title: Market Review - Week 28
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“When I despair, I remember that all through history, the way of truth and love has always won. There have been tyrants and murderers and, for a time, they seem invincible but in the end, they always fall. Always.” Mahatma Gandhi  
  • Markets started the week on a positive note with the US ISM manufacturing survey increasing to 50.9, indicating a modest pick-up
 
  • UK mortgage approvals in May hit a high since 2009 implying a robust recovery in the housing market
 
  • At home, Irish exchequer returns for June were positive with better than expected revenues, and cuts in current and capital spending. This left us about €800m better off (0.5% GDP) and makes our year-end target of a 7.4% deficit look very comfortable
 
  • Further good news was contained in the Irish PMI (purchasing managers’ index) which rose to 54.9 in June up from 52.7 in May, with service companies adding jobs at the fastest pace since January. Crucially this survey has tended to be a good lead indicator
 
  • Portuguese political instability caused markets to wobble midweek when it was announced that the government had lost the leader of its junior coalition partner. This caused the yields on their sovereign bonds to temporarily hit 8%
 
  • Irish unemployment fell again in June, from 13.7% in May to 13.6%, which seasonally adjusted is the lowest rate since August 2009. Interestingly, it was not only emigration and employment growth helping the numbers but a reduction in the number of new claims also
 
  • The week finished on a very positive note for equities with unexpected guidance from the Bank of England and the ECB that interest rates would remain low. The Euro Stoxx 50 was up 2.8% on the day. Bonds markets were largely unchanged on the news
 
  • The story of the week for me…should start with “play it again Sam”. The most famous grand piano maker in the world has agreed to be bought by the private equity firm Kohlberg & Co for a whopping $438m in cash. The 160 year old company, who were founded in a loft on Manhattan’s lower west side, sell their grand pianos for up to $218,000 each. They also make saxophones, clarinets and trombones amongst other instruments but have made their name in grand pianos and are a firm favourite with the concert pianists. The deal appears to be part of a move back into luxury goods by private equity firms looking to capitalise on the recovering finances of the well to do. Needless to say when it comes to all things luxury, China has been the fastest growing market for the company since 2005.

item.title: Market Review - Week 29
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“If the facts don’t fit the theory, change the facts.” Albert Einstein  
  • Markets have been volatile of late with strong gains on one day being offset by losses the next. Most recently, strong gains driven by optimistic sounds from the Bank of England and the ECB around maintaining low interest rates going forward were knocked on the head by the US Fed reinforcing the markets view they would initiate the withdrawal of the monthly asset purchases from September
 
  • The Euro Stoxx 50 started the week well up 2.1% on Monday driven by increased optimism around growth prospects and the euro also gained against the dollar
 
  • Ireland are to start discussions with the Troika about exiting the bailout programme, however, it would still require a potential emergency line of credit for the banks particularly with a banks stress test scheduled for 2014
 
  • The UK industrial production data for May was disappointing for April and May but encouragingly it has not prevented the IMF from revising up its forecast for UK growth form 0.3% in 2013 to 0.9%. Every little helps…
 
  • The UK housing market is proving resilient with the RICS survey at a 3 year high
 
  • The dollar weakened against the Euro significantly late in the week with a statement from Fed Chairman, Ben Bernanke, that monetary policy would remain accommodative for the foreseeable future. The rate touched off $1.32 on the day. Stock markets however responded very well to the news
 
  • News flow around Irish consumer spending has been weak of late, however, the most recent measure of Consumer Confidence has hit its highest point since 2007. Lower inflation has helped, driven by a fall in energy and mortgage costs
 
  • Car sales in Ireland around the new 132 plate have proven interesting with more cars sold in the first week of July this year (4,675) than the entire month of July last year (4,424)
 
  • The story of the week for me…is a dirty one, but not what you might be thinking. In fact this is the kind of dirt that could kill you prematurely. Specifically we are talking about smog and the 5.5 years it could cut form your life expectancy if you live in certain parts of China. In the north of the country the high levels of smog experienced cause increased lung cancer, heart attacks and strokes. It is a regular occurrence to see a run on air filters in your local shop when the air quality takes a dip. The really scary statistic in all of this featured in a report from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who calculated that air pollution caused the loss of 2.5 billion years of life expectancy in the 1990’s alone.

item.title: Market Review - Week 30
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“To alcohol! The cause of, and solution to, all of life’s problems.” Homer Simpson  
  • Markets in Europe are back in focus for international investors with news that the opposition socialist party in Portugal are demanding a renegotiation of the terms of their bailout programme. Their 10 yr sovereign bond yields continue to range between 7-7.5% as a result
 
  • Ireland was the beneficiary of some good news from the rating agencies with S&P ugrading the outlook on Irish debt from “stable” to “positive”. In stark contrast, Moody’s continue to rate Irish debt as sub-investment grade and with a negative outlook. However, they did issue a note last weekend suggesting that sustained economic growth would cause them to review their rating with an upward bias
 
  • Chinese GDP for Q2 was released early in the week and was +7.5% on 2012. Although in line with market expectations, it provided a boost to market sentiment
 
  • US retail sales, although up 0.4% for June, were below expectations. Consumer sentiment has dipped recently although still remains above the 2007 highs.
 
  • US inflation also fell modestly to 1.6%. The Federal Reserve will be watching that very carefully to avoid any further signs of weakness. They would like to see some inflation in the system to signal underlying strength in the economy
 
  • UK inflation is running at closer to 3%, above their 2% target but not an immediate cause for concern with other pricing indicators showing signs of weakness
 
  • The week ended positively for markets with the Euro Stoxx 50 up 1.4% and the S&P up 0.5% driven by better than expected US unemployment numbers. They were the lowest since May at 334,000
 
  • In Europe, sentiment received a welcome boost when the Spanish government held a successful debt auction raising over €3bn
 
  • The story of the week for me…is an educational one. Literally. The US based accreditation body, AACSB, have published their findings for 2013 on graduate and undergraduate education, which makes for some interesting reading. It seems the US have 9,799 business degree programmes. There are only 1,786 in Europe. In 2012, over 156,000 students enrolled on an MBA programme in the US. The number for the rest of the world combined was only 110,000! Maybe that is because 493 ‘schools’ in the US offer the MBA. Outside of the US there are only 194 ‘schools’ offering the same programme. So in a world where who you know can sometimes be just as important as what you know….if you have an MBA, the chances are you got it in the US.

item.title: Market Review - Week 31
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“There is no sin except stupidity.” Oscar Wilde  
  • Markets had a soft start to the week on the back of poorer than expected results in the technology sector in the US led by global giants Microsoft and Google
 
  • That was followed by poorer than expected US existing home sales figures. The S&P 500 still managed to finish up on the day which may indicate that investors think the weak housing numbers could delay the Federal Reserve reducing its support for the economy. Later in the week however, new home sales hit a 5 year high and the S&P 500 fell.
 
  • The Japanese government upgraded their growth forecasts early last week which help lift the major Asian markets. Their stock market is up over 30% year to date already in local currency
 
  • Closer to home, in more ways than one, Ireland witnessed its first annual rise in property prices since 2008. Dublin is leading the way with prices up 4.2% year on year, while the rest of the country is actually down 1%, a function of the oversupply that still exists outside the capital. Anecdotally, even within Dublin the market it is very localised and reduced supply in some areas has caused prices to rise over 10% in the same period. With house building at subdued levels, it is difficult to see this situation abating in the short term. Legislation around repossessions may offer increased liquidity in the Dublin market later in the year
 
  • The Purchasing Managers Index for Europe provided a 1.4% midweek boost to the Euro Stoxx 50. The index rose to 50.4 in July (over 50 indicating expansion), the first such reading since early 2012
 
  • Housing stats in the UK continue to impress with monthly construction data suggesting output bounced back in Q2. April was up 4.6% on the previous year and May was flat. UK GDP growth is likely to be driven by the domestic economy in the short term and turning around one of the weakest sectors in the last few years will go a long way towards achieving that
 
  • The week ended on a positive note for Europe with a rise in the German IFO business sentiment survey
 
  • The story of the week for me…was about football. At the end of a league season in football each team adds up the points awarded for winning or drawing games. Where two teams have equal points, the winner is chosen based on goal difference - the total number of goals you scored minus the number of goals scored against you. Whoever has the largest goal difference wins. Such a situation occurred recently in Nigeria and raised eyebrows when Plateau United Feeders beat Arkurba 79-0 in the last game of the season, while the other team sharing top spot, Police Machine, beat their opponents Bubayaro 67-0. Clearly, both teams were trying to get their goal difference as high as possible. Needless to say, the players and officials from all four teams involved have been banned for life. For the record, the top scorer for Police Machine scored 11 goals…his best game all season!!

item.title: Is SEPA the New Y2K?
item.dc:creator: Darragh OFlanagan
item.content:encoded:
The General Gist: You may have heard the acronyms SEPA, BIC or IBAN recently. Have you wondered what they meant but quickly forgotten about them? If so, then you wouldn’t be alone. SEPA is the Single Euro Payments Area which comprises a total of 32 countries (so far). Its aim is to standardise Euro payments across Europe for businesses and consumers. This comes into full effect from February 1st 2014. The main things you’ll need to know about are BIC and IBAN numbers: Business Identifier Code (BIC): a unique identification code for both financial and non-financial institutions. It’s kind of like your bank sort code but it specifies a particular business, country and region all within the one BIC. International Bank Account Number (IBAN): an international means of identifying bank accounts across national borders. This is what you’ll use instead of your bank account number from February onwards. The format of these is different for every country but for Ireland this one IBAN will contain your country code, sort code and bank account number. Are you with me so far? The concept isn’t too daunting once you know the basics. However, now you may be thinking that you can simply ignore SEPA and go about your daily routine. I’m afraid not! SEPA is a mandatory EU Regulation so all businesses will have to conform to SEPA by the 1st February 2014. Bank account numbers and sort codes will be a thing of the past and replaced with IBAN and BIC for all businesses in Europe. Now for the Hard Part: Irish Life has been around for a long time (1939 to be exact), so you can imagine that bank accounts and sort codes have been part of our business processes for eons. With the introduction of SEPA we now have to convert all of our systems and processes to be in line with European regulations. It’s similar to Y2K in the sense that organisations Europe wide need to check and upgrade heavily integrated features of their IT systems before a fixed date. No small task! I’m currently working as a lead IT developer on the SEPA project and as a result I get to delve into the bowels of the business like never before. It is challenging work but the change will enable businesses and consumers to make payments to 32 countries and will in turn facilitate trade and strengthen European competitiveness. To quote Martin Luther King Jr.,
 Our very survival depends on our ability to stay awake, to adjust to new ideas, to remain vigilant and to face the challenge of change.
For more information about SEPA visit: http://www.readyforsepa.ie/ and check back over the next while for more updates on how changes to our systems for SEPA impact our business.
item.excerpt:encoded: You may have heard the acronyms SEPA, BIC or IBAN recently. Have you wondered what they meant but quickly forgotten about them? If so, then you wouldn’t be alone.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: SEPA, IBAN

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks Darragh for this well explained post. Absolutely SEPA is going to rule the payment structure of European countries. As the deadline date for switching to SEPA is very close all the bank and financial services provider are busy to complete all the formats required for SEPA Migration. Even there are few bank say for example ING who have already completed the SEPA transition and working on that and most of the companies are done with their SEPA planning.
omega 時計... ブランド 腕時計 レディース...

item.title: Unravelling the Mystery of IBAN
item.dc:creator: Darragh OFlanagan
item.content:encoded:
The Basic Stuff: The International Bank Account Number (IBAN) is an internationally agreed means of identifying bank accounts across national borders. From February 1st 2014 this will replace bank account numbers and sort codes in Ireland. Not all countries use the same format for the number. However, they all have some common features. Irish IBANs: What’s in an IBAN? Banks in this country provide you with an IBAN made up of 22 letters & numbers. The structure is shown below (for Ireland only). IEdd aaaa bbbb bbcc cccc cc • IE is the country code for Ireland • dd is the check digit for validation • aaaa is the bank code • bbbbbb is the sort code • cccccccc is the account number All IBANs begin with a country code, so the very first thing you can do is assess what nation it’s referencing. The check digit is calculated using a specific mathematical computation which you won’t need to worry about doing yourself. Bank codes are letters which specify an organisation (e.g. Bank of Ireland would be BOFI). Sort codes and account numbers remain the same as they currently are. So if your account is (1) in Ireland, (2) with AIB, (3) has a sort code of 01-02-03 and (4) an account number of 12345678, the result would be as below. IE23 AIBK 0102 0312 3456 78 Simple as that! Now for the Hard Part: Irish Life is Ireland's leading life, investment and pension company so we are well used to dealing with accounts based in Irish banks. However, with the introduction of IBAN we have to be able to accept payments from any bank within the 32 SEPA countries around Europe. Given that not all countries use the same IBAN format this can be a tricky business but at the same time it opens up payment options to a whole new international level. Irish Life as a company are committing to enhancements which contribute to an overall European effort. Why is this change good for the consumer? Well, you’ll be able set up payments with us just like any other company in the SEPA region. 32 countries, 1 IBAN, easy! To quote Vince Lombardi;
Individual commitment to a group effort—that is what makes a team work, a company work, a society work, a civilization work.
item.excerpt:encoded: The International Bank Account Number (IBAN) is an internationally agreed means of identifying bank accounts across national borders.

item.title: Canadian with his finger on the pulse of Irish Life
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded: Canadian Bill Kyle loves sport and has wasted no time in immersing himself in Gaelic games since landing here on July 1st to take over as Irish Life chief executive. He was at the Dublin-Cork hurling semi-final and the Dublin-Kerry football equivalent, both lauded as classic matches. It might explain the Dublin jersey with Kyle’s name printed on the back hanging on its lonesome from a coat rack in his generously proportioned corner office on the ninth floor of the Irish Life building on Abbey Street.  And the hurley and sliotar in Cork and Clare colours respectively, draped across one on the window sills.  “They were just unbelievable matches,” he says in a discernible north American accent. To read the rest of this interview, click here
item.excerpt:encoded: The following is an interview with Bill Kyle taken from the Irish Times on Friday 20th September

item.title: Market Review - Week 33
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“You can never cross the ocean unless you have the courage to lose sight of the shore.” Christopher Columbus  
  • Ireland got off to a strong start to the short week with exchequer returns for July indicating government finances are in good shape and still on track to beat its deficit target. Tax revenues are marginally ahead year to date, driven in large part by the +12.6% increase in Corporation tax. Government expenditure is also slightly better than expected. While the spending budget was reduced by 1.8%, the actual amount spent was 15.9% below target. This means we could beat our 7.4% GDP deficit by around 0.5% this year
 
  • The US had a quiet start to the week despite the strong services sector surveys. The non-manufacturing ISM rose to 56 in July from 52.2 in June. A number greater than 50 indicates expansion within the sector
 
  • In the bigger picture, the US and Eurozone have been instrumental in driving the Global Purchasing Managers Index to 54.1 in July, its highest level since March 2012 and indicative of the further strengthening of the world economy over the summer months
 
  • Irish consumer confidence figures were released at the back end of the week and, although
they fell a little in July, they are still close to the highest readings since 2008.  
  • Irish car sales reported for July were very strong with 11,500 cars sold, compared to only 4,432 sold this time last year
 
  • Irish CPI inflation was 0.7% in July, unchanged from June. However, this number largely reflects external pricing. If you strip out energy and mortgage interest, CPI inflation was 1.1% in July. Indeed, looking only at Services price inflation the number excluding mortgage interest is closer to 2.3%
 
  • Chinese export numbers at the end of the week were up strongly at +5.1% in the year t the end of July. This coincided with the release of Chinese industrial production numbers which showed a 9.7% increase year to date, up from +8.9% in June
 
  • The story of the week for me…is as scary as it is interesting. Sergey Brin, the billionaire founder of Google, has emerged as the investor behind a bizarre project – laboratory grown beef. The first public tasting of a “burger” took place in London yesterday. The investment by Brin enabled scientists to produce enough lab-grown fibres to make three 140g (5oz) burgers, with each containing 20,000 muscle fibres grown in special chambers. The UN Food and Agriculture Organisation estimate that demand for meat will grow 73% by 2050 and demand will be environmentally unsustainable due to shortages of land to feed the extra livestock (not to mention the subsequent greenhouse emissions!) Despite the fact that it apparently tasted “meaty but rather dry”, nobody seems to have picked on the fact that these burgers cost €233,333.33 each. One problem solved, one to go…

item.title: Market Review - Week34
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Bart, with $10,000 we’d be millionaires! We could buy all sorts of useful things…like love!” Homer Simpson  
  • The week got off to a quiet start with much of the positive momentum around the Chinese economy being offset by continued speculation around when the Fed will start to reduce the $85bn it currently spends every month buying back bonds
 
  • US treasury yields have traded up in recent weeks on the back of this speculation and currently trade at over 2.8%
 
  • UK house prices are officially expanding at a faster rate than any time since November 2006 with all regions in the UK benefitting from the increase in pricing
 
  • Technology companies were to the fore in the US with Apple recording a particularly strong day (+4.75%) after Carl Icahn disclosed on Twitter that his company had a “large position” in the company. Mixed fortunes for Blackberry though, as the company recently put itself up for sale but has found there to be little interest at this stage
 
  • US banks are starting to show some confidence in Europe as lending to selective Eurozone banks from their US counterparts picks up
 
  • Euro area GDP growth was positive at +0.3% for Q2 2013
 
  • Irish trade data for June was also positive with goods export volumes up 2.3% in Q2 after a sharp fall of 4.9% in Q1. This fall was largely driven by the difficulties in the pharma sector early in the year but this data suggests the worst may be behind us
 
  • At the back end of the week we got confirmation that US inflation is now running at 2%, which may further incline the Fed to cut back on its spending given the continued fall in the jobless claims at the same time
 
  • UK 10 year government bond yields are following the same path as the US with sellers forcing prices down and yields up to 2.7%, with similar effects in Germany where the yield is now 1.9%
 
  • The story of the week for me…was about jobs. Not just any old jobs, dream jobs. There are not many people who can claim to have theirs but Hannah Fraser certainly does. From the age of nine, she got her first taste of what it would be to be a mermaid when her mother helped her design a costume. Having tasted some success as a photographer and a brief modelling career, she became a full time professional mermaid! Her work includes underwater modelling and performance art. She recently launched a range of diving watches for Omega at an event in Capri and now lives in Hollywood. Living the dream..

item.title: Markert Review - Week35
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Weather forecast for tonight: dark...” George Carlin  
  • The US FOMC (Federal Open Market Committee) released their monthly minutes confirming that the Fed will begin to taper QE (Quantitative Easing) before the end of this year, possibly as soon as the end of Q3. The FOMC also expressed that they expect this exercise to finish by the middle of next year.
   
  • Emerging market assets were hit hard due to the market’s reaction towards the FOMC minutes which resulted in increased expectations that global liquidity will diminish as the US Federal Reserve withdraws stimulus from the economy.
   
  • Japanese exports slipped for the first time in eight months in July, as subdued demand in key markets such as the US and Asia offset the boost to manufactures from a falling Yen.
   
  • Irish property prices were released for July – prices in Dublin were up 3.3% on the month and 8.8% YoY (Year-on-Year), the single largest monthly rise since 2005. The trend in Dublin is one of growth, underpinned by a shortage of supply. Outside the capital, prices fell 0.1% on the month and 1.5% Year on Year.
   
  • Figures published by the CSO highlight how austerity has impacted consumer spending, with expenditure on goods and services falling by 12% since 2008. An analysis of the CPI (Consumer Price Index) shows health insurance has more than doubled, while the cost of education has jumped by 30%, public transport by 29%, electricity by 31%, and gas by 27%. Total expenditure on food, drink, and tobacco has fallen by 5%, while money spent on mortgage interest and rents has fallen by 11%.
   
  • The Eurozone’s recovery eked out further gains in august as the Composite Markit Purchasing Managers’ Index, combining both manufacturing and services sector, rose to 51.7 in a “flash” or preliminary reading for August from 50.5 in July – its highest level in two years. (Any reading above 50 indicates overall growth). New manufacturing orders, particularly in Germany, drove this expansion.
   
  • The story of the week for me….involves the Norwegian Prime Minister pretending to be a taxi driver demonstrating his charm to voters, which ultimately backfired when it transpired that passengers were paid for the ride and most cut the journey short due to his bad driving!

item.title: Market Review - Week36
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“One person with a belief is equal to a force of ninety-nine with only interest” John Stuart Mill  
  • Speculation that Greece may need a further debt write-down as well as a third, smaller bailout package was fuelled by comments from the Greek Finance Minister last weekend. But with the domino effect of the last haircut fresh in investors’ minds, it remains an unlikely probability in the short term. Nevertheless, the budgetary arithmetic for 2014 still points to a €11bn shortfall which may need to be plugged by a third, smaller bailout.
 
  • Orders for US durable goods were released this week, recording their biggest drop in almost a year in July (-7.3% vs. expected 4%). While the sharp fall in orders in the volatile aircraft sector was expected, the core orders series (ex-aircraft) also declined 0.6% over the month versus an expected 0.5% rise.
 
  • The CSO reported for the year to the end of June that the number of people in employment has risen by 33,800. Figures released show a 1.8% increase in the numbers in work, which now stands at 1,869,900. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate now stands at 13.7%. The CSO figures also suggest that public sector pay has risen by 1.3% over the 12 months to the end of June, at a higher rate than wages in the private sector.
 
  • The Bank of England Governor, Mark Carney, gave his maiden speech striking a typically dovish tone (promoting monetary policies that involve the maintenance of low interest rates). Carney spoke of labour productivity in the economy which must increase to catch up with trend growth, meaning a more gradual improvement in unemployment and consequently a lower bank rate.
 
  • Irish emigration statistics continue to rise. At one stage there was a person leaving the country every six minutes, which is the highest number since records began back in the 1980’s. What is particularly striking is that more than a third of the people leaving to set up a new life abroad are between the ages of 15 and 24.
 
  • In company news it has emerged that Steve Ballmer, the CEO of Microsoft, is to step down after spending 30 years in the company, much of which was spent beside his friend and former CEO, Bill Gates.
   
  • The story of the week for me….comes from the Edinburgh Fringe festival. They run a competition for the funniest one liner, which this year was won by the English comedian Rob Auton for his one-liner - "I heard a rumour that Cadbury is bringing out an oriental chocolate bar. Could be a Chinese Wispa."

item.title: Market Review - Week37
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Without a struggle, there can be no progress” Frederick Douglas  
  • The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) released their latest Interim Economic Assessment noting a moderate recovery is underway in the major advanced economies. The report outlined that the euro area as a whole is technically out of recession and economic growth in the major advanced economies is expected to continue at a similar pace in the second half of 2013.
 
  • The European Central Bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged following data suggesting that the economy in the single currency area is recovering.
 
  • The Eurozone Manufacturing PMI (Purchasing Managers' Index) rose to reach its highest level since June 2011 posting a reading of 51.3 (a reading above 50 is indicative of expansion and a reading below 50 is indicative of contraction). The PMI has now signalled expansion for two consecutive months.
 
  • UK survey data this week indicated that the UK Manufacturing and Services sectors maintained a robust start to the third quarter of 2013 with growth rates for both variables at their highest since 1994. The seasonally adjusted Markit Purchasing Manager’s Index (PMI) hit a two-and-a-half year high of 57.2 in August. The PMI has now signalled expansion for five successive months.
 
  • US employers added 169,000 jobs in August. In its monthly employment report, the Bureau of Labour Statistics lowered the combined total for job gains in June and July by 74,000. This suggests that the labour-market recovery is weaker than first thought and could defer the Federal Reserve's plans to reduce its monthly bond-buying programme.
 
  • Irish exchequer returns released over the week showed a slippage in tax receipts against government targets. The most puzzling aspect was a 0.6% shortfall in income tax, despite the 1.8% rise in employment in the year to Q2. Nevertheless, the government remains on course to hit this year's deficit target.
 
  • The story of the week for me…. Was about the latest addition to the skyline of London, a glass clad 37-storey tower dubbed the “Walkie Talkie,” which was blamed last week for melting parts of a car parked on the street below. The building reflects the sun’s rays with such intensity that you can even fry an egg standing in a specific location in the street below the building.

item.title: Market Review - Week38
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
"Continuous effort not strength or intelligence is the key to unlocking potential." Winston Churchill   France, the Eurozone's second biggest economy, cut its 2014 growth forecast and confirmed that it will overshoot budget deficit targets this year. France hasn't posted a budget surplus in any year since 1974, while it has had a trade deficit every year since 2002.   Irish CPI (Consumer Price Index) inflation fell to a three-year low of 0.2% in August. This primarily reflects lower energy prices and mortgage interest costs. Excluding these items, CPI inflation was 0.7% in August. Services price inflation (ex-mortgage interest) was 2.3%, indicative of a gradually reflating economy and the return of positive wage growth in 2012 and 2013.   Although growth outlook is mixed across Emerging Markets in Asia, the latest Asian Business Cycle Indicators (ABCIs) suggest signs of growth stabilisation for China and a more positive outlook for the Philippines and Singapore. The key downside risk facing Southeast Asia, China and India is the prospect of the tapering of quantitative easing (QE) policy in the US.   China's exports rose in August while inflation remained subdued, exports are up 7.2% yoy (year on year) in August. Imports also rose last month, gaining 7%. Total foreign trade grew 7.1% in August over the same month in 2012. The trade surplus widened by 8.4% yoy to 28.52bn last month, the highest since January this year.   Consumer Confidence in the U.S. declined to the lowest level since April, indicating household spending may take time to pick up. The Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan preliminary index of consumer sentiment has fallen to 76.8 this month from August’s 82.1.   According to the Office for National Statistics the United States unemployment rate fell to 7.7 % in the three months through July from 7.8 % in the second quarter (Q2).   The story of the week for me…. Was an article outlining Greece's next wave of austerity driven reforms, which are aimed at improving the civil service. Public sector workers will no longer enjoy a privilege they have had for more than two decades - six extra days of paid holiday every year if they use a computer at work.

item.title: Market Review - Week32
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“A two year old is kind of like having a blender, but you don’t have the top for it.” Jerry Seinfeld   Ireland started the week on a good note with news that the mortgage approvals were up 7.3% on June 2012, while loans for new house purchases were up 8.8%   House prices in the UK continue to rise with the Nationwide survey indicating a rise of 0.8% in the month of July. This is the sixth straight month of house price rises indicating the success of their Help-to-Buy scheme in turn sentiment in the sector around   A recent report on the Irish mortgage market pointed out that arrears are high and set to rise, with 90+ day mortgage arrears already at some commentators’ expected peak levels of c.16% by value. Even though employment rose over 1.1% from March 2012 to March 2013, it has been unable to prevent these further increases. This points to a rise in strategic non-payment of mortgages by people who believe their houses can’t be taken from them or perhaps, that if they refuse to pay, they will benefit from some form of debt write down. The upcoming repossession legislation may challenge those assumptions   Over 1,900 cars were sold on the 1st July in Ireland with the new ‘132’ plate   Irish Manufacturing PMI (purchasing managers’ survey) rose to 51 in July from 50.3 the previous month. A number over 50 indicates the sector is growing. This follows on from the European Manufacturing PMI which also expanded in July, the first such expansion since mid-2011.   US GDP growth came in slightly better than the 1% expected briefly pushing 10 year Treasuries above 2.7% as markets typically rotate out of bonds and into equities in anticipation of growth   No further change in rates came from the EBC or the Bank of England late in the week but markets will be watching closely for any change in language going forward that might shed some light on Mario Draghi’s comment that rates would stay low for an “extended” period   Following the strong Irish and European manufacturing surveys early in the week came a sharp increase in the US survey (from 50.9 to 55.4) and the Chinese survey (to break through the critical 50 level). Equity markets reacted very positively to this on both sides of the Atlantic with Euro Stoxx 50 up 1.5% and S&P 500 up 1.3% on the day   The story of the week for me…goes back to World War II. It has recently emerged that the Bank of England helped to sell gold looted from the National Bank of Czechoslovakia by the Nazi’s after the invasion in 1939. In today’s money, over €736m was “transferred” to the Reichsbank account in the Bank for International Settlements, the so-called central banks’ bank. Perhaps money is the root of all evil…?

item.title: Sizing up SEPA DD Mandates
item.dc:creator: Darragh OFlanagan
item.content:encoded: Irish Life is Ireland's leading life, investment and pension company, so naturally we deal with many direct debits. Here is a brief overview of the new Single Euro Payments Area (SEPA) Direct Debit Mandates which will come into effect from February 2014. The Basic Stuff You’ve probably heard of SEPA, IBANs, BICs, etc. and they’ve hopefully become a familiar concept by now. But what’s this other idea of SEPA direct debit mandates all about? The basic concept: A company requests money from a customer, with their prior approval, and credits it to themselves. What Does This Mean? The SDD mandate allows a biller to collect funds from a payer's account, provided that a signed mandate has been granted by the payer to the biller. The mandate is signed by the payer to authorise the biller to collect a payment and to instruct the payer's bank to pay the agreed collections. The mandate can be issued in paper or electronic formats (e-mandates). Each one will have unique mandate reference (UMR) which will be assigned by the biller. For example, if a new customer signs up for a protection plan with Irish Life that requires monthly direct debits, they will sign a mandate form. This mandate allows us to collect the DD payment every month from the customer’s bank account. The UMR will be generated by Irish Life and communicated to the customer. Are you with me so far? Now for the Hard Part SEPA comes into full effect on 1st February 2014. We’ll need to be ready to handle these new SEPA Direct Debits (SDDs) since all existing national systems will close on this date. As Ireland's leading life, investment and pension company, we deal with a lot of direct debits. Introducing SEPA DD mandates, generating UMRs and the general administration of these concepts is a large task for any organisation. However, it’s one that should benefit the consumer under SEPA legislation. Once upgrades are in place for SEPA, it will be possible to exchange Euro payments between any accounts within the payments area as easily as it is within national borders today. As Sumner Redstone (majority owner of CBS and Viacom) once said, “We need to listen to consumers’ needs.”

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: sepa

item.title: Market Review - Week44
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
"Success consists of going from failure to failure without loss of enthusiasm” Winston Churchill   It was a short week in Ireland and the UK with a bank holiday on Monday and mid-term breaks meant markets were quieter than usual   UK GDP numbers released at the end of the previous week showed the economy expanded by 0.8% in Q3, driven largely by the services sector, with a turnaround evident in the fortunes of construction and manufacturing, which had been drags on performance in recent months   Irish retail sales are showing signs of recovery also, which although influenced by the 132 car registration series, also show some resilience on an underlying basis   Irish property prices are back in the news with a rise of 1.8% in September alone and up 3.6% on the year. Dublin leads the way with a frothy 12.3% rise since this time last year, while property outside the capital is still falling and down 2.6%. Interestingly, the latest mortgage approval numbers are largely unchanged implying cash purchases still make up over 50% of transactions rather than first time buyers. Although a welcome relief for some, the rise in prices appears to be relevant to very specific parts of the market and driven by supply rather than underlying demand at this stage   More good news on the domestic employment numbers late in the week with the live register below 400,000 for the first time since May 2009   Finally on the home front, there were manufacturing numbers out on Friday which, at 54.9, indicated the 5th month in a row of growth above the 50 (no change) level. This is the strongest reading in over 2 years   The EU Commission issued the results of a survey measuring Irish consumer confidence which pointed to a strong recovery. In fact, they were the highest recorded numbers since February 2006   The Story of the week for me… Monday morning giving you a headache? Perhaps you should spare a thought for Eduardo Leite, a construction worker from Rio. While working on a site, a 6ft long iron bar fell from the 5th floor of the building he was working on, pierced his hand hard and went through his head narrowly missing his brain and came out just below his left eye brow. The surgeon elected to pull the rest of the bar through his head in the same direction it entered. After the surgery was complete Eduardo appeared perfectly lucid with no signs of negative consequences. Brings a whole new meaning to the phrase splitting headache.

item.title: Market Review – Week47
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Failure is the opportunity to begin again, more intelligently.” - Henry Ford The OECD (Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development) cut half a percentage point off its forecasts for global growth this year and next, attributing the revisions to a slowdown in emerging markets, political gridlock in Washington DC and uncertainty over the Federal Reserve’s tapering of bond purchases for the downgrade. The forecast expects the global economy will grow 2.7% this year and 3.6% in 2014, compared with estimates of 3.1% and 4%, made in May.   Irish social protection as ratio of economic output was the highest in EU in 2011. Social protection which includes gross public welfare and health spending, for Ireland when measured in relation to GNP (gross national product, which mainly excludes the profits of the foreign-owned sector) amounted to 37% compared with an average of 29.7% of GDP for the EU28 and in Denmark (34.3%), France (33.6%), the Netherlands (32.3%), Belgium (30.4%), Greece (30.2%) and Finland (30.0%), and below 20% in Latvia (15.1%), Estonia (16.1%), Romania (16.3%), Lithuania (17.0%), Bulgaria (17.7%), Slovakia (18.2%), Malta (18.9%) and Poland (19.2%).   New data on population trends show that in the 28-member country European Union growth was up over 1m last year (2012), with immigrants being responsible for most of the rise.   Total health spending per capita fell in 11 of 33 OECD countries between 2009 and 2011, notably by 11.1% in Greece and 6.6% in Ireland.   The latest EBS DKM Affordability Index shows that the national affordability level for first time buyers remains stable at 17.3% of net income for a working couple purchasing the average property, with this figure forecasted to rise to 17.7% by the end of this year.   A survey of venture capital per capita suggests that Ireland is Europe's most entrepreneurial country.   German business confidence rose to the highest level in more than 18 months in November, signalling the recovery in Europe’s largest economy remains on track even though growth slowed in the third quarter (Q3).   Eurozone PMI signals slowing growth for a second successive month in November. At 51.5, down from 51.9 in October, the flash estimate of the Markit Eurozone PMI (purchasing managers' index) Composite Output Index remained above the 50.0 ‘no-change level’ for a fifth successive month in November, but signalled a slowing in growth for the second month running.   The Federal Reserve vice Chair Janet Yellen moved closer on Thursday to becoming the first woman to lead the U.S. central bank after a Senate committee backed her nomination and the chamber changed its rules to make it easier for nominees to be confirmed.   The story of the week for me… A volcanic eruption has given rise to a new island in the Pacific

item.title: Market Review – Week39
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“The value of an idea lies in the using of it." – Thomas Edison   The U.S. Federal Reserve surprised markets by keeping its asset purchases steady at $85bn a month while cutting its growth forecast to within a range of 2.0% to 2.3%. Earlier forecasts had predicted growth of 2.3% to 2.6%.   U.S. New-home construction picked up in August, indicating continued growth for the sector despite recent signs of softening demand. Housing starts rose 0.9% from July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 891,000.   U.S. Consumer price inflation edged down to 0.1% month-on-month in August from 0.2% reported in July, year-on-year (yoy) consumer prices are up 2%.   Irish GDP rose 0.4% quarter-on-quarter (qoq) in Q2 2013 after a 0.6% decline in Q1 2013. GDP is down 1.2% year-on-year (yoy). The rebound in Q2 was driven by consumer spending (+0.7%) and exports (+4.5%). GDP is still down 1.2% in the year to Q2 2013.   The Italian government revised its GDP forecast to -1.7% for 2013 compared with a previous projection of -1.3% made in April. For 2014, growth is now seen at 1.0%, down from 1.3% previously.   A surge in Germany’s ZEW economic sentiment indicator signalled expectations of improved growth in the second half of 2013. The sentiment indicator has risen to 49.6 (the long term average is 23.84).   UK House prices are up 3.3% year-on-year (yoy) in July from 3.1% in June. The year-on-year increase reflected growth of 3.7% in England and 1.8% in Northern Ireland, offset by falls of 2.0% in Scotland and 0.7% in Wales. The UK House Price Index (HPI) is still below its peak in January 2008. However, the English HPI at 182.4 in July 2013 is now 0.9% higher than at the previous peak in January 2008.   The story of the week for me…. It’s one thing for one person to be caught short when it comes to toilet paper, but for a whole nation it's a rather more serious affair. Last week Venezuela ordered its National Guard to take control of a toilet paper factory to avoid scarcity of the product, in what it called “an effort to ensure consistent supplies.” Such shortages of consumer goods is beginning to become a common theme in Venezuela, as a result of the inability to import enough raw materials and machinery into the country, due to a shortage of hard currency as a result of the exchange controls imposed by the socialist government.

item.title: Market Review – Week40
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
"We are not creatures of circumstance; we are creators of circumstance." - Benjamin Disraeli   China's economy signalled strength in September as a flash index of manufacturing activity rose to a-six month high. The preliminary HSBC China Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index rose to 51.2 in September compared with a final reading of 50.1 in August (a reading above 50 indicates expansion and one below 50 indicates contraction).   Japan's consumer prices are up 0.8% in August from a year earlier on higher gasoline and other energy prices, posting the highest margin of increase since November 2008.   U.S. household spending rose in August by 0.3% as incomes were buoyed by solid wage gains.   U.S. new home sales rose by 7.9% in August, to 421,000. The out-turn for U.S. new home sales was broadly in line with expectations, easing concerns that the U.S. housing market is beginning to soften.   A flash estimate of the Markit Eurozone PMI Composite Output Index (a key benchmark indicator for measuring businesses and economic conditions) rose to a 27-month high in September, signalling the largest rise in activity since June 2011. The flash PMI posted gains for the sixth consecutive month; up from 51.5 in August to 52.1(a reading above 50 indicates expansion and one below 50 indicates contraction).   Irish house price inflation accelerated to 2.6% in August, and to 10.5% in Dublin. Cash buyers now account for close to 60% of transactions in the Irish housing market.   British services output inched up in July and productivity rose across the economy for the first time in two years in the second quarter, suggesting the country's recovery is moving onto a firmer footing. The dominant service sector's output rose 0.2% in July from the previous month and 1.8% from July last year.   The story of the week for me…is the Spanish government’s latest efforts to boost productivity. Spanish MPs are to consider changing their time zone to bring it in line with GMT (Greenwich Mean Time), claiming that it would improve eating, sleeping and working habits

item.title: Market Review – Week41
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
"Trying times are not the times to stop trying." - Ray Owen   September surveys provided further evidence that the Eurozone recovery has gathered momentum. The final Markit Eurozone Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) composite output, based on surveys of manufacturing and the service sector, rose to a 27-month high of 52.2 in September. This is up from 51.5 in August (a reading above 50 is indicative of expansion and a reading below 50 is indicative of contraction).   The Eurozone (EA17) seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate was 12.0% in August 2013. The EU28 unemployment rate was 10.9%. In both zones, rates have increased compared with August 2012, when they were 11.5% and 10.6% respectively.   The European Central Bank (ECB) left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.5%.   The World Bank lowered its forecasts for East Asia’s developing countries to grow at 7.1% for 2013, and 7.2% for 2014. The reasons cited were slower growth, lower investments and exports in most of the region's economies. As well as the need for structural and policy reforms to stabilise growth, ahead of monetary stimulus withdrawals and interest rate hikes in advanced economies.   Business conditions continue to improve at a solid pace in the Japan. As the manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) rose to a seasonally adjusted 52.5 in September from 52.2 in August (a reading above 50 is indicative of expansion and a reading below 50 is indicative of contraction).   The Irish services Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) fell to 56.8 in September, still indicating a robust pace of growth, but down substantially on the 61.6 recorded in August (a reading above 50 is indicative of expansion and a reading below 50 is indicative of contraction).   The story of the week for me…is about the frenzy of excitement around Twitter's impending IPO. Some investors last week mistook the nearly worthless stock of long-dead electronics retailer Tweeter for the "tweeting" site, sending shares up more than 1,000%.

item.title: Market Review – Week42
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
"They always say time changes things, but you actually have to change them yourself.” - Andy Warhol   President Obama nominated Dr. Janet Yellen to succeed Ben Bernanke as chair of the Federal Reserve, and she will be the first women to lead the central bank, 100 years after its creation.   The HSBC Emerging Markets Index (EMI), a monthly indicator derived from the PMI (purchasing managers' index) surveys, remained only just above the neutral threshold of 50.0 in September, signalling muted output growth in global emerging markets. The EMI was little-changed at 50.8, from 50.7 in August, and the average for Q3 (50.3) was the lowest since Q1 2009 during the global financial crisis.   The International Monetary Fund cut its world growth forecast by 0.3% to 2.9% and next year by 0.2% to 3.6% amid deteriorating emerging market prospects, as the US prepares to exit its easy money policies and political stalemate in Washington DC threatens to disrupt the global recovery.   The US Energy Information Administration (EIA) estimates that the United States will be the world's top producer of oil and natural gas hydrocarbons in 2013, surpassing Russia and Saudi Arabia. For the United States and Russia, total petroleum and natural gas hydrocarbon production, in energy content terms, is almost evenly split between petroleum and natural gas. Saudi Arabia's production, on the other hand, heavily favours petroleum.   UK industrial production for August dipped 1.1% in the month, abruptly ending a series of positive data on the British economy in recent months while in Germany, output rebounded after a dip in July.   Irish consumer prices on average, as measured by the CPI, were 0.2% higher in September compared with September 2012, according to the CSO. The most notable changes in the year were increases in Alcoholic Beverages & Tobacco (+4.8%), Education (+4.8%) and Miscellaneous Goods & Services (+2.0%). There were decreases in Communications (-4.5%), Clothing & Footwear (-4.1%), Furnishings, Household Equipment & Routine Household Maintenance (-3.9%) and Transport (-2.7%).   The stories of the week for me…Diamonds, the saying goes, are a girl's best friend. Jupiter and Saturn just might be full to the brim with them, according to scientists from the American Astronomical Society's Division for Planetary Sciences. Chunks of diamonds may be floating in hydrogen and helium fluid deep in the atmospheres of Saturn and Jupiter. What's more, at even lower depths, the extreme pressure and temperature can melt the precious gem, literally making it rain liquid diamonds.

item.title: Market Review – Week43
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
"The greatest danger for most of us is not that we aim too high and we miss it, but we aim to low and reach it” - Michelangelo   Eurostat data released this week showed Spain, Greece and Ireland had the highest budget deficits in the EU in 2012. Ireland's deficit as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) was 8.2%, behind Spain (10.6%) and Greece (9.0%).   Spain's central bank announced an end to the country's two year recession as the Eurozone's fourth-largest economy gained from exports in the third quarter. The Banco de España (Spanish Central Bank) said Spain achieved a marginal growth rate of 0.1% from the previous quarter.   US jobs numbers released this week were a lot worse than expected – coming in at 148,000 new payrolls in September versus an expected 180,000. The 430,000 jobs added in the three months to September is the slowest pace of growth since July 2012, suggesting that the thus-far resilient US recovery has succumbed to the avoidable sequester cuts and the shutdown/debt ceiling debacle. With the worst of the impact from the shutdown not hitting the economy until October, the jobs numbers could deteriorate further in the final quarter of the year.   The Rightmove measure of asking prices in England and Wales released this week indicate asking prices in England & Wales rose by 2.8% in October, up 3.8% on the year. Rightmove indicates that the strong rise on the month was driven by London (up 10.2% on the month) and the south-east (+2.3%) amid reports from estate agents of a buying frenzy in the capital with stocks in prime areas almost completely depleted.   The first official estimate on how the UK economy has performed in the three months to the end of September was released last week. Rising by 0.8%% between July and September, which builds on a 0.7% GDP rise in the April-June period and is the best quarterly performance since 2010.   China's manufacturing activity rose to 7-month high in October boosted by a mini-stimulus program that includes faster spending on urban transport, tax breaks for business. The Flash China Manufacturing PMI (purchasing managers index) was at 50.9 (50.2 in September) - a seven-month high. Meanwhile, Flash China Manufacturing Output Index was at 51.0 (50.2 in September) - a six-month high.   A report issued by the World Economic Forum affirmed the world’s gender gaps narrowed slightly this year. Iceland showed the least inequality among men and women, Finland ranked second followed by Norway and then Sweden, all unchanged from last year. Ireland maintained its position as sixth on the list.   The Story of the week for me… A violin that was being played as the Titanic went down was sold for 900,000 pounds ($1.46 million) at auction, a record price for memorabilia from the lost ocean liner
