item.title: Market Review – Week45
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
"Things do not happen. Things are made to happen.” - John F Kennedy   The European Central Bank (ECB) cut its key interest rate to a new record low of 0.25%, responding to a plunge in inflation to 0.7% in October and weak Eurozone economic data. The rate change will take effect from 13th November.   The European Commission released their economic growth forecasts for the second half of 2013, expecting a 0.5 % rise compared to the same period in 2012 in the EU. On an annual basis, real GDP growth for 2013 is estimated at 0.0 % in the EU and -0.4 % in the Eurozone. Looking ahead, economic growth is forecast to gradually gather pace over the forecast horizon, to 1.4 % in the EU and 1.1 % the Eurozone in 2014, reaching 1.9 % and 1.7 % in 2015, respectively.   US nonfarm payroll employment rose by 148,000 in September while nonfarm payroll employment rose by 204,000 in October, the unemployment rate was little changed at 7.3%.   The US economy grew at higher than expected growth in the third quarter (Q3). GDP (gross domestic product) grew at an annualised rate of 2.8% up from 2.5% in the second quarter (Q2).   Gross capital investment by the US public sector has dropped to 3.6% of US economic output, the lowest since 1947, compared with a post WW2 average of 5%.   The HSBC Emerging Markets Index (EMI), a monthly indicator derived from PMI surveys, signalled the fastest rise in output in seven months in October. At 51.7, the EMI remained well below its long-run trend level of 54.0. But the latest figure represented an improvement on the trend shown over Q3 (50.3), the lowest of any quarter since Q1 2009 during the global financial crisis (a reading over 50 indicates expansion and a reading under 50 indicates contraction).   The number of new Irish private cars licensed reached 69,402 in the year to the end of October 2013, a fall of 6.3% compared to the same period in 2012.   The year-on-year (YOY) rise in average Irish house/apartment rents nationwide accelerated to 4.8% in the third quarter (Q3) of 2013, up from 4.2% in the second quarter (Q2), according to the quarterly Daft.ie Rental Report. The acceleration is mainly due to trends outside Dublin, with rental inflation outside Dublin rising from 0.9% to 1.8% in recent months. In Dublin, rents were 7.6% higher than a year previously. This is related to very tight supply, with fewer than 1,500 properties available to rent on November 1, compared to over 6,700 on the same date four years previously. The average rent nationwide is now €824.   The story of the week for me….following on from Venezuela’s toilet paper crisis a few months ago, the Venezuelan government has sent armed troops into a chain of electronics shops to force the company to start selling products at cheaper prices. This tactic was employed by President Nicolas Maduro’s socialist government in an effort to combat inflation, one of many economic problems hampering Venezuela’s economy.

item.title: Market Review – Week46
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
"A goal without a plan is just a wish.” - Antoine de Saint Exupery   The Eurozone economy grew 0.1% in the third quarter (Q3) of 2013. The EU28 expanded by only 0.2%. France and Italy contracted (both at -0.1%) while growth in Europe's largest economy, Germany, was at 0.3%.   Spanish inflation has gone to zero. The index of consumer prices has been revised down for October to 0.0% year on year. There was a small year-on-year drop in the price of services and a slowdown in the rise of price inflation in food, drink and tobacco prices.   The Irish government formally announced that it will leave the EU/IMF programme of funding support without a precautionary credit line (PCL). Market reaction was negligible as it had been well flagged in advance.   Figures from the Irish Banking Federation showed that new mortgage lending was €750m in Q3, up from €518m in Q2. But the bigger picture is that mortgage lending has been weak in 2013. Just €1.6bn of new mortgages have been drawn in the first nine months of the year. This suggests that the end-year figure will struggle to match the €2.6bn recorded in 2012, on current trends down at least 10%.   The Bank of England (BOE) announced the UK economy is set to grow faster than it had expected in August, but stressed that a subdued outlook for inflation means it is still unlikely to raise interest rates soon. Releasing its latest quarterly forecasts, the BOE said the unemployment rate may fall to 7% much earlier than it had previously thought. The UK unemployment rate was reported at 7.6%, down from 7.8%.   Japan's economy slowed to an annualised real growth of 1.9% in the July-September (Q3) period, following a 3.8% expansion the previous quarter (Q2). The data showed that exports dropped 0.6% from the previous quarter, while the rate of quarter-on-quarter growth in household consumption declined from 0.6% to 0.1%. Private residential investment rose by 2.7%.   The Unites States trade deficit widened to $41.8bn in September from $38.7bn in August.   The story of the week for me….A famous hotel rebuilt every winter in northern Sweden using only ice is to install fire alarms under the new National Housing Board rules.

item.title: Mo' time like the present for cancer awareness
item.dc:creator: T.J.
item.content:encoded:
So another “Movember” is just over, and wives and girlfriends around the world can breathe a sigh of relief as their partners get to shave their moustaches for the first time in a month.  Millions will have been raised around the world all going towards raising awareness and funds for mens health issues. I recently attended the Dublin Web Summit, and Justin Coughlan, the co-founder of the Movember movement told us how the foundation grew from a group of mates in Melbourne deciding to grow their “Mo’s” for the month of November to becoming what is now, one of the top 100 Non-Government Organizations in the world.  Since its inception, they have raised over €321m!
Since its inception, they have raised over €321m!
Prostate and Testicular Cancer are still major killers of men in Ireland.  A look back at death claims paid out by Irish Life since 2008 show that 75 claims have been paid out for Testicular cancer and 282 for Prostate Cancer.  A more startling fact is uncovered when we examine the age profile of the claimants.  The average age for Testicular cancer claims is 38, with the youngest claim being  24 years old.  56 is the average age of Prostate cancer claimants, with 29 the youngest. [caption id="attachment_2490" align="aligncenter" width="228"] Click here to see an infographic for Irish Life claim statistics[/caption] The Irish Cancer Society website have a section on their website devoted to Men’s Health which includes tips on how to spot cancer early on.  All men in the country should read it and be aware of the symptoms, as most cancers can be treated and cured if they are found early.
most cancers can be treated and cured if they are found early
[caption id="attachment_2496" align="alignleft" width="84"] my own effort at Movember[/caption]   So if you see a man over the remainder of the month sporting the classic handlebar look, or the wispy downy fluff(see my own pic on the left!), or anything inbetween, on their upper lip, know that they are suffering this embarrassment for a very good cause.  Give them a nod, a bit of encouragement or even put your hand in your pocket and donate a few quid to the cause because it all helps.  You can make a donation to the Irish Cancer Society by following this link.
item.excerpt:encoded: With the end of "Movember" in sight, we take a look at the work the importance of raising the awareness of Mens Health and delve into some Claim Stats from Irish Life to back this point up.

item.title: Irish Life sparkles at the Annual Pension Awards
item.dc:creator: Laura Taylor
item.content:encoded:
Thursday 27 November at the Pension Awards was a great night for Irish Life and our colleagues in Setanta Asset Management - we’re both part of the Great-West Lifeco family in case anyone doesn’t know yet! Between us we picked up four prestigious awards at the Irish Pensions Awards 2013. The Awards aim to recognise companies who have consistently delivered excellence, professionalism and dedication in maintaining the highest standards in Irish pension provision.   Irish Life Corporate Business won both the ‘Communication Award’ and the ‘Innovation Award’. Irish Life Investment Managers were awarded ‘Investment Manager of the Year’ while Setanta Asset Management won ‘Equities Manager of the year’  

BOW TIES AND SPEECHES

This Black-Tie event was held in the new Double Tree Hilton Hotel (aka the Burlington).  As the evening kicked off, we nervously joked about acceptance speeches if we were honoured with a win. The nerves continued throughout the meal - similar I’m sure, to how members of a wedding party feel throughout their meal. We were relieved for a stint by MC, Neil Delamere, who’d make a great best man. His humour was as one person said was “on the right side of irreverent”.  

DRUM ROLL

Before we knew it, winners of the first few categories were announced. Colleagues and competitors, applauded and cheered. No tears, thankfully. Patrick Burke, Managing Director Irish Life Investment Managers graciously accepted the award for Irish Life Investment Manager of the Year, a massive win for the business. Equities Manager of the Year was announced, and we were thrilled to celebrate with our new colleagues in Setanta Asset Management. Next up, Irish Life Corporate Business. We were announced as winners of the Communication Award. David Harney, Managing Director Irish Life Corporate Business and I made our way to the stage to collect the award. Thankfully collecting the award was all that was required - and no acceptance speeches were allowed (which was just as well - the nerves after facing Neil Delamere and the paparazzi would have got the better of me!) But that wasn’t all, we’d barely sat down again when David and Paula Martin, Senior Manager e-business Irish Life Corporate Business were called to the stage to accept the Innovation Award.  

STRENGTH IN NUMBERS

Four awards, what an honour - in a year of change for both Irish Life and Setanta. We hope that this success is further evidence of our winning combination of global expertise and strength backed by local insight and customer care.
“To receive industry recognition awards for our commitment to delivering innovative products, backed by the highest standards of communication and service excellence. In a year of major change for everyone in Irish Life, this is a real badge of honour for us. We’re delighted.”

item.title: Market Review – Week48
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“A Pessimist sees the difficulty in every opportunity; an optimist sees the opportunity in every difficulty.” - Winston Churchill   The planned €1.4bn sale of the semi-state company Bord Gáis Energy was put on hold as bids fell short of the government’s asking price.   When Ireland joined the European Economic Community in 1973 55% of total exports went to the UK. This ratio dropped to 18% in 2012 while exports to the rest of the EU grew from 21% in 1973 to 40% in 2012 (the EEC/EU expanded from 6 to 27 countries over this time period).   Irish House Prices rose 15% in Dublin in the year to October 2013 while residential property prices at a national level increased by 6.1%. This compares with an increase of 3.6% in September and a decrease of 8.1% recorded in the twelve months to October 2012. Mortgages issued at a national level are at the lowest level since 1974.   According to the Central Bank, the number of Irish mortgages in arrears for more than 90 days rose in the third quarter (Q3) of the year compared to the previous three months. The proportion of residential mortgages in arrears greater than 90 days rose to 12.9% by the end of September, up from 12.7% in the previous three months.   The Eurozone (EA17) seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate was 12.1% in October 2013; the EU28 unemployment rate was 10.9%. In both zones, rates have risen compared with October 2012, when they were 11.7% and 10.7% respectively.   Eurozone annual inflation is expected to reach 0.9% in November 2013, up from 0.7% in October, according to a flash estimate from Eurostat released earlier in the week.   The recovery in the Eurozone manufacturing sector accelerated again in November. Although the pace of expansion remained modest overall, the real positives were that growth extended into a fifth successive month with the rate of increase hitting a near two-and-half year high. Greek PMI (purchasing managers' index) rose for first time in 4 years.   The Story of the week for me… Researchers at the Emory University School of Medicine, have shown that memories can be passed down to later generations through genetic switches that allow offspring to inherit the experience of their ancestors, according to new research that may explain how phobias can develop.

item.title: Market Review – Week49
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“It always seems impossible until it’s done.” - Nelson Mandela   The Bord Gáis Energy Index rose 4% in November 2013 as the four key commodities of the Index (oil, natural gas, coal and electricity) increased month-on-month. Both wholesale natural gas and electricity prices increased considerably (+6% and +8% respectively) over the month. Colder weather, some minor supply disruptions and a stronger pound versus the euro combined to raise the month-on-month wholesale prices.   Irish unemployment rate fell to a low of 12.5% in November. This is the lowest rate recorded since June 2009.   The US unemployment rate declined from 7.3% to 7.0% in November, and nonfarm payroll employment rose by 203,000. Employment rose in transportation and warehousing, health care, and manufacturing.   Real US gross domestic product (GDP) increased at an annualised 3.6% in the third quarter of 2013, according to the Bureau of Economic Analysis. The growth rate was 0.8% more than the initial estimate released the previous month. In the second quarter, the growth rate was 2.5%.   Trade ministers from 159 nations agreed the first global trade deal in decades and the only global agreement since the World Trade Organisation was founded in 1995. The ministers agreed a “trade facilitation” agreement to set common customs standards and ease the flow of goods through borders around the world. They also agreed on a range of issues from how the WTO should respond to government food security programmes to securing better market access to the rich world for the globe’s least developed economies.   The HSBC Emerging Markets Index (EMI), a monthly indicator derived from the PMI (purchasing managers' index) surveys, continued its upward trajectory in November on the back of faster manufacturing growth. The EMI rose to 52.1, from 51.7 in October, signalling the fastest expansion in business activity across global emerging markets since March 2013.   Bank of Ireland announced plans to raise €580m of equity through a share placing as part of a deal to repay €1.8bn of State-owned preference shares. The bank had faced a March 2014 deadline to pay the State back before a clause under its €4.8bnn bailout increased the cost of buying the shares back by 25%, or €450m.   The Story of the week for me…is about inflation in Venezuela. In the run-up to December 8th municipal elections, President Nicolas Maduro's government launched an "economic offensive" to try to win over voters fed up with chronic shortages of basic goods and annual inflation of 54%. As a result, Venezuela's government said it was temporarily occupying the local subsidiary of multinational packaging company Smurfit Kappa accusing.

item.title: Market Review – Week50
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“To climb steep hills requires slow pace at first.” - Shakespeare   Today Ireland will be the first nation in the euro zone to leave its bailout package provided by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund back in 2010 receiving the last tranche of funds from its European Union/International Monetary Fund €85bn loan on Friday.   Irish industrial production fell by 11.6% in November. The fall reflected the pharmaceutical sector, with output down 23.3% on the month. In contrast, activity in the traditional manufacturing sector rose 0.3% in November, up 1.5% on the year.   Annual consumer price inflation was 0.3% higher in November compared with November 2012, according to data released by the CSO. The most notable changes in the year were increases in Alcoholic Beverages & Tobacco (+6.2%), Education (+4.5%) and Restaurants & Hotels (+3.1%). There were decreases in Clothing & Footwear (-4.6%), Furnishings, Household Equipment & Routine Household Maintenance (-4.2%), Communications (-3.1%) and Transport (-1.7%).   The average monthly standardised rent in Dublin in Q3 this year was €1,041, compared to €978 a year ago, and €1,015 in Q2 this year. For houses, it was €1,157 compared to €1,095 a year ago, and €1,124 in Q2 this year, while for apartments, it was €1,042 in Q3, compared with €983 a year ago, and €1,022 in Q2 this year. Outside Dublin, the average standardised rent in Q3 this year was €620, compared to €622 a year ago, and €612 in Q2 this year. For houses, the figure was €622 in Q3, compared with €619 a year ago, and €608 in Q2 this year, while for apartments, the figure was €624, compared with €636 a year ago and €627 in Q2 this year.   In the month of October 2013, seasonally adjusted industrial production fell by 1.1% in the Eurozone (EA17) and by 0.7% in the EU28. Year on Year (YOY) industrial production increased by 0.2% in the Eurozone and by 0.8% in the EU28.   A key element missing from the UK recovery story to date has been wage growth. Average weekly earnings grew by just 1% in the year to October, well below the current CPI inflation rate of 2.2%.   The International Energy Agency’s (IEA) Oil Market Report (OMR) raised the estimate of global oil demand for 2013 by 130,000 barrels per day (130 kb/d), to 91.2m barrels per day (mb/d), on stronger-than-expected third-quarter demand growth among OECD countries of 320 kb/d. Global demand is now seen advancing by 1.2 mb/d in both 2013 and 2014, to reach 92.4 mb/d in 2014.   The Story of the week for me…Christmas in Texas has become even sweeter thanks to a giant gingerbread house that has broken a world record for confectionary construction. The recipe is simple; Mix 820 kg of butter, 1,327 kg of brown sugar, 7,200 eggs, 3,266 kg all-purpose flour, 31 kg ground ginger and a few other ingredients, bake and form into panels for mounting. Coming in at 35.8 million calories and covering an area of 2520 square feet, the 21-foot high gingerbread house has been declared the biggest gingerbread house by the Guinness World Records.

item.title: Market Review – Week51
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Minds are like parachutes – they only function when open” - Thomas Dewar   Irish GDP data showed a bounce-back in the second half of 2013. GDP is up 1.7% to the end of September 2013. The rise in Q3 was entirely driven by domestic demand, with consumer spending up 0.9% and a 10.9% rise in investment spending. In contrast, exports fell by 0.8%. The rebound in the Irish economy is consistent with the 3.2% employment growth recorded over the same period.   The Irish Government released their Medium-Term Strategy with a commitment to balance the budget by 2018.   The Economic and Social Research Institute (ESRI) announced that “the Irish economy has turned the corner” as domestic demand in 2013 is estimated to have grown by 0.9%, the first increase in this aggregate since 2008.   Credit agency Standard & Poor's cut its long-term rating of the European Union by one notch to AA+ stating it had concerns about how the Eurobloc's budget was financed.   The UK unemployment rate has fallen to its lowest level since 2009. At 7.4%, this is the lowest rate since the February-to-April period in 2009. The number of people out of work dropped by 99,000 to 2.39m in the three months to October.   The US Federal Reserve announced it will reduce its $85 billion a month in bond purchases by $10 billion starting in January 2014. Markets rallied after the announcement and as a result the S&P500 jumped 1.7% to a record close of 1,810.65.   Revised GDP estimates show the U.S. economy grew 4.1% in the third quarter (Q3), the fastest rate of growth in almost two years. The upward revision was attributed to stronger business spending, pointing to some underlying strength that should be sustained.   The Story of the week for me…There was a time when outdoor Christmas decorations consisted of little more than a string of fairy lights hung loosely around a window frame and a holiday wreath stuck on the front door. Last week a Guinness World Record was set in Australia for the most number of Christmas lights, consisting of half a million lights (or 502,165 to be exact) spread along string which if you rolled it out straight would stretch a distance of 29.8 miles (48 km).  

Index Performances and Market Data

Equity Markets (%) 2008 2009 2010 2011 2012 YTD
ISEQ -66.2 27 -3 0.6 14.7 31.83

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week02
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Everything should be made as simple as possible, but not simpler” - Albert Einstein   The CSO announced that the number of new private cars licensed for the first time fell by 17.4% to 639 in December 2013 compared to December 2012 but up over 30% in January 2014 versus January 2013   The value of Irish food and drink exports was roughly €10bn in 2013. This total amounts to 5.5% of expected total headline Irish exports in 2013. This represents an increase of 9% on the previous year and is up 40% in the last four years with revenues almost €3bn higher than in 2009   Bids valued at €14bn were made for the new Irish 10-year bond issue, raising €3.5bn in total. Bond yields have fallen to the lowest since 2006, on signs that the State is making a successful return to debt markets. The bond was issued at 3.543%.   The European Central Bank (ECB) left its key interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.25% despite concerns about a fragile recovery and falling inflation. In London, the Bank of England kept its benchmark rate unchanged at 0.5%.   The Eurozone (EA17) seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate was 12.1% in November 2013, stable since April. The EU28 unemployment rate was 10.9%, stable since May. In both zones, the rates increased compared with November 2012, when they were 11.8% and 10.8% respectively. The lowest rate was in Austria at 4.8% and the highest was in Spain at 26.7%.   The US added only 74,000 jobs in December but the jobless rate fell to 6.7% as the workforce reduced.   The HSBC Emerging Markets Index (EMI), a monthly indicator derived from the PMI (purchasing managers' index) surveys, signalled overall growth of output across global emerging markets in December. The EMI fell to 51.6, from 52.1 in November, signalling a weaker rate of expansion.   Japan's Nikkei 225 had its best performance since 1972, 41 years ago while in the US, the Dow Industrial Average had its best year since 1995.   Commodity prices fell in 2013 for the first time since 2008 as the Federal Reserve announced a taper of its monthly bond purchases; China scaled back metal demand while record harvests are maintaining a downward pressure on food prices and gold and silver plunged the most since 1981 against a backdrop of improving prospects for the world economy. In the currency markets, while the euro rose against the US dollar, the currency is up against most other currencies.   The Story of the week for me… Most adults struggle to recall events from their first few years of life and now scientists have identified exactly when these childhood memories fade and are lost forever. A new study into childhood amnesia – the phenomenon where early memories are forgotten – has found that it tends to take affect around the age of seven.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week03
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“We build too many walls and not enough bridges” - Isaac Newton   Moody's Investors Service on Friday restored an investment grade rating to Ireland after it had cut Irish sovereign debt to junk status in 2011. The agency upgraded Ireland's government debt ratings to Baa3/P-3 from Ba1/NP and the outlook on the ratings is now positive.   Prices on average, as measured by the CPI (consumer price index), were 0.2% higher in December compared with December 2012. The price of goods fell by 0.9% and the most notable changes in the year were increases in Alcoholic Beverages & Tobacco (+5.7%), Education (+4.5%) and Restaurants & Hotels (+2.8%). There were decreases in Clothing & Footwear (-4.0%), Furnishings, Household Equipment & Routine Household Maintenance (-3.7%), Communications (-2.4%), Transport (-1.1%) and Food & Non-Alcoholic Beverages (-1.1%).   The ESRI/KBC measure of consumer confidence surged in December, to its highest level since June 2007, as Ireland exited the EU/IMF bailout.   The European Commission has warned in its latest quarterly economic report on the Eurozone that per capita living standards could fall to 60% of US levels by 2023, which would be a ratio comparable with the mid-1960s.   Spain's economy grew the most since Q1 2008 in the fourth quarter of 2013. Gross domestic product (GDP) expanded 0.3% in the three months to December, compared with a 0.1% rise in output in the third quarter of 2013.   Eurozone seasonally adjusted industrial production rose 1.8% in the month of November 2013 and it expanded by 1.5% in the EU28.   According to leading indicators published by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), growth is set to improve in most large economies during the first half of 2014, with the exception of India, which is set for a slowdown.   The World Bank revised up its global GDP forecast to 3.2% in 2014.   The Story of the week for me…Davos 2014, the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum is set to open on Wednesday with more than 2,500 due to attend at an average cost of $40,000 per ticket.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week04
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“You will never find time for anything. If you want the time, you must make it.” - Charles Buxton   According to data released by Eurostat Ireland was the only country in the EU to experience disinflation between 2008 and 2012, but prices remain high by EU standards. Ireland was the fifth most expensive EU state in 2012, after Denmark, Sweden, Finland and Luxembourg with prices 15% above the EU average. However, this represents a considerable improvement on 2008 when Irish prices were the second highest in the EU, at 30% above the EU average.   Dublin house prices rose 15.7% last year; National prices are up 6.4%. Residential property prices in Dublin are 49.1% lower than at their highest level in February 2007. The fall in the price of residential properties in the rest of Ireland is somewhat lower at 46.8%. Overall, the national index is 46.4% lower than its highest level in 2007   Eurozone public debt fell for the first in the three months to September, since the end of 2007, giving a positive signal after years marked by crisis.   From a high level, German economic sentiment fell slightly in the latest survey. In January 2014 the ZEW Indicator of Economic Sentiment fell only marginally by 0.3 points and now stands at the 61.7 points-mark (historical average: 24.4 points).   The UK unemployment rate has fallen to 7.1%, just above the level at which the Bank of England has said it will consider raising interest rates. The jobless fall was the biggest since 1997.   China's economy grew 7.7% year on year in 2013, the same as 2012 while beating the government's target of 7.5%   Global growth is expected to increase in 2014 after having been stuck in low gear in 2013, says the IMF’s latest WEO Update. The IMF forecasts global growth to average 3.7% in 2014―up from 3% in 2013―and to rise to 3.9% in 2015.   Investors start 2014 more optimistic about global growth prospects, especially for the US but increasingly for Europe as well, according to the BofA Merrill Lynch Fund Manager Survey for January 2014. The proportion of investors who believe the global economy will strengthen this year has risen to a net 75% from a net 71% in December, continuing a trend of rising optimism that started in late 2012.   The Story of the week for me…A new food fad is sweeping South Korea - gastronomic voyeurism, or watching people eat online. There are about 3,500 people in South Korea doing such online programmes, some sponsored by restaurants. Some say it makes eating alone feel less awkward.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week05
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Life is like a riding a bicycle. To keep your balance, you must keep moving” - Albert Einstein   Quarterly National Accounts for Q3 2013 still show that Irish household debt remains exceptionally high. However, household net worth rose by 3.5% on the quarter to €489.6bn, or €106,605 per capita. This was the largest increase in Irish household net worth since Q4 2006. In part, the rise in net worth reflected households saving to reduce their debts. Household debt fell by €1.6bn on the quarter to €168.6bn, €36,717 per capita. Nonetheless, Irish household debt still remains exceptionally high by international standards at 196.1% of disposable income, down by 2.1 percentage points on the quarter.   The Eurozone (EA17) seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate was 12.0% in December 2013 and has been stable since October. The EU28 unemployment rate was 10.7% in December 2013, down from 10.8% in November. Jobless numbers rose by 130,000.   Recent upward pressure on European short-term borrowing rates had prompted some commentators to suggest a further ECB rate cut may be likely.   Investors resumed their flight from emerging markets despite the latest round of central bank interventions to allay concerns about rising economic and political hazards in developing countries. The MSCI Emerging Markets index is down -4.4% percent for the month of January, the weakest start to a year since 2009.   The UK economy grew by 1.9% in 2013, its strongest rate since 2007, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). GDP (gross domestic product) increased by 0.7% in the fourth quarter of 2013. However, the Office for National Statistics’ Q4 GDP first estimate is based only on survey data for October and November. So the GDP figures are still likely to be revised.   The US economy grew at a slower annualised rate than the third quarter's 4.1% growth, the final six months of the year delivered the strongest second half since 2003 boosted by exports, consumer spending and business investment. Real gross domestic product (GDP) increased 3.2% in the fourth quarter of 2013, according to the “advance” estimate released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. In the third quarter, the growth rate was 4.1%. For the full year 2013, real GDP increased 1.9%, compared with 2.8% in 2012.   The Story of the week for me…A Guinness world record for the region with the most lightning has been given to the North-western state of Zulia in Venezuela. Producing up to 3,600 flashes per hour and 1.2 million a year with the number of lightning bolts estimated at 18 to 60 per minute. Each flash packs enough energy to light up 100 million light bulbs between the months of April to November every year.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week06
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“One can choose to go back to safety or forward toward growth” - Abraham Maslow   Rising Irish wholesale electricity and coal prices offset decreasing oil and wholesale natural gas prices resulting in a 1% month-on-month increase in the Bord Gáis Energy Index in January.   The year-on-year increase in the average rent nationwide accelerated to 7.1% in the final quarter of 2013, up from 2.2% a year previously, according to the quarterly Daft.ie Rental Report. The average advertised rent nationwide is now €865, compared to €790 two years ago. The average rise in Dublin was 11.2% to €1,210. The acceleration in rent inflation is due mainly to trends in Dublin, with rental inflation in the capital rising from 4.9% to 11.2% in the same period. Rents are now 17.6% higher than their lowest point in this cycle, which occurred three years ago, and 15.7% below peak levels of 2007.   The Irish construction sector continued to show further growth at the start of 2014, the Ulster Bank Construction PMI shows. The index, which was released this morning, came in at 56.4 in January, down from 58.3 in December but still signalling a strong monthly increase in activity. A reading above 50 indicates expansion while below 50 signifies contraction. Within the residential segment of the index, where activity remains around a 40-year low, the PMI stood at 59.8 in January compared to 63.2 in December while in the commercial sector it fell to 59.3 from 63.2 the previous month. Strong gains in new orders helped produce the fifth consecutive month of increasing employment while business sentiment was only slightly weaker than December’s record high as firms forecast further growth in activity during 2014.   Output in the Eurozone economy expanded for the seventh successive month in January. At 52.9, up from 52.1 in December, the final Markit Eurozone PMI (purchasing managers' index) Composite Output Index posted its highest reading since June 2011, but nudged lower from the flash estimate of 53.2. The upturn was led by the manufacturing sector, where accelerated growth of both total new orders and new export business drove the rate of expansion in production to a near three-year record   Business activity across emerging markets expanded in January at the slowest pace in four months, dragged down by sluggish services sectors in the BRIC quartet of big developing countries. HSBC's composite emerging markets index of manufacturing and services purchasing managers' surveys slipped for the second month running to 51.4 in January. A reading above 50 indicates expansion while below 50 signifies contraction.   The Story of the week for me…Silvio Berlusconi is not giving up. Despite a conviction for tax fraud, clandestine scandals and a ban on him running for office, the billionaire leader of Italy’s centre-right is said to be planning

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week08
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist, that is all” - Oscar Wilde Analysis published by Credit Suisse revealed the real value of Irish equities, with income reinvested, grew by a factor of 96.6 in the 114 years from 1900-2013, compared to 4.9 for bonds.   According to the CSO, Irish prices as measured by the CPI (consumer price index) were 0.2% higher in January 2014, compared with January 2013. The most notable changes in the year were increases in Education (+4.6%), Alcoholic Beverages & Tobacco (+4.3%) and Miscellaneous Goods & Services (+2.8%). There were decreases in Furnishings, Household Equipment & Routine Household Maintenance (-3.3%), Communications (-2.4%), Clothing & Footwear (-2.3%) and Transport (-2.1%).   A new study based on an analysis of the Property Price Register shows that the number and value of transactions in Dublin rose substantially during 2013. The study reveals that the number of house sales in the capital last year rose to 10,000, an increase of 17% on 2012. There were 246 sales in Dublin for €1m or more. The lowest price achieved was €6,000 in respect of a house in Marino. The most popular areas to buy property were Dublin 15 (697), Dublin 14 (649), Dublin 16 (605), Dublin 18 (522) and Dublin 6 (512). Dublin dominates the market as it accounts for over a third of the 29,200 houses sold in the country last year. However house sales outside Dublin are also up 17%, driven in the main by increased sales in Cork, Limerick and Galway.   The UK's annual inflation rate, as measured by the consumer prices index, dropped to 1.9% in January. This is the first fall below the Bank of England's 2% target in more than four years.   China's manufacturing contracted in February according to a flash purchasing managers’ index (PMI), which dropped to a seven-month low of 48.3 in February, from 49.5 the previous month. The period included the Lunar New Year shutdown. A reading above 50 indicates expansion while below 50 signifies contraction.   According to the BofA Merrill Lynch Fund Manager Survey for February, a growing proportion of investors (46% in February) acknowledge that a hard landing in China and commodity collapse represent the biggest tail risk to the global economy. That figure compares with 37% in January and 26% in December. Belief in global economic growth has moderated, 56% expect the global economy to strengthen in the coming 12 months, down 19% from 75% last month. Global equity allocations are down; 45% of asset allocators say they are overweight equities, down from 55% in January.   The Story of the week for me… Most people entering crocodile territory keep a wary eye out on water and land, but research suggests they need to look up. Though the reptiles lack obvious physical features to suggest this is needed, crocodiles in fact climb trees all the way to the crowns, according to University of Tennessee researcher Vladimir Dinets.

item.title: Competition time again!
item.dc:creator: Colin
item.content:encoded: At Irish Life, we're always looking at new ways to improve our Life Insurance offerings. And with the launch of our LifeCare range of additional benefits, I really think we've outdone ourselves. You can find out all the details about MedCare, NurseCare and ClaimsCare over on irishlife.ie, but in the meantime, to celebrate our launch, we've got a fantastic family holiday to Disneyland Paris worth €1500 to give away. Enter the competition on our Facebook page. You don't have to be an existing customer to enter, but there are some terms and conditions, so make sure you get over there and enter today!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Collin, It was great to know about your Life Insurance offerings.
Just Signed up for new life Insurance and Income protection with yourselves.

item.title: MedCare – Medical Second Opinion service from MediGuide
item.dc:creator: Michelle Kearns
item.content:encoded:
If you, or a member of your family, have ever been diagnosed with a serious illness or medical condition, you will know how overwhelming this can be.  The focus switches quickly to working with your doctor to consider every possible option around finding the best treatment plan. Imagine how comforting it could be at this difficult time to know that amongst your options could be a second opinion on your diagnosis and treatment plan from one of the world’s leading medical centres. That’s why Irish Life has just launched MedCare – as part of our new LifeCare range of services. MedCare gives you access to a Medical Second Opinion service provided by MediGuide, a company in the USA. MedCare is currently available to customers who start a new Protection plan from 3rd February 2014 with Irish Life – excluding the Over 50s and Simple Life Insurance plans. With MedCare, if you are diagnosed with one of the conditions covered by MediGuide, you can access a review of your diagnosis and treatment plan from one of 90 leading medical centres worldwide, who are at the forefront of medical research and advances in diagnoses and treatment. In the U.S., for example, many of these medical centres are specialists in particular illnesses such as cancer or cardiovascular-related conditions. And, as they are typically based in cities or regions that have large populations, they tend to have a lot of experience of applying cutting-edge science to diagnosing conditions on a regular basis. Click here to see the current list of medical centres: http://www.irishlife.ie/life-assurance/medcare-medical-centers.html The health conditions and illnesses covered under the Medical Second Opinion service range from cancer and cardiovascular disorders to arthritis, asthma and female infertility. To see the full list, log on to http://www.irishlife.ie/medcare-conditions.html. And, as an extra benefit, the service can also be used by your spouse / partner, your children, your parents and your spouse’s / partner’s parents. Once you have an Irish Life plan, there is no additional  cost to you for requesting or receiving a Medical Second Opinion. So if you are thinking about life insurance, it may be worth checking out the range of services currently offered by Irish Life. For further details on MedCare and the Medical Second Opinion service, talk to your financial adviser or log on to irishlife.ie/medcare.    
This information is correct as at February 19th 2014. MediGuide provide an independent and confidential service. MediGuide is independent from Irish Life and Irish Life accepts no liability for this service. Your access to the MediGuide Medical Second Opinion service is subject to MediGuide terms and conditions and data processing controls.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It was great to know about MedCare. Thanks Michelle for sharing.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week09
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“The absence of alternatives clears the mind marvellously” - Henry Kissinger   Irish employment increase by 3.3% or 61,000 in the year to the fourth quarter of 2013, bringing total employment to 1,909,800 (the highest number since June 2009) driven by Agriculture, forestry and fishing (+29.8% or 26,800), Accommodation and food service activities (+14.7% or 17,400) and Professional, scientific and technical activities (+12.7% or 13,000).   UK house purchase data showed a surge in mortgage approvals to just below 50,000 in January, the highest level in six years.   Eurozone Growth forecasts were raised to 1.1% by the European Commission. Economic data over recent quarters has confirmed a gradual recovery in the euro area.   Eurozone annual inflation was confirmed at 0.8% in January 2014, stable compared to December 2013. A year earlier the rate was 2.0%. Monthly inflation was -1.1% in January 2014.   The Cyprus government resigned on Friday after parliament failed to approve draft legislation to privatise three state utilities as part of the island’s €10bn bailout by international lenders.   French unemployment was at a record high in January. The latest figure brings the total number of unemployed to a record 3.23m – about 11% of the workforce. The total number of those seeking a full-time job, including those in part-time work, reached 4.92m.   US real GDP (which measures output produced in the United States) grew at an annual rate of 2.4% in the fourth quarter of 2013.   Russia's central bank unexpectedly raised its policy interest rate sharply to 7% from 5.5%. The Bank of Russia's move came as the Russian rubble plunged to record lows following Moscow's intervention in Ukraine.   Commodities advanced to their highest levels in almost six months as escalating tension in Ukraine fuelled concern that energy and agricultural supplies will be disrupted while increasing demand for gold as a haven. Brent crude in London jumped 2 %, wheat in Chicago surged 4.7 %, while gold futures in New York increased 1.3 %. Natural gas and corn also advanced.   The Story of the week for me…Mt Gox, once the world's largest bitcoin exchange, filed for bankruptcy in a Tokyo district court. After 744,408 bitcoins, valued at more than $390 million were reported stolen. Mt Gox once claimed to host nearly 80 percent of all bitcoin transactions worldwide, and was the primary source cited for bitcoin prices.

item.title: Irish Life Death and Specied Illness Claims 2013
item.dc:creator: Martin Duffy
item.content:encoded:
Who knows how to handle claims the best?

  Irish Life was already the biggest payer of death and illness claims in Ireland up to this point, but now with the addition of the Canada Life business, the biggest payer of life insurance and protection claims just got substantially bigger. In 2013 we paid on average €675,000 in death and illness claims every single working day - over €168m in total.

Summary of Irish Life claims in 2013

Death Claims Specified Illness Claims
Number of claims paid 1,714 810
Amount paid €112.4m €56.4m
Average claim amount €65,560 €69,638
Partial SIC claims n/a 13
Average age of claimant 63 51
Average duration inforce 15 years 12 years
Adult claims – male/female split 61%/34% 55%/43%
Number of Child claims – up to age 21 82 24
 

Specified Illness Claims

 
Percentage of claims
Malignant cancer 59%
Heart related 21%
Stroke 7%
Multiple sclerosis 2%
 

Specified Illness Claims - Malignant Cancer

 
Number of claims
Breast 130
Prostate 71
Colon 24
Melanoma 16
Thyroid 16
  Since we launched partial payments in 2009, Irish Life has paid 56 partial payment illness claims. Some examples we paid in 2013 were for ductal carcinoma of the breast, severe burns, cerebral aneurysm and surgical removal of one eye.  

Death Claims

Over 35% of our claims were in the age group 41-60, the prime age for parents to ensure that they have adequate life insurance in place. The biggest cause of death for males aged 40-49 are accidents, followed by heart related deaths, and then cancer. The average death claim amount is still low - and only 1 in 5 death claims was for over €100,000. The largest death claim paid was for €1.1 million.   See more on Twitter #670keveryday.

item.title: 'Time to Read' initiative, on RTE's Nationwide 10th March
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded: Irish Life Investment Managers, as part of the Irish Life Corporate responsibility programme work with Business in the Community (BITC - www.bitc.ie). Having establishes a very successful link with Patrician College a secondary school in Finglas, BITC approached ILIM in 2010 and asked them to be one of the six participants in the "Time to Read" pilot programme. This is a programme aimed at primary schools to assist 7 and 8 year olds with their reading. Irish Life were delighted to get involved and were linked with St Finian’s National School in Finglas. The results of the pilot were extremely positive and the programme was rolled out to various primary schools in Ireland in 2012. Irish Life has maintained its link with St Finian’s and the Time to Read programme continues every Tuesday morning when volunteers from Irish Life read with children in the school. In addition the children visit their local library to understand the benefits of same and the children also do a site visit to Irish Life. To date about 20 staff has been involved with the programme. The "Time to Read" programme will be featured on RTÉs Nationwide programme Monday 10th March 7pm. http://www.rte.ie/tv/programmes/nationwide.html

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week10
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Vision is the art of seeing the invisible” Jonathan Swift   Irish pension managed funds delivered a positive month of returns during February, with an average return of 2.5% for the month. Irish Life Investment Managers took the top spot with a return of 2.9% for the month.   The Bord Gáis Energy Index fell 5% in February due to month-on-month falls in wholesale gas and electricity prices. Approximately 23% of Ireland’s electricity demand was met by wind, which displaced more expensive gas powered plants and helped lower Irish wholesale electricity prices. The Index currently stands at 140, which is 7% lower than February 2013 and 40% up on December 2009.   The KBC Ireland/ESRI Consumer Sentiment Index increased to 85.5 in February, from 84.6 in January and 59.4 in February last year.   The Central Bank reported that the number of Irish mortgage accounts in arrears for principal dwelling houses (PDH) fell by 3.3% to 136,564 in Q4 2013 from 141,269 at the end Q3. This represents 17.9% of the total mortgage market. However, accounts 360 days+ in arrears grew to 60,422. The value of PDH mortgages in arrears is €24.4bn.   The recession-scarred Spanish labour market passed a milestone as employment showed its first annual rise since the start of the financial crisis in 2008. After 68 consecutive months of losses and stagnation, the number of employed Spaniards rose to 16.2 million in February, 60,000 higher than the same month last year.   The EU confirmed that, following the end of Ireland’s EU-IMF bailout, Ireland is now subject to two review missions a year until 75 per cent of the State’s bailout loans are paid back. The last ESM loan is scheduled to be repaid in 2042.   The European Central Bank (ECB) left its key interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.25% despite concerns about credit availability in struggling economies and falling inflation. In London, the Bank of England kept its benchmark rate unchanged at 0.5%. The HSBC Emerging Markets Index (EMI), a monthly indicator derived from the PMI (purchasing managers' index) surveys, fell for the third month running to 51.1 in February 2014, from 51.4 in the first month of 2014. That signalled the weakest growth in global emerging market output since last September, with the EMI also remaining well below its long-run trend level of 54.0.   The Story of the week for me…A team of engineers led by SAP have set a new Guinness World Record for the largest data warehouse, a 12.1 petabyte data warehouse. To give you an idea on just how big 12.1 petabytes is, a single petabyte of MP3 songs, each 4 minutes long, would take 2,000 years to play.

item.title: We paid over €168 million in Claims last year
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
Cancer Remains Leading Cause of Death and Illness

  Today we revealed our annual claims data which once again provides a valuable insight into the health of the nation. The data details the illnesses and conditions that led to payments of over €168 million in Life Insurance and Specified Illness Cover claims in 2013. Here are some main figures; • €112.4 million paid in Life Insurance for 1,714 deceased customers •  €56.4 million paid for 810 Specified Illness Cover claims •  That’s €449,800 in Life Insurance claims and €225,600 in Specified Illness Cover claims every working day during 2013 •  Cancer and heart-related complaints remain the two main overall causes of both Life Insurance and Specified Illness Cover claims •  Significant gender differences – percentage of heart related conditions for men was double the rate for women •  Almost half (47%) of all life cover claims for people under 40 were as a result of accidents •  Largest Life Insurance payment was €1.15 million and largest Specified Illness Cover claim was €1.1 million The analysis of the claims book, which for 2013 includes data from both Irish Life and Canada Life, reports that €112.4 million was paid out for 1,714 Life Insurance claims and a further €56.4 million for 810 Specified Illness Cover claims. The average payment was €65,560 in respect of Life Insurance claims and €69,638 for Specified Illness Cover claims although the figures show wide variations in the size of claims settled. Commenting on the data Gerry Hassett, our Managing Director, Irish Life Retail said: “The scale of the Life Insurance and Specified Illness Cover claims paid shows that it is crucially important for people to look after the interests of their dependants in the event of death and serious illness.” He added: “It also makes financial sense when you consider that a healthy 30-year old non-smoker will pay just under €38 per month for €100,000 life cover and €100,000 Independent Specified Illness cover, assuming a 20 year term.”  The 2013 claims book shows that cancer remains the biggest cause of both Life Insurance and Specified Illness Cover claims, accounting for 44 per cent of Life Insurance claims and 58 per cent of Specified Illness Cover claims, with heart-related conditions accounting for 16 per cent of Life Insurance claims and 22 per cent of Specified Illness Cover claims. Visit our Claims Map
Gender variations The figures, however, show significant variations between males and females in the cause of claims. While cancer accounted for more than half of Life Insurance claims for females the corresponding figures for males was 41 per cent while heart-related conditions accounted for double the level of claims for males as for females. The disparity between males and females was even more pronounced in the case of Specified Illness Cover claims. Cancer accounted for almost three quarters of female Specified Illness Cover claims but just under half of male claims, while heart-related conditions accounted for more than one third of male Specified Illness Cover claims but just 7 per cent of female claims. The largest single Life Insurance claim paid out by Irish Life and Canada Life in 2013 was over €1 million in respect of a male in his 50s, while the largest claim paid out for a female was almost €800,000 for a customer in her 50s. In the case of Specified Illness Cover claims, the largest payment was €1.1 million to a male in his 40s for cancer, while €380,000 was paid to a female in her 40s, also for cancer. The figures also show that of the 138 claims paid out for accidental death, 25 were the result of a road traffic accident, which equated to €2 million in payments. Alcohol was a factor in 6 per cent of all accident claims, which is down slightly from 7 per cent in 2012, and 14 per cent in 2011. We paid out many claims shortly after the cover was taken out, for example a 60-year-old female was paid €250,000 for a Specified Illness Cover just 17 weeks after she took out the policy. In the case of Life Insurance claims, the estate of a male in his 50s was paid over €500,000 just six months after the policy was taken out and €30,000 was paid to the dependents of a customer who died in an accident three months after he started the cover. ClaimsCare Claims Hub And because we believe in paying claims, we're constantly trying to make it easier for you to get the help you need. With that in mind, we just launched our ClaimsCare Claims Hub - an online home for all the information you need about making a claim with us.   Appendices Irish Life and Canada Life – Life Insurance claims 2013
Early Claims Settled
Over €180k to the estate of a female in her early 40s who died of a stroke, the policy had been in place for 10 months
€200,000 to the estate of a male in his early 40s who died of a Heart Attack, the policy had been in place for 11 months
Largest Claims Settled
 Over €1 million to the estate of male in his mid-50s who died of heart disease
Over €800k to the estate of a male in his mid-40s who died of a brain tumour
Almost €800k to the estate of a female in her early 50s who died of surgical complications
Almost €600k to the estate of a female in her early 50s who died of lung cancer
  Irish Life and Canada Life – Specified Illness Cover Claims 2013
Early Claims Settled – Specified Illness Cover
€50,000 to a male in his late 40s who was diagnosed with Malignant Cancer – Melanoma – nine weeks after taking out cover
€250,000 to a female in her early 60s diagnosed with a Malignant Cancer, 17 weeks after taking out the policy
Largest Claims Settled – Specified Illness Cover
 €1.1 million to a male in his 40s for Malignant Cancer of the Thyroid
€510,000 to a male in his late 50s for Malignant Cancer of the Prostate
€380,000 to a female in her late 40s for Malignant Cancer – Melanoma
€277,000 to a male in his 50s for kidney failure
€265,300 to a female in her 40s for Malignant Cancer of the Breast

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week11
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Ever tried. Ever failed. No matter. Try Again. Fail again. Fail better” - Samuel Beckett   Consumer Prices in February, as measured by the CPI (consumer price index), increased by 0.5% month-on-month and was 0.1% lower Year-on-Year. This is the first time since July 2010 that the CPI has fallen on an annual basis. The most notable changes in the year were decreases in Communications (-4.0%), Furnishings, Household Equipment & Routine Household Maintenance (-3.6%), Clothing & Footwear (-3.4%) and Transport (-2.0%). There were increases in Education (+4.6%), Alcoholic Beverages & Tobacco (+3.3%) and Miscellaneous Goods & Services (+3.2%).   New cars licensed in February were up 23% on 2013 levels and new goods vehicles licensed were up by 45%. This provides further evidence that the rebound in Irish consumer and business confidence has led households and companies to increase their spending.   Irish national accounts data showed Irish GDP was down 0.3% in 2013 but GNP was up 3.4%.   The National Treasury Management Agency (NTMA) has raised €1 billion in an auction of benchmark 10-year bonds, reaching its target in the first regular sale of Government debt since exiting the bailout in December. The agency said it received total bids of 2.9 times the amount on offer, with a yield of 2.967%.   ECB governing council member Christian Noyer indicated that he sees the strong euro creating economic pressures. While not advocating any explicit action to weaken the euro, Noyer did suggest the ECB end sterilisation of the now defunct SMP bond buying programme in order to flatten money market curves.   Bank of England Governor Mark Carney indicated that he believes a 2-3% range for UK interest rates over the medium term is plausible.   New York, London, Hong Kong and Singapore remain the top four global financial centres. Dublin's IFSC slips to 66 of 83 cities -- down 10 ranks in the biannual survey of financial services professionals and is ranked number 19 of the top 20 European centres.   Recovery is under way in the world’s advanced economies, underpinned by supportive financial conditions and reduced drag from budgetary tightening, but activity in the major emerging markets is mixed, according to the OECD’s latest Interim Economic Assessment.   Shanghai Chaori Solar Energy Science & Technology Co. failed to make an 89.8 million yuan ($14.7 million) interest payment. This is the first domestic corporate bond default in the history of the People’s Republic of China.   The Story of the week for me… Environmental engineers and coastal erosion researchers estimate that Ireland is 250 acres smaller – as the recent floods and storms tore large blocks off the country's coastline.

item.title: Hey Superwoman – yes I mean you!
item.dc:creator: Sarah Blake
item.content:encoded:
I know women often think they are invincible. I see women in my life laugh at the thought of manflu and play things down if they’re not feeling great. We just keep going no matter what! But I’m sure we can all think of women in our lives that were hit out of the blue with a serious illness or died suddenly. My grandmother passed away from breast cancer at 68. She would never entertain the thought of being ill and was one of the toughest women I know, she sure seemed like Superwoman to me. Unfortunately no matter how tough we feel and healthy our lifestyle, we can’t take our good health as a given. This is brought home to us in Irish Life every time we look at all the life insurance and specified illness insurance claims we pay to our customers. Some of Irish Life’s 2013 claim statistics:
  • We paid out €168 million in life and specified illness insurance claims to both men and women.
  • We paid out 579 life insurance claims and 344 specified illness insurance claims to women.
  • 38% of all our life and specified illness insurance claims are paid to women.
  • The average age of women making specified illness claims was just 53.
  • The most common cause of claims for women is cancer (malignant), followed by stroke (resulting in permanent symptoms).
  • We paid one customer who was diagnosed with a benign brain tumour €100,000. She only had her plan in place with us for 12 weeks.
  • We paid the family of a customer €100,000 when she passed away from sudden adult death syndrome. She had her plan for just 2 years.
Most women make a big contribution to their households either through working or looking after the family so it’s important to consider the financial impact if something were to happen to you. I know it’s not a happy thought but maybe just for today imagine what would happen if you couldn’t be Superwoman someday. You can find more information on the claims we paid in 2013 here or you can get a quote for life insurance here. Remember you must keep up payments to stay on cover. Please see our product booklets for more information.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: life insurance claims women
A look at some of the life and specified illness claims that Irish Life paid to women in 2013.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great post, so many woman think that it's the men who need the insurance. But women are just as susceptible to death as men. Men just get hurt easier!
So true Kerrie, thanks for reading!

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week12
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Patience is the companion of wisdom” - St. Augustine   The Irish Quarterly Rent Index shows continued growth in Dublin Rents of 2.1% for Q4 2013, while outside Dublin rents dropped by 0.9%. On an annual basis, this means that rents in Dublin grew by 7.6%, comparing Q4 of 2013 to Q4 of 2012. In contrast, the market outside Dublin posted an increase of 1.1%.   Ryanair announced plans to issue a bond allowing the carrier to access capital markets as it looks for secured and unsecured debt financing for its order of 175 Boeing 737 aircraft.   The European Union’s plan for an integrated banking union passed a decisive milestone after member states and the European Parliament reached agreement on the Single Resolution Mechanism, a centralised resolution body and accompanying €55 billion fund that will be responsible for winding-up troubled banks in the Eurozone.   Matteo Renzi, the Italian prime minister, announced a $10bn package of tax cuts and other measures to revive growth in Italy’s stagnant economy, increase investment in education and create jobs in particular for young people at a time of high unemployment.   Greece reached a deal with international lenders on a range of structural reforms that will allow it to unlock €10bn tranche of bailout aid. The €10bn payment will cover sovereign bond repayments which are due in May.   The flash estimate of the Markit Eurozone Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) came in at 53.2, only slightly lower than February’s 32-month high of 53.3 and registering expansion for the ninth consecutive month. A reading above 50 indicates expansion while below 50 signifies contraction.   The Federal Reserve’s new forecasts, released yesterday, expect policy rates to increase to 1% by the end of 2015, and to 2.25% by the end of 2016. The Federal Reserve also tapered its monthly asset purchases by another $10bn, to $55bn.   Financing provided by venture capital for developing companies, mainly in the high tech sector, last year amounted to $33bn in the US; $7.1bn in Europe; $3.5bn in China and $2.3bn in Israel. In Ireland VC financing amounted to$364m.   The Story of the week for me… An ornament bought by a scrap dealer to be melted down for its gold has turned out to be a missing Faberge egg worth £20 million. The Imperial Easter Egg was designed by Carl Fabergé for Tsar Alexander III in 1887 and seized by the Bolsheviks during the Russian Revolution.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week13
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“I think of life as a good book. The further you get into it. The more it begins to make sense” - Harold Kushner   The number of new Irish start-ups is reported to have risen by an average of 127 per day in Q1 2014.   In the year to February, residential property prices at a national level, increased by 8.1%. Compared to an increase of 6.3% in January and a decrease of 2.6% recorded in the twelve months to February 2013. In Dublin residential property prices fell by 0.6% in February and were 13.3% higher than a year ago.   Irish home mortgage approvals in February 2014 on an annualised basis were at the lowest since 1972, even though Ireland's population has grown by 53% in the interval from 3m to 4.6m.   Eurozone annual inflation is expected to be 0.5% in March 2014, down from 0.7% in February, according to a flash estimate from Eurostat, the statistics office of the European Union.   In 2013, average hourly labour costs in the whole economy excluding agriculture and public administration were estimated to be €23.7 in the EU28 and €28.4 in the Eurozone EA17. The lowest hourly labour costs were recorded in Bulgaria €3.7, Romania €4.6, Lithuania €6.2 and Latvia €6.3, and the highest in Sweden €40.1, Denmark €38.4, Belgium €38.0, Luxembourg €35.7 and France €34.3. They were at €29.0 in Ireland.   Frankfurt, the Eurozone's financial capital, is named Europe’s trading hub for the Chinese yuan/renminbi.   Unemployment in France rose 0.9% in February. The data show that the number of people registered as jobless reached a record 3,347,700, the highest since 1996, up 0.9% over the previous month and 4.7% in the year.   The US Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is up an annualised 2.6% in Q4 2013.   US consumer confidence unexpectedly rose in March and is now at its highest level since the crisis began sitting at 82.3, the highest since January 2008, from an upwardly revised 78.3 in February.   Russia’s credit rating outlook was cut to negative from stable by Standard & Poor’s, which said economic risks have risen because of Western sanctions over the seizure of Ukraine’s breakaway Crimea region.   The Story of the week for me…  A 33-year-old man has set a Guinness World record

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week14
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Never be afraid to sit a while and think” – Lorraine Hansberry   The Bord Gáis Energy Index rose 1% in March as a 6% month-on-month rise in Irish wholesale electricity prices was offset by falling oil (down 1% month-on-month) and wholesale UK gas prices (down 5% month-on-month). The index is up 41% since the start of 2010.   The Central Bank expects GDP (gross domestic product) to grow by 2% this year, powered by employment growth, investment by companies and improving economic growth overseas.   The average asking price for properties outside of Dublin has risen during the first quarter of 2014; the first quarterly rise since mid-2007. Nationally, the average asking price is now €177,000, up 3.5% from the same time last year and down 53% from the peak. Asking prices in Dublin increased by 1.3% in the first quarter of 2014, the fourth quarter in a row Dublin has recorded a price increase and puts the average asking price in the capital at €244,000.   The European Central Bank (ECB) left its key interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.25% despite concerns about credit availability in struggling economies and falling inflation. ECB chief Mario Draghi told a news conference that he and his colleagues expected a prolonged period of low inflation and that if it dragged on too long, action in the form of quantitative easing could be taken.   The Eurozone (EA18) seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate was 11.9% in February 2014. It was 12.0% in February 2013. The EU28 unemployment rate was 10.6% in February 2014, down from 10.7% in January 2014 compared with 10.9% in February 2013.   The HSBC Emerging Markets Index (EMI), a monthly indicator derived from the PMI (purchasing managers' index) surveys, fell for the fourth month running to 50.3 in March, from 51.1 in February, indicating only a marginal increase in private sector output across global emerging markets. Output has contracted since February in three of the four largest emerging economies. China posted a marginal decline for the second month running, while India slipped back into contraction. Meanwhile, Russian private sector output fell at the fastest rate since May 2009.   Nigeria has rebased its gross domestic product (GDP) data, which has pushed it above South Africa as the Africa’s biggest economy. Nigerian GDP now includes previously uncounted industries like telecoms, information technology, music, online sales, airlines, and film production. GDP for 2013 totalled 80.3 trillion naira ($509.9bn). That compares with South Africa's GDP of $370.3bn at the end of 2013.   The Story of the week for me… There are a number of hazards in golf: sand traps, the rough and water. You can now add wildfires to that list. Researchers believe that titanium golf clubs are responsible for sparking wildfires in California. The reason behind this logic is that as the titanium club strikes a ball, nearby rocks can tear particles of titanium from the sole of the head and bits of the particle surfaces will react violently with oxygen or nitrogen in the air, heat is produced and foliage ignites in flames.

item.title: European Movement Ireland Seminar Dublin April 11 2014
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_2695" align="aligncenter" width="550"] Pictured (l-r) are Leo Varadkar, TD, Minister for Transport, Tourism and Sport, Catherine Day, Secretary General, European Commission, Maurice Pratt, Chairperson, European Movement Ireland and Paul Mahon, President and CEO, Great-West Lifeco[/caption] Paul Mahon, President and CEO, Great-West Lifeco Inc., was a keynote speaker at a seminar hosted by European Movement Ireland as part of its 60th anniversary celebrations, on the EU’s trade relations with North America. The seminar, held April 11, 2014 in Dublin, focused on the importance of bilateral free trade agreements currently under negotiation between the EU and the United States and Canada, and their potential impact on Ireland.
Paul spoke about Great-West Lifeco’s investment in Irish Life, and why Ireland and Canada can each benefit from closer trading links, particularly with the new EU deal. The other keynote speakers were Catherine Day, Secretary General, European Commission; and Leo Varadkar, TD, Ireland’s Minister for Transport, Tourism and Sport. To read Paul’s full speech click here

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week15
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Enjoy the little things, for one day you may look back and realise they were the big things” – Robert Brault   The Economic and Social Research Institute (ESRI) expects economic growth in Ireland to remain strong in 2014 and 2015, with GNP (gross national product) of over 3.5% forecast in both years. However, the institute warned that if measures to increase housing supply in Dublin are not implemented, the current housing shortfall could undermine recovery as higher house prices and rents make it more expensive for people to live and work in the economy.   Greece has returned to global capital markets for the first time since the Eurozone crisis erupted in 2010, attracting big demand for its government bonds in a sign of growing confidence in the Eurozone weakest economy. Investors purchased up 3 billion euros of 5-year bonds with demand for the bonds coming in around 11 billion euros.   The global recovery is becoming broader, but the changing external environment poses new challenges to emerging market and developing economies, says the IMF’s latest World Economic Outlook (WEO). The WEO warns of the risk from persistently low inflation/deflation in advanced economies, in particular in the Eurozone. The IMF forecasts global growth to average 3.6% in 2014, up from 3% in 2013, and to rise to 3.9% in 2015.   China's exports slumped for the second straight month in March. The Chinese premier firmly ruled out a stimulus program highlighting that job creation was the government’ policy priority and that it did not matter if growth came in a little below the official target of 7.5%.   According to the East Asia Pacific Economic Update developing countries in the East Asia Pacific region will see stable economic growth in 2014 (forecast of 7.1% in 2014), bolstered by a recovery in high-income economies and the market’s modest response so far to the Federal Reserve’s tapering of its quantitative easing programme.   The Bank of Japan refrained from taking extra monetary easing measures, opting instead to continue pumping up the monetary base.   The US has warned Beijing against manipulating its currency following a sharp depreciation (>2.5%) of the renminbi since 2014.   The Story of the week for me… Thanks to a new "interactive 3D experience" athletes the world over will be able to navigate the London marathon from the comfort of their own treadmill. Marathon organisers have combined with treadmill video producers to create a new system that combines HD video of the entire 26.2 mile.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week16
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Anyone who has never made a mistake has never tried anything new” – Albert Einstein   The CSO published the government finances for 2013 and the figures show that the General Government Deficit continues to fall standing at 7.2% in 2013, an improvement on the 2012 position of €13.44bn (8.2% of GDP).   The number of jobless in the UK dipped by 77,000 to a five-year low of 2.24m in the three months to February 2014.   Italy's government approved the country's first sweeping income tax cuts in more than a decade, in an attempt to boost its economy, giving up to €80 a month in extra cash to three-quarters of the workforce.   Economic activity in the US rebounded in recent weeks from weather-related slowdowns earlier this year, according to the Federal Reserve's "Beige Book" survey of regional economic conditions.   Janet Yellen (Chairperson of the Federal Reserve) announced that the Federal Reserve’s policy hinges on three "big questions,” including low inflation and labour-market slack, as they consider when the economy is healthy enough to begin raising rates.   According to the BofA Merrill Lynch Fund Manager Survey for April, Investor confidence in global economic growth remains high even as expectations of higher short-term rates increase. A net 66% of global fund managers believe the US is still the most over-valued equity market, little changed from March and February. A net 55% think Emerging Markets are undervalued, up from 49% in March and the highest reading ever. Only a net 2% would like to underweight emerging markets, down sharply from 21% in March.   China's gross domestic product growth slipped to 7.4% in the Q1 2014 to its slowest level in 18 months as the world's second-largest economy continues to shift down a gear.   Growth in residential property prices across large and medium-size Chinese cities slowed further in March as lending limits and discounts undercut demand, according to analysts and property developers.   Both the Irish and UK commercial property markets have strengthened in Q1 of 2014 with the latest JLL Irish Property Index showing overall returns at 9.1% while, commercial property values in the UK rose by a further 1.0% in March. According to the IPD UK Monthly Property Index, values have now risen by 6.8% over the last 10 months of consecutive growth, although overall they still remain below their 2007 peak levels.   The Story of the week for me…  The extent of China's soil pollution, long guarded as a state secret, was laid out in an official report that confirmed deep-seated fears about contaminated farmland and the viability of the country's food supply. The report highlights nearly one-fifth of its arable land is contaminated by pollution.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: There are numerous kinds of life insurance coverage, but they generally fall straight into two types: term insurance policy and long term insurance.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week17
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“One can choose to go back toward safety or forward toward growth” – Abraham Maslow   Unemployment in Ireland fell to 11.8 percent in March, the lowest rate in five years. However, Eurostat has revealed Ireland is the fourth highest of the union's 28 countries for the number of long-term jobless people. The statistics show that about 60pc of those out of work are on the Live Register for more than a year.   As earning season was well underway it has emerged European companies’ earnings growth has yet to meet expectations. Over half the 101 companies of the 374 Stoxx600 European companies that have reported so far on their first quarter performance have disappointed consensus earnings. While in the US of the 240 companies of the S&P 500 that have reported earnings to date for Q1 2014, 73% have posted earnings above the average estimate.   The Eurozone took another step to recovery after investor’s flocked to Portugal’s first regular debt auction since applying for international help in 2011, pushing its borrowing costs to their lowest level in eight years. The auction of the 10-year bond raised €750m with a yield of 3.57%, paving the way for Portugal to become the second Eurozone country after Ireland to escape from its three-year rescue programme.   According to a report published by Davy, Ireland’s household and corporate debt levels look exceptionally high on historical and international comparisons with no sign that the pace of deleveraging is abating. Although Irish household debt has fallen by 17% from its peak in 2008, tax rises and wage cuts have hurt disposable incomes. Hence, the ratio of disposable income peaked later, in 2011, at 212% – only falling to 196% by Q3 2013. This suggests that Irish households are at an early stage of their deleveraging process. In comparison, UK household debt has fallen for six years from a peak of 170% of disposable income in 2008 to 140% in 2013.   Warm weather and the stockpiling of gas has knocked nearly a quarter of the wholesale price of gas, according to the latest Wholesale Market Report on Irish energy prices. The crucial factor in lowering prices was warmer weather conditions since winter last year, and the absence of any major unplanned outages in sources of supply to the network. As a result, there is 27% more gas in the European system now than at the same time last year.   The US Federal Reserve showed signs that it is highly likely to slow its asset purchases by another $10 billion in the coming weeks as the economy shakes of its winter torpor.   The Story of the week for me… A blast from the past - In 2006 a global real estate agency compared the cost of a single-family dwelling, 2,200 square feet (approximately) four bedrooms, two and one-half baths, family room (or equivalent) and two-car garage in neighbourhoods/zip codes within a market that is typical for corporate middle-management level families, in 384 markets including 42 outside North America. It found that for the cost in Dublin of $1.4m (€1.1m), you could buy nine similar houses in Houston, Texas, three in Amsterdam, two in Sydney and almost two in Tokyo.
