item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week18
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Either you run the day or the day runs you” – Jim Rohn   In the year to March, residential Irish property prices at a national level, increased by 7.8%. This compares with an increase of 8.1% in February and a decrease of 3.0% recorded in the twelve months to March 2013. Dublin prices are up by 14.3% in the 12 months.   Live Register data for April shows another fall in the Irish unemployment rate to 11.7%. The unemployment rate has now fallen from 12.1% in December 2013 and from its 15.1% peak in early 2012. On a seasonally adjusted basis, there were 392,700 claimants in April, the lowest level since April 2009. The unemployment rate is now at its lowest since March 2009.   The Eurozone (EA18) seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate was 11.8% in March 2014, stable since December 2013, but down from 12.0% in March 2013. The EU28 unemployment rate was 10.5% in March 2014, stable compared with February 2014, but down from 10.9% in March 2013.   Eurozone annual inflation is expected to be 0.7% in April 2014, up from 0.5% in March, according to a flash estimate from Eurostat, the statistics office of the European Union.   The US added jobs in April at the fastest pace in more than two years and the jobless rate plunged, signalling that the economy rebounded from a winter slide. The release marked the best month of job creation since January 2012 and the second-best month since the economy emerged from recession in mid-2009. The jobless rate dropped to 6.3% from 6.7%, hitting the lowest level since September 2008.   US economic growth shuddered to a halt, increasing at an annual rate of 0.1% in Q1 2014, making the first quarter one of the weakest paces of the five-year recovery as poor weather appeared to have stalled business investment while weak overseas demand hit exports.   The UK economy grew by 0.8% in the first quarter (Q1) of 2014, according to data published by the Office for National Statistics (ONS), indicating that the economy is now 0.6% smaller than its 2008 peak.   According to the World Bank, Developing countries in the East Asia Pacific region will see stable economic growth in 2014, bolstered by a recovery in high-income economies and the market’s modest response to the Federal Reserve’s tapering of quantitative easing. According to the report, Developing East Asia will grow by 7.1% this year, largely unchanged from 2013. As a result, the World Bank says East Asia remains the fastest growing region in the world, despite a slowdown from the average growth rate of 8.0% from 2009 to 2013.   The Story of the week for me… The United States has enjoyed the largest economy in the world since it displaced Great Britain in 1872. As of Friday the World Bank announced that China’s economy (growth of 24% between 2011 and 2014) will surpass the United States (growth of 7.6% between 2011 and 2014) in 2014 and take the top spot. India will become the third-largest economy having previously been in tenth place. The size of its economy almost doubled from 19% of the US in 2005 to 37% in 2011.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week19
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Action speaks louder than words but not nearly as often” – Mark Twain   The Bord Gáis Energy Index fell by 5% in April as a steady supply of gas to the UK, coupled with falling demand weighed on wholesale gas prices generally. However, tensions as a result of the Ukrainian crisis and the on-going potential threat to European gas supplies did push wholesale prices higher on occasion.   The Central Bank reported that Irish household debt declined by €2.4bn during Q4 2013, falling to €166bn or €36,203 per capita. This marked the largest decrease in debt since Q4 2012.   Prices on average in Ireland, as measured by the CPI (consumer price index), were 0.3% higher in April compared with April 2013. The sectors which caused the largest upward contribution to the CPI in the year were Miscellaneous Goods & Services (+0.38%), Restaurants & Hotels (+0.30%) and Alcoholic Beverages & Tobacco (+0.21%).   The European Central Bank (ECB) left its key interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.25% despite concerns about credit availability in struggling economies and the threat of deflation. Furthermore, the European Central Bank sent an unusually strong signal that it would likely cut interest rates or take other stimulus measures in June to combat the low inflation that threatens Europe's recovery.   The euro zone's economy grew at the fastest pace for almost three years in April, but manufacturers and service providers continued to cut their prices.   The Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 0.5%, the lowest rate since 1694 when the Bank was founded   In a further sign that the U.K.'s economic recovery continues to strengthen, activity in the key services sector expanded at the fastest pace so far this year, while jobs growth surged.   The HSBC Emerging Markets Index (EMI), a monthly indicator derived from the PMI (purchasing managers' surveys), continued to indicate only a marginal increase in output across global emerging markets in April. The EMI posted 50.4, from 50.3 in March, well below its eight-and-a-half year long-run trend level of 53.9. Overall April data indicated falling output in the four largest emerging economies (Brazil, Russia, India and China)   In the latest sign of concerns over debt in China's financial system, Beijing's local banking regulator has warned banks to step up their vigilance in lending to individual borrowers.   The Story of the week for me…  Apple is in the final stages of talks to purchase Beats Electronics (primarily a headphone manufacturer) for $3.2 billion, a fraction of Apples $150 billion cash reserves.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week20
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Nothing is a waste of time if you use the experience wisely” – Auguste Rodin   Moody’s has upgraded Ireland’s credit rating by two notches to Baa1 from Baa3 with a “stable outlook.” This is the second time in six months that it has raised Irelands rating.   GDP rose by 0.2% in the Eurozone (EA18) and by 0.3% in the EU28 during the first quarter of 2014, compared with the previous quarter, according to flash estimates published by Eurostat. In the fourth quarter of 2013, GDP (gross domestic product) grew by 0.2% in the Eurozone and by 0.4% in the EU28.   The euro zone's trade surplus shrank in March compared with the same month a year earlier, as exports and imports fell for the first time since the end of 2013.   Germany's central bank is willing to back an array of stimulus measures by the European Central Bank next month if needed to fight unacceptably low inflation, underscoring the Bundesbank's shift away from its reputation in recent years as the euro zone's policy rebel.   EBS released its latest EBS DKM Affordability Index showing that the Irish national housing affordability level for first time buyers remains stable at 19.3% of net income for a working couple purchasing the average property. This figure is forecasted to rise to 19.6% in the next month. While affordability is now at levels last seen by the end of 2008, it is still well below the peak level of 26.4% of net income for a working couple in December 2006, as falling interest rates and prices more than offset a rise in personal taxes.   Bank of England officials signalled that they remain on track to raise interest rates in the U.K. early next year, as their counterparts at the European Central Bank ready fresh stimulus measures to revive a fitful recovery in the 18-nation euro zone.   Japan's economy regained momentum in the first quarter of this year despite sluggish global growth, as domestic demand spiked in anticipation of a consumption-tax increase and improved employment.   The number of Americans filing first-time jobless benefits fell sharply last week to a seven-year low, a sign of strength in the labour market following several weeks of instability.   The Bank of America Merrill Lynch Fund Managers' Survey for May found that investors are sitting on more cash and have reduced equity holdings compared to a month ago. Average cash levels have reached 5% of portfolios, the highest level since June 2012 and up from 4.8% in April. A net 22% are taking below normal levels of risk, up from 11% a month ago. The proportion of asset allocators overweight equities has fallen to a net 37% from a net 45% last month.   The Story of the week for me…  Japan will allow individuals to own inflation-linked bonds from next year in response to growing demand for protection against rising prices as the Bank of Japan continues its ultra-easy monetary policy.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week21
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Live out your imagination, not your history”  – Stephen Covey   Ahead of European elections on the weekend, Irish 10-year government bond yields rose by 9 basis points to 2.81%, their highest level since May 2nd   Sentiment gained little from a mixed bag of European PMIs, indicating that the recovery in Q2 remained reliant on Germany, with France contracting. UK GDP growth was unrevised at 0.8% in Q1, with the recovery broadening out into investment spending.   According to an official with the European Central Bank, the ECB is more concerned with low growth or stagnation combined with low inflation or even deflation, and increasing levels of public debt than with inflation.   IMD the Swiss business school announced its annual world competitiveness ranking. As part of its ranking, the IMD World Competitiveness Center also looks at perceptions of each country as a place to do business. The top 3 are US, Switzerland and Singapore with Ireland in 15th place up from 17th in 2013 and behind Malaysia with a 12th rank.   Bank of Japan Gov. Haruhiko Kuroda said he saw little reason for the yen to strengthen against key currencies, signalling concern that a further rebound could cast a shadow over the Japanese economy and the central bank's fight against deflation.   The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits rose last week but the total number of unemployed people drawing benefits has hit a post-recession low, a sign of general improvement in the U.S. labour market.   Bank of England Gov. Mark Carney spelled out a series of potential risks to the U.K. economy, noting that the central bank has a wary eye on the housing market and signalling that officials are uncomfortable with the strength of the pound. Mark Carney seems determined to leave U.K. rates as low as possible as long as possible, when they finally start to go up, to raise them slowly.   Fitch Ratings on Friday upgraded Greece's sovereign rating to B from B-, still in junk territory   A key gauge of China's factory activity showed signs of stabilising in May, but the world's second largest economy was still struggling to gain traction and analysts said more government help might be needed in the months ahead.   The Story of the week for me… amid growing concerns about the strength of France's economic recovery France's national rail company announced on Tuesday it had ordered 2,000 trains for an expanded regional network that are too wide for many station platforms

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week22
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“To climb steep hills requires slow pace at first”  – William Shakespeare   In the year to April, residential property prices on a national level, increased by 8.5%. This compares with an increase of 7.8% in March and a decrease of 1.2% recorded in the twelve months to April 2013. Dublin prices rose 3.1% in the month and are up 17.8% in 12 months. The price of residential properties in the rest of Ireland fell by 0.3% in April compared with an increase of 1.2% in April of last year.   The International Monetary Fund announced that the Bank of Japan may need to maintain its current pace of monetary easing for an extended period to give Prime Minister Shinzo Abe time to complete his economic revival agenda.   Japan remained the world's largest net creditor nation in 2013, but China made steady gains. That is little surprise, given Japan's expanding trade deficits and low returns on foreign assets. China, on the other hand, runs large trade surpluses.   The European Central Bank warned that the main risk for European financial markets is a reversal in potentially "fickle" capital inflows into the euro zone, a factor which has benefited banks and governments in recent months through lower borrowing costs.   Standard & Poor's Ratings Services on Friday upgraded Spain's long- and short-term foreign and local currency sovereign ratings to BBB/A-2 from BBB-/A-3.   German lawmakers adopted a controversial bill that will lower the retirement age and raise pension payments for some workers at a cost of $218 billion through 2030.   Russia, Belarus and Kazakhstan signed a treaty formally creating the Eurasian Economic Union, as President Vladimir Putin pushes forward with his goal of reintegrating the economies of the former Soviet Union and creating a counterbalance to the European Union.   Bank lending to euro-zone businesses fell in April, marking nearly two years of declines and indicating that credit scarcity is still a drag on the currency area's weak economic recovery.   Revised GDP figures indicate that the U.S. economy contracted in the first quarter, the latest stumble for a recovery that has struggled to find its footing since recession ended almost five years ago. U.S. 1Q preliminary GDP contracted at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.0%; economists predicted a 0.6% decline.   Narendra Modi, the son of a tea seller with political roots in India's Hindu nationalist movement, was sworn in as prime minister of the world's largest democracy, putting in place a leaner central government and promising Indians "a glorious future."   The Story of the week for me… The Italian government has decided to include illegal economically productive activity in their estimates of the country’s GDP in a bid to boost its shaky economy.

item.title: Aiming for top class claims service
item.dc:creator: Sarah Blake
item.content:encoded:
Last year we paid over 2,500 claim payments worth over €168 million to families right across Ireland. Making a claim is not something you do every day and we know it can feel very daunting at a time when you are already feeling vulnerable. The way we look at it is when someone makes a claim this is our moment to try to be our absolute best. That’s why we’ve a team of over 20 dedicated claims handlers who are specially trained to help make the process as easy as possible. We know that we can’t take away people’s loss or help them through their illness but we aim to provide the best claims service we possibly can. We aim for a 10 out of 10 service I work on our customer satisfaction research team and every month we have an independent research company call our customers who made specified illness cover claims with us to get their feedback on the service that they received. In 2013 customers scored us:
  • 9.4/10 for our claims team being helpful, knowledgeable and keeping their promises.
  • 9.3/10 for the speed of paying their claim.
  • 9.2/10 for our claims team treating them fairly.
We measure to decimal places because we want to get those scores as close to 10 as possible! Within that customer feedback I regularly see examples of how our claims team really go out of their way to help our customers. Here are just a few examples:
  • Deborah was reviewing a death claim that was paid for a customer. She noticed that the illness the customer had might fall under one of our definitions for specified illness cover. Deborah requested further medical information from the hospital and her investigations meant that as well as paying the original life claim we would also be sending the family another cheque for a separate specified illness cover claim.
  • Shane one of our financial advisers spotted that a customer mentioned a previous illness in a meeting in relation to a different plan. He passed this to the claims team who saw the customer had another plan with Specified Illness Cover. Shane encouraged and helped the customer to make a claim when the customer didn’t think they could. This led to a full claim paid to the customer.
  • Nuala was contacted by an adviser to let her know about a customer who needed to make an urgent claim as they were receiving private treatment for their illness. Nuala told the adviser exactly what was needed for the claim and the adviser arranged this the same day. The claim came in on a Monday and the cheque was received by the customer on the Thursday.
9 out of every 10 of our claims customers would recommend us to family and friends. That’s something that we’re really proud of. Source: The Leadership Factor, December 2012 - December 2013. 104 of 818 Specified Illness claims paid in 2013 surveyed. To find out more about our claims service visit irishlife.ie/ClaimsCare

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week23
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“You will never find time for anything. If you want the time you must make it.”  – Charles Buxton   Ireland’s credit rating was upgraded one level by Standard & Poor’s. The rating was raised to A- from BBB+ with a positive outlook.   The Bord Gáis Energy Index was unchanged month-on-month in May with rising Brent crude oil prices being offset by falling wholesale gas and electricity prices. In May 2014 the Index stood at 133 which is 3% lower than 12 months ago.   Boosted by new export orders from the U.K., Irish manufacturing orders posted its 12th successive monthly rise in May.   Eurozone annual inflation is expected to be 0.5% in May 2014, down from 0.7% in April, according to a flash estimate from Eurostat, the statistics office of the European Union.   The European Central Bank took extraordinary steps Thursday to stave off the threat of low inflation in Europe cutting the benchmark interest rate from 0.25% to 0.15% and the deposit rate for bank funds to a negative 0.10% in a bid to get banks to lend more to credit-starved customers.   The Eurozone (EA18) seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate was 11.7% in April 2014, down from 11.8% in March 2014, and from 12.0% in April 2013. The EU28 unemployment rate was 10.4% in April 2014, down from 10.5% in March 2014, and from 10.9% in April 2013. The lowest rate was in Austria at 4.9% and the highest was in Greece at 26.5%.   The Bank of England kept its official rate at 0.5%, the lowest rate since the bank was founded by a charter signed in 1694.   A member of the Bank of England's financial stability panel noted that the U.K. economy is still fragile despite a recent growth spurt and its financial system remains vulnerable to a variety of risks from at home and abroad.   U.S. nonfarm payrolls advanced a seasonally adjusted 217,000 last month, providing renewed evidence that the five-year-long recovery accelerated this spring. The jobless rate was unchanged at 6.3%. Nonfarm payroll employment fell by 8.7m from January 2008 through February 2010. Since then, employment has risen by 8.8m meaning all the jobs that were lost during the recession have been recovered. Of course the population has also increased since 2008.   The net worth of U.S. households and non-profit organizations rose roughly 2% in the first quarter to $81.8 trillion, the highest on record, according to a report by the Federal Reserve.   According to the World Bank China's economy is expected to record slower growth over the medium term, but Beijing has the ability to roll out economic support measures to meet its official target of about 7.5% this year.   The Story of the week for me… The 10-year German bund yield is close to its lowest since the Battle of Waterloo in 1815.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week24
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“We don’t see things as they are, we see them as we are”  – Anais Nin   According to the Central Bank Ireland's recovery is under way, but its fragile lenders and the large amounts of debt held by households pose considerable threats to stability.   Research shows that Irish consumer spending and debt changes are highly dependent on house prices with the impact greater than most other countries.   According to the quarterly Private Residential Tenancies Board (PRTB)/ESRI Rent Index,on an annual basis nationally, rents were 3.5% higher than in quarter 1 of 2013. Nationally, rents for houses were 1.6% higher, while apartment rents were 5.6% higher than in the same quarter of 2013. Annual growth in the Dublin market was stronger, up by 8.4%, with Dublin house rents up by 6.7% and Dublin apartment rents higher by 10.3%. In the 12 months to end of March 2014 Rents in Dublin rose ten times the level outside the capital.   The CSO announced that consumer prices as measured by the CPI (consumer price index) were 0.4% higher in May compared with May 2013. The most notable changes in the year were increases in Education (+4.5%), Miscellaneous Goods & Services (+4.0%), Alcoholic Beverages & Tobacco (+3.4%) and Restaurants & Hotels (+2.2%). There were decreases in Communications (-4.7%), Clothing & Footwear (-3.5%), Furnishings, Household Equipment & Routine Household Maintenance (-3.2%) and Food & Non-Alcoholic Beverages (- 1.9%).   The U.K.'s two chief financial-policy makers warned in strident tones that the British fervour for real estate had swelled into a threat to the wider economy, and the government moved to enact new powers to curb mortgage lending amid a gathering boom.   The UK unemployment level fell by 161,000 to 2.16m in the three months to April, bringing the unemployment rate down to 6.6%. Meanwhile UK employment rose again at a record pace in the three months to April but average earnings growth fell substantially below inflation.   Standard & Poor's Ratings Services revised its outlook on the U.K. to stable from negative, pointing to the robust and broadening recovery in the country's economy.   The Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said that U.K. interest rates could rise sooner than investors expect, sending the clearest signal yet that Britain's central bank is inching closer to calling time on record-low borrowing costs.   A gauge of U.S. inflation ticked lower, a sign price pressures remain tame amid subdued economic growth. The producer-price index for final demand fell a seasonally adjusted 0.2% in May from a month earlier. Economists expected a 0.2% rise.   The harsh U.S. winter and the Ukraine conflict have chilled the outlook for economic growth, but highly developed economies will lead a rebound later in the year, the World Bank projected cutting its global growth estimate to 2.8% from 3.2%   China's economy is struggling to find equilibrium, with government stimulus measures gaining traction last month while the vital housing market continues its swoon.   The Story of the week for me… Out of the 19 FIFA World Cup tournaments so far, 6 tournaments have only been won by the host Country.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week25
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“All great achievements have one thing in common - people with a passion to succeed.” – Pat Cash   Minister for Finance Michael Noonan indicated that he believes a €2bn budgetary adjustment in 2015 will not be necessary to meet the deficit target of 3% of GDP. This follows recommendations from the IMF for a €2bn adjustment in Budget 2015, focused on better targeted social spending in place of costly universal benefit payments and widening the base of products subject to VAT.   In measures of per capita consumption and GDP (gross domestic product) the typical German living standard is the highest in Europe while the Irish, Italians and Spanish are among the Eurozone's poorest, according to data published by Eurostat, the EU's statistics office.   In 2013 Irish prices for consumer goods and services were 18% above the European Union (EU) average despite Ireland being the only member country to have experienced a fall in prices in the period 2008-2012.   The International Monetary Fund announced that the European Central Bank should consider buying assets, including sovereign bonds, on a large scale, if inflation in the euro zone remains low.   While the recent upheaval in Iraq remained largely supportive for oil prices, as with other recent geopolitical flare-ups, the spill over to equities was limited   German investor sentiment dipped to an 18-month low in June as the ZEW Economic Expectations for Germany lost 3.3 points. Now standing at 29.8 points (long-term average: 24.7 points), the indicator has decreased for the sixth time in a row.   The IMF cut its forecast for US economic growth by 0.8 percentage point to 2%, citing a harsh winter, a struggling housing market and weak international demand for the country's products   Global investors have regained an appetite for risk against the backdrop of strong liquidity and a fairly positive economic outlooks. According to the BofA Merrill Lynch Fund Manager Survey for June a net 66% of respondents expect the global economy to strengthen over the next year. A net 48% of asset allocators are overweight equities, up 11%, even though a net 15% now regard the asset class as over-valued, this measure’s strongest response since 2000. Appetite for real estate has also risen. The net 6% overweight reported ranks as the highest in eight years. In contrast, underweight positions in bonds (now regarded as over-valued by a net 75%) have reached their highest level since the end of 2013.   Janet Yellen’s second news conference as Fed chair conveyed no new information about the timing of future interest rate moves. However she noted noting that the Federal Reserve Bank has trimmed back its stimulus program by $10bn a month to $35bn beginning July.   Argentina unveiled a plan to change the terms of its bonds that aims to prevent the country's second default in 13 years, while continuing a long-running battle with a small group of creditors.   The Story of the week for me…  Brazil are the only team to have featured in all 19 World Cups played so far

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week26
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“When you come to a roadblock, take a detour.” – Mary Kay Ash   Residential property prices at a national level, increased by 10.6% in the 12 months to May. This compares with an increase of 8.5% in April and a decrease of 1.1% recorded in the twelve months to May 2013. However, residential property prices are still 47.0% lower than their highest level in September 2007.   One year ago, Croatia joined the European Union sparking hopes that membership of the rich 28-nation bloc would transform the fortunes of the tourism-dependent economy. But as the anniversary looms, the hoped-for boom has largely failed to materialise. Croatia remains one of the bloc's weakest economies, mired in a seemingly never-ending recession that has pushed unemployment to 20 percent; half of the country's youth are without a job.   Bulgaria, the European Union’s poorest member state, raised €1.5bn in a new government bond issue that attracted orders of €4bn against a backdrop of political and financial uncertainty in the country.   US real gross domestic product (GDP) fell an annualised 2.9% in the first quarter of 2014, according to the third estimate released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. This is the fastest rate of decline since the first quarter of 2009, when output fell 5.4% and has been mainly blamed on bad weather.   The Bank of England has become the first leading central bank to try to prevent a new credit boom after it imposed limits on mortgage borrowing. Limiting the proportion of mortgages a bank can issue with large loans relative to the borrowers incomes.   Growing appetite by U.S. investors for South Korean debt has fueled a record pace of bond issuance this year as buyers judge the country to be one of the safest places to park their money within the region.   Central bank reserve managers across the world are ready to take a more cautious approach to investment as the U.S. Federal Reserve continues to reduce its monetary stimulus, with the full effect of such tapering still to be felt so far as demand for riskier assets is concerned.   The Bank of International Settlements (BIS) released its annual report noting that its overall impression is that the global economy is healing but remains unbalanced. Growth has picked up, but long-term prospects are not that bright. Financial markets are euphoric, but progress in strengthening banks' balance sheets has been uneven and private debt keeps growing. Macroeconomic policy has little room for manoeuvre to deal with any untoward surprises that might be sprung, including a normal recession.   A gauge of China's factory activity (HSBC PMI) showed fresh signs of strength in June, hitting a seven-month high of 50.8, pointing to improvement in the world's second-largest economy as export demand improves and a government stimulus program takes hold.   The Story of the week for me… The first FIFA World Cup was held in Uruguay back in 1930 and 13 countries participated in the very first tournament.

item.title: Irish Life's investment manager comes out top in Europe winning two European Pension Awards
item.dc:creator: Ger
item.content:encoded:
Equities Manager of the Year and Passive Manager of the Year [caption id="attachment_2788" align="alignnone" width="560"] Colm ONeill, Eunice Dreelan, Bill Kyle, Patrick Burke and Gerry Hassett with the two awards[/caption]

 

3rd July 2014 – Irish Life announced today that its investment manager was named Equities Manager of the Year and Passive Manager of the Year at the European Pension Awards 2014. Irish Life Investment Managers was the only Irish investment company to be recognised in this year’s awards and the only manager to win two awards in 2014. These prestigious European awards, now in their 7th year, recognise outstanding achievement in the varied fields of European pension provision, honouring the investment firms, consultancies and pension providers across Europe that have set the professional standards in order to best serve European pension funds in these increasingly challenging times. This year’s awards received more entries than the previous six years. As with previous years the judges were drawn from across the European pensions sphere to include providers, pension funds, consultants and representatives from various European pensions and investment associations. Commenting on the win, Patrick Burke, Managing Director of Irish Life Investment Managers said:
“This is a great honour for our team and we are grateful to the European Pension Awards for this recognition.  We believe these awards are testament to Irish Life’s customer first focus and our ability to provide innovative solutions, which is core to our business.” “Our objective is to understand the evolving needs of our customers and to provide inspired investment solutions to our growing client base – solutions which will provide the opportunity for growth while employing strategies that deliver protection in times of market stress. Listening to our clients and developing solutions according to their wants and needs has been critical to achieving our objectives and continuing to grow our business – the strategies which were recognised with these awards form the foundation of the Irish Life MAPS range of funds and consequently we are very pleased that they have been recognised in this manner.”
Irish Life Investment Managers came up against some of the leading global managers to be named equity manager of the year. The category recognises the manager who has led the way in managing equities in the past 12 months and has proved itself to be the most exceptional player in the industry and invaluable to European pension funds. The passive manager award recognises the manager which demonstrates strong returns, provides excellent customer service and shows a true understanding of the needs of their clients.

item.title: Earnings Season provides further support for equity markets, but the outlook is unclear
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
SUMMARY:With quarter three earnings season almost complete, Ruth Cooney takes a look at the headline figures and assesses the outlook for 2011.

Although central bank policy and Eurozone sovereign concerns have been dominating the headlines, the third quarter earnings season both in Europe and the US has provided a support for markets. With the third quarter reporting season 90% complete for the S&P 500 companies and 50% complete for MSCI Europe companies, the trends seen over previous quarters continued for the third quarter. Aggressive cost cutting persisted for the sixth consecutive quarter and exposure to emerging market economies continued to push earnings higher than analysts' expectations. Revenues, however, fell short of expectations in the US, although European companies reported stronger revenues than expected. The outlook also remained uncertain as expectations for the fourth quarter were left unchanged but forecasts for 2011 have been revised lower. Third Quarter Earnings Forecasts have risen substantially since the start of the reporting season Companies continue to cut costs amid the gradual and volatile economic recovery: The third quarter earnings season results have supported equity markets in that 73% of the S&P 500 companies that have reported to date have beaten earnings expectations, while 44% of MSCI Europe companies that have reported have delivered above consensus earnings. S&P 500 earnings were 31% higher than the third quarter 2009. Continued aggressive cost cutting delivered the strong performance in the US as revenues continued to miss expectations. In Europe, on the other hand, the economic recovery was more evident as much of the better than expected earnings was underpinned by improved revenues as well as increased efficiencies. The uncertain economic outlook in the US and lacklustre recovery in revenues has resulted in further costs cuts and a reluctance of companies to fully commit to capital investments or to engage in significant rehiring of labour. Companies in the US continued to note the lack of clear signposts to healthy demand, particularly from the US consumer. In contrast the European companies with exposure to the consumer had mixed comments with slower growth observed in developed markets. Emerging markets continued to drive earnings, offsetting a lacklustre performance from developed market. Companies with exposure to the emerging market region saw double digit growth, albeit some companies noted that this was from a very low base. As a result companies are making strategic investments in these regions to take advantage of the longer term growth outlook from these regions. The region that companies have highlighted is the BRIC region (Brazil, Russia, India and China). The strong growth rates achieved in these regions have been offset by flat to low single digit growth rates that are being observed in the developed markets. As a result companies are committing the majority of their capital investment and hiring strategies towards these regions. This was particularly evident in the technology sectors where firms are already very internationally exposed. Rising commodity prices have prompted fears of future margin pressure Commodity prices have rallied strongly over the past few weeks and have spurred inflationary concerns. Companies are anticipating that these increases in input prices will be offset by continued efficiency gains or further operating cost cuts. However there are concerns that given the lacklustre performance of the developed economies, particularly the consumer, that there will be a limited potential for the companies to pass on higher prices, and hence may pressure margins over the coming quarters. Outlook for earnings remains less transparent Although companies continued to report better than expected earnings, confidence in future earnings outlook remained cautious. In general forecasts for the fourth quarter were left unchanged, while a modest downgrade was seen for 2011 estimates in both Europe and the US. The weakness was attributed to the subdued recovery in revenues and the impact of higher input prices. 2011 negative earnings revisions were most evident in the energy sector but the financial and utility sectors also suffered downgrades. These downgrades were not evident in every sector as earnings estimates for the technology sectors as well as the consumer discretionary sectors were revised higher, particularly as these sectors tend to have a higher exposure to the emerging market region. Also after six consecutive quarters of cost cutting the ability of companies to continue to cut costs is more limited. 2011 Earnings forecast continued to be revised modestly lower These earnings reports have been supportive of the gains made in equity markets since the start of October. However the lack of transparency around the economic outlook has tainted the outlook for earnings growth going into next year. A more convincing recovery in revenues, particularly in the US would provide a further catalyst for equity market going into 2011. However the overhang of further downgrades to 2011 forecasts in this fragile economic recovery as well as concerns of input price inflation may remain a drag for equity markets going into the year end.

item.title: Why did the four year plan fail to help Irish government bond markets?
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
Why did the four year plan fail to help Irish government bond markets?

Monday, 29th November 2010  Ruth Cooney is markets economist with Irish Life Investment Managers

SUMMARY: The four year austerity plan announced by the government last week failed to calm market jitters because of unrealistic growth targets and continued uncertainty about the overall cost of the bank bailout

The government released the much awaited four year plan on Wednesday (November 24th), despite the uncertain political environment that erupted at the start of the week. The four year plan was seen as a way for the government to regain credibility and show bond markets its ability to tackle its problems, but most importantly convince investors that it can reduce the government's deficit as a percentage of GDP to 3% by 2014, in line with Maastricht guidelines. This deadline has been extended to 2015 with the announcement of the EU-IMF Deal. However the response by markets has not been the desired one in that the spread of the Irish ten year government bond over the German ten year government bond has increased from 5.86% to 6.43%, implying the Irish ten year government bond is yielding 9.3% (bid price). Elsewhere there have been increased contagion effects as the spreads have also widened for other peripheral countries such as Spain and Portugal, while the Euro has also fallen against many of the major currencies including the Dollar, Sterling and the Yen. Peripheral Government bond spreads widened Concerns about the recovery and the cost of the Banks' bailout have yet to be addressed: In my view there are two main reasons for the lack of credibility of the plan. Firstly the economic growth expectations are now seen by the market as unrealistic, which implies that additional cuts will have to be made. Secondly the plan does not consider the crux of the government's problems, i.e. the cost of bailing out the banking sector and more importantly the interest that is likely to fall due on the loans to be taken out to finance this bailout. The economic assumptions which the plan is based upon The risks to the economic outlook are to the downside:- The plan assumes that the Irish economy will grow by an average of 2.75% growth over the four years with slower growth in 2011 being offset by over 3% growth in 2012 and 2013. As to be expected that domestic recovery will lag and the bulk of the recovery is coming from exports. Exports are expected to grow by 5% in 2011 and 2012, even though the advanced economies, who are Ireland's predominant trading partners, are only expected to grow by between 2-3%, according to the latest IMF October World Economic Outlook. The inflation forecasts are also demanding as the government is assuming that prices will increase by on average of 1.3% over the four years, despite the current deflationary policies being adopted aimed at restoring competitiveness, such as cutting the minimum wage. Therefore the EU and IMF extension of one year in order to meet the 3% deficit target by 2015 over the weekend is welcomed. It does not mean that the €15bln savings can be stretched over this period as additional savings will have to be made in 2015 if the recovery is slower than the government have predicted. Then if the interest on the debt that is available to the government to bail out the banking sector is included, the 3% deficit target seems even more challenging.

item.title: It could be worse...
item.dc:creator: irishlife
item.content:encoded:
It could be worse…

Monday, 8th November 2010  Pat O'Sullivan is head of investment strategy with Irish Life

SUMMARY: Pat O'Sullivan takes a look at the outlook for the Irish economy over the next four years, and finds some positives for      the future in current household savings rates.

The government announced that a further €6 billion will be extracted from the economy in 2011, the 10-year Irish government bond is yielding 7.74%, the weather has turned decidedly nasty and there were more empty seats in the Aviva stadium than in the Dail. Hard to believe that it could be worse, but at least we will get free cheese to comfort us in our times of sorrow. However, in view of the time of year, a good bottle of Bordeaux would have been more appropriate, at least then we could have drowned our sorrows. To add to the overall bonhomie of last week, the Department of Finance (DoF) released an Information Note on the outlook for the economy and the budgetary position for 2011 to 2014. This shouldn't be confused with the now (in)famous 4-year plan. This will be published sometime later this month (but probably not before the South West Donegal by-election is out of the way). However, this information note probably lays the ground work for the 4-year plan and points to a less than rosy outlook for the Irish economy. The following table summarises the main economic forecasts outlined in the Information Note: Irish Economic Outlook 2011 -2014
2010 2011 2012 2013 2014
Real GDP 0.25 1.75 3.25 3 2.75
GDP (€m) 157,300 161,200 168,100 175,400 183,500
Employment -4.0 -0.25 1.25 1.5 1.75
Unemployment (%labour force) 13.5 13.25 12 11 9.75
Inflation (HICP) -1.5 0.75 1 1.75 1.75
Source: Information Note on the Economic and Budgetary Outlook 2011-2014, Department of FinanceSimply put, the DoF doesn't expect much in the way of growth next year, but the economy is expected to pick up some steam from 2012 onwards. The key driver of growth over the coming years will be the export sector as domestic demand is expected to remain anaemic, as is the case currently. Domestic demand is expected to fall again next year due to the fact that, "personal savings rates look set to remain at fairly elevated levels, given the need for households to repair their balance sheets. With household disposable income forecast to be broadly unchanged, consumer spending is projected to be flat in real terms next year. Government consumption is forecast to fall by 3%, due to the impact of further budgetary consolidation." From 2012 onwards, the economy will still be dependant on strong export growth, while the domestic engine is expected to continue spluttering under the weight of a high savings ratio. Households are expected to use these savings to repair their balance sheets, with a focus on paying off debt. Household balance sheets and household savings According to the Central Statistics Office, net savings of households increased from €3.6bn in 2008 to over €11bn in 2009 – the only sector to show an increase in savings over this period. The derived household net saving ratio, which expresses net savings as a percentage of net disposable income, increased from 3.9% in 2008 to 12.3% in 2009. It can be expected that the household savings ratio will fluctuate in the range of 10% to 12% this year and for the foreseeable future given the pressing need of households to repair their balance sheets. However, the source of household savings won't come from accelerating incomes but rather from more frugal habits. Consequently, while the net disposable income of households fell by €2.1bn, from €91.7bn in 2008 to €89.6bn in 2009, the €10bn decline in consumption by households down to €81bn in 2009 was far more pronounced. Irish Household Savings Ratio – neither a borrower nor lender be: a bit late but we are all savers now! While much of the savings have been precautionary in nature - and are either sitting in cash or paying off debt - it does mean that at some stage in the future there will be significant pent up demand for consumption and investment products. The risk adverse nature of the overall economy is highly understandable and is unlikely to change anytime soon. Nevertheless, Irish households have the capacity to save in the region of €10 billion a year and this should go a long way towards repairing very fragile balance sheets.

item.title: Water Safety Tips
item.content:encoded:
The summer is well upon us now and the weather has not been too bad. When we think of good weather we instantly think barbeques, beaches and of course swimming. One major concern of the warm weather is your skin but another concern which is often forgotten is how to be safe in the water.

In 2011 128 people drowned in Ireland. Of these 128 fatalities 56 of these where accidents, the highest number of accidental drowning’s in Ireland since 2002. A further breakdown of the facts shows a massive divide between males and females. In total 48 males accidently drowned compared to just 8 females.  A breakdown of the ages of death shows another trend with the majority of deaths falling between the ages of 24 and 64.

The majority of these accidental drowning’s occurred inland and are preventable. By following a few simple guidelines this accidental drowning rate can be largely reduced.   (1) NEVER SWIM ALONE – No matter if you’re swimming in the sea, in a lake, in a river or in a private pool never swim alone. Its common belief that children are they only ones who need to be protected in the water but the fact is we all need looking after. As the facts above point out the main group responsible for these deaths is the adult male group. This is the group of people most   likely to take the risks in the water. Adult males (especially younger) see themselves as being invincible and capable of doing anything. Well this is wrong the water is stronger then you will ever be. Always swim with another capable swimmer.   (2) Know your limits – We all have different abilities in the water and it our own responsibility to know our own. Your ability in the water should be a major consideration when deciding where to swim. If you’re a swimmer of weak ability you should not be swimming in areas where you will be unable to touch the ground. The chances of a swimmer with a weak ability coming into difficulties are much larger than the chances of a strong swimmer.     (3) Swim in safe areas only – When swimming it’s always best to swim in areas monitored by trained lifeguards. This is not always possible but a certain amount of thought should be used to decide where to swim. If an area has a sign telling people not swim there listen to the message as there is a good reason for the presence of the sign. Areas such as quarries and reservoirs must always be avoided. These dangerous areas are very deep and often contain undergrowth and underlying currents (these conditions can also be found in rivers and lakes).     (4) NEVER swim after the consumption of alcohol – After the consumption of alcohol there are a number of things which we should not do, one of these is go for a swim. Drinking alcohol impairs your senses, encouraging risk-taking behaviour, meani

ng you are more likely to get into trouble. If you drink and get into the water, tired muscles and confusion from being under the influence of alcohol, makes it harder to get out of trouble. There is a range of physical changes which occur when an individual consumes alcohol and then engages in aquatic activity.

item.title: Market Review – 2014 Week27
item.dc:creator: DavidH
item.content:encoded:
“Success is the sum of small efforts, repeated day in and day out.”  – Robert Collier Irish Life Investment Managers was named Equities Manager of the Year and Passive Manager of the Year at the European Pension Awards 2014. Irish Life Investment Managers was the only Irish investment company to be recognised in this year’s awards and the only manager to win two awards in 2014 Ireland’s economy surged in the first quarter of this year on the back of rapidly rising exports as the CSO posted a GDP (Gross Domestic Product) figure of 2.7% for Q1. In a sign that the price surge in the property market is gaining momentum, asking prices in Dublin continue to increase this quarter while price growth has also extended to the national market. The mix adjusted average asking price in Dublin increased by 4.5% in Q2 2014, the largest increase since Q1 2006. The national mix adjusted average asking price grew by 1.3% for the same period, the first such increase since the peak of the market in Q4 2006. Continuing steep rises in wholesale oil prices have offset declines in wholesale natural gas prices this month leaving the Bord Gáis Irish Energy Index unchanged month-on-month in June, but is still up 33% since December 2009. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi kept the door open to additional stimulus including large-scale asset purchases if needed to fight excessively low inflation, while rejecting concerns over super-easy monetary policies at the ECB and other central banks. The European Commission approved an emergency request by Bulgaria to grant a credit line of $2.3 billion to its lenders after the country suffered runs on two banks. The euro zone's annual rate of inflation (0.5%) was unchanged at its lowest level in more than four years in June. Janet Yellen pushed back strongly against the notion the central bank should consider raising interest rates to avoid fuelling future financial crises, in her most detailed and forceful comments on financial stability since taking the Federal Reserve's helm in February. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose above 17000 for the first time after a stronger-than-expected report on U.S. job creation helped reassure investors that economic growth can support stock benchmarks at all-time highs. UK house prices have overtaken their 2007 peak, with the annual growth in home prices rising to to 11.8% in June from 11.1% a month earlier. The increase in June was the 14th straight month of house price increases. MPs have called on the UK’s financial watchdog to investigate allegations of price rigging in the London gold market. Indonesia has become the latest emerging economy to tap the euro debt market selling 1 billion euros ($1.4 billion) worth of seven-year notes at 2.976%. The Story of the week for me… Germany and Brazil hold the top spot for most appearances in the World Cup final. Both countries have made it to the finals on 7 different occasions.
